title: Whats on Monday
description: 1:50 A.M. (STARZ) A DANGEROUS METHOD (2011) A disturbed young Russian, Sabina Spielrein (Keira Knightley), is brought to a clinic in Zurich in the early 20th century, and a doctor named Carl Jung (Michael Fassbender, above with Ms. Knightley) performs a new treatment called psychoanalysis to help her. Soon she becomes his lover and finally a colleague. But as emotionally connected as Sabina is to Jung, it is with his mentor, Sigmund Freud (Viggo Mortensen), that she finds a more cerebral affinity. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film from David Cronenberg, based on a play by its screenwriter, Christopher Hampton, and drawn from a book by John Kerr, a subtle and intellectually thrilling true story. The movie is full of ideas about sexuality  some quite provocative, even a century after their first articulation  but it also recognizes and communicates the erotic power of ideas, he said. There are scenes of kinky activity between Sabina and Jung that will no doubt enjoy long life in specialized corners of the Internet, but the most unsettling aspect of A Dangerous Method may be the links it suggests between sex and thinking. The mind is both slave and master of the bodys appetites, and the absurd and terrifying task of stabilizing that dynamic, in theory and in practice, is embraced equally by the film and the fragile, serious historical figures who inhabit it.

title: Mark Cuban Thinks Im a Moron
description: I was recently reviewing press reports from the Clinton Global Initiative, and I was struck to find an interview with Mark Cuban where he said that any entrepreneur or small-business owner who starts a business with borrowed money is a moron. As someone who borrowed money to start a loan brokerage, I guess its pretty clear what that makes me  along with thousands of other small-business owners and entrepreneurs I have met over the years.

title: Broadways Vanya and Sonia Recoups Investment
description: In another sign that Broadways 2012-13 season was strong overall for plays at the box office, Christopher Durangs comedy Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike has recouped its $2.75 million capitalization and will have the rest of the summer to earn profits for its investors, the producers announced on Monday. Vanya and Sonia, starring David Hyde Pierce and Sigourney Weaver, is the fifth play from the season to recoup, joining Glengarry Glen Ross (which starred Al Pacino), The Heiress (Jessica Chastain), Lucky Guy (Tom Hanks) and Ill Eat You Last (Bette Midler). Another play, Grace, narrowly missed recouping, in part due to the fall-out of Hurricane Sandy.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Investigates 2007-8 Honda Odysseys for Spontaneous Braking Issue
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating owner complaints of unexpected braking and whether there should be a recall of almost 344,000 Honda Odyssey minivans from the 2007-8 model years. The complaints are similar to those that resulted in the recall of about 183,000 different Honda and Acura models in March.

title: Saint Laurent: Sexual Swagger
description: PARIS  With pants clinging from a high waist, around the groin, over pin-thin thighs and on in a lightning streak of shiny leather to pointed shoes, the Saint Laurent show was a triumph of teen-scene sexual swagger.

title: London Theater Journal: Trapped
description: LONDON  So you think life was better 30 years ago, when Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan ruled the earth? How about 100 years ago, in the gentle twilight of the glamorous British gentry? People at least knew who they were then, and where they were going. Right?

title: Feeling Stressed? Its Probably Harming Your Health
description: If you believe stress is affecting your health, you are probably right, a new study concludes, and that perception may increase your risk for heart disease.

title: The Battle of Gettysburg
description: At the end of the three-day battle that began on July 1, 1863, Confederate and Union armies endured the largest loss of lives in the Civil War.

title: July 1: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Threes a Trend | Fisherman Sandals for Work and Play
description: The fisherman sandal, that well-ventilated shoe-sandal hybrid made with woven leather straps and an enclosed toe, was worn with business suits as well as the kind for swimming in several Spring/Summer collections in Paris and London. Christopher Kane showed his versions in primary colors with matching short sets, while Guillaume Henry at Carven opted for a more traditional palette to complement his crisp tailored trousers and shorts. Phillip Lims 70s surf-inspired show included the buckled sandal in black as well as blue metallic and clear plastic.

title: Snowden Seeks Asylum in Russia, Putting Kremlin on the Spot
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlin on Monday found itself confronted with a dilemma it had hoped to avoid, after an official revealed that Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor wanted by the United States, had submitted a request to Russia for political asylum.

title: Construction Worker Hurt in Daylight Shooting in Midtown
description: A 56-year-old construction foreman seated behind the wheel of a company van was ambushed by a former co-worker on Monday in a brazen daylight shooting just after the height of the morning rush in Midtown, the authorities and witnesses said.

title: Three Justices Bound by Beliefs, Not Just Gender
description: WASHINGTON  You can tell a lot about the Supreme Court by looking at who voted with whom. There are 36 possible pairs of justices, and in the term just concluded something interesting happened.

title: Weekend Gun Report: June 28-30, 2013
description: Elena Kagan, who joined the Supreme Court three years ago, was in Aspen this weekend for the annual Ideas Festival, where she was interviewed Saturday afternoon by Jeffrey Rosen, the legal writer and scholar. She talked about how famously all the justices get along, and reiterated various positions she had taken in cases where her record was already well known. But she did offer one tidbit worth repeating.

title: The Media and Wendy Davis
description: With a tip of the hat to the Weekly Standards John McCormack, who tweeted about the interview over the weekend, here are the six questions asked of Texas State Senator Wendy Davis on ABCs This Weekafter her (temporarily) successful filibuster of a bill that restricted abortion after 20 weeks of pregnancy and increased regulations on Texan abortion clinics:

title: When Youre the First Pregnant Woman at Your Company
description: I never felt like a woman in the workplace until I became pregnant. My gender was not an issue in terms of my pay or general treatment. At a boozy after-work hangout, I discovered I made more than a male co-worker with the same title, because I had asked for and received raises where he had not. If you had asked me what being pregnant at work might be like before I conceived, I probably would have said something glib along the lines of: Im not the first working woman to ever have a kid. Havent they figured it out by now?

title: Camels in Amsterdam
description: Last weeks Odd Dice was one of the easier puzzles weve featured on Numberplay. It was meant to be that way  the challenge was offered to introduce the Dutch Mathematical Olympiad, an annual competition open to all high school students in the Netherlands. Last weeks puzzle was from Round One of the 2009 event; this week we move onto the Tweede Ronde of the competition with a camel distribution problem and a verbal arithmetic bonus from 2012.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Chad Ackley joined Doner, Southfield, Mich., part of MDC Partners, as executive vice president and executive creative director. He succeeds Murray White, who left, the agency said, to return to his hometown of Melbourne, Australia. Mr. Ackley had most recently been group creative director at the San Francisco office of DDB West, part of the DDB Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group. Also at Doner, Karen Cathel and Sam Sefton, creative directors, were promoted to senior vice presidents and group creative directors.

title: Making the Right Call, Even in Death
description: It is one of a doctors most important final acts in caring for a patient, even though the patient is no longer around to appreciate it.

title: Dior Couture
description: Raf Simons conceived the collection as four loosely aligned geographic groups: Europe, Asia, the Americas and Africa. Each group expressed a central idea.

title: Full Employment: The Big Missing Piece
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Image of the Day: July 1
Outrage in Europe Grows Over Spying Disclosures
description: PARIS  Damage from the disclosures of United States spying on its European and Asian allies spread on Monday, threatening negotiations on a free trade agreement, hurting President Obamas standing in Europe and raising basic questions of trust among nations that have been on friendly terms for generations.

title: In a Truck in Brooklyn, a Church Offers Spiritual Guidance
description: Lucia Mora, 47, was nervous as she entered the white R.V. parked on 42nd Street in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

title: Raw Footage: Arizona Wildfire Aftermath
description: Aerial video clips from Yarnell, Ariz., show the remains of houses burned by a wildfire that swept through the area, killing 19 firefighters.

title: B.E.T. Awards Red Carpet
description: Looks from the red carpet at the B.E.T Awards, including Kendrick Lamar, Janelle Monae and Pharrell Williams.

title: Creditors to Determine Whether to Release Greek Aid
description: ATHENS  Officials representing Greeces international creditors were back in Athens on Monday, three weeks after mass layoffs at the state broadcaster ERT prompted a political crisis that led one party to quit the shaky coalition government.

title: The Courts Most Cohesive Wing
description: The three female justices on the Supreme Court, who are also the most liberal, agreed more often on cases this term than any other group on the court.

title: Boat of Light, Boat of Stone
description: The Times reporter Henry Fountain takes a look at two vessels: one powered by solar energy, and one made of concrete.

title: Actors and Directors for Readings of August Wilson Cycle Are Veterans of Playwrights Work
description: Phylicia Rashad, Ruben Santiago-Hudson, Kenny Leon and Leslie Uggams are among the actors and directors coming together for staged dramatic readings of 10 August Wilson plays, the project directors announced on Monday. Others include S. Epatha Merkerson, Taraji P. Henson, Marion McClinton, Stephen McKinley Henderson, Wendell Pierce and Jesse L. Martin.Tickets went on sale Monday for the performances, which will begin Aug. 26 with Ma Raineys Black Bottom. The readings, before studio audiences at New York Public Radios Jerome L. Greene Space in New York, are to be recorded for New York Public Radio archives.

title: Dining Calendar
description: During Italian Dine-Out, an Italian restaurant week of sorts, 23 Italian restaurants across the city will offer discounted lunch and dinner menus. Most of the restaurants have online reservations available for the Italian Trade Commission-sponsored promotion, which runs through Saturday.

title: Monday Motorsports:  Rosberg, Kenseth and Loeb Score Major Racing Victories
description: Nico Rosberg held off a furious charge by Mark Webber on Sunday to win the British Grand Prix at Silverstone. It was a race marred by numerous tire failures that affected many of the front-runners.

title: Egyptians React to Armys Ultimatum
description: As our colleagues David Kirkpatrick, Kareem Fahim and Ben Hubbard report, the head of the Egyptian military, Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, gave President Mohamed Morsi 48 hours to respond to the peoples demands or the armed forces would move to impose its own road map for the future.

title: Red Bulls Rewind: On to the Dog Days
description: It was the Red Bulls first win in a month in Major League Soccer on Sunday and it was the first start of the season for one of the teams surprise packages last year.

title: Songs of Birds and Babes, Evolution of a Baseball Pitcher, Boats Powered by Sun and Made of Stone
description: Do humans learn to speak the way songbirds learn to sing? In the evolutionary subway series, who would sweep, Homo erectus or Neanderthal? Sailing by the sun and floating a stone.

title: What Gettysburg Proved
description: It took no more than a few days after the Battle of Gettysburg for the men who had fought there to realize how important it had been. The Battle of Gettysburg, like Waterloo, must stand conspicuous in the history of all ages, wrote a staff officer, Frank Aretas Haskell, who himself would die less than a year later in a much less conspicuous battle at a place called Cold Harbor. And even by the most remote measure, Haskell was right.

title: Really? The Claim: Children Tend to Gain Weight Over Summer Recess
description: THE FACTS

title: Determining Corzines Role in the Demise of MF Global
description: How much responsibility should a chief executive bear when the company collapses? That question will be front and center in the civil case  leveled by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission against Jon S. Corzine for his role in the misuse of customer money at MF Global as it fell apart in October 2011.

title: Lost in Arizona Fire, an Elite Crew That Rushed In
description: PRESCOTT, Ariz.  The men were mostly born and bred in this city on the mountains, surrounded by thick forest of pion pine and chaparral brush, parched by years of drought. They were young men, mostly, 14 of them in their 20s  outdoorsmen, fathers, heroes to the local high school athletes they themselves once were.

title: Urban Smog and Hazy Economic Prospects in China
description: Beijing has been hot and smoggy for the last few days. The pollution was so bad that over the weekend the authorities advised residents to stay indoors. The near-term prospects for Chinas economy appear at least as hazy.

title: 19 Firefighters Fall on the Wildland-Urban Interface
description: 8:25 p.m. | Updates below | Theres an enormous financial cost attending the expansion of Americas wildland-urban interface  the term for areas where communities have sprouted in forested areas  in parts of the country prone to wildfires.

title: Pressure and Pain
description: Q. What effect does the barometric pressure have on humans? Can it cause headaches and other discomforts?

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Thom Browne Spring/Summer 2014
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Schohaja.

title: Walkabout  7/1: Trans-Atlantic Flights for $10 and Interactive Hotel TVs
description: Across the Atlantic for $10? Michael OLeary, above, the chief executive of Ryanair who has suggested ideas like standing cabins and pay toilets, has a new concept: Europe to U.S. flights for $10. (Bloomberg)

title: Icahn Says He Has Secured Financing for Alternative to Dells Buyout
description: 3:26 p.m. | Updated

title: Street Style: Shirtdresses
description: The best of readers photos from the week of June 24.

title: Former Morgan Stanley Banker Joins Perella Weinberg
description: The boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners has added a new partner in its health care group.

title: Explaining 2 Polls With Conflicting Findings
description: The crowded field contending to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in City Hall got an unexpected jolt last week from two polls with seemingly divergent findings. The first poll was accompanied by a news release proclaiming Weiner Surpasses Quinn Among N.Y.C. Dems, while a day later the other poll came out with a statement announcing Quinn, Thompson, Weiner Tied in New York City Primary.

title: Look Whos Talking for Mr. Peanut Now
description: A familiar advertising spokescharacter who began talking only two and a half years ago is speaking with a new voice.

title: Spurious Tuberculosis Drugs Pose a Threat
description: Substandard tuberculosis drugs sold by pharmacies in poor countries are a growing public health threat, but the problem could be alleviated if governments enforced World Health Organization standards, a new study reports.

title: At Home, Before Mount Vesuvius Erupted
description: LONDON  The British Museums exhibition on the ancient Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum is designed to make us feel at home.

title: Investment Plans and Forecasts Dont Mix
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published this year. His sketches are archivedon the Bucks blog.

title: The Bible, a Hit on Cable, Will Have Its Sequel on NBC
description: In an indication of the shifting center of power in television, a broadcast network, NBC, has stepped up to buy the sequel to a hit cable mini-series, The Bible, which appeared on the History Channel.

title: Texas Democrats Try to Keep Their Momentum Going
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  All eyes are on Texas today, but the drama at the end of the first special session of the 83rd state legislature is not likely to repeat itself  at least not yet. While Gov. Rick Perry has brought back the 150 members of the House and the 31 members of the Senate to deal with unfinished business on abortion, transportation and criminal justice, theyll almost surely gavel in, refer bills to committee and gavel out. Except for a few serial grandstanders, most lawmakers wont be heard from in any meaningful way inside the Capitol.

title: Twenty Pies to Make This Summer
description: Revel in the season with a pie (or a tart, or a cobbler). Here are 20 recipes to carry you through the warm months.

title: Inbee Parks Winning Streak
description: The South Korean golfer Inbee Park on Sunday won her third straight major tournament, the U.S. Womens Open at Sebonack Golf Club in Southampton, N.Y.  a streak no other female golfer has managed since Babe Didrikson Zaharias in 1950.

title: F.D.A. Prefers Smaller Dosage of Merck Sleep Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration has rejected an application by Merck to sell a new sleeping pill, but indicated that it would probably approve the drug in lower doses.

title: Forget Pie or Cobbler: Call It a Sonker
description: The Timess Kim Severson visits Mount Airy, N.C., to learn more about the sonker, a soupy baked fruit dessert native to Surry County.

title: Mandelas Relatives Argue Over Burial Plans
description: JOHANNESBURG  Nelson Mandela remained in critical but stable condition in a Pretoria hospital on Monday, more three weeks after being admitted for a serious lung infection tracing back to his years in apartheid prisons, the South African presidents office said.

title: As Bond Market Tumbles, Pimco Seeks to Reassure Investors
description: As investors prepare for a long-term shift in interest rates, few large financial firms are as vulnerable as the giant money manager Pimco.

title: Andrew Carmellini on Pie
description: Just the word pie, its very evocative of an American spirit of cooking, said Andrew Carmellini, the celebrated chef, who originally hails from Ohio. So evocative, in fact, that one of his restaurants in downtown Manhattan, the Dutch, originally grew out of his impulse to open a spot that would specialize in pies like buttermilk and shoofly, strawberry-rhubarb and salted Key lime. On the occasion of the Pie Issue, Mr. Carmellini, 42, spoke about pie as icon and inspiration.

title: You Had Me at Bigger Alligators': Times Readers Pitch Summer Blockbusters
description: In a feature for this weeks Arts & Leisure section, Brooks Barnes of The Times examined the inner-workings of Hollywoods blockbuster factory by asking a team of insiders to diagnose the potential problems of a fake summer film, Red, White & Blood. (No one objected to the title, at least.)

title: Jury Hears Zimmermans Recorded Account of Night of Fatal Shooting
description: SANFORD, Fla.  For the first time, the jury in the trial of George Zimmerman on Monday heard the defendant, in taped police interviews, give his version of events the night he fatally shot Trayvon Martin, an unarmed 17-year-old, in a townhouse complex here 16 months ago.

title: Sonkers, Grunts, Slumps and Crumbles
description: MOUNT AIRY, N.C.  The sonker has become my Moby Dick.

title: Preserving a Tortoise, and a Legacy
description: WOODLAND PARK, N.J.  Lonesome George, the giant Galpagos tortoise whose death a year ago signified the extinction of his subspecies, is taking on a new life  as an in-the-flesh reminder of what has been lost in the natural world.

title: Time Warner Intends to Move to Planned Skyscraper at Hudson Yards
description: Time Warner Inc. has a tentative deal to move its headquarters farther west in Manhattan in what would be a major reshuffling meant to accelerate the long-awaited development of what is known as Hudson Yards while leaving Columbus Circle in the hunt for a defining corporate presence.

title: On Becoming an Orphan
description: I was lucky enough  I do see it that way  to be with my parents when each died. My mother gave us more warning: a couple of strokes, a cancer diagnosis, three months of hospice care, a two-week final vigil, death in her own bed at age 80.

title: Americas New Mothers Among the Youngest
description: While digging through the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Developments annual education report last week, I came across this fascinating chart:

title: An Oarsman Is a Verb Meaning to Row
description: The summer heat is finally here  makes you want to get out on the water and splash around with some oars, no? Especially when you see tranquil scenes like the cover of this book, how can you not get up for a little boating?

title: Unseeded Mexican Beats 14th Seed in Wimbledon Juniors
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Unseeded Lucas Gomez, 17, of Tijuana, Mexico, upset 14th-seeded Guillermo Nez of Santiago, Chile, 6-4, 7-5, in the first round of the Wimbledon junior championships.

title: Yankees Rodriguez Cleared to Begin Playing in Minors
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The simulated at-bats, the sliding drills and the controlled segment of Alex Rodriguezs recovery from hip surgery have come to an end. Nearly a week after the furor over whether Rodriguez was given official clearance to play in games subsided, the word finally came down Monday.

title: The Media, Immigration and G.O.P. Donorism
description: As long as Im playing the media critic on social-issues coverage, this piece last week from the Washington Posts Chris Cillizza and Sean Sullivan offered a fascinating example of how the press covers the role of money in the immigration debate:

title: On Marriage, Holding Back the Tide
description: Because the Supreme Courts rulings on the Defense of Marriage Act and Californias Proposition 8 failed to say whether gay and lesbian Americans have a constitutional right to marry the person of their choosing, the fight over same-sex marriage resumed almost immediately. And opponents of marriage equality made it plain they would keep trying to hold back the tide.

title: Zynga Hires Xbox Boss to Initiate Turnaround
description: Zynga, the social games maker that has stumbled badly over the last year, said it had replaced its founder and chief executive, Mark Pincus, with the head of Microsofts Xbox video game business, Don Mattrick.

title: A New Monday for the Met, Now Open Seven Days a Week
description: On March 30, 1880, the home of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Fifth Avenue opened its doors to the public for the first time. It was a Tuesday, perhaps foreshadowing a feature of the modern Met. For the past 42 years, it has been closed on most Mondays.

title: Appeals Courts Ruling Helps Google in Book-Scanning Lawsuit
description: Google scored a victory in the long-running lawsuit over its book-scanning project on Monday, as a federal appeals court ruled that it was premature that the authors suing Google had been certified as a class.

title: Stephens Gets Comeback Win and Then a Vote of Confidence
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Before Sloane Stephens could walk onto Court 18 for her fourth-round match against Monica Puig of Puerto Rico, she had to wait for the match between Kirsten Flipkens and Flavia Pennetta to finish, with Flipkens sinking to the grass in joy when she won.

title: Tripping Up Memories of Alcohol
description: For recovering alcoholics, memories associated with drinking  the smell of a bar, ice clinking in a glass  are among the greatest threats to sobriety.

title: Disneys Chief Agrees to Hold Off on His Retirement Until 2016
description: Robert A. Iger will remain chief executive of the Walt Disney Company until July 2016, an extension of 15 months beyond his previously announced retirement date, the entertainment conglomerate said on Monday.

title: Dolan Sought to Protect Church Assets, Files Show
description: Files released by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee on Monday reveal that in 2007, Cardinal Timothy F. Dolan, then the archbishop there, requested permission from the Vatican to move nearly $57 million into a cemetery trust fund to protect the assets from victims of clergy sexual abuse who were demanding compensation.

title: Solving a Viral Mystery
description: As the scientists peered into the darkness, their headlamps revealed an eerie sight. Hundreds of eyes glinted back at them from the walls and ceiling. They had discovered, in a crumbling, long-abandoned village half-buried in sand near a remote town in southwestern Saudi Arabia, a roosting spot for bats.

title: Angkors Urban Environs, Mapped From Above
description: Archaeologists have long studied the ancient, crumbling temples of Angkor in Cambodia as sites of worship and gathering. But how Angkor functioned as a city remained unknown.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Firefox Smartphone, and Virus Collector
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Moochers, Grifters, and the Beveridge Curve
description: OK, still grieving, but time to stick my toe back into the blogosphere.

description: My Friday column, on deception by derivative, compared the latest disclosures about Italys deception in getting into the euro zone to Enrons balance sheet deceptions before it collapsed.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Rescue Robots and Shopping in Space
description: In honor of beach season, lets call this the summer fun edition of The Week, complete with geometrically shaped sandwiches and desserts  raspberry jam parabola, anyone?  to liven up your picnic.

title: In Question to Serena Williams, a Hint of Sexism
description: For Serena Williams, it must have been a toss-up as to which she found more offensive: her fourth-round Wimbledon loss Monday to Sabine Lisicki or the fourth question in her post-match news conference, when she was asked if it was tough not having her father there to lend support.

title: More on Archimedes
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Quantum of Solace
description: Niels Bohr, the Danish physicist and philosopher-king of quantum theory, once said that a great truth is a statement whose opposite is also a great truth. This pretty much captured the spirit of those elusive rules that govern the subatomic world, where light can be a wave  no, a particle  well, actually, whatever you need it to be for your particular experiment.

title: Revolution, Hanging by a Thread
description: In his 1783 Farewell Address to the Army, George Washington called the perseverance of the Armies of the United States through eight long years of war, little short of a standing Miracle and though not a deeply religious man, he thanked the singular interpositions of Providence for his troops survival and ultimate triumph.

title: Giambattista Valli
description: Giambattista Vallis fall haute couture collection was based some of his garland-embroidered dresses and sweet dresses on Svres, Meissen and Wedgwood plates, among others in the cupboard.

title: Tearful Robson Regrets Missed Opportunity
description: WIMBLEDON, England  If you wound the clock back and told Laura Robson at the start of the tournament that she would reach the fourth round and come within a few loose forehands of the quarterfinals, she would probably have taken it. But it illustrates how much her expectations have risen that she walked off court Monday after a 7-6 (6), 7-5 defeat to the former world No. 15 Kaia Kanepi feeling disappointed in herself.

title: Another Chance on Student Loan Rates
description: If youve been following the debate over the potential increase in the interest rates on subsidized student loans, you may be wonder how its turning out. Today is, after all, July 1  the deadline by which Congress had to act to fend off a doubling of the rates.

title: Aruba Promotes Its Sustainable Energy
description: Energy-conscious travelers may soon find the Dutch island of Aruba high on their list of destinations. The island has announced that it is on track to become the first sustainable energy economy in the world.

title: Dior: Letting Loose
description: A year after Raf Simons showed his first couture collection for Dior, he continues to shake up the fashion world. His impact is felt not just in Paris, but everywhere: in the simplifying of clothes, in modernist beadwork, in the variety of peplum jackets or bustiers worn with cigarette pants, in vivid colors that touch on nature and contemporary art.

title: Judge Rejects 3 Lawsuits Against Former Elmo Puppeteer
description: A federal judge in New York, saying the statute of limitations had run out, has dismissed three lawsuits by men who said that the former Sesame Street puppeteer Kevin Clash sexually abused them when they were underage.

title: Income for Movie Writers Falls, While TV Writers Rises
description: LOS ANGELES  The earnings of movie writers continued a three-year slide in 2012, while income from television writing continued to edge upward, according to an annual report from the Writers Guild of America, West.

title: In Performance: Carla Gugino
description: Ms. Gugino performs a scene from Daniel Pearles new play A Kid Like Jake, about a couple and their son who likes to dress up as Cinderella. The show is at LCT3s Claire Tow Theater.

title: Polymers: Why Some Recyclable Items Just Dont Mix
description: Not all plastics are equal. For 25 years, thats been evident to New York City residents, as many puzzled over which of their plastic containers  soda bottles? yogurt tubs?  would be accepted for recycling, perhaps without completely understanding why they had to choose.

title: Immigration and Entrepreneurship
description: One of the key economic arguments underpinning the immigration overhaul is that immigrants create jobs  not only because they spend money, but because they tend to be unusually entrepreneurial and innovative and so create job opportunities for the people around them. Think of Silicon Valley figures like Sergey Brin, Andrew Grove or Vinod Khosla  or the designer Liz Claiborne. The bill that passed the Senate last week, under Subtitle H, even included special provisions for what is being called a start-up visa, to be granted to people who start companies that meet certain venture capital, hiring and revenue requirements.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Hong Kong, Arizona and South Africa.

title: A Warm Welcome for Obama in Tanzania
description: President Obama arrived in Tanzania on Monday, greeted by cheering throngs much larger and louder than those he saw in Senegal and South Africa.

title: Re-Election Is Likely for McConnell, but Not Guaranteed
description: Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Kentucky secretary of state and a Democrat, announced on Monday that she will challenge Senator Mitch McConnell, a Republican, in 2014.

title: Seasonal Park Avenue Restaurant to Close
description: Park Avenue Summer (and Autumn, Winter and Spring; the restaurant changes its name and look each season) will close at the end of the year. Michael Stillman, a partner in Fourth Wall Restaurants, the owner, said the lease was up after 21 years and an agreement could not be reached with the co-op board, which runs the building. He said they hoped to relocate. We definitely want to continue with this concept, Mr. Stillman said. Its been doing very well, and everyone seems to like the seasonal changes. He also said they would close the Post House, in the Lowell Hotel, in August because the restaurant and the hotel lobby are being renovated, a job expected to take about six months. That one is a question mark, he said.

title: Chefs on the Move
description: Ghaya Oliveira, the pastry chef at Boulud Sud and Bar Boulud, has been promoted to executive pastry chef at Daniel Bouluds flagship, Daniel. A native of Tunisia who worked in finance, she switched careers after emigrating to America. At Boulud Sud she added several Middle Eastern dishes to the dessert menu, including grapefruit givr with sesame halva and rose loukoum; pistachio kataifi, and rose-marzipan gelato. She replaces Sandro Micheli, who has been the executive pastry chef for nearly two years and who plans to return to France. Tyler Atwell, who was at the Mandarin Oriental in New York, will succeed her at Boulud Sud and Bar Boulud.

title: The Drama of Travel, Made Into Television
description: MY very first international trip was on TWA back in 1990. I went to Madrid and went backpacking with my college roommate for about five weeks. I went with $1,000, and we lived on wine, cheese, bread and chocolate. That trip changed my life.

title: New Approach to Depression
description: Martha Rhodes experienced her first bout of depression at 13. By her late 50s, she had taken just about every antidepressant there is, including Zoloft, Lexapro and Paxil  which did the trick for many years, but had side effects  then Effexor, Lamictal, Seroquel and Abilify.

title: Alice Munro Retires
description: The acclaimed short-story writer says shes putting down her pen.

title: Alice Munro Puts Down Her Pen to Let the World In
description: CLINTON, Ontario  Accepting a literary prize in Toronto last month, Alice Munro, the acclaimed short-story writer  our Chekhov, as Cynthia Ozick has called her  winner of the Man Booker International Prize and just about every important North American literary award for which she is eligible, told a newspaper interviewer, Im probably not going to write anymore.

title: Evolution of the Pitch
description: Humans can throw a lot faster than chimpanzees--one of our closest genetic relatives. But why? And when did we evolve a throwing arm?

title: Gay Marriage: Same, but Different
description: During a late-night monologue, the talk show host David Letterman once asked a series of questions about gay marriage.

title: Critics Question Karzai Choices for Human Rights Panel
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As Afghan political appointees go, they may not seem that unusual taken as a group. One is a mullah who sees Shariah law as the best source for human rights legislation. Another was in the central bureau of the countrys most powerful fundamentalist party. A third is a bureaucrat seen as close to the president, and a fourth is a retired police four-star general.

title: Kentucky Secretary of State Will Challenge McConnell in Senate Race

title: With Bursts of Color and Energy, Indian Classics Get a Workout

Last week I watched six performances of American Ballet Theaters production of Frederick Ashtons Sylvia at the Metropolitan Opera House, with American, Argentine, Brazilian, Cuban, Italian and Russian dancers in the lead roles; I love both the works music and its choreography. But on Saturday night, as I watched three types of classical Indian dance at the Kumble Theater in Brooklyn, I wanted to bring all those thousands of Lincoln Center balletomanes with me to see how this was just as marvelous  sometimes even more so.

Craft has often been shunned in the realm of the fine arts  perceived as being too homespun and perhaps too useful  but, as the exhibition shows, younger artists have begun embracing its materials, tools and techniques. The exhibitions title comes from A Psalm of Life, a poem by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, explained the shows curator, Julie Joyce. It alludes to self-reliance and shows how these artists generally make their work themselves rather than having it manufactured.

title: How to Listen
description: Years ago, I met once a week, 9 a.m. sharp, with a therapist whom I will call Dr. Mason. We would settle in well-worn chairs, Dr. Mason, a slender, balding middle-ager in blazer and striped tie, and me, an anxious academic in Levis and tweeds. Sometimes Id plunge into whatever was on my mind, but other times we would sit and look at each other in silence as I struggled for words. But Dr. Mason had a simple method of getting me to begin. He would lean slightly forward, all the while maintaining eye contact and then when he got my attention, he would nod.

title: Border Patrol Body Slam

The promoter Gabriel Ramirez wanted to bring lucha libre, traditional Mexican-style professional wrestling, to the United States. When he dressed American professional wrestlers as Border Patrol agents to play the main villains, he knew he had a lucrative idea that would appeal to Latino audiences. More than entertainment, however, what he built is a type of Theater of the Oppressed, where social hierarchies are turned upside down and where, unlike in some media coverage, the Mexicans are the heroes.

title: Place With Complimentary Towels

Only in English  well, possibly in other languages, but I cant speak to them  can the word complimentary mean both praising and free of charge, so that when I see a clue like Place with complimentary towels, the only thing I can think about is, why hasnt anyone come out with towels like that? All it would take is embedding a voice chip in the towels so that when you enter the bathroom to perform your daily ablutions, the towels would say, Have you lost weight? You look fabulous! The government argued that members of Al Qaeda had sought information made available online by the antisecrecy group after Private Mannings leak, the largest disclosure of confidential materials in American history. Among the evidence were letters written by Osama bin Laden, discovered during the May 2011 raid on his compound in which he was killed, requesting materials from WikiLeaks. Also Monday, prosecutors called a counterintelligence adviser from the Defense Intelligence Agency, saying he would be their last witness. After the witness answered questions about his background, the judge closed the court for classified testimony. The trial will resume Tuesday. Once the government rests its case, the defense will present its evidence.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 11 A.M. (Sundance) RAN (1985) In his masterwork inspired by Shakespeares King Lear, the Japanese director Akira Kurosawa tells the story of Hidetora Ichimonji (Tatsuya Nakadai), an exhausted 70-year-old warlord who wants to turn the vast dominion acquired through 50 years of bloodshed over to his three sons, on whose kindness he will then depend. The two older sons agree to their fathers terms and swear loyalty to him and to each other. But when the youngest argues that by dividing the lands, Hidetora is creating conditions that will lead to disaster, his father sends him into exile. At the same time, the wife (Mieko Harada, above) of his oldest son  the daughter of a lord conquered by Hidetora  encourages her husband to humiliate his father so he can assume control of the family in his own name. Though big in physical scope and of a beauty that suggests a kind of drunken, barbaric lyricism, Ran has the terrible logic and clarity of a morality tale seen in tight close-up, of a myth that, while being utterly specific and particular in its time and place, remains ageless, infinitely adaptable, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times.

title: What the N.S.A. Knows About You
description: Its difficult to have an informed opinion about the National Security Agencys collection of metadata without understanding what metadata is, not that thats stopped anyone. The name suggests that its data about data, and the Obama administration has gone to some lengths to reassure Americans that metadata is definitely not content, which unlike your metadata presumably enjoys Fourth Amendment protections. But Glenn Greenwald, among others, has said thats a distinction without a difference: In reality, it is hard to distinguish email metadata from email content.

title: Sequester Hits the Long-Term Unemployed
description: Sunday was the five-year anniversary of the Emergency Unemployment Compensation program, a federal program signed into law by President George W. Bush that initially added 13 weeks of unemployment benefits to the standard 26 weeks states already offered eligible jobless workers. The 13 additional weeks of benefits were intended to be temporary, but as the recession worsened, Congress decided to keep the program going and even lengthened the amount of time that workers could receive benefits. For a while workers could receive as many as 99 weeks in some states, the longest duration of jobless benefits on record.

On Sunday night in the town of Thandwe, in the western state of Rakhine, two Muslim houses were reportedly burned down by a Buddhist mob in retaliation for the alleged rape of a Buddhist girl by a Muslim man.

title: Beijing Increases Security in Xinjiang
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities tightened their grip on Tuesday on the far western region of Xinjiang, where two clashes left dozens dead last week, by confiscating knives and offering rewards for information about possible separatist attacks, according to the state news media. The police also issued arrest warrants for 11 people said to be wanted for murder, bombings and other acts of violence.

title: Bette Midler Hangs Up the Phone on Ill Eat You Last
description: Bette Midler wrapped up her Broadway run on Sunday in Ill Eat You Last, her hit play about the Hollywood agent Sue Mengers, and by Monday she was starting to decompress. Her voice was strained after three months of chain-smoking herbal cigarettes as the nicotine-and-pot-loving Mengers, but otherwise she seemed hardy during a telephone interview about her first role on Broadway in some 40 years. There was little bitterness, for instance, at the two-dozen theater insiders who declined to nominate her for a Tony Award for best actress for Ill Eat You Last  a decision that was one of the biggest surprises of the theater season.

title: General Ewells Dilemma
description: Gen. Richard S. Ewell of the Confederate Army was frustrated and angry on the afternoon of July 1, 1863, the first day of the Battle of Gettysburg. The cause of his grief was Robert E. Lee, who had just issued a confusing order that forced Ewell to reconsider whether he should carry out an important attack. What he did next may have arguably decided the battle, and certainly became one of the most controversial series of events of the entire war.

title: An E.T.F. Too Far
description: Exchange-traded funds are taking over the financial world. At last official count, there were nearly 1,200 of them at the end of 2012, compared with about 100 a decade ago, according to the Investment Company Institute trade group. With a new issue now linking to the virtual currency Bitcoin, the $1.3 trillion index tracker industry seems to cover nearly everything. And yet the most important asset class of all has been ignored. Breakingviews stands ready to remedy the situation.

title: Image of the Day: July 2
An Ex-Villain Returns as Mr. Sweets
description: In its frantic, Looney Tunes-style madness, Despicable Me 2 brings to mind a cautionary childrens story about an aspiring baker who learns the hard way that doubling the recipe for bread doesnt mean doubling the baking time. It tries so hard to double your pleasure that it emerges from the test kitchen slightly burned. Like the jams and jellies that its reformed main character, Gru, makes in his new line of work, the film combines too many flavors, along with extra sugar. Once again, the lesson that more is not necessarily better, something rarely learned by blockbuster sequels, is forgotten.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Again Challenges Adequacy of G.M. Recall
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is intensifying its investigation into whether General Motors should have recalled about 551,000 vehicles instead of 8,000 for a brake light problem, according to a report posted on the agencys Web site. It is the third time this year N.H.T.S.A. has challenged the adequacy of G.M. recalls.

title: Sharp Rise in Womens Deaths From Overdose of Painkillers

But a new analysis of federal data has found that deaths in recent years have been rising far faster among women, quintupling since 1999.

title: A Regiment is Sacrificed at Gettysburg
description: Union forces along the northern edge of Gettysburg, Pa., occupied a precarious position on July 1, 1863. Advancing Confederates poured deadly volleys into the rapidly thinning blue ranks as a steady stream of wounded trickled into the normally peaceful Pennsylvania town.

title: Donors Are Likely to Ask Karzai to Rethink Rights Panel Choices

Major donor nations and the United Nations will call on Wednesday for Mr. Karzai to reconsider the appointments, according to two Western diplomats.

title: London Theater Journal: Heaven and Earth
description: LONDON  The line is hazy that separates the natural from the supernatural in the world of Conor McPherson, a writer who whispers to the part of us that wants and fears to believe in ghosts. Watching The Night Alive, his beautiful new play at the Donmar Warehouse, I wasnt sure on which side of the divide I was between things worldly and otherwise. And, I thought, theres not another dramatist living who could pull off the kind of ambiguity he exercises so exquisitely here.

His adventures were heard on radio, starting in the 1930s, and seen on television from 1949 to 1957, but unlike some of his cape-wearing peers, he has mostly stayed in the past, an object of fuzzy nostalgia and mocking incredulity, a symbol of simple pleasures and retrograde attitudes.

title: No Porn, Just Books and Zines
description: The rumble of trains and the beeps of swiping fare cards dont seem to distract shoppers huddled inside a tiny newsstand at the Metropolitan Avenue subway station in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Some customers squat, flipping through literary magazines and novels with titles like Killing Williamsburg. Others thumb through booklets of photocopied Polaroids. There isnt a daily paper or a gossip magazine in sight, and almost no one looks up when a curious commuter asks, What is this place?

title: Foraging for Forgotten History Around Washington
description: For the last 15 years, Andrew Carroll has traveled to military bases and V.F.W. halls across the country for the Legacy Project, a repository for American war letters he founded in Washington.

title: Even Boutique Gyms Need Back Offices as They Grow
description: Elizabeth Cutler stepped gingerly over the myriad electrical wires that snaked across the floor and pointed to a room not much larger than a closet, outfitted with a phone, chair and flat-screen television.

title: Paris Couture Fashion Week: Armani Priv Fall 2013
description: Scenes from the couture fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: A Stillborn Bands Rock Is Rediscovered
description: Forty years ago a mob of rock critics gathered for a convention cooked up by a promoter for the Memphis band Big Star, which played a praised set. That image of a cherished, practically mythic concert for an adoring and grateful few helps lay down the mood for Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me. A well-sourced account of a perfect, broken dream, Drew DeNicola and Olivia Moris slightly shaggy documentary captures what its like to discover music so good it seems as if it were made just for you.

title: Megyn Kelly to Get Prime-Time Slot on Fox News
description: The second quarter of 2013 cemented the recent ratings trends in cable news, with CNN rising and MSNBC falling, while Fox News continued its overall dominance.

title: Crucial Rule Is Delayed a Year for Obamas Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  In a significant setback for President Obamas signature domestic initiative, the administration on Tuesday abruptly announced a one-year delay, until 2015, in his health care laws mandate that larger employers provide coverage for their workers or pay penalties. The decision postpones the effective date beyond next years midterm elections.

title: Pirelli Explains Silverstone Tire Problems and Announces Changes for Formula One
description: Several incidents of exploding tires during the British Grand Prix at the Silverstone racecourse on Sunday resulted in a meeting between the tire manufacturer Pirelli and Formula Ones sanctioning body, the Paris-based Fdration Internationale de lAutomobile. The near crash situations experienced by a few drivers in the race recalled the days when tragedy was all too common in Formula One events.

title: Fukushima Plant Operator Intends to Restart Reactors Elsewhere
description: TOKYO  The operator of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant said Tuesday that it would ask regulators to allow it to restart two reactors at a separate site in eastern Japan, even as problems with the companys cleanup in Fukushima continue to multiply.

title: Motive Remains Uncertain in a Shooting in Midtown
description: The brazen Monday morning shooting on a busy stretch of Ninth Avenue appeared at first to be a straightforward case of violent workplace retribution: a laid-off worker returning for revenge.

title: Motorola Ad Seems to Catch the Made in U.S.A. Bug From Apple
description: On the day before Independence Day, Motorola Mobility, the handset maker owned by Google, will be running a new advertisement in newspapers for its next smartphone. The ad, however, wont show a phone. Its all about how the handset will be made in America.

title: Candy Crush Saga Is This Summers Sweet Treat
description: Its hard to know what, exactly, is so addictive about Candy Crush Saga, a puzzle game that challenges players to get three or more matching types of candy in a row.

title: The Collections | The Top Five Mens Wear Shows in Paris
description: The final leg of the European spring/summer 2014 shows continued the relaxed trend that began two weeks earlier in London. Suits, when present, were barely constructed, mostly unlined and often included shorts. Sporty weekend wear dominated, and a light, romantic mood permeated the collections.

title: Joseph Simone
description: Mr. Simone, 57, is the president of the Simone Development Companies, a real estate development and investment firm founded by his father, Pat Simone.

title: As Texas G.O.P. Revives Abortion Ban, a Look at Public Opinion
description: The Texas Legislature began a second special session on Monday to again take up a bill that would, among other provisions, ban abortions in Texas after 20 weeks of gestation. The bill failed in a previous special session after State Senator Wendy Davis stood for roughly 11 hours in a filibuster that brought national attention to the fight.

description: A clip from Crystal Fairy, featuring Michael Cera and directed by Sebastin Silva.

description: Images from the actors film and television career.

title: After Obamas Visit, an Electric Moment for Tanzania Lingers
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  The curving stretch of road along the Indian Ocean behind the State House was once simply called Ocean Road. Now, a black-and-white-striped post holds a sign bearing its new name: Barack Obama Drive.

title: Timeline of Turmoil in Egypt From Mubarak and Morsi to Sisi
description: Egypts three-year experiment with democracy has ousted Hosni Mubarak and deposed Mohamed Morsi, the countrys first elected leader. Explore key moments of their rule and the aftermath.

title: 140 Characters Spell Charges and Jail
description: One night last summer, Jarvis Britton of Birmingham, Ala., sent out a series of Twitter messages that he later described as stupid jokes. Prosecutors did not think they were funny.

title: James Martin, Technology Consultant and Oxford Benefactor, Dies at 79
description: James Martin, a British technology expert, author and prognosticator who viewed mankinds onrushing future with alarm and excitement and used his considerable fortune to address his concerns, died on June 24 near his home in Bermuda. He was 79.

description: Recent Sale

description: The death rate from drug overdoses among women varies widely.

description: WIMBLEDON, England  Victoria Azarenka, the worlds second-ranked womens player, has no structural damage after her painful slip at Wimbledon last week, according to her coach Sam Sumyk.

title: Perry Fights Back on Abortion in Texas
description: Emily Ramshaw, a Texas Tribune editor, discusses Gov. Rick Perry's response to the filibuster that blocked his restrictive abortion bill, and how it may help fuel his political ambitions.

title: Texas Governor Fuels Speculation About His Next Move
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  For Gov. Rick Perry, the longest-serving Texas governor, three four-year terms apparently may be enough. Or not.

description: One educational institution is an august university spread across 835 acres, where thousands of students study everything from ancient philosophies to emerging technologies.

title: Two of Plutos Moons Get Names From Greek Mythologys Underworld
description: For an astronomical body that circles the Sun but is not officially a planet, Pluto has a lot going on, out there four billion miles from the Sun where comets and other icy bodies roam. Among other things, Pluto has a retinue of at least five  count em, five  moons circling it.

title: To Basels Defenses, the Fed Adds a To-Do List
description: After overlooking so many excesses before the financial crisis, bank regulators have spent the last five years trying to regain credibility.

title: Audit of City Crime Statistics Finds Mistakes by Police
description: A long-awaited report ordered by the police commissioner in New York has found deficiencies in the Police Departments efforts to detect whether its crime statistics are being manipulated.

title: Democrats Push Christie to Support Gay Marriage
description: WESTFIELD, N.J.  State Democratic lawmakers on Tuesday sought to put Gov. Chris Christie on the defensive for his opposition to same-sex marriage, saying he is standing in the way of history after last weeks Supreme Court decisions acknowledging the equal rights of gays and lesbians.

title: Nomination of Probst Indicates Thaw in U.S.O.C.-I.O.C. Relations
description: The chairman of the United States Olympic Committee has been nominated for membership to the International Olympic Committee, a potential boost for the United States, which is seeking to expand its Olympic footprint.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 2, 2013

title: Confusing the Public on the Affordable Care Act
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: You Say You Want a Revolution
description: American politicians love to evoke our Revolution against British rule, and will certainly do so again this week, adding their own verbal fireworks as the nation celebrates its independence. Last January in his second inaugural address, President Obama made his own distinctive use of this hallowed reference when he analyzed our history as a continuing effort to carry out the ideals of the revolution and presented his administration as the most recent step in this gradual process.

title: Muslims on Guard in Myanmar
description: In Yangon, Myanmar, the Muslim community is on edge. Many worry the recent violence between Buddhists and Muslims elsewhere in the country will arrive in their city.

title: Payroll Cards Are Under Scrutiny by New Yorks Attorney General
description: New Yorks top prosecutor is investigating some of the states largest employers over their use of A.T.M.-style cards to pay their hourly employees.

title: Who Won the Civil War?
Why the Civil War Still Matters
description: FRANKLIN, Tenn.  IN his 1948 novel Intruder in the Dust, William Faulkner described the timeless importance of the Battle of Gettysburg in Southern memory, and in particular the moments before the disastrous Picketts Charge on July 3, 1863, which sealed Gen. Robert E. Lees defeat. For every Southern boy fourteen years old, he wrote, there is the instant when its still not yet two oclock on that July afternoon.

title: In Egypt, Democrats vs. Liberals
description: WASHINGTON  MILLIONS of Egyptians have spoken: President Mohamed Morsi, elected a year ago, has failed. With vast throngs calling for his ouster and demanding new elections, the army has given him an ultimatum: satisfy the crowds by Wednesday evening or face military intervention. How could this happen, two years after the military helped demonstrators rid Egypt of the autocrat Hosni Mubarak?

title: For DiPietro and Islanders Owner, a Bond Is Broken
description: The 15-year, $67.5 million contract that goalie Rick DiPietro signed with the Islanders in 2006 was called a lifetime contract, but in the years that followed, as DiPietro was sidelined by injury after injury, it was derided as an albatross. Still, the Islanders stuck by DiPietro, refusing to cut him loose for a combination of reasons, not least among them the close relationship between DiPietro and the team owner, Charles Wang.

title: Data Mining, Without Big Brother
description: IN the wake of revelations about the National Security Agencys surveillance programs, President Obama has acknowledged the imperative to balance privacy and security. But so far, his administrations defense of the programs has failed to assure the public that this balance has been achieved  or that basic privacy rights and civil liberties are being protected.

title: A Spokesman Finds Fame Interviewing Tiny Experts
description: How ubiquitous are those AT&T commercials with the inquisitive guy talking earnestly with the cute, lippy children? So ubiquitous that the guy  a comedian, actor and writer named Beck Bennett  sometimes finds himself, despite his best intentions, watching himself on television.

title: Stephens, Last American Remaining, Falls in Quarterfinal
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The 20-year-old American Sloane Stephens exited Wimbledon Tuesday with a 6-4, 7-5 quarterfinal loss to the French veteran Marion Bartoli. The event likely would not have been expected to cause quite as much discontent among the No. 1 Court crowd as it did.

title: The Amazing Energy Race
description: President Obama delivered his most important national security and jobs speech last week. I think he also mentioned something about climate change.

title: Farm Bill Defeat Shows Agricultures Waning Power
description: WASHINGTON  The startling failure of the farm bill last month reflects the declining clout of the farm lobby and the once-powerful committees that have jurisdiction over agriculture policy, economists and political scientists said this week.

title: In Myanmar, Suspicion and Fear Among Neighbors
description: After decades of peaceful coexistence with the Buddhist majority in the country, Muslims say they now live with fear and anxiety about the next attack by rampaging mobs.

title: Myanmars Muslim Minority Confronts Fear and Mistrust
description: YANGON, Myanmar  Night can be very dark in Yangon, a city where street lamps, when there are any, flicker on and off with the uneven electricity supply. For a group of Muslim men guarding their neighborhood until dawn, it is never clear what is lurking down the potholed roads and alleyways.

title: For G.M. and Honda, a Fuel-Cell Partnership
description: General Motors and Honda will develop and share a hydrogen fuel cell for vehicles they would produce around the end of the decade, the automakers announced on Tuesday.

title: Listening In on Europe
description: There seems a touch of playacting in the outrage that France, Germany and other European governments have been venting since the online edition of Der Spiegel, the German newsmagazine, reported last weekend that the National Security Agency had bugged diplomatic offices and monitored their internal computer systems. Spying on allies looks bad and is rarely discussed in public except when, as now, spy agency documents are leaked to the press. But governments on both sides of the Atlantic (and almost everywhere else) have spied on allies and enemies alike for a long time.

title: More Unfairness Toward Immigrants
description: One year ago, the Obama administration declared that it was halting the deportations of some unauthorized immigrants who were brought to the United States as children and would allow them to seek work-authorization papers and Social Security numbers. This raised a question for the states: Would these young people, known as Dreamers, also be allowed to drive?

title: A Chance for Pro Sports to Help on Health Care
description: The Obama administration thought it had a smart way to publicize the benefits of health care reform: get some professional athletes to help spread the word.

title: When the Bill of Rights Had 12 Amendments
description: We treat the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights almost like sacred texts, inevitable and immutable. But if youre in Manhattan on Wednesday, you can see drafts of the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights when they were still works in progress. To celebrate the Fourth of July, the New York Public Library is displaying these documents side by side for the first time.

title: Deadline on Trading Rules Abroad Splits an Agency
description: Wall Street lobbyists, seeking to delay a July 12 deadline for rules that would rein in lucrative trading by banks overseas, pressed their case before a top Washington regulator last week.

title: As Arizona Fires Rage On, Inquiry Into Firefighters Death Focuses on Wind
description: PRESCOTT, Ariz.  A swelling army of firefighters aided by bulldozers, air tankers and helicopters struggled on Tuesday to subdue the forest blaze that killed 19 elite firefighters on Sunday and continued carving a destructive path through two mountainside communities whose residents were forced to flee.

title: After Disaster, Bangladesh Lags in Policing Its Maze of Factories
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Not even two months after the collapse of the Rana Plaza factory building claimed more than 1,100 lives, a team of engineers arrived to assess another factory in the center of the capital. It was named Al-Hamra Garments, and it was one of hundreds of factories undergoing post-disaster inspections as Bangladesh sought to prove that its critical apparel industry was safe.

title: Long Goodbye: Contracts That Keep on Giving
description: Rick DiPietro is a 31-year-old goalie who has had surgery on both knees, a hip, his groin and his face, and has sustained more than his share of concussions. He was waived Tuesday by the Islanders.

title: F.C.C. Is Told Verizon Underpaid Data Refunds
description: WASHINGTON  An independent telecommunications lawyer filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday, claiming that Verizon Wireless had vastly understated the amount it collected from false data charges on customer bills when it agreed to refund the levies in 2010.

description: Concern over the visible swaying of the decades-old Astrotower in Coney Island forced the evacuation and closing of a nearby amusement park on Tuesday afternoon as city engineers checked the structures stability.

title: Hoping the Songs Lead Him to Freedom
description: The sweet harmonies of classic spirituals unite the sometimes fractious voices of the young men in Choir Boy, the ambitious new play by Tarell Alvin McCraney that opened on Tuesday night at City Center in a lively Manhattan Theater Club production. The boys of the Charles R. Drew Prep School may rarely agree on anything  not even the true value of the songs themselves  but when they raise their voices in unison, they offer a glimpse of a world in which the cruelty that can divide and destroy is dissolved in a graceful, embracing order.

description: WASHINGTON  The vast protests gripping Cairo put President Obama in a position both awkward and familiar, recalling the winter of 2011, when he grappled with what to do about another embattled Egyptian president, a restive military and angry young Egyptians quick to see a meddling American hand in their political drama.

description: Excerpts from The New York Timess interview with Jason Kidd, the Nets new coach.

description: Michael S. Dell may have to dig deeper into his pockets if he wants his $24.4 billion bid for the computer company he founded to succeed.

title: South Asians in Queens to Get Ballots in Bengali
description: When New York voters go to the polls for the primary on Sept. 10, South Asians in Queens will for the first time find ballots translated into Bengali, the first new language to be introduced at city polling booths in more than a decade, election officials said.

title: Missouri: Judge Reinstates Mayor
description: A St. Louis County judge reinstated Adam Paul as mayor of Ellisville on Monday, nearly three months after the City Council removed him in an acrimonious and personal dispute. Judge David Lee Vincent III nullified the Councils impeachment proceeding, saying it violated Mr. Pauls due process rights by not giving him enough time to prepare a defense to charges that he had failed to respond to a subpoena. The irony is that the old Council accused Adam Paul of violating the City Charter and they used that as the basis to remove him from the office of mayor, said Chet Pleban, Mr. Pauls lawyer. Ironically, he was restored to the office of mayor because the Council violated the City Charter. Mr. Paul was a political novice who came to power on the back of a campaign against providing tax incentives for a developer to build a Walmart in Ellisville. Mr. Paul claimed that the Council had it in for him because of his opposition to the Walmart, while council members accused him of being brash, disrespectful and violating rules.

title: Suntory Units $4 Billion I.P.O. Rises in Tokyo Trading Debut
description: HONG KONG  Shares in Suntory Beverage and Food rose on Wednesday in the closely watched trading debut of the biggest new share offering in Asia this year.

title: Georgia: 21 Charged After Inquiry Finds Alzheimers Patients Were Abused
description: Twenty-one people were charged Tuesday after the Georgia Bureau of Investigation said it found widespread abuse of patients at a specialized care facility northeast of Atlanta. The bureau said its review had found that employees at Alzheimers Care of Commerce had struck patients, delayed changing diapers and used bedsheets as restraining devices. The inquiry also uncovered that people with felony convictions were involved in patient care, a violation of state regulations. The authorities filed more than 70 charges against current and former facility employees. The centers owner, Donna Wright, was among those charged.

title: Putting Off the Employer Mandate
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Alex Rodriguez came to this damp, breezy city to begin his latest comeback, hoping for better luck with the weather than he had had recently in Florida.

title: A Split in Allegiances Among Roosevelt Scions
description: They are the dynastic titans of New York progressive politics, governors-turned-presidents who forged a place in history by guiding the fate of their nation. But Theodore Roosevelt and Franklin D. Roosevelt were not entirely similar.

title: Bush a Fond Presence in Africa for Work During and Since His Presidency
description: On a humid morning in Tanzania on Tuesday, two American presidents stood side by side in a ceremony where neither spoke. One was the son of a Kenyan whose election broke barriers for African-Americans. But it was the other one who might command as much, if not more, respect among many Africans today.

description: How the auto industry fared in June.

title: William H. Gray III, Pastor and Lawmaker, Dies at 71
description: William H. Gray III, a third-generation Baptist minister from Philadelphia who won a seat in Congress in 1978 and rose to become the highest-ranking black lawmaker in the country, died on Monday in London. He was 71.

title: Satin Overcomes Quirks at the Plate and Walks a Long Path to the Majors
description: At every minor league stop  and there have been quite a few of them for Josh Satin  a coach or instructor needled him about changing his unorthodox batting mechanics, quieting his aggressive leg lift or circular hand motion. It became a ritual of spring.

title: Rawleigh Warner Jr., Brash Chairman of Mobil, Dies at 92
description: Rawleigh Warner Jr., who as chairman of the Mobil Corporation pushed the company to acquire vast crude oil reserves and to enhance its image by introducing Masterpiece Theater to public television and a combative voice to newspapers op-ed pages, died on June 26 at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 92.
