description: In an op-ed, Robert Hicks writes:

title: A Park Where Canos Eyes Get Big and See Better
description: MINNEAPOLIS  A package containing two bats with black and brown barrels arrived for Robinson Cano on Tuesday. The Yankees clubhouse manager, Lou Cucuzza Jr., gave them to Cano, but that was as far as they got. Cano left them at his locker when he headed to the indoor batting cage at Target Field.

title: Depth of Discontent Threatens Muslim Brotherhood and Its Leader
description: CAIRO  The Muslim Brotherhood, among the most powerful forces in Egypt, is facing perhaps the worst crisis in its 80-year history. Its members have been gunned down in the streets. Its new headquarters have been ransacked and burned, its political leader, President Mohamed Morsi, abandoned, threatened and isolated by old foes and recent allies.

title: The Report of the Crime Reporting Review Committee
description: An assessment of the NYPDs crime reporting and CompStat auditing processes produced by the Crime Reporting Review Committee established by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly. Published 2013.

title: Russia: 23 Dead, Others Stranded in Siberian Helicopter Crash
description: A commuter helicopter carrying several dozen passengers, including at least 11 children, crashed in a remote Russian region on Tuesday, killing 23 and prompting a frantic attempt to reach survivors stranded deep in the Siberian taiga. A company official said heavy wind caused the crash. Many residents travel by helicopter between villages in Yakutia, a far-northern region where terrain is rugged and roads are few.

title: Myanmar: General Lands on American Sanctions List
description: Despite a recent thaw in relations, the United States placed a senior Burmese general on its sanctions list on Tuesday, accusing him of buying military equipment from North Korea in defiance of international sanctions. A Treasury Department statement emphasized that the penalties, including an asset freeze, affect only Lt. Gen. Thein Htay, the head of Myanmars Directorate of Defense Industries, and not government figures. The list did not detail what equipment he had bought.

title: France: Political Guillotine Flashes, and Party Discipline Is Served
description: Moving to enforce cabinet discipline, President Franois Hollande on Tuesday fired Delphine Batho, the environment minister, who had said earlier on Tuesday that the proposed 2014 budget was bad. Ms. Batho, 40, had expressed her unhappiness with the 7 percent cut projected for her ministry. She also said, Theres a disappointment with regard to the government, theres a doubt about our will for change. Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault summoned her for a meeting after her comments, on RTL Radio. She will be replaced by Philippe Martin, 59.

title: For at Least One Night, Gonzalez Lifts Yankees
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Within the last two months, utility infielder Alberto Gonzalez has been designated for assignment by the Chicago Cubs, traded to the Yankees, designated for assignment again, cleared waivers, outrighted to the minor leagues, then recalled when the Yankees cut the light-hitting Reid Brignac to finish a shuffle of backup infielders.

title: A Look at the Mens Quarterfinals
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Unlike the womens quarterfinals, the mens Round of 8 on Wednesday comes with four clear favorites.

title: Emerging Talent on Display in the South of France
description: The Cote dAzur has inspired generations of artists and designers, so its no surprise that it is emerging as a locus for the international design scene. The eighth annualDesign Parade, a three-day festival and competition at the Villa Noailles, the iconic Modernist house overlooking the French city of Hyres, opens to the public on Friday. It features the work of 10 young designers from Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, France and Italy, who will exhibit their work to an international jury, with one taking home the Grand Prix. (This years festival also includes, among others, exhibitions devoted to the work of the architect and furniture designer Marcel Breuer, and a collaboration between the Dutch designer Aldo Bakker and the French porcelain manufacturer Svres.)

title: Amare Stoudemires Custom Lanvin Wedding Suit
description: The chic red number the Knicks star wore to his wedding reception last weekend was the result of a year-long collaboration.

title: How Exercise Can Calm Anxiety
description: In an eye-opening demonstration of natures ingenuity, researchers at Princeton University recently discovered that exercise creates vibrant new brain cells  and then shuts them down when they shouldnt be in action.

title: The New Economics of Part-Time Employment
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Wilson Extracted From Prison Yard
description: A force team was required to remove Ronell Wilson from a prison yard after he refused to leave.

title: Prime Minister Tells Portuguese He Wont Resign
description: MADRID  Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho of Portugal on Tuesday defied calls for his resignation, even after his coalition government was torn by divisions over austerity policies that prompted the resignation of a second minister in two days.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (BBC America) MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD (2003) In Peter Weirs adaptation of two novels by Patrick OBrian, Russell Crowe, above, stars as Capt. Jack Aubrey, the commander of a British frigate whose crew must battle a faster, larger French vessel off the coast of South America during the Napoleonic wars. Paul Bettany is Stephen Maturin, the ships surgeon  so deft he even operates on his own abdomen  and the sensitive foil to his friend Aubreys fierceness. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film, which won Oscars for best cinematography and sound editing, and whose land-based scenes were filmed on the Galpagos Islands, hums with humor, passion and life. He added, It makes you wish Napoleon were still around, so we  that is, I mean, the British Empire  could beat him all over again.

title: Video: Detectives Killer Is Presented as a Threat in Jail
description: Jurors in the federal death penalty part of the trial of Ronell Wilson, a Staten Island man who was convicted of murdering two undercover police detectives, watched a dramatic video on Monday that was made inside a federal jail, showing several correction officers storming a confined recreation area to subdue Mr. Wilson, who had refused to comply with demands to leave the area.

title: Ex-Champion Sees Tough Road for, Well, Everyone
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The only certainty about Wimbledon 2013 is that the tournament is sure to continue staunchly avoiding predictability. Whenever you suspect that the cast-iron favorites are finally emerging through the carnage, the next days play upends all expectations. One might as well spin the roulette wheel when it comes to picking the eventual champions.

title: Suspended Sentences in Olympus Fraud Case
description: TOKYO  The former chairman of Olympus, the camera maker that has been embroiled in one of Japans biggest accounting frauds, was found guilty of abetting a $1.7 billion cover-up by a Tokyo court on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Drone Strike in Pakistan Kills at Least 16
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 16 people were killed and five others wounded when an American drone strike hit a suspected Haqqani militant compound in a remote tribal region of northwestern Pakistan late Tuesday, according to Pakistani government and intelligence officials.

title: Barring of Bolivian Plane Infuriates Latin America as Snowden Case Widens
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The geopolitical storm churned up by Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American intelligence contractor, continued to spread on Wednesday as Latin American leaders roundly condemned the refusal to let Bolivias president fly over several European nations, rallying to his side after Bolivian officials said the presidents plane had been thwarted because of suspicions that Mr. Snowden was on board.

title: Indian Politicians Scramble for Electoral Benefits From Flood Relief Work
description: NEW DELHI  A week after floods began to ravage the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand on June 16, Narendra Modi, the chief minister of the western Indian state of Gujarat, an ambitious and controversial politician seeking to topple the Congress Party-led United Progressive Alliance coalition in New Delhi, visited the disaster-struck state with a team of bureaucrats experienced in disaster management to help evacuate stranded pilgrims. A newspaper reported that he helped rescue 15,000 Gujarati pilgrims. A friend quipped, How could he get so many on a single plane?

title: After Marrow Transplants, 2 More Patients Appear H.I.V.-Free Without Drugs
description: Two H.I.V.-infected patients in Boston who had bone-marrow transplants for blood cancers have apparently been virus-free for weeks since their antiretroviral drugs were stopped, researchers at an international AIDS conference announced Wednesday.

title: From Russia to Georgia, a Lesson in Relativity
description: Jana Romanova has been compiling a handbook of rules for relatives. Unconditional support is one of the big ones. So, too, is your duty to fix another relatives mistake as soon as you can. And her favorite?

title: Army Ousts Egypts President; Morsi Is Taken Into Military Custody
description: CAIRO  Egypts military officers removed the countrys first democratically elected president, Mohamed Morsi, on Wednesday, suspended the Constitution and installed an interim government presided over by a senior jurist.

title: Homer Simpsons Perfect Car Comes to Life at 24 Hours of LeMons
description: The 24 Hours of LeMons beater-car racing series has fielded just about every theme-based car you can imagine since it began several years ago. There has been an A-Team van, a few Animal House Deathmobiles and even a plane-car loosely based on the Spirit of St. Louis (if Charles Lindbergh had been an underachieving ground-dweller with low expectations about where he was going in life).

title: New York Today: Shes Back
description: Updated, 12:22 p.m. | Its been a rough couple of years for the Statue of Liberty.

title: Q&A: Using Skype or FaceTime
description: Q.

title: European Markets Slump on Political Crises
description: PARIS  Global stocks fell and oil rose above $100 a barrel on Wednesday as concern about the political crises in Egypt and Portugal added to traders growing anxieties.

title: Daily Report: G.M.-Honda Partnership Aims for Fuel Cell by End of Decade
description: General Motors and Honda will develop and share a hydrogen fuel cell for vehicles they would produce around the end of the decade, the automakers announced on Tuesday, Lindsay Brooke reports in The New York Times.

title: Deutsche Annington Shelves I.P.O. Plan
description: LONDON  A German real estate company owned by Terra Firma, the private equity firm run by the British financier Guy Hands, has shelved a planned initial public offering, citing adverse market conditions.

title: Pressure to Raise Offer for Dell
description: Michael S. Dell may have to raise his $24.4 billion bid for the computer company he founded, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced reports. A special committee of Dells directors encouraged Mr. Dell over the weekend to raise the offer price of $13.65 a share, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday. But Mr. Dell has not committed to a course of action and has not discussed raising the current price with his private equity partner, Silver Lake, Mr. de la Merced reports.

title: Unarrested Development
description: Early on in This Is the End, a fame-inflected look at the end of days, Michael Cera, played by Michael Cera, is impaled and hoisted high above Los Angeles, wriggling, covered in blood and patting his pockets for his lost cellphone. He finds the phone, but the rest of it doesnt go so well.

title: Making a Medicine as Easy to Find as a Can of Coke
description: Diarrheal disease, which kills a million children younger than 5 each year, has an image problem. It doesnt raise much alarm in industrialized countries, where it is merely a nuisance that can be treated with inexpensive, readily accessible remedies. In poorer countries, though, where a large majority of these children are dying, those remedies often cannot be found.

title: Heres an App to Help You Find a Local Find
description: In 2010 Rich Winley was running a marketing company in Greenville, S.C., when he decided to participate in a seven-week business exchange program to Australia through his local Rotary Club. The group traveled from the small town of Darwin in the north down to Sydney, visiting a different city every two or three days.

title: Kristen Stewart Shakes Up the Chanel Suit
description: The Girl: With slicked-back hair and a masculine tailored jacket, the actress brings an androgynous look to the classic Chanel suit at the brands couture show in Paris.

title: In the Americas Cup, Yachts That Can Sail on Air
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Max Sirena, the Italian skipper of Luna Rossa Challenge, was standing inside a converted airplane hangar. Watching his shore crew at work on wing sails and gleaming hulls, he wondered if it was still right to define the focus of all this expert attention as a boat.

title: A Challenge Not Taken, a Match Not Won
description: Li Na made a mistake that contributed to own demise against Agnieszka Radwanska in the quarterfinals at Wimbledon on Tuesday.

title: Scalping Tickets for a Joan Baez Show
description: Dear Diary:

title: Extinct TV Shows from 1980s and 90s Find New Life in Comic Books
description: Fans of canceled television shows from the 1980s and 1990s will soon have new material to comfort them. NBC Universal is partnering with Lion Forge Comics, a digital publisher, to develop comics for several series of yore. The first wave of announced comics are Airwolf, which ran from 1984 to 1987, Knight Rider (1982-1986), Miami Vice (1984-1989), Punky Brewster (1984-86) and Saved by the Bell (1989-1993).

title: Readers Protest David Brookss Mutts Column, and He Responds
description: In the course of a given week, I hear from many readers who dont like something that one of The Timess star columnists has written. I may agree or disagree, but I only rarely write about it. Thats because by virtue of their job descriptions, columnists are supposed to stir things up and get people talking. Yes, they have to deal in the world of facts and truth, but their opinions  and the way they express them  are almost unassailable. So I let the protests pass.

title: A Mini Waterproof Case for the iPad Mini
description: Lifeproof has made its name building phone and tablet cases that are water, dust, snow and shock proof without adding the armor cladding of many submersible cases. It claims its new Fre case for the iPad mini is its most streamlined yet.

title: Updates on the Toppling of Morsi
description: The Lede followed events in Egypt on Wednesday, where the countrys first democratically elected president, Mohamed Morsi, was deposed by the military following days of mass protests and deadly street clashes.

title: The Gun Report: July 3, 2013
description: So Gabby Giffords shot a gun yesterday.

title: Hong Kong Rents Push Out Mom and Pop Stores
description: HONG KONG  Nam Kee Noodles is a typical Hong Kong restaurant: functional, popular and busy.

title: Fighting Communism, One Athlete at a Time
description: SHANGHAI  Li Na, the Chinese tennis star, didnt make it all the way at Wimbledon this time: She lost out in the womens quarterfinals on Tuesday. But she has scored a broader success: Making it in the tennis world largely on her own.

title: A Walking Tour of One of Londons Finest Market Streets
description: At the top end of Portobello Road in Notting Hill is Golborne Road, one of Londons best market streets. I visit on Friday mornings, when antiques dealers and Moroccan food vendors line the street in front of the permanent shops, which belong to a mix of Moroccan and Portuguese butchers, bakers, fishmongers and, of course, more antiques dealers. Here, Ill guide you through the Portobello Road area for your next Friday morning visit.

title: July 3: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Judge Orders Return of Bodies of Mandela Kin Amid Dispute
description: JOHANNESBURG  An ugly squabble between Nelson Mandelas eldest grandson and more than a dozen other family members over the bodies of three of his children intensified Wednesday afternoon as the police broke down the gates surrounding the burial site to fulfill a judges order that the bodies be exhumed and returned to a nearby village where the ailing Mr. Mandela himself is to be buried.

title: Inventory Makes All the Right Choices for You
description: THE HEIGHT OF STYLE is no style, to dress like you did not bother to get dressed at all, like your closet consists of exactly one perfectly fitting T-shirt, one broken-in but quietly tailored pair of jeans, one chambray or denim shirt that looks as if you lifted it from your grandfathers closet, and not much more.

title: What Were Reading
description: Food Republic: Admit it: You covet Japanese barware. You make your own bitters. You wouldnt even think about owning a bottle of vodka. These, and 14 other signs that youre a cocktail snob.  Patrick Farrell

title: Beauty Products Welcome Booze to the Ingredient List
description: Food and grooming products have intersected for years, but booze in ones body wash is a relatively recent development. Herein, some new products based on popular warm-weather cocktails.

title: Floods Scare Tourists from Undamaged Parts of Uttarakhand
description: RUDRAPRAYAG, Uttarakhand  Rescue operations in the flood-struck parts of Uttarakhand are nearly finished, and almost all of the stranded pilgrims have returned to their homes. What they leave behind are half a million people who have no way to earn a living as tourists stay away from the entire state.

title: After Failed Attempt in April, Europe Approves Emissions Trading System
description: LONDON  The European Parliament approved on Wednesday a measure intended to revive sagging prices and confidence in the European Unions emissions trading system, the centerpiece of Europes effort to cut greenhouse gases and a model for similar systems around the world.

title: U.S. Postal Service Logging All Mail for Law Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON  Leslie James Pickering noticed something odd in his mail last September: a handwritten card, apparently delivered by mistake, with instructions for postal workers to pay special attention to the letters and packages sent to his home.

title: Fashion Label Nicole Farhi Is in Bankruptcy
description: LONDON  Nicole Farhi, the upmarket fashion label, has run out of money and filed for a form of bankruptcy proceedings in the latest sign of trouble for British retailers.

title: Software as a Monthly Rental
description: Theres a new reason for Photoshop to be famous.

title: Three Noteworthy Apps for Children
description: Here are three recently released noteworthy apps to entertain children during the summer.

title: Paid Sick Leave Laws Generate Concern, but Not Much Pain
description: Back in 2007, as a new paid sick leave law  the first in the nation  was about to take effect in San Francisco, Bill Stone was worried. Mr. Stone owns the Atlas Cafe in the citys Mission District, and the new law directed him to provide his 21 employees with one hour of paid time off for every 30 hours worked, up to nine days a year. Basically, its just going to make it more expensive to operate your business, Mr. Stone told NPR at the time. Small business is going to have to pass that cost onto their customers.

title: Why Asian Internet Companies Struggle to Become Global
description: Asia is home to nearly half of the 2 billion Internet users in the world. It makes most of the hardware  laptops, smartphones, tablets and other gadgets  that is used to gain access to the Internet. In countries like South Korea and Japan, it has some of the fastest wired and wireless networks for carrying Internet traffic.

title: Is Paid Sick Leave as Damaging as Some Businesses Fear?
description: Whenever lawmakers debate new regulations for businesses, it is easy to find business owners who fear the worst. Six years ago, the nations first paid sick leave law was set to take effect in San Francisco, and Bill Stone wasnt happy. Mr. Stone owns Atlas Cafe, in the citys Mission District. Basically, its just going to make it more expensive to operate your business, Mr. Stone told NPR at the time. Small business is going to have to pass that cost onto their customers.

title: Mail Covers: Snail Mail Surveillance
description: A collection of documents highlighting the use of surveillance of envelopes by the Postal Service and law enforcement agencies.

title: What You Get for ...$1,199,000
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: Homes for $1,199,000
description: This weeks properties include a log home in North Carolina, an adobe in Tucson and a 1907 house in Minneapolis.

title: Crazy Cousins
description: According to Tolstoy, cousinhood is a dangerous neighborhood, and if youve ever had a small horde of somewhat-related kids over to your house you may find you agree. As two new picture books demonstrate, cousins may be surprisingly different, but they tend to share a common sense of fun, and things can get wild fast.

title: Paris Couture Fashion Week: Chanel Fall 2013
description: Scenes from the couture fashion week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: House Hunting in ... Belgium
description: A THREE-BEDROOM TOWN HOUSE IN A FLEMISH COUNTRY MANOR

title: Real Estate on the North Sea Coast of Belgium
description: This Belgian coastal market, filled with second-home investment properties, is stronger than that of the country as a whole.

title: Breaking Away From the Citibike Peloton
description: In her Lives essay in this past weekends magazine, Mary H. K. Choi writes about learning to ride a bike in New York as an adult.

title: Bodies of Subversion
description: Margot Mifflin updates the history of women and tattoos.

title: Give Em the Bird
description: Chicken, salads and more fixings for a perfect summer feast.

title: Our Bodies, Our Ink
description: Among the first mainstream American celebrities to openly wear  tattoos was Janis Joplin.  On her left wrist, she had a Florentine bracelet. On her chest, she wore a small heart  the size of a candy heart. Just a little treat for the boys, she told Rolling Stone, like icing on the cake.

title: Jean Paul Gaultier
description: The couture collection was shown in Paris.

title: How to Make a Perfect Summer Feast
description: Weekends cant come quickly enough now that weve passed the Rubicon of the Fourth of July. We need them to banish memories of summer commuting and the stick and pull of work clothes at noon, when you get three feet outside your office and already regret going to the bank. Whether youre in a friends backyard or a city apartment with the air-conditioner on high, the next two months are meant for barefoot padding from Friday until Monday dawn. We ought to cook to match.

title: Commanders in Chef: Recipes From TV Presidents
description: HOW TO GRILL LOBSTERSBy Tony Goldwyn, President Fitzgerald Grant, Scandal

title: Jean Paul Gaultier: Fall 2013 Couture
description: Paris

title: Death of Cirque du Soleil Performer Was Accidental, Officials Say
description: The death of a Cirque du Soleil performer at a show in Las Vegas has been ruled an accident, the local authorities said.

title: Murray Survives in Five Sets; Djokovic and del Potro Advance
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Andy Murray did not want to hear it. He did not want to hear about how his draw got so much easier with Rafael Nadal, Roger Federer and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga out. He did not want to hear about how he was never going to have a better chance to win Wimbledon. And he certainly did not want to hear about how lucky he was to have the unseeded Fernando Verdasco as his quarterfinal opponent.

title: Image of the Day: July 3
Slap Shots Content Is On the Move
description: Thank you for visiting Slap Shot. This blogs regular features, including live game analysis, reader discussion, news and notes from Jeff Z. Klein and others, can now be found on the Hockey section front.

title: Excerpt: Mindy's Toast
description: David Rakoff reads an excerpt from his novel Love, Dishonor, Marry, Die, Cherish, Perish, with feedback from Ira Glass.

title: Loves Labors, Published
description: David Rakoffs third book of essays, Half Empty, came out in the fall of 2010, nine months after he learned that the pain hed been experiencing in his left arm and shoulder was the result of a malignant sarcoma. David was an extraordinary essayist  the book won the Thurber Prize for American Humor, and, like his two previous collections, was a best seller  so it came as some surprise when he called his editor at Doubleday to say that he wanted his next book to be a novel written in rhyme.

title: Knight Capital Chief Quits
description: The popular leader of the trading firm Knight Capital, Thomas M. Joyce, unexpectedly resigned from the company a few days after it was formally taken over by the high-speed trading firm Getco.

title: What to Drink at a Summer Feast
description: Serving complicated cocktails at a cookout is kind of like wearing a ball gown to a ballgame  overdressed and a little incongruous, if not downright silly. With beer-can chicken, a cooler full of whatever beer helped make the chicken possible makes perfect sense. To get things started, though, I get a big punch bowl ready. The tequila-watermelon punch I wrote about last August would be great with Sam Siftons tomato-watermelon salad in this weekends Feast spread:

title: Report Says Airport X-Ray Scanners Pose Little Risk
description: Travelers often worry about radiation exposure from airport scanners, but a new report says that the risk is actually low: passengers absorb less radiation from airport X-ray backscatter scanners than they do while standing in line waiting for the scan itself.

title: Isle of Skye in Williamsburg
description: The Caledonia Scottish Pub, a popular spot on the Upper East Side, has a spacious new branch in Williamsburg called Isle of Skye, serving more than 100 different kinds of whiskey. A thick black binder lists them by region and price, along with some dramatic descriptions. In addition to the usual peaty and smoky adjectives, some whiskeys are sweet with iodine and heather or described as having hints of poached peaches and smoked meats.

title: Afghan Court Reverses Convictions in Torture of Girl
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A court has reversed the convictions of three Afghans jailed for torturing a young relative who had refused to become a prostitute, alarming activists who had celebrated the guilty verdicts as a warning to all those who would seek to reverse the strides made by women here in the past 12 years.

title: Beware the Fees on Europes Budget Airlines
description: Travel writers (myself included) often recommend low-cost carriers like Ryanair and easyJet as an affordable way to get around Europe. But that advice should come with an asterisk explaining how their baggage policies and fees differ from what most passengers are used to in the United States.

title: Hotel Review: Castello di Casole in Tuscany
description: Rates

title: Russian Mayor, an Opposition Figure, Is Arrested
description: MOSCOW  The popular mayor of Yaroslavl, an anticorruption activist who is one of the few opposition figures in Russia to hold a major public office, was arrested late Tuesday and charged with bribery and extortion in a case that immediately set off accusations against the Kremlin of political intimidation.

title: Wrist Injury Sidelines Marin Alsop
description: Marin Alsop, the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and chief conductor of the So Paulo Symphony Orchestra, has canceled her conducting schedule for July because of a wrist injury, Baltimore Symphony officials said Wednesday. Ms. Alsop, 56, apparently sprained her right wrist in an accident Monday night in So Paulo.

title: Getting Insurance to Pay for Midwives
description: Medical doctors deliver more than 85 percent of American babies, and the overwhelming majority of births in the United States take place in hospital labor and delivery wards. But in many European countries, midwives attend to most pregnancies, often in clinics, resulting in maternity charges that are a fraction of those in the United States.

title: Summer Blockbusters
description: Gail Collins: David, are you a summer movie fan?

title: Lighting Out for a Midtown West Rental
description: The market was sizzling six years ago when William Tracy bought a 1,300-square-foot one-bedroom loft in the Grand Madison, a 1906 building near Madison Square Park. He paid a bit more than $1.5 million, with condominium charges and taxes in the low $2,000s.

title: The Economics of Mad Geniuses
description: In a magazine column this week, I talked about how expanding access to mental health care could be a cost-effective way to help the economy, given the economic costs of untreated or inadequately treated illness (like worker absenteeism and subsidized housing).

title: Creating a Liver Bud
description: Over 72 hours, human liver cells self-assemble into a three-dimensional liver bud.

title: Samsung Electronics Acquires Boxee, a Video Start-Up
description: Samsung Electronics confirmed on Wednesday that it had acquired assets and talent from Boxee, a video start-up. The acquisition should help Samsung improve its software for its Internet-connected televisions.

title: Beautycounter Promotes Its Environmentally Themed Products
description: On an evening in June, guests from the worlds of art, fashion and film were mingling at the airy TriBeCa loft of Lela Rose, the designer. In the crowd was the actress and singer Mandy Moore, clad in a slinky dress designed by Ms. Rose and carrying a silver Givenchy clutch purse.

title: Scientists Fabricate Rudimentary Human Livers
description: Researchers in Japan have used human stem cells to create tiny human livers like those that arise early in fetal life. When the scientists transplanted the rudimentary livers into mice, the little organs grew, made human liver proteins, and metabolized drugs as human livers do.

title: Congressional Budget Analysts Release Positive Economic Assessment of Immigration Overhaul
description: Congressional budget analysts on Wednesday released a positive economic assessment of the broad overhaul of the nations immigration laws that passed the Senate last week, saying that the new legislation would cut more than $800 billion from the federal deficit over the next two decades and lead to 9.6 million new legal residents in the country.

title: What Shes Having
description: To the Editor:

title: Conscientious Objections
description: To the Editor:

description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Bigger on the Inside: A Royal Visit to the Set of Doctor Who
description: One of Britains most enduring characters and his faithful companion got to meet their second most-famous equivalents  you can decide who is who  when Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, visited the actors Matt Smith and Jenna Coleman on the set of the BBC science-fiction adventure series Doctor Who on Wednesday.

title: Oregon Looks at Way to Attend College Now and Repay State Later
description: Going to college can seem like a choice between impossibly high payments while in school or a crushing debt load for years afterward, but one state is experimenting with a third way.

title: U.S. Border Agency Allows Others to Use Its Drones
description: As Congress considers a new immigration law that would expand the fleet of unmanned drones along the border, the agency in charge of border protection is increasingly offering the military-grade drones it already owns to domestic law enforcement agencies and has considered equipping them with nonlethal weapons, according to documents recently made public.

title: James Bonds Submersible Lotus Resurfaces
description: James Bonds gadget-laden, amphibious Lotus Esprit, from the 1977 film The Spy Who Loved Me, is about to enter the public eye after years in seclusion. RM Auctions will offer the submersible car for sale at its Battersea Park sale in London on Sept. 9.

title: Why You Can Ignore Those Odd $1 Credit Card Charges
description: I usually check my credit-card accounts online regularly, to keep on top of spending and to help spot any unauthorized purchases. Recently I noticed something odd I hadnt seen before  a series of $1 charges, from the convenience store where I usually gas up my car.

title: Triple Play: Week 13 Results
description: The spirit of Jackie Robinson did little to inspire the players in question No. 1. Everth Cabrera wound up on the disabled list with a hamstring injury, and Jacoby Ellsbury, Nate McLouth and Starling Marte all failed to steal a base.

title: Reform, Not Cap, Is Right Move on Fund Bonuses
description: European fund managers can heave a sigh of relief. On Wednesday, the European Parliament rejected the plan of Sven Giegold, a German representative, to place strict limits on bonus payments and to outlaw some performance fees.

title: Christopher Buckley: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of They Eat Puppies, Dont They? says his favorite writer is Evelyn Waugh, even though he so despised Americans that, if he were alive to hear this compliment, he would swat it back across the net.

title: In Open Letter, Top Morsi Aide Says Coup Is Under Way
description: CAIRO  A top adviser to President Mohamed Morsi issued an open letter Wednesday afternoon lamenting what he called the imminent takeover of Egypts first freely elected government.

title: Kenzo Ads That Make You Look Twice
description: THERES SOMETHING FUNNY about those Kenzo advertisements.

title: Is This the Worst Ever Political Ad?
description: On Monday, Alison Lundergan Grimes, Kentuckys secretary of state, announced that she was challenging Mitch McConnell in his bid for a sixth term in the Senate. On Tuesday, the McConnell campaign released a bizarre, auto-tuned attack ad called What Rhymes with Alison Lundergan Grimes? Answers include: Left wing mime and Not ready for prime time. It is catchy only in the sense that it is grating and looks like an ad your grandfather, trying far too hard to seem hip, might make for your High School student council race.

title: Gene Sleuths Find How Some Naturally Resist Cholera
description: People living in the Ganges Delta, where cholera is an ancient, endemic and often lethal disease, have adapted genetically to the scourge through variations in about 300 genes, say researchers who have scanned their genomes for the fingerprints of evolution.

title: In Case of Emergency: My Cellphone Knows What to Do
description: I am lucky. Ive never been in a disaster or in a situation where I worried about my survival. Perhaps thats because I have lived in safe places and not tried too many risky activities. When my wife was a girl, though, she had to call a mountain rescue team after getting lost in difficult weather. Back then, she had to rely on her wits and a basic cellphone to call for help. Now, when emergencies or disasters strike, smartphone apps can offer detailed assistance.

title: Eyes Stay on Rodriguez, With the Benefit of Perspective
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Nobody boycotted Alex Rodriguez from right outside the gates of Joseph P. Riley Jr. Park or booed him with any great conviction inside the jammed stadium during his latest re-emergence into professional baseball.

title: Zimmerman Studied Stand Your Ground in Class, Florida Court Is Told
description: SANFORD, Fla.  In the spring of 2010, a military prosecutor with the Army taught a college class near here that delved into Floridas Stand Your Ground law. One of his pupils stood out for his diligence: George Zimmerman, who earned an A.

title: Texas Republican Personifies Challenge for Immigration Bill
description: GONZALES, Tex.  The questions about immigration at Representative Blake Farentholds town meeting were urgent and to the point.

title: Blood Alcohol Testers for Those Without Badges
description: Cheap microelectronics are democratizing the world of blood alcohol measuring equipment. A field once dominated by $10,000 machines owned only by police departments and requiring significant training is now filled with devices that cost as little as $30 and can hang from a key chain.

title: The Long and the Long of Maxiskirts
description: Floor-sweeping and lean, with a romantic floaty movement, maxiskirts work especially well for summer because of how easily they dress up and down. During the day, pair with a silk tank, worn loose, and flat sandals or wedges, then pop on a blazer for a meeting.

title: A Clean-Cut Bag That Respects Its Owners Style
description: The woman who is drawn to the cosmopolitan natural leather bags from the young Italian label AB A Brand Apart is likely to have innate style but may not necessarily be able to identify the bag of the season. Designed by Andrea Br, AB (for his initials) A Brand Apart is, as the designer puts it, kind of an outsider in the fashion system. Made with modern world travelers in mind, the collection includes this shoulder bag, clean and classic with a metallic silver closure (also in black with a green closure), $650; minimalist totes with the Latin phrase Omnia mea mecum porto (All thats mine I carry with me) inscribed on an interior pouch, $450; and a metallic envelope clutch, $226, thats chic and easy to toss into a suitcase.

title: Its Weinstein vs. Warner Brothers Over Use of the Title The Butler
description: LOS ANGELES Never ones to avoid controversy, especially when it comes to selling a movie, Harvey Weinstein and the Weinstein Company now have an attention-getting fight over Lee Danielss coming film The Butler on their hands. Warner Brothers had objected to the title, citing rights to a similarly titled short from 1916, and won in industry arbitration this week. Now Weinstein according to a flurry of press reports, including those on the Deadline.com site  has asked its lawyer David Boies to appeal or take further legal action.

title: Jamaica to Prohibit Smoking in Public Places
description: Jamaica will soon join the ranks of countries that prohibit smoking in public places. The nationwide ban will take effect July 15. People will no longer have to involuntarily inhale tobacco smoke, with its over 40 carcinogens, Fenton Ferguson, the minister of heath, said in a statement when the new regulations were announced in late June.

title: Glittery Tees for After the Fireworks
description: Ryan Lo, an emerging designer in London, is not afraid of girly-ness: he uses loads of pink and glitter, and cites pop cultural references like Ally McBeal and the Bonnie Tyler song Total Eclipse of the Heart. His collection for summer, inspired in part by the artist Yayoi Kusama and Studio 54, includes T-shirts with glittered fruit and flowers  watermelon, tiger lily, dragon fruit, a kiwi patch. I just wanted something fresh and sweetly erotic for the summertime, Mr. Lo said. The tees kind of remind me of the famous Japanese candy Hi-Chew. Yum.

title: A Guide to Tie-Dye
description: As an artist living in New York, Shabd Simon-Alexander discovered the perfect medium for her work when, by chance, she attended a garden party where there was a table set up for tie-dyeing. Hooked from that moment, and with experience in fashion design, she spent a year developing tie-dye techniques (and enjoying nonstop compliments for the pieces she wore) before introducing her namesake label. This summer she spreads the love, with Tie-Dye: Dye It, Wear It, Share It, which includes history and color theory, along with detailed how-to projects. People have a very narrowly defined idea of what tie-dye is, she said, but theres a 2,000-year history. Happily timed for a season of elevated tie-dye on the runway (Miu Miu, Band of Outsiders) and from popular designers like Raquel Allegra, the book is a nice summer BBQ gift.

title: No Quid Pro Quo by Youre the Boss Writer, but Intrigue, Anyway
description: Ed Zitron may not be the savviest public relations person around. When he e-mailed a New York Times business editor, he asked for the strictest anonymity about his complaint: that a writer for the Youre the Boss small-business blog was demanding money as a trade for mentioning his clients.

title: Swiss Offer Plan to Solve Dispute Over Data on U.S. Tax Evaders
description: PARIS  The Swiss government said on Wednesday that it had found a way to allow the countrys banks to turn over data to the United States in spite of strict banking secrecy laws, potentially opening the way for hundreds of lenders to end the threat of criminal prosecution by the Justice Department.

title: State Senator Makes a Fashion Statement
description: MUCH HAS BEEN READ into the pink running shoes worn by Wendy Davis, the state senator from Texas whose 11-hour filibuster to block passage of an anti-abortion bill last week made her a political celebrity. They were practical, and yet provocative.

title: Health Inspectors Close Perla
description: 5:14 p.m. | Updated New York Citys health department confirmed Wednesday afternoon that it had closed Perla yesterday following an inspection.

title: Think Like a Doctor: A Mysterious Fever Solved!
description: On Tuesday we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 37-year-old woman in Tennessee who had a persistent fever despite being treated with antibiotics. In addition, we asked that you identify the test used to confirm the diagnosis.

title: Deadlines
description: Death has been a great literary theme for so long you might think thered be little left to say on the subject, but in recent decades the literature of death has taken an interesting and novel turn. Writers are recording their own deaths as they happen.

title: Gone Girls
description: In mid-December 2010, the Suffolk County police discovered the bodies of four women, each wrapped in burlap, on a desolate, bramble-covered stretch of sand called Gilgo Beach. The corpses were later identified as those of four prostitutes, Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman, Maureen Brainard-Barnes and Amber Lynn Overstreet Costello. The work was believed to be that of a serial killer, and for several months to come, the media circus that accompanied the official investigation  centering on the search for another prostitute, Shannan Gilbert, who had disappeared after a nearby assignation the previous May  kept much of the New York area and the nation entranced. It was a gothic whodunit for the Internet age, replete with prostitutes, drugs, family dysfunction, investigative incompetence, not to mention a strange, insular beach community and, of course, the Web sites of Craigslist and Backpage, where the women had advertised for customers. Robert Kolker, who wrote about the murders for New York magazine in 2011, has produced in Lost Girls a compelling, nearly unputdownable narrative of the case and its attendant issues; a horrific, cautionary tale that makes for a very different type of beach read.

title: The Sacrifice of the Second Wisconsin
description: On April 22, 1861, Philo Wright, a 19-year-old schoolteacher living in the far southwest corner of Wisconsin, answered President Lincolns call for volunteers and joined a budding local unit called the Grant County Grays. His life suddenly began to change rapidly: a month later the unit became Company C of the Second Wisconsin Volunteer Regiment, and a month after that the Second Wisconsin became the first three-year regiment to reach Washington. By July, three months after leaving his small-town classroom behind, Wright was fighting at the First Battle of Bull Run in a brigade commanded by William Tecumseh Sherman.

title: Computer Visionary Who Invented the Mouse
description: Douglas C. Engelbart was 25, just engaged to be married and thinking about his future when he had an epiphany in 1950 that would change the world.

title: Guns on a Plane
description: Whatever you think about the Second Amendment or the increasing number of states that are allowing people to carry a concealed weapon, you surely agree that anyone who walks around with a gun should be, at the very least, responsible and aware.

title: Yeezus Falls Sharply as Wales Gifted Hits No. 1
description: Is Kanye Wests latest album a hit? Its certainly being talked about everywhere; even Lou Reed weighed in on the record, Yeezus (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam), calling it majestic and inspiring. But so far its sales are far from blockbuster.

title: Lets Put on a Show ... Someday
description: Wallace Shawn and Andr Gregory may be the most renowned playwright-director duo in New York theater, so much so that two of the citys most renowned theaters, the Public and Theater for a New Audience, are sponsoring a series to celebrate their 40-year collaboration.

title: We Didnt Name Him Wowee
description: I grew up in a small town (Deshler, Ohio, population 1,799) and that small town is stockpiled with great nicknames.

title: CT Scan May Be Too Good at Finding Lung Problems, Study Finds
description: CT imaging is a very good way to find pulmonary embolisms  sudden blockages of an artery in the lung, which can be fatal if not treated quickly. But a new analysis finds that the procedure might be too good, revealing tiny embolisms that are harmless and leading to treatments that are unnecessary, expensive and potentially dangerous.

title: Chesapeake Discovers the Price of a Costly Quest for Oil
description: Chesapeake Energy is discovering the price of its costly quest for oil.

title: Looks From Couture Fashion Week
description: Giorgio Armani offered a feast for the eyes; Raf Simons, nourishment for the mind.

title: Some Couture for Thought
description: PARIS  Unless youre a rich woman or Rihanna, the pleasures of haute couture are confined to what you can see in magazines or on the Web. Its a small-frame view, with a lot of hyperventilating about craft and allure, and even with that, its still hard to see what all the fuss is about.

title: In Tours Fifth Stage, a Focus on a Rider Who Is No Longer in the Race
description: MARSEILLE, France  Mark Cavendish stood on the podium here, smiling broadly and accepting the kisses and flowers that came with his Stage 5 win at the Tour de France. But not even a victory by Cavendish, the worlds best sprinter, could take the focus Wednesday from Ted King, who did not even race in the stage, a 142-mile ride along the Mediterranean coast.

title: Musical Revivalists With a Cause
description: The people who run Encores! at City Center know the drill. When buttonholed by loyal attendees of the series, which revives mostly lesser-known Broadway musicals in semi-staged concert versions, theyre used to sentences that begin What about or You should do, followed by a show title.

title: Looks From Paris Mens Fashion Week
description: With high-quality materials and precisely cut suits, men are given a simple look for spring.

title: Living the Life They Expect
description: PARIS  Designers harped a lot about freedom this season, and probably to the bafflement of men, who generally have little trouble doing exactly what they want.

title: Valentino
description: The couture collection was shown in Paris.

title: More Changes at Granta
description: The recent announcement that Ted Hodgkinson, the online editor for the literary magazine Granta, would be leaving his position revived the chatter surrounding the London-based quarterly, which has lost seven staff members since its top editor, John Freeman, announced in April that he would be stepping down.

title: Valentino: Fall 2013 Couture
description: Paris

title: The Work Behind Childs Play
description: Remember that glorious moment at the top of a long, narrow metal slide, when you screwed up the courage to zoom into oblivion? Or, even better, the chance to escape into a tunnel, safe from the prying eyes of parents?

title: A Years Worth of Verse at Poets House
description: Its something of a sport to say that poetry is dying, but nearly 3,000 books currently on display in Battery Park City offer a strong counterargument.

title: Emotional Win for Polish Tennis
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Chair umpires have made no shortage of announcements through the decades at Wimbledon, but not many could have felt the need to say what Carlos Ramos said Wednesday as Jerzy Janowicz and Lukasz Kubot reached a critical phase of the second set on Court 1.

title: Peter Thums Mission: A Jewelry Line Created from Guns and Bullets
description: It was a warm Monday evening in early June, the sun still bright in the sky, and about three dozen fashionably dressed New Yorkers were gathered for a party at the rooftop bar of the Jane Hotel, chatting away.

title: Obamas Insurance Delay Wont Affect Many
description: On Tuesday, the White House announced that it would delay for another year one provision of the 2010 health care reform act. Larger employers will now have until 2015 before they will have to provide insurance or face penalties. The administrations explanation is that it is listening to businesses concerns about getting their coverage ready in time, and trying to be flexible. But what people are really concerned about is whether this will make a difference in health care coverage and the progress of reform.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Robert Kolkers Lost Girls
description: This week, Robert Kolker talks about Lost Girls: An Unsolved American Mystery; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Chuck Klosterman discusses I Wear the Black Hat; Meghan ORourke on her essay about authors recording their own deaths as they happen; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Yoga Practitioners Gaze at Their Inner Selfies
description: Like many yoga aficionados, Laura Kasperzak, 36, practices early in the morning when she can get some time by herself. No ones up at 5:30 with me, she said, referring to her husband and two young children. But unlike most other Zen seekers, before she does her first downward dog, she sets the timer on her Nikon camera to photograph herself every two seconds. After all, about 245,000 people who follow her on Instagram are waiting to see the results.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Robert Kolkers Lost Girls
description: This week, Robert Kolker, Chuck Klosterman and Meghan ORourke.

title: Amazon Is Poised to Re-Enter Web Art Market
description: The selling of expensive contemporary art online has had a rocky history. Sothebys and the art-information company Artnet both tried and failed as pioneers in the late 1990s, giving up after deciding buyers were not yet ready to pay five or six figures for works they had not seen in person. The VIP Art Fair had slightly better luck when it began in 2011, though it was plagued by technical problems that showed how tricky it was to transplant the experience of bricks-and-mortar selling into a virtual environment.

title: Cher Talks About (What Else?) Being Cher
description: After nearly a half-century of being world famous, Cher has encountered every type of boldface name. Shes shared a stage with Bette Midler, tangled with Madonna and worked for Phil Spector, who was her first boss and, she says, paid her $25 for a years work. She even had a thing with Tom Cruise back in the 80s before he became a Scientologist.

title: Differing Styles Flashed Amid Staccato Rhythms
description: Phronesis finished its late set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night with a dynamic prcis, the sort of tune that sews up everything you need to know about the band. It was Abrahams New Gift, by the bassist Jasper Hoiby, who set up its slanted rhythmic scaffolding with a quick, complicated ostinato, his long fingers flying across the strings.

title: A Conceptual Palette, Spare to Hallucinatory
description: Ever since the small, nondescript East Village storefront space known as the Stone opened for business in 2005, the artists who appear there have determined its agenda. Founded and operated by the composer and saxophonist John Zorn, the Stone initially engaged a different artist to fill the calendar each month; later, two-week stretches became the norm.

title: Deft Card Reading at New England Summer Regional
description: Douglas Doub of West Hartford, Conn., has won six national titles and represented the United States in four world championships. On June 21 at the New England Summer Regional in Sturbridge, Mass., he displayed excellent card reading in the diagramed deal from a knockout teams.

title: Wheelies: The Smoky Hot Hatch Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Egypt and Islamic Democracy
description: During the upheavals that toppled Hosni Mubarak just over two years ago, I quoted from Reuel Marc Gerechts 2004 book The Islamic Paradox to offer a case for something like optimism about the Egyptian future. Now that further upheavals have apparently toppled Mubaraks successor, with the Egyptian military providing the decisive push, it seems worth reproducing that quote today:

title: Fourth of July Week Shopping Events and Openings
description: Fourth of July

title: Dress Me Up in Your Love
description: For her article in the magazine last year about a manufacturing community in Alabama with an increasing number of female breadwinners, Hanna Rosin spoke to men and women who were grappling with the change. While a new dynamic was evident throughout the community, every middle-aged couple insisted that the man was still head of the household.

title: Assembling a Tasting Menu of Global Talent
description: The Lincoln Center Festival, which opens Saturday, offers New Yorks cultural cognoscenti the opportunity to show off their global bona fides.

title: Advice for Caregivers of Relatives With Cancer
description: Readers were invited to ask Julia Bucher, a registered nurse and an author of a caregiving book, about handling a family members new illness, specifically cancer. Dr. Bucher is an associate professor of nursing at York College of Pennsylvania, in York, Pa., where she has taught community health nursing, research and health policy since 2006. She also works as an advanced practice nurse at one of York Colleges nurse-managed centers. Her research focus is problem solving and coaching the family caregivers of people with cancer. For eight years she was a regional planner for the American Cancer Society. She received her Ph.D. in community systems planning and development from Penn State University in 1992.

title: Broadway Success Has a Price: $2,500
description: Jonathan Reinis didnt make any producing decisions on the Broadway musical Pippin, but he put $125,000 into the $8.5 million show, enough to receive a prominent producers credit. Yet after Pippin won the Tony Award for best musical revival last month, Mr. Reinis was invited to pay more  $2,500 in return for his very own Tony.

title: Making of a Film to Memorialize the Fallen
description: The year was 2010. Like so many Marines before me, I faced a nagging question: How would I react in combat? I wanted to know, and there was only one way to find out: I joined a unit heading to Afghanistan, the Third Battalion, Fifth Marine Regiment, the Darkhorse battalion, as a scout sniper.

title: Progress, but No Agreement, in Bay Area Transit Talks
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Negotiations over a new contract between the San Francisco Bay Areas main commuter railroad and striking workers ended without an agreement early Wednesday morning as train service remained stalled for a third day.

title: Countdown to Ouster in Egypt
description: A timeline of four critical days in Egypt as massive street protests on Sunday kicked off a chain of events culminating in the army ousting Egypt's president.

title: China Says Foreign Makers of Baby Formula May Be Fixing Prices
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government is investigating possible price fixing by foreign companies that produce infant milk powder for Chinese consumers, according to reports this week by the state news media.

title: Cross-Country, by a Road Less Traveled
description: Hidden amid the flash of 42nd Street in Manhattan, like a tarnished penny on the floor of a nightclub, is a small brown sign bearing the words Lincoln Highway. To those who notice it at all, its a random curiosity, a beacon without context. It betrays no indication that it points the way to a road that once stretched across the continent, one that traced the trails forged by early pioneers and augured the future of car travel in this country.

title: A Philadelphia Street, Transformed
description: On South 13th Street, check-cashing joints have been replaced by hot restaurants and chic shops.

title: Driving the Lincoln Highway
description: A trip on the road once called Main Street Across America.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: The Origin of Google Docs, and Spying on Your Own E-Mail
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: The Employer Mandate Has Been Delayed. Will It Be Rewritten?
description: It seems that almost nobody was ready for the employer mandate in the Affordable Care Act to take effect  not government regulators, not the managers of health insurance exchanges, and not the employers  and that a years delay could buy time for the government to write regulations and for companies to figure out how to comply with them. But many businesses hope to get something else from the one-year delay: an opportunity to rewrite other aspects of the mandate that they find difficult.

title: A Chance for Oversight on Civil Liberties
description: On May 29, after a years delay by Senate Republicans, David Medine was sworn in as chairman of the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. Exactly one week later, the Guardian published a secret order from the Federal Intelligence Surveillance Court, showing that the government was collecting the phone records of most Americans.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Indonesia, Austria and South Africa.

title: Wimbledon Womens Semifinals Preview
description: WIMBLEDON, England  This is the first time that the semifinals of a Grand Slam event are without a Spanish man, an American woman or a Russian woman since Wimbledon 1998.

title: This Week's Movies: July 5, 2013
description: The New York Times film critics on Despicable Me 2, The Lone Ranger and The Way, Way Back.

title: Lawyer Seeks Confidentiality for a Relative of Bin Laden
description: The lawyer for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law to Osama bin Laden who is awaiting trial in Manhattan on a charge of conspiring to kill Americans, asked a federal judge on Wednesday to bar the government from any kind of monitoring of the defenses phone calls, e-mail or other communications.

title: Shopping for Fans
description: The hotelier Carlos Couturier goes looking for fans as the temperature in New York City creeps up to 90 degrees.

title: Fans: Breezy Does It
description: Carlos Couturier arrived at the first stop on his shopping trip on a bicycle, although the temperature in New York City was well over 90 degrees.

title: Sales at Vermont Woods Studio, Nancy Koltes and Others
description: Vermont Woods Studios is discounting most furniture by 20 percent, through July 9, with free shipping (the Vermont Shaker Moon bed in queen, usually $1,974, is about $1,579); (888) 390-5571, vermontwoodsstudios.com.

title: An Eames Chair Returns to Its Roots
description: The classic molded plastic chair designed in 1949 by Charles and Ray Eames was originally made of fiberglass. It was manufactured by Herman Miller for 40 years, until growing awareness of the materials health hazards led the company to halt production. A safer polypropylene version was released in 2000, but it lacked the threaded, almost wood-like, appearance that appealed to the original buyers. Last month, at the NeoCon furniture fair in Chicago, the chair was reintroduced in fiberglass, but now the material emits no harmful gases or particles and is fully recyclable, representatives of Herman Miller said. The new version is offered in its nine original colors, in armchair and side chair versions, with a variety of bases. It will be available in September and will cost from $399 to $628. Information: hermanmiller.com.

title: A Crib to Remember
description: When Sophie Demenge and Michael Ryan, furniture designers, found out that they were about to be parents, they began searching for a crib but were disappointed with what was available. There was nothing modern or simple, and most had awful drop-side rails, which Michael rightly refused to buy, Ms. Demenge said. So they designed their own. Oeuf, the couples furniture company for children, is now 10 years old and has just introduced Elephant, a crib created with Carlos Tscar, a Spanish designer. Elephant takes 10 minutes to assemble and requires only a screwdriver. Like all Oeuf cribs, it can be transformed into a toddler bed (a conversion kit, sold separately, will be available in a few months). The material is medium-density fiberboard with a water-based nontoxic finish. Available in white or gray, it measures 57 by 33.75 by 34.75 inches and costs $675. Information: (718) 965-1216 or oeufnyc.com.

title: Ceramic Table Lamps and Pendants Designed From the Bottom Up
description: Friends for more than a decade, Frances Palmer, a ceramic artist, and Chad Jacobs, a lighting designer, never thought to collaborate until one of Ms. Palmers clients asked her to design a lamp. She asked Mr. Jacobs, whose company is called Bone Simple Design, for help with the shade and wiring. Three years later, the pair has developed a collection of 16 table lamps and 10 pendants, all one of a kind. Ms. Palmer made the bases, some inspired by Korean ceramics, others by Alberto Giacomettis lamps for Jean-Michel Frank, and Mr. Jacobs decided on appropriate shades. He explored different materials, including elastic banding and rope, and even hand-painted stylized dahlias on one, inspired by Ms. Palmers garden. He gave me free rein, and I did the same, Ms. Palmer said. Pendant lamps start at $1,200; table lamps range from $1,800 to $3,800. Information: (212) 627-0876.

title: Sleep Studio Opens in SoHo
description: Sleep Studio, an emporium for slumber, opens in SoHo on Monday. The 3,700-square-foot store offers apothecary items, teas, loungewear and everything needed to dress a bed. But the star is a proprietary sleep system, developed with the German manufacturer Froli, that can be added to your existing bed or custom-ordered with one of the beds the shop sells. The system features plastic springs that look like pods, which can be adjusted to provide different degrees of resistance. The pods move laterally as well as up and down, so we can customize the support level for different zones of your body, and on each side of the bed, said Michael Rothbard, Sleep Studios president. The Froli system starts at $2,000; other items range from an $18 essential oil blend by the Aromatherapy Company to a $33,000 walnut dresser by Chi Wing Lo for Giorgetti; 73 Wooster Street (Spring Street), (212) 756-1280, sleepstudio.com.

title: Nobody Pays Any Attention To What I Say
description: Or thats what people keep telling me. Actually, one of the odd but revealing things about modern conservatives is the way they alternate between paranoia about the vast left-wing conspiracy and insistence that people who disagree with them are part of a tiny fringe with no real following. Joe Scarborough thinks (or thought  has he updated?) that I was all alone in questioning deficit panic; the fairly large anti-me industry has been insisting for around a decade that Ive lost all credibility except among credulous New York liberals.

title: The Gnome Home
description: A quirky 1929 home left clues as to its designer, a master of detail.

title: How to Restore a Mystery House
description: Lucia and James Case were living in the affluent Buckhead district of Atlanta and watching their children depart from their square, stolid house, when they decided they needed a home that better suited their personalities.

title: How Should I Decorate a Small Bedroom for Showings?
description: Q. One of our bedrooms is so small theres barely enough space for a queen bed. How should I decorate it for showings? Is it better to get rid of the night stands and lamps, or will the room look worse without them?

title: Excerpt: 'Drunk History'
description: Jack Black portraying Elvis Presley in this new Comedy Central series, which features re-enactments of drunken historical narratives.

title: The Potato Chip of Pets
description: Llama owners say its impossible to stop at one or two.

title: The Llama Is In
description: People who keep llamas as pets will readily offer you any number of reasons: llamas are quiet, theyre gentle and affectionate, they dont take a lot of work to maintain and, for outdoor animals, they dont smell bad.

title: Name These Baby Llamas
description: These three crias, or baby llamas, do not have names yet, but you can help. Their owner, Richard Snyder of Snyder Quality Llamas in Milford, Pa., opens his barns to the public on the last Sunday in July and holds a naming contest, inviting visitors to pick names for his babies. This years open barn day will be on July 28th from 1-5 p.m., but if you cannot make it, feel free to submit suggestions here.

title: Astrotowers Swaying Above Raises Doubts on Holiday Business Below
description: Nostalgia often comes in the form of a memory  real, faded or invented from lore.

title: Mother Daughter Me: A Feel-Good Experiment That Wasnt
description: In 2009, fascinated with multigenerational living and still nursing childhood wounds, Katie Hafner invited her elderly mother to move with her and her teenage daughter, Zo, into a large San Francisco house. Brilliant and funny, Helen, as her daughter calls her to protect her privacy, had also been a divorced alcoholic who lost custody of Ms. Hafner and her older sister. History was not magically forgotten through sharing an address again. (At the time Ms. Hafner was 51; her mother, 77; her daughter, 15.)

title: Unprecedented Globalization
description: A couple of weeks ago I posted a chart showing the long-term trend of world trade in manufactures relative to world production. The paper I took the chart from, however, only went up to 2000. And I decided to update it for the next edition of Krugman Obstfeld Melitz. And its pretty striking:

title: Rich Payday for New Zynga Chief
description: There is nothing virtual about the currency that Zyngas new chief executive, Don A. Mattrick, will get for taking the helm of the troubled social games company.

title: Stricter Rules for Abortion Clinics Are Approved by State Senate in North Carolina
description: The North Carolina Senate approved new limits on abortions Wednesday, defying opponents who complained that the Republican majority breached protocol by passing the restrictions less than 24 hours after their surprise introduction.

title: Paris Couture Fashion Week: Maison Martin Margiela Fall 2013
description: Scenes from the couture fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: Photographers Lens: Obama in Africa
description: The Timess Doug Mills examines a few key moments that occurred while following President Obama on his seven-day tour of Africa.

title: Ergonomic Tools That Prune Away Gardening Pains
description: A decade ago, my wife and I built an absurdly ambitious garden that involved homemade fencing, a bamboo-and-string trellis for the beans and, for me, about 10 backbreaking hours behind a tiller.

title: Paul Smith, Jazz Pianist, Is Dead at 91
description: Paul Smith, a jazz pianist who accompanied singers like Bing Crosby, Doris Day, Sammy Davis Jr. and Rosemary Clooney but who was best known for his long association, both on record and on concert stages worldwide, with Ella Fitzgerald, died on Saturday in Torrance, Calif. He was 91.

title: Murray Can Curse on His Own, Thank You Very Much
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Andy Murray curses frequently and creatively enough on his own to lift the eyebrows of anyone watching his matches.

title: Legislators Reap Benefits of Part-Time Jobs at Law Firms, Filings Show
description: Some of the most influential members of the State Legislature earn large paychecks from part-time jobs with law firms, according to financial disclosure filings released on Wednesday under a new state ethics law that requires legislators to reveal their outside income.

title: O Say, Can You Sing at the Ballpark? Its a Tough Song
description: It is a notoriously difficult song to sing, a musical high-wire act, with an octave-and-a-half range and a devilishly spaced melody. You usually sing it a cappella in a stadium where the echo hits your ear a half-beat behind the melody, and the lyrics are so familiar and fraught with meaning that every fan in the stands can hear the slightest mistake or botched note.

title: Irans Next Leader Advocates a Less Intrusive State
description: Irans president-elect, Hassan Rowhani, repeated in a speech on Wednesday his promises of more freedoms for Iranians, saying the government should not interfere in peoples private lives.

title: The Mouse Inventors Vision of Computing
description: Beginning in the 1950s, when computing was in its infancy, Douglas C. Engelbart set out to show that progress in science and engineering could be greatly accelerated if researchers, working in small groups, shared computing power. He called the approach bootstrapping.

title: Jim Nayder, Specialist in Annoying Music, Dies at 59
description: Jim Nayder, whose ear for music that might set a dogs teeth on edge led him to found The Annoying Music Show on public radio, died on June 27 at his home in Chicago. He was 59.

title: State Department Urges U.S. Citizens to Leave Egypt
description: Increasingly alarmed about the violent Egyptian political upheaval, the United States sharply raised the threat level in its travel advisory to Egypt on Wednesday, warning citizens to defer visits and advising American residents there to leave.

title: 3 Long Terms of Hot Dogs, Groundhogs and Corny Puns for Bloomberg
description: For 12 years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has endured more than his share of corny, obligatory appearances: uttering pun upon pun about hot dogs, goading groundhogs into weather predictions, even singing show tunes as a hippie before an audience of yowling reporters.

title: A Shifting Tone for Silicon Valleys Lobby
description: When Mark Zuckerbergs new political lobby, Fwd.us, started, it drew criticism for playing Washington politics. Now its changing its tactic.

title: After a Stumble, Tech Lobby Refocuses on Immigration
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  On a recent Monday evening, in a large, warmly lighted room at a technology incubator here, guests drank pinot noir, waiters offered seared tuna, and a young man in a T-shirt and sneakers introduced himself to a gathering of tech entrepreneurs as a tech entrepreneur himself: Hi, Im Joe Green, president of Fwd.us.

title: On Tulsas Long-Shot Olympic Pitch, Mayor and Others Say Never Mind
description: Tulsas long-shot pitch to host the 2024 Olympics may be in trouble.

title: Red Bulls and Juninho Part Ways
description: As the Red Bulls trained at their stadium in Harrison, N.J., on Wednesday, preparing to travel for Thursdays match at the Colorado Rapids, the club admitted failure when it said it had parted ways with its highest-profile acquisition of the off-season.

title: Rift Over Austerity Plans Is Seen in Ailing Portugal
description: MADRID  Just as the financial markets had eased the pressure on Portugal and other ailing euro economies, the implosion of the coalition government in Lisbon came as an unwanted reminder of the deepening rift among European politicians over whether to continue enforcing the austerity plans urged by international lenders.

title: F.D.A. Rule Could Open Generic Drug Makers to Suits
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday signaled its intention to permit generic drug makers to make changes to their safety labels, a move that could open the door to lawsuits against generic drug companies for the first time since a Supreme Court decision barred such suits two years ago.

title: With Civil Wars Rancor Faded, Reasons to Celebrate
description: VICKSBURG, Miss.  Even when this city was known as the place that did not celebrate the Fourth of July, it was not entirely true.

title: For Brazilian Official and Family, Controversy Over a Trip
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  As crowds protesting government corruption and overspending on World Cup soccer stadiums clashed with the police outside Maracan stadium in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday, a top Brazilian legislator was inside the stadium with his fiance, family members and friends. After watching Brazils victory over Spain in the final of the Confederations Cup tournament, the congressman said on Twitter: BRASIL: national team A+! The fans too, A+! The champion is back!

title: The Humanities in Crisis? Not at Most Schools
description: It can be hard to see through the dust kicked up, periodically, by the boomlet of stories on the decline of the humanities.

title: Crisis in Egypt
description: Despite his failings, and there were plenty, President Mohamed Morsi was Egypts first democratically elected leader, and his overthrow by the military on Wednesday was unquestionably a coup. It would be tragic if Egyptians allowed the 2011 revolution that overthrew the dictator Hosni Mubarak to end with this rejection of democracy.

title: Questioning the Struggle
description: One of the most riveting moments in the George Zimmerman trial this week was the playing of a police tape that showed Zimmerman re-enacting what he said happened the night he fatally shot Trayvon Martin.

title: How Could We Blow This One?
description: I just finished a five-month leave from this column, writing a book with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, and what struck me while away from the daily fray is a paradox that doesnt seem quite patriotic enough for July Fourth.

title: The Cost of Revolution
description: Many signers of the Declaration of Independence made significant personal sacrifices for the cause.

title: The Case for Miniature Llamas
description: It sounds like a punch line: a miniature llama.

title: Letting Employers Off the Hook, for Now
description: The Obama administration made a reasonable decision this week to give employers another year before they will be required to make available affordable insurance to their workers or pay a fine. Republicans are portraying the decision as evidence that the whole health care reform is headed for a train wreck, but it actually affects only a narrow slice of companies and workers. It should have no bearing on whether the core provisions of the Affordable Care Act  notably the opening of health care exchanges and subsidized coverage for people on modest incomes  take effect on Jan. 1, 2014, as scheduled.

title: Every Ordinary Fourth
description: Here we are in the high seas of summer, rounding the corner called the Fourth of July. Most years, it seems, we barely get a glimpse of it before changing tack and sailing on toward all those months that end in ber.

title: Cardinal Dolan and the Sexual Abuse Scandal
description: Tragic as the sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church has been, it is shocking to discover that Cardinal Timothy Dolan, while archbishop of Milwaukee, moved $57 million off the archdiocesan books into a cemetery trust fund six years ago in order to protect the money from damage suits by victims of abuse by priests.

title: You Call That a Filibuster? Texas Still Claims Record
description: FORT WORTH, Tex.  State Senator Wendy Daviss exhausting filibuster of at least 11 hours at the Texas Capitol last week turned her into a national political star. Bill Meiers filibuster in the same building  on the same floor, at the same desk  36 years earlier left him with a stiff back, rubbery legs, a ragged voice and a footnote-size place in history, though few people outside Texas remember.

title: Development Project in Istanbul, Focus of Violent Protests, Is Stopped by Court
description: ISTANBUL  An Istanbul court on Wednesday halted a government-backed plan to rebuild Taksim Square, a development project that incited nearly a month of huge antigovernment protests in June.

title: Im Back From Book Leave!

But my first column after my return was written as I was traveling here, and it reflects the enormous frustration I felt on my leave as I saw political momentum on addressing guns collapse.

title: Spare Times for July 5-11
description: Swimming in the City (daily through Labor Day) If you start now, you will have just enough time before Labor Day  with a little to spare  to dip a toe each day into one of the citys 55 free outdoor public pools. Among them is the Olympic-size pool in McCarren Park, in Greenpoint-Williamsburg, Brooklyn, above, reachable from Lorimer Street. Normal operating hours for pools run by the Department of Parks and Recreation are daily, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.  with an hour break for cleaning from 3 to 4 p.m. Some pools open earlier for lap swimming or for swimming lessons for children, and at night some offer swimming lessons and water aerobics sessions for those 18 and older; for more information, nyc.gov/parks/pools.
