title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) FRIDAY NIGHT SPOTLIGHT: THE FILMS OF FRANOIS TRUFFAUT A monthlong tribute to this film critic turned director, and mainstay of the French New Wave, kicks off with four films starring Jean-Pierre Laud, Truffauts on-screen alter ego. This first installment begins with The 400 Blows (1959), above, Truffauts feature film debut, in which he drew inspiration from his childhood for a story about Antoine Doinel, a 12-year-old who escapes his dysfunctional family by turning to crime. Words cannot state simply how fine is Jean-Pierre Laud in the role of the boy, Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. Out of this brand-new youngster, M. Truffaut has elicited a performance that will live as a delightful, provoking and heartbreaking monument to a boy. The homage continues at 9:45 with Antoine and Colette, Truffauts episode from Love at Twenty (1962)  an omnibus project featuring five segments directed by five filmmakers from five countries  and a short sequel to The 400 Blows, set three years later, in which Antoine has his first sentimental adventure. In Stolen Kisses (1968), at 10:30, Antoine, fresh out of the army, looks for work and ponders an affair with an older woman. In Bed and Board (1970), at 12:15 a.m., Antoine faces up to the responsibilities of adulthood. And in Love on the Run (1979), at 2, Antoine, now divorced, continues his search for romantic fulfillment. The night ends at 4 with The Green Room (1978), based in part on The Altar of the Dead and two other stories by Henry James, in which Truffaut stars as a writer and World War I veteran who spends his life grieving the loss of his young wife.

Greece: Parliamentary Group Advises Criminal Charges for Ex-Finance Chief
description: A Greek parliamentary committee on Thursday recommended that former Finance Minister George Papaconstantinou be indicted on criminal charges over his handling of a list of more than 2,000 wealthy Greeks with Swiss bank accounts  a potential source of tax revenue that was never used by the authorities, fueling public anger in the debt-racked nation. Mr. Papaconstantinou, above, has denied accusations that he removed the names of four of his relatives from the list, known as the Lagarde list after Christine Lagarde, currently the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, who gave him a computer disk bearing the names in 2010 when she was Frances finance minister in a bid to aid Greeces efforts to fight tax evasion. But last month, Greeces financial crimes squad said it had traced more than $7.8 million in undeclared assets in the bank accounts of the four relatives. Mr. Papaconstantinou faces charges of tampering with a document, breach of faith and violation of duty after 7 of the 13 lawmakers on a cross-party panel formed in January proposed that Greeces Parliament should vote on whether to indict him.

description: First baseman Ike Daviss minor league exile appears to be over. He will rejoin his Mets teammates in Milwaukee on Friday, according to a person in baseball with knowledge of the move, and it is expected that he will be in the lineup in this weekends three-game series against the Brewers.

description: INTERNATIONAL

description: A police officer was shot and wounded Thursday night while patrolling the Cypress Hills Houses, a project in East New York, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Financing Indian Elections Turns Costlier and Murkier
description: On June 27, Gopinath Munde, deputy leader of the opposition in Lok Sabha, or lower house of Parliament, was caught complaining on camera in Mumbai that his campaign expenses for his parliamentary election in 2009 had skyrocketed to 80 million rupees ($1.3 million at current rates). This was more than 30 times the permissible limit of 2.5 million rupees at the time.

title: Bay Area Train Service Resumes With Extension of Labor Pact
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The San Francisco Bay Areas main commuter railroad resumed service on Friday afternoon after a four-day strike by transit workers, though the reprieve to its 400,000 daily riders could be short lived.

title: Mayhem in Cairo as Morsi Backers Fight for Return
description: CAIRO  Egypts bitter split over who should be ruling the country exploded into violent clashes in the streets of Cairo and elsewhere on Friday as masses of demonstrators celebrating the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi battled crowds of Islamists who wanted him reinstated.

title: Viktor & Rolf: Conceptual Couture
description: Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren celebrate 20 years of introducing their conceptual ideas to the fashion world.

title: You May Touch a Stranger
description: The photographer Richard Renaldi is a matchmaker for tense times, asking complete strangers to pose with their bodies touching, as if they were intimates. On a recent afternoon in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it was not going well. He wanted to pose an Orthodox Jewish man with someone from outside the Orthodox community.

description: Q.

title: Teenagers in The Times | June 2013
description: Welcome to another edition of Teenagers in The Times, a monthly feature we started a year ago this month as a way to collect all the news about young people in one handy spot.

title: Fatal Jabs
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  As a form of capital punishment, lethal injection has led to bungled executions in which the condemned have grimaced or groaned in apparent pain, had violent reactions to the drugs, or waited hours as executioners failed to find a vein. It is the most common way to administer capital punishment in the United States, China and, eventually, Vietnam.

title: Summer Reading Contest | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In The Times this week: The Dining sections special pie issue, with recipes, graphics, articles and how-tos.

title: With Surf Like Turf, Huge Algae Bloom Befouls China Coast
description: BEIJING  In what has become an annual summer scourge, the coastal Chinese city of Qingdao has been hit by a near-record algae bloom that has left its popular beaches fouled with a green, stringy muck.

title: U.N. Rights Official Questions Detention of Islamist Leaders in Egypt
description: GENEVA  The top human rights official at the United Nations, Navi Pillay, expressed concern on Friday at the reported detention of Muslim Brotherhood leaders in Egypt and called on military authorities there to make clear the basis on which they are being held or release them.

title: How Aspirin Might Stem Cancer
description: The use of aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs significantly reduces the risk for cancer, but no one has been able to explain why. Now researchers have found that these drugs slow the accumulation of a type of DNA change called somatic genome abnormalities, or S.G.A.s, that lead to uncontrolled cell growth.

title: Daily Report: Snowden Trained as Hacker While With N.S.A.,  Rsum Says
description: In 2010, while working for a National Security Agency contractor, Edward J. Snowden learned to be a hacker, Christopher Drew and Scott Shane report in The New York Times.

title: In Japan, Prepaid Cards Streamline Taxi Service
description: TOKYO  One of the least appetizing parts of riding in a New York taxiis fishing out my wallet to pay the driver. Either I have so many bags that it is deeply buried, or Im in an older Crown Victoria with seat cushions so worn out that my hips seem have sunk down several feet, making wallet retrieval that much more difficult.

title: This Week in Egypt
description: Egyptians contemplate the return of military rule.

title: Rediscovering Radio Through Apps
description: Growing up, the radio provided the soundtrack for doing my hair in the morning and the ride to school. It kept me company during late nights while I finished my homework and entertained during long summer road trips with my family.

title: Two Former Popes to Be Made Saints
description: VATICAN CITY  Pope Francis sped two of his predecessors toward sainthood on Friday: John Paul II, who guided the Roman Catholic Church during the end of the cold war, and John XXIII, who assembled the liberalizing Second Vatican Council in the 1960s.

title: Pope Propels John Paul II and John XXIII to Sainthood
description: VATICAN CITY  Showing more of his sprightly personality and his priorities, Pope Francis sped two of his predecessors toward sainthood on Friday: John Paul II, who guided the Roman Catholic Church during the end of the cold war, and John XXIII, who assembled the liberalizing Second Vatican Council in the 1960s.

title: Basel Report Finds Diverging Bank Views on Risk
description: LONDON  Regulators are still grappling with how best to rein in banks appetite for risk.

title: Jobs Data Is Strong, but Not Too Strong, Easing Fed Fears
description: Strong, but not too strong.

title: The Mom From The Cat in the Hat Finally Speaks
description: Every mother feels societal pressures, but few have experienced as much parenting scrutiny as the mother from The Cat in the Hat. In this interview, she tries to set things straight.

title: Friday Reading: Three Short Workouts vs. One Long One
On The Political Economy Of Permanent Stagnation
description: Ive been having a strange reaction to recent news about economic policy. Stuff is happening: the Fed bungled its communications, doing its bit to undermine modest economic progress; the European Commission is sorta kinda relaxing its demands for austerity; the Bank of England appears to have issued forward guidance that its going to issue forward guidance; and so on. But with the possible exception of Abenomics, its all pretty small-bore stuff.

title: Dont Fuel the Syrian Fire
description: Regarding Syria scorecard (Views, June 24) by Thomas L. Friedman: The last thing America should do is provide more weapons to the rebels. It would only add fuel to the fire. Instead, the U.S., Europe, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Russia and Iran should offer asylum to the refugees and stop further entry of arms into Syria.

title: Down and Out Cold in the 30s
description: Charles Bronson achieved stardom relatively late in life, after surviving a harsh childhood as one of 15 children of Polish-Lithuanian parents in the coal country of Pennsylvania, service as an aerial gunner in World War II and close to 20 years as a hard-working journeyman actor in Hollywood movies and TV shows. (Thats him, for example, as Vincent Prices evil henchman in the 3-D House of Wax from 1953.)

title: Tetra Pak Comes Under Scrutiny in China
description: SHANGHAI  Chinese officials are investigating the Swiss food packaging giant Tetra Pak for abusing its market dominance in China, the latest in a growing number of multinational companies to come under regulatory scrutiny.

title: Druids Take Manhattan
description: The rare moment of celestial alignment known as Manhattanhenge.

title: How the Other Half Lives
description: At 20, my mother had hardly been outside Brooklyn, and when she did finally leave a year later, it was only because she married a cop from Queens  which she then called the country. That cop would become my father, but by the time I was 2, they had divorced, and to make a little extra money afterward, she decided to take on a weekend job cleaning apartments.

title: 6.23.13 Issue
The Mermaids of Weeki Wachee Springs
description: In a town with a population of four, live mermaids perform three or four daily shows for an entrance fee of just $13.

title: Who Made That Scratch-Off Lottery Ticket?
description: In the 1960s, grocery stores handed out free cards covered with a waxy coating that hid a possible cash prize. To find out if youd won, you either scratched off the coating or wiped it off with a rag dipped in butter. The prizes tended to be small  as low as half a penny  but customers loved them.

title: Map or Menace?
description: In the basement of my German grandmothers farmhouse, I found a large, framed map of her homeland. It is beautifully illustrated, with drawings of churches, castles and factories, coats of arms from various cities and a quotation from Goethe. It is, however, from 1937, a date that is prominently displayed. Although the map has no Third Reich iconography, Germanys borders greatly exceed its current ones. Is it ethical to hang it in my living room? ALEX HOYT, NEW YORK

title: What Marcia Gay Harden Knows About Trophy Wives
description: Youre joining Aaron Sorkins Newsroom this season. Because Sorkin is famous for writing long speeches, I wonder if its a mixed blessing for an actor: meaty parts, but so much dialogue to learn.  When I first got the role, Jeff Daniels said: Ill give you a little Aaron Sorkin tip: Come to set with your lines down for the rehearsal. I said, What? Usually the actor learns them during the day. But as an actress, I have never had a sigh of consternation when I get something complicated. You know how it is when you feel used in a good way. Its like that old song, keep on using me, til you use me up. I just feel grateful.

title: This Is What Real-Life Mermaids Look Like
description: The performers of Weeki Wachee Springs, the last mermaid show.

title: The Last Mermaid Show
description: It was only a two-hour drive across Central Florida from Disney World to Weeki Wachee Springs, but the distance traveled was much further, from sleek theme parks, hotels with room service and package vacation deals to a rundown motel with broken Wi-Fi situated across the highway from a thrift store and a Hooters. To get there, I took State Road 50 through mile after mile of swamp and farmland, which was dotted with pawn shops looking to buy guns and gold, and billboards with photographs of babies and reminders that my heart beat 18 days from conception. Strip malls were broken up by new town-home complexes, old trailer parks and churches.

title: For the Employment Rate, an Uptick
description: The share of American adults with jobs rose slightly in June, to 58.7 percent. That matches the highest level since the end of the recession in 2009, but remains well below the prevailing level before the recession.

title: Monty Python Producer Wins Royalties in Spamalot Lawsuit
description: How many members of the Monty Python comedy troupe have there been? Think carefully before you respond, because an incorrect answer could cost you hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: South African Government Denies Mandela Was in Vegetative State
description: JOHANNESBURG  The South African government has denied a report that former President Nelson Mandela was in a permanent vegetative state in a Pretoria hospital, saying Mr. Mandela, the anti-apartheid leader, remains in critical but stable condition.

title: The Euro is No Peacemaker
description: In Europes Truths (Globalist, July 2), Roger Cohen contended that the euro must continue to maintain European peace. But Europe never needed an overarching government, let alone monetary integration, to establish peace. Switzerland and Norway have neither and remain peaceful. In forcing austerity upon the Mediterranean states and mandating that European taxpayers finance their bailouts, the E.U. has divided Europe, prompting a surge of anti-Europeanism and xenophobia. Continuing down this path will only amplify Europes social and economic crisis.

title: Developing Indias Personality
description: The personalities of Tina Nagpal, a 26-year-old banker with ICICI, and Akshay Agarwal, 18-year-old graduate of Delhi Public School seemed to have nothing in common  except, apparently, the need for urgent intervention.And thats how, on a balmy June morning, the well-turned-out woman and the goofy teenager ended up trying to make party conversation without breaking into a sweat as a roomful of peers and a patient, yet firm, instructor watched, some of them with notebook and pen.

title: Operas New Face
description: Last year, The Times spoke to the director Chen Shi-Zheng on his reinterpretation of the traditional Beijing Opera. His latest work, Monkey: Journey to the West, will open in New York this month.

title: Sexy Danes Wicked Roles
description: Dont mess with perfection: Thats the approach Mads Mikkelsen took after being cast in NBCs Hannibal as a certain gourmand cum serial killer whose taste for human flesh, accompanied by some fava beans and a nice Chianti, was immortalized by Anthony Hopkins in The Silence of the Lambs. After all, imitation isnt necessarily the sincerest form of flattery when you dont think you can outact the master.

title: Skin Cancer on the Rise in Young Women
description: On a hot July day last summer, I was lying on the beach at Coney Island with my younger brother when he noticed a dark mole on the back of my arm. You should really get that checked at the dermatologist, he said in a worried tone.

title: Cristina and the Supremes
description: BUENOS AIRES  Ask any opponent of President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner to name one good policy to have come out of the decade since Nstor Kirchner, her deceased husband and predecessor, rose to power and youll undoubtedly hear: reform of the Supreme Court.

title: Video Reviews of The Lone Ranger, Despicable Me 2 and The Way, Way Back
description: In this weeks video, Times critics look at The Lone Ranger, Despicable Me 2 and The Way, Way Back. See more of this weeks reviews here.

title: July 5: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: In Tel Aviv, Alicia Keys Performs Concert That Had Drawn Protests
description: After a performance of her song Karma with a shout to the audience of Ma koreh, Tel Aviv? (Hebrew for Whats happening, Tel Aviv?), Alicia Keys opened her July 4 concert at the Nokia Arena there, The Jerusalem Post reported. The show had drawn protests while in its planning stages but went ahead without incident  other than a cameo appearance from Ms. Keyss 2-year-old son, Egypt.

title: A Surge in Part-Time Workers
description: The June jobs report saw a surge in part-time workers, and the health care law that starts coming into full effect next year might be in part responsible. The number of part-time workers for economic reasons climbed to 8.2 million in June from 7.6 million in March.

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Replacing Detectors Comes at a Price

title: Bleaker Pastures
description: A donkey is tethered between two identical pails, each filled with the same amount and type of oats. If free will exists, the donkey will eat from one before the other. But if free will doesnt exist, the donkey  lacking any justification for its preference  will just sag in place until it starves to death. Buridans Ass became an Enlightenment joke at the expense of medieval determinism, specifically that of the French cleric Jean Buridan, whose critics reduced his philosophy to a caricature: between equivalent options, there can be no choice.

title: Interview With a Hijacker
description: The Skies Belong to Us, Brendan I. Koerners account of the epic hijacking of an airliner in 1972, is reviewed this week. One of the hijackers, Roger Holder, was a troubled Vietnam vet. Koerner told me that in recreating the story, he spoke with a galaxy of people who knew Holder. He also sat down with the subject himself.

title: Pre-Closing Credit Checks
description: Buyers waiting to close on a mortgage should avoid doing anything that might change their credit picture until after the documents are signed and the money is delivered.

title: Badfellas
description: Reviewing Edmund Wilsons Apologies to the Iroquois, W. H. Auden suggested that one of the ways in which an Intellectual Dandy can be recognized is by the unpredictability of his work. With this in mind, we can certainly. . . . But this is not how one begins a review of a Chuck Klosterman book. One begins a review of a Chuck Klosterman book like this: If Chuck Klosterman were murdered tomorrow by the lead singer of Limp Bizkit  a man he has characterized in print as rocks sleaziest baboon  then I Wear the Black Hat would be remembered as his fifth-greatest book. Better?

title: Kafkaesque
description: Kafka. K. The letter is his alone. He liked the word Zweifellosigkeit, which can be awkwardly translated as indubitableness. To be true, a work had to be indubitable. He felt his story The Judgment to be so. He wrote it in eight hours, almost in ecstasy. This is the only way to write, he said. He dedicated it to Felice Bauer, a woman he had recently met at his friend Max Brods house. In his diary he describes her as having an empty face that wore its emptiness openly. From 1912 to 1917 he wrote hundreds of letters to her. When he stopped corresponding, he dreamed of her as someone who was dead and could never live again. He burned her letters when their long engagement was finally broken off; she saved his. They are one of the great unnerving monuments of literature.

title: Clunkers
description: On a recent flight from El Paso to Austin, just before takeoff, I leaned forward to stuff my paperback copy of The Brothers Karamazov into the seat pocket. A flight attendant named Susan immediately appeared over my shoulder to scold me for placing the book there, explaining how it could dislodge during the ascent and cause injury. I removed it, pointed to the title and explained to her that if the book  granted, a hefty one  caused an injury, the wound would be spiritual rather than physical. She wasnt amused (although my seatmate was).

title: Poison, Incest, Intrigue
description: On June 29 in the jubilee year of 1500, lightning made a direct hit on Vatican City, striking the roof directly above the corrupt, scheming Spanish-born Pope Alexander VI  better known in our time as Rodrigo Borgia  while he sat on his majestic throne. The blast sent a stone fireplace on a higher floor crashing through the ceiling, leaving His Holiness engulfed by an avalanche of wood and plaster. In her evocation of this scene in Blood and Beauty, her novel about the notorious Borgias, Sarah Dunant sends papal guards rushing to save their lord, throwing themselves onto the pile, tearing at the rubble with their bare hands.

title: Theirs for the Taking
description: On June 2, 1972, a few minutes before his flight from Los Angeles was scheduled to land in Seattle, a tall, skinny black man in an Army dress uniform walked up the aisle and handed the flight attendant an index card that said he was wired to bomb the plane. Like everything else about the man, his note seemed to veer between the meticulous and the insane. He had drawn a diagram of the bomb he said he was carrying in his briefcase; it was so credible the pilots concluded he had had training in explosives. But his note seemed the product of a manic mind: Success through Death, it read, and it said that he had accomplices in the cabin from the violent radical Weatherman group, and the not-violent radical group Students for a Democratic Society. The pilots decided to comply. They asked the man where he wanted to go. North Vietnam, he said.

title: Was It Something I Said?
description: Have you heard the one about the poet who couldnt stop telling jokes, no matter how hoary, juvenile or offensive? Well, youre about to, because its the subject of The Joker, Andrew Hudginss raw and risky account of a need to laugh that can seem peculiar, immature and even socially corrosive to those who do not share it. As a memoir, the book is an odd duck in the pond of joke lit, which is populated mostly by psychologists like Freud, folklorists like Gershon Legman and cultural journalists like Jim Holt.

title: Soused
description: The essay, the guidebook, the love story, the comforting exchange of facts in a bewildering world of emotion  all are to be found in Thomas E. Kennedys Kerrigan in Copenhagen. The novels title character, Terrence Kerrigan, is an American expat whose pregnant wife packed up their 2-year-old daughter and vanished, leaving him to eke out a somewhat intellectual and definitely dipsomaniacal middle age in the archly named serving houses of Denmarks capital city. The year is 1999, and Kerrigan has been hired to write a guide to the 100 best bars in town. The result is a spiraling exploration of alcohol, history, literature, art and jazz  and Kerrigans wounded psyche.

title: Altered Ego
description: Most of us have dreams of glory, imagining those 15 minutes when everybody whos anybody knows who we are and what were famous for. Writers are particularly susceptible to this fantasy. And now that the Internet spreads the news even before it happens, our pirouette in the spotlight seems closer than ever.

title: Missing in Motown
description: If you really want to know what shape your hometown is in, just take a good look at the street you live on, trying to see it as a stranger might. Thats the simple, heartbreaking truth Lori Roy delivers, sotto voce, in UNTIL SHE COMES HOME (Dutton, $26.95), a quietly shocking account of the tiny tremors in the life of a city that warn of cataclysms to come.

title: Inside the List
description: BRIDE AND DOOM: Its wedding season, and blissed-out newlyweds face very different challenges in two newcomers to the hardcover fiction list. In Elin Hilderbrands Beautiful Day, at No. 7, the guests who descend on a perfect Nantucket Island wedding turn out to be a bunch of cynics whose own marriages have imploded or are about to. Margot wondered if all family wedding weekends were doomed to be exercises in painful self-examination, Hilderbrand writes of the maid of honor, who at 40 might be expected to know that most family occasions are exercises in painful self-examination. Oh, well. Hilderbrand has lived for two decades on Nantucket, where all 12 of her novels are set, and she understands that readers turn to her mainly for glimpses of East Coast Yankee blue-blood privilege and elitism at its very finest, which she provides in silver-plated bucket loads. Beautiful Day is her seventh consecutive best seller.

title: What Did You Do in the Dirty War?
description: In the 1970s, during the years that Argentinas last military dictatorship was busy raping, torturing and killing thousands of the countrys citizens, a large obelisk in Buenos Aires was adorned with this menacing piece of advice: Silence is health. That dictatorship ended in 1983, but no one recovers quickly from a bludgeon, especially not a child. The Argentine novelist Patricio Pron was born in 1975, a year before the Dirty War began. The nameless narrator of his artful novel My Fathers Ghost Is Climbing in the Rain isnt merely silent; hes erased.

title: Pecking Order
description: John Grays Silence of Animals is an attack on humanism. He condemns this widely accepted secular faith as a form of delusional self-flattery.

title: Paperback Row
description: FLIGHT BEHAVIOR,  by Barbara Kingsolver. (Harper Perennial, $16.99.) In the mountains of southern Appalachia, Dellarobia Turnbow, the restless farm wife at the center of Kingsolvers novel, is stopped in her tracks by a valley blazing with its own internal flame: a colony of monarch butterflies, its flight pattern thrown off by chaotic weather patterns. To religious-minded residents, the mass migration signals the divine, but entomologists see something disturbing about the state of the earth.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BILLIONAIRES APPRENTICE: The Rise of the Indian-American Elite and the Fall of the Galleon Hedge Fund,  by Anita Raghavan. (Business Plus, $29.) Indian-Americans populate every aspect of this meticulously reported true-life business thriller.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE PINK HOTEL  By Anna Stothard  Picador, paper, $15.

title: Whinny if You Miss Central Parks Horses
description: For the most part, all the pretty horses are gone, at least from the bridle paths in Central Park. They were sent to new pastures in 2007, when the Claremont Riding Academy on West 89th Street was closed. By that time the parks trails had become as rutted and stony as a Taliban route through Tora Bora. Theres often talk of bringing horses back to Central Park, but if they return, will they have a place to go?

title: NoLIta Condo Project Reborn as a Rental
description: Water leaked in and wrecked boilers. Stucco peeled. Vandals stole copper pipes.

title: Captain of Your Own Yacht (for This Weekend, Anyway)
description: TOM O. HANSEN, a marketing executive, walked into the Fort Lauderdale, Fla., boat show in 2003 and did what many boat enthusiasts do: he gawked at a dream yacht, in this case an 85-foot Azimut that cost $4.5 million.

title: In Dumbo, Town Houses in a Warehouse Zone
description: A group of town houses hidden behind a unified facade of concrete and glass in formerly industrial Dumbo has some calling the edifice a future landmark  and others saying its reminiscent of a 1970s-era office building.

title: New Yorks Beau Monde Finds Downtown
description: For a select group of New Yorkers, having dinner at Harry Cipriani on 59th Street is considered going downtown.

title: Hold the Rude Reply
description: We had dinner with another couple at an elegant restaurant. I wore a beautiful and very expensive Chanel dress. When I walked in, the woman we were meeting said, Oh, I have that same dress. She then told me she bought it at a discount store for about a thousand times less than I paid for mine. Wasnt that the most disgusting comment ever? She never compliments me and often makes nasty comments about my jewelry. (You look so sparkly!) How would you get back at her?

title: WQXR Hosts Musical Home in Harlem
description: When Terrance McKnight gets a piano  thats his goal for this year, a piano and some bookshelves  his apartment in Harlem will be perfection.

title: Book Review Podcast: Lost Girls
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Mimi Swartz reviews Robert Kolkers Lost Girls: An Unsolved American Mystery. Ms. Swartz writes:

title: The Lagging Public Sector
description: Private sector employment in the United States is growing at about the same rate it did during the best days of the last decade.

title: The Empire State Building, Now in 16 Million Colors
description: The Empire State Building threw itself a bit of a dance party on Thursday night.

title: Changing Tastes Fuel an Amenities Arms Race
description: Some amenities seem like a good idea when a building opens for sales or rentals. But times change.

title: Technology Workers Are Young (Really Young)
description: Its well known that technology is a young mans game. Still, it is surprising to see just how young (and how male).

title: Pushing for Change, Within the Bounds of Orthodoxy
description: For Blu Greenberg of the Bronx  mother of 5, grandmother of 23, founder of Orthodox Jewish feminism  June was a very good month.

title: Key Points From Fridays Jobs Report
description: The Times's Nelson D. Schwartz analyzes the latest report released on Friday, which showed better than expected job growth in June.

title: London Theater Journal: Shakespeares Liars and Lovers
description: LONDON  Iago was always a good liar. But I have never known him to be quite as credible as he is in Nicholas Hytners smashing production of Othello at the National Theater here.

title: A New Way to Make Pizza
description: This week, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman turns to a summer weekend staple, the grill, to make pizzas. She writes:

title: Image of the Day: July 5
An American Dream I Couldnt Share
description: He walked into my backyard and we fell in love. Thats the only way it could have happened: I had imprisoned myself in a bougainvillea- and lemon tree-bordered secret garden overlooking the Santa Monica Mountains, but my deck had a hole that needed patching, so he came to fix it.

title: Bosss Remark, Employees Deed and Moral Quandary
description: About 9 a.m. on Friday, Oct. 28, 2011, Jon Corzine, chief executive of MF Global and formerly a United States senator, governor of New Jersey and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, called Edith OBrien, the assistant treasurer of MF Global in Chicago, according to a complaint filed last week by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Apricots to Savor, While You Can
description: Any fruit as orange as an apricot has to be high in phytonutrients. Of all the stone fruits, apricots have the most beta carotene  three to eight times as much as nectarines and peaches. Theyre a very good source of vitamin C, and theyre high in potassium.

title: Prosecutor Urges Six-Year Term for Russian Opposition Leader
description: MOSCOW  In closing arguments on Friday, a prosecutor urged a Russian judge to convict the political opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny of embezzlement and sentence him to six years in jail  a verdict that would destroy his political career and eliminate him as a threat to President Vladimir V. Putin by imprisoning him until after the next presidential election.

title: How to Preserve the Past? Try Alcohol
description: For an inebriated storyteller, enthusiasm often outpaces execution. They have to get it out, no matter how many times they mess it up, said Derek Waters, a creator of Drunk History, beginning Tuesday on Comedy Central.

title: Dark Knight Returns Cover May Return Plenty for Auction House
description: The cover of issue No. 2 of The Dark Knight Returns will be sold next month by Heritage Auctions. Officials are estimating that it could sell for more than $500,000. The Dark Knight Returns, written and illustrated by Frank Miller, was published in 1986 and it, along with Watchmen, by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons, ushered in a new era of storytelling in comic books.

title: The Week in Pictures, July 5
description: A look back at this weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: The Wounded Lion of the Union
description: At this years sesquicentennial of the battle of Gettysburg, thousands of visitors will wander the battlefields, contemplating the terrible and magnificent events of those three days. Many will make their way to one of the most compelling spots on the battlefield, the rocky tor called Little Round Top, where they will ponder, discuss, and probably argue about the deeds of one of the battles most famous participants, Col. Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain of the 20th Maine.

title: Off the Charts: Dividends Return
description: The proportion of both large and small American companies paying dividends has been rising since the 90s, and the dividend rate for large companies has rebounded to record levels. But over the last 12 months, the number of companies reducing or eliminating their dividends has begun to rise.

title: Positive News Muddles Political Talking Points
description: Ana Navarro, a Republican strategist and commentator, had a novel thought in response to Fridays jobs report, which showed 195,000 new jobs created in June:

title: In London, an Olympic Park Is Reimagined
description: The first phase of the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park will open to the public in late July. Located in the former Olympic Park, the main site of the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games, the new 560-acre urban park in East London will include recreational and sports facilities, outdoor event spaces, art installations, attractions and ample areas to picnic and take in nature when it opens fully in 2014.

title: Dividend Payments Are Making a Modest Comeback
description: DIVIDENDS are gaining in popularity among companies, but they are still not close to being as common as they were in the 1980s, before a fascination with technology companies and potential capital gains led many investors to view dividend payers as stodgy and boring.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A four-bedroom contemporary in Greenwich and a 1930 Tudor in Garden City.

title: Pan-Cooked Chicken Scaloppine With Spiced Roasted Apricots
description: Roasted apricots go well with savory dishes like these chicken breasts, which are called scaloppine when theyre pounded thin, as they are here. When you pound meat thin like this, you can get a lot out of one piece. The scaloppine cook very quickly.

title: 2 Afghan Suicide Bombings Kill 14
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A pair of suicide bombings killed at least 14 people in southern Afghanistan on Friday, including a dozen policemen who were sitting down to lunch when a man in a police uniform set off his explosives, Afghan officials said.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A two-bedroom condo on the Upper West Side, a Greenwich Village studio in a co-op building and two-family row house in Brooklyn.

title: Photoshops New Rental Program, and the Outrage Factor
description: My review of Photoshop CC on Thursday  especially its availability only as a rental, with a monthly or yearly subscription fee  generated a lot of reader feedback. Some of it was astonishing.

title: Insecurities Loud and Clear
description: Katharine McPhees character on the ill-fated TV series Smash may not have been happy when Ana Vargas, played by Krysta Rodriguez, started to edge into the spotlight. But for some of us it was a pleasure to watch Ms. Rodriguez in some of the stronger numbers. Fans of Ms. Rodriguez, who originated the role of Wednesday Addams in the 2010 Broadway production of The Addams Family, can see her on Broadway again in First Date, a musical comedy that begins previews this week. She stars with Zachary Levi, new to Broadway but known on TV as a charming nerd in Chuck.

title: Video Shows Shooting of Protester in Egypt
description: As my colleagues Ben Hubbard, David Kirkpatrick and Mayy El-Sheikh report from Cairo, large protests in support of the ousted president Mohamed Morsi were marred by violence on Friday, when witnesses said that at least five demonstrators were killed by security forces outside the Republican Guards barracks where it is believed Mr. Morsi is being held.

title: Latin Excitement in Three Boroughs
description: Music isnt waiting for immigration reform; ideas cross borders. The annual Latin Alternative Music Conference returns this week, eclectic as ever and stretching to the Bronx, where it starts on Tuesday with a free show at 7 p.m. at Crotona Park (Claremont Parkway and Crotona Avenue) by the Brooklyn rapper Joell Ortiz and two Chilean disc jockeys, DJ Raff and Latin Bitman. Free concerts at Central Park SummerStage, midpark at 70th Street, include the rappers Fat Joe (from the Bronx), Cuarto Poder (from Venezuela) and Los Rakas (from Panama via Oakland, Calif.) on Wednesday at 6 p.m.; the Mexican trad-rocker Lila Downs on Thursday at 6 p.m.; and the Mexican pop-folk songwriters Julieta Venegas and Carla Morrison on Saturday at 3 p.m.

title: Batman Is Back, and He Bruises
description: Every generation is apparently destined to have its own Batman. Octogenarians no doubt think of the original comic book character, who first appeared in 1939. For people in their 50s, perhaps the 1966 television series starring Adam West comes to mind. Younger fans primarily know the various movies.

title: The View From Argentina
description: Latinbeat, the Film Society of Lincoln Centers annual survey of Latin American cinema, Friday through July 21, begins with La Paz, the newest movie by the Argentine director and playwright Santiago Loza, whose work is remarkable for its empathy and its attention to atmosphere. La Paz follows the gradual progress of Liso (Lisandro Rodrguez), a young upper-middle-class man, struggling to reconnect with those around him after being discharged from a mental hospital. The only people he can relate to are his familys Bolivian maid and his grandmother.

title: Where the Sounds Are Site Specific
description: The Original Music Workshop, a multidisciplinary arts organization that is building a modern performance and rehearsal facility in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is presenting concerts in its unfinished space and elsewhere in town. This week, the workshop is collaborating with the River to River Festival to produce Ex-Situ, a series of three site-specific events.

title: Casting Himself in Different Modes
description: With Paul McCarthys raucous, messy, emotionally wrenching recasting of the Snow White myth taking up lots of space at the Park Avenue Armory and his revisiting of the film Rebel Without a Cause doing the same at Hauser & Wirth in Chelsea, it is easy to forget Life Cast, his neater and quieter exhibition at the uptown Hauser & Wirth. It emphasizes a different side of his sensibility, something relatively classical against the Expressionism of the other shows.

title: City Ballet Al Fresco
description: New York City Ballet comes to the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, its lush summer home of almost five decades, for just one week this season, down from two weeks each year since 2009 and, before that, a luxurious three. Lets hope the pattern doesnt continue; the combination of these dancers, a clear night and seating on the lawn is one of the great pleasures of summer dance.

title: Sail Away, Mellow Cruisers
description: Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff assess the decline and nautical re-emergence of smooth jazz.

title: Metamorphosis, Self-Help and Lots of Trouble
description: Pretty Lights

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Aix-en-Provence, France; Virginia; and  Santa Fe, N.M.
description: Festival dAix-en-Provence, France The 65th edition of this festival, which runs through July 27, will mark two important 200th birthdays in classical music: Giuseppe Verdis, with productions of Rigoletto in a medieval palace, and that of Richard Wagner (above), with arias from Tristan und Isolde and Die Walkre performed by the Orchestre de Paris.

title: British Company Applies for Shale Gas Fracking Permit
description: LONDON  Cuadrilla Resources, a private equity-backed British oil and gas company, continues to try to find a way to produce shale gas in its home country.

title: Smooth Sailing in a Sea of Evolution
description: The Spirit of New York was making good time down the Hudson on a recent evening, approaching the southern tip of Manhattan, when the members of BWB emerged from below deck to a full-throated cheer. It was the first installment of the current Smooth Cruise season, and the applause kept going as BWB  a collaboration of the guitarist Norman Brown, the saxophonist Kirk Whalum and the trumpeter Rick Braun  played a snippet of Milestones, by Miles Davis, and then swerved into Michael Jacksons Billie Jean.

title: Yes, the Sequester Is Affecting the Job Market
description: The across-the-board automatic federal budget cuts that began in March do not seem to be derailing the recovery so far, given that the job market over all has continued to grow. And certainly some of the scariest predictions about the sequester didnt come true (partly because Congress stepped in to prevent their occurrence). But if you look closely at the data, the sequester still does seem to be affecting certain industries pretty badly.

title: The MacFarlane-Simpsons Bet
description: Perhaps no broadcast network has bet as aggressively and as successfully on animation as Fox, which for more than two decades has used it to anchor its Sunday night schedule.

title: Foxs Experiment in Animated Living
description: LOS ANGELES  You cant be totally sure which room in the rambling office space on Sunset Boulevard here might be cooking up the future of network prime-time animation, so Nick Weidenfeld does his best to be in them all.

title: Wild Salmon Is Worth the Price
description: I have come to view a meal of wild salmon as a splurge, a treat to be savored, and Im willing to pay the price. Wild salmon is a seasonal thing, available from May to October. Its not cheap, but the flavor is incredible  sweet, silky, meaty  and the vermilion color is magnificent.

title: Popcast: Sailing the Seas of Smooth
description: Attention, mellow cruisers!

title: All-American Goddesses
description: Can you have ballet without ballerinas? Yes. In the 18th century, women were the second sex in Western theater dance. Though some female stars were called queens of dance, men were known as gods.

title: Listening to a Disconnected Society
description: He sees! He sees! But what can he see? sings one of the sightless men in The Blind, an a cappella opera by the Russian-American composer Lera Auerbach opening this week at the Lincoln Center Festival.

title: Big Ticket | 14-Rooms on Park Avenue for $23 Million
description: An elegantly appointed 14-room apartment at 720 Park Avenue, one of the architectural gems to emanate from the exacting toolbox of the prolific Rosario Candela in the late 1920s, sold for $23 million and was the most expensive transaction of the week, according to city records.

title: Djokovic Outlasts Del Potro in Epic Wimbledon Semifinal
description: WIMBLEDON, England  In an age of Twitter and text messages, of instant gratification and endangered attention spans, mens tennis continues  despite all the ferocious currents to the contrary  to excel at long form.

title: Little Interest in Lone Ranger Is a Blow for Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  The train wreck was supposed to stay on-screen.

title: A Croatian Islands Day in the Sun
description: Hvar, an island in the Adriatic Sea off Croatias Dalmatian coast, is in many ways a contradiction. As a visitor, you might wake up and hike across brambly hillsides to a medieval ghost town, and by sundown be drinking infused cocktails while dancing to techno music. Its an island where opulent hotels continue to sprout up across the coastline, but the equivalent of $30 can still get you a room in the house of a local grandmother.

title: Touring Game of Thrones
description: The hit HBO series is drawing fans to Northern Ireland, where key scenes from the show are filmed.

title: Mapping Game of Thrones Sites
description: While Game of Thrones is filmed in places like Morocco, Iceland and Croatia, home base is Northern Ireland. Heres a fans guide to some publicly accessible locations north and south of Belfast, culled from details provided by the Northern Ireland Tourist Board and Northern Ireland Screen. [Related Article]

title: Following Game of Thrones to Belfast and Beyond
description: The Dark Hedges are not easy to find. You must follow a serpentine road along a bucolic stretch of Northern Ireland, past sheep, and glens and yellow fields of rapeseed until somewhere between the sleepy towns of Ballycastle and Ballymoney  if you keep your eyes peeled and your foot off the gas pedal  you spot a shadowy lane flanked by centuries-old beech trees. These are the Dark Hedges. Their sinewy branches twist toward the sky like the many arms of the Indian goddess Durga. The highest boughs stretch across the lane to the trees on the opposite side, their leaves overlapping, eclipsing the sun. Locals say this place is haunted by a solitary ghost known as the Grey Lady.

title: A Game of Chicken at Dell as a Proxy Advisers Report Looms
description: As a shareholder vote on the proposed buyout of Dell Inc. approaches, its founder, Michael S. Dell, and the investment firm Silver Lake are standing firm, not raising their $24.4 billion offer.

title: Crib Sheet: How I Work (Self-indulgent)
description: Charlie Stross  who is, sad to say, my favorite living science-fiction author now that Iain Banks has died  has been writing a series of crib sheets on his blog: explanations of how his various novels came to be written. (Have I mentioned that Neptunes Brood  which is, among other things, about interstellar monetary economics  is one of his best yet?) I, at least, find this kind of thing fascinating. And then I read Felix Salmon on the growing plague of link rot, and realized that the closest thing Ive ever done to one of Strosss crib sheets, a piece I wrote 20 years ago about my work in trade theory and posted to my long-moribund MIT web page, could all too easily vanish from human ken.

title: 2 Mothers Testify, Each Saying That Screams on the Phone Were Her Sons
description: SANFORD, Fla.  George Zimmermans mother testified on Friday that it was her son who was overheard crying for help in a 911 call made the night he fatally shot Trayvon Martin.

title: Nudity, Fake Violence and Sex Prove a Winning Combination for Park Avenue Armory
description: The Los Angeles artist Paul McCarthys WS, an NC-17 retelling of the Snow White fable at the Park Avenue Armory, has become the art institutions second-most-attended exhibition. It has drawn 11,000 visitors since its opening two weeks ago despite its adults-only admission policy, armory officials said.

title: Border Mystery, Moved to a New Border
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Demian Bichir was filming a movie in the south of France when he was offered the lead role on a new television thriller, The Bridge, now filming here. He decided to run it past his colleagues, including his co-star Jude Law. Thats when I found how great it was, said Mr. Bichir, the actor perhaps best known for his work on Weeds. They told me: Are you kidding? Its fantastic.

title: Gay Marriage Stirs Rebellion at Synagogue
description: LOS ANGELES  Sinai Temple is a Conservative Jewish congregation perched on a hill in Westwood, famous for its wealth, its sizable population of Persians, many of whom fled Iran after the fall of the shah, and a well-known and outspoken rabbi who has at times pushed his congregation on ideologically adventurous paths.

title: Generic Pain Relievers Work. So Why Do I Buy Name Brands for My Children?
description: When staring at the slew of options in the pain relief aisle, what do you take off the shelf  the Tylenol or Advil, or the cheaper (sometimes as much as three times cheaper) generic version?

title: A Scooter That Doesnt Just Putter Along
description: With great road manners and the hottest engine in its class, the high-performance BMW C 600 could be a star among maxiscooters.

title: From Lucky Encounter in Vietnam to 40 Years Married
description: Booming's "Making It Last" column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: How Regulators Can Restore Trust in Bank Capital
description: The Basel Committee just dealt another blow to the self-assessment of banking risk. This powerful group of global supervisors published new evidence on July 5 unmasking shortcomings in the models that tell lenders how much capital they need. For fans of the status quo, it makes gory reading.

title: The Artist Dustin Yellin Is on the Lookout for the Dark Side
description: When you think about the millions of strange things we have wrought over the centuries, it is a mystery why we have such inadequate forms of classification to break them all down. That thing over there that does nothing? Thats art. This thing here that does something? Design. That thing over there that has done nothing for 100 years is an antique, and this thing here that once did something but now does nothing? A found object.

title: BBC Shelves Its 3-D TV Programming Plans
description: The BBC has become the latest broadcaster to put down its 3-D glasses.

title: A Celebration of Cheese in North Carolina
description: The new Western North Carolina Cheese Trail plots out a road trip highlighting 10 artisanal and farmstead cheesemakers located across the scenic western wedge of the state.

title: Telecom Italia Seeks to Spin Off Its Landline Grid
description: Italys telecommunications regulator may decide this coming week whether to support a proposal to rescue Telecom Italia, the troubled former telephone monopoly, by allowing it to spin off a stake in its landline grid, the largest in Italy.

title: Scenes of Bloodshed in Cairo
description: Several people were killed and hundreds wounded by gunfire outside the compound in Cairo where Mohamed Morsi was believed to be detained

title: Movie Review: The Lone Ranger
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Lone Ranger."

title: From Paris Couture Fashion Week, the Shape in Things to Come
description: I LOVE THE DEBATE here on the blog about the Dior show and whether Raf Simonss haute couture collection broke contemporary ground. The comments range from bo-ring and failed experiment to accolades from longtime blog regulars Marko, E. Frantz and Augustuzs Neto, who said of Mr. Simonss efforts: This is the apex of fashion designing, true designing. The man should get a statue on the Ave. Montaigne in recognition for such extraordinary and massive achievements.

title: The Death of Photography Has Been Greatly Exaggerated
description: 10:07 p.m. | Updated to clarify the link to the black-and-white photograph from The Daily News of the 1986 Fourth of July celebrations.

title: Movie Review: 'Despicable Me 2'
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Despicable Me 2."

title: Movie Review: 'The Way, Way Back'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Way, Way Back."

title: A Life Graced With Love Letters and Notes
description: Christina Daigneault and Simon Van Booy are anomalies in a digital world: they write letters and thank-you notes; the kind that require stamps.

title: The Price of Amazon
description: The Amazon.com story is remarkable. Within living memory, bookselling was a local activity. A major city would have two or three large independent stores selling new books and other large, scruffier stores selling secondhand books. Paperbacks would receive wide if uneven circulation on bus station and drugstore racks. It was not a perfect system, but it had the advantage of being diffuse and thus hard to control. The hippie, black and womens movements of the 1960s would not have been so successful in challenging authority without the bookstores, which made their ideas widely available and sympathetic in a way that television, for instance, did not.

title: European Open Bridge Championship Winners Reveal Best Deal
description: The Sixth European Open Bridge Championships took place in Ostend, Belgium, from June 15 to 29.

title: Reading His Suspect to Sleep
description: As Endeavour begins Sunday night on PBSs Masterpiece Mystery!, we first glimpse the young Detective Constable Endeavour Morse singing in a choir. Those with the Morse bug, or the British mystery bug in general, will remember that the first episode of Inspector Morse back in 1987 began with the middle-aged detective inspectors rushing from a crime scene to a choir rehearsal. Mission accomplished.

title: Touch Screens Are Tested for Piloting Passenger Jets
description: BORDEAUX, France  As Denis Bonnet slipped into the right-hand seat of a commercial jet demonstrator in the airliner cockpit design center here at Thales, the French electronics group, his hand reached forward to tap an angled glass screen resembling an oversize iPad.

title: Chrysler Announces Worldwide Safety Equipment Recall
description: In three actions, Chrysler is recalling about 841,000 vehicles worldwide, the automaker announced late Wednesday. The recalls, which affect about 712,000 vehicles in the United States, are designed to correct problems with head restraints, side air bags and electronic stability control.

title: Talking About Sex in Mali
description: Erin Luhmann, the 2013 win-a-trip winner, writes her second blog post from southern Mali, where she spent time talking to a group of women about sex, love and female empowerment

title: Yankees Rally, but Most Welcome News Is Off Field
description: The Yankees came home Friday to open an important weekend series against a division rival, the Baltimore Orioles. But in what has become a ritual this season, the focus before the game was on rehabilitating veterans who will be in various parts of the United States this weekend, but not in the Bronx.

title: 90 Degrees + A.C. + Open Doors = Hamptons Energy Policy?
description: While in East Hampton, N.Y., to discuss Americas energy choices and issues related to the current gas-drilling blitz at a screening of the anti-fracking manifesto Gasland, Part II, I couldnt help noticing something that illustrates the mismatch between attitudes and actions on energy in this country:

title: Understating Job Growth
description: One of the many bright spots in the June jobs report was that April and May had their employment gains revised upward by a combined 70,000 jobs. In other words, job growth in those months was actually better than originally reported.

title: Starting Wedded Life With an Endless Summer
description: Unique, seasonal gift ideas.

title: Grilled Sausages and Radicchio
description: Melissa Clark adds radicchio, crisp on the inside and charred on the outside, to grilled sausages for an easy-to-make summer meal.

title: Nigella Lawson: Another Star Chef Becomes a Cause
description: LONDON  The photographs of the art dealer Charles Saatchi with his hands around the neck of his wife, the celebrity chef Nigella Lawson, look as startling now as when they were published last month. But what has happened since has been, in its way, equally unsettling.

title: A Minimalist Approach to Cooking on Vacation
description: Over a lifetime of cooking in spartan rental-house kitchens on summer trips, Ive baked pie in a skillet, shaken salad greens dry in a pillowcase and whipped cream in a (clean) coffee can. Once, when we arrived to find the stove broken, I used a charcoal grill to boil a pot of pasta because thats all we brought for dinner and the nearest supermarket was 20 miles away.

title: Sgolne Royal Is Not Willing to Be a Footnote
description: With a new book, the former French presidential candidate Sgolne Royal is trying to reverse what Le Point Magazine described as her slow descent into hell.

title: A Film Fans Love Letter to Jaws
description: 10:57 a.m. | Updated Jamie Benning may be both a movie fans greatest hero and a copyright lawyers worst nightmare.

title: The Morality of Meditation
description: MEDITATION is fast becoming a fashionable tool for improving your mind. With mounting scientific evidence that the practice can enhance creativity, memory and scores on standardized intelligence tests, interest in its practical benefits is growing. A number of mindfulness training programs, like that developed by the engineer Chade-Meng Tan at Google, and conferences like Wisdom 2.0 for business and tech leaders, promise attendees insight into how meditation can be used to augment individual performance, leadership and productivity.

title: Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Beach Cars
description: With a collection of 30 vintage automobiles, including the Rolls-Royce used in the 1960s television detective series Burkes Law, Jim Inglis can be reasonably sure he wont see another car like his when he drives from his home in Palm Beach, Fla., to the nearby Breakers resort. That wasnt the case one summer day four years ago when a Fiat 600 Jolly identical to his 1961 model  down to its coral paint color  pulled in behind him.

title: Just Add Sunscreen and a Beach Blanket
description: If youd like to cruise around a seaside community in a car with a surrey top, be prepared to spend at least $15,000, according to the CPI Value Guide. But the most desirable beach cars can cost $80,000 or more.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Indonesia, Washington, D.C., and South Africa.

title: Fun, Fun, Fun
description: Beach cars are the auto worlds head-turning, sun-loving equivalent of a two-piece bathing suit or a skimpy Speedo.

title: A Drive of a Lifetime, Nearly Ending in Mechanical Mayhem
description: Memo to the new owner of the 1954 Mercedes-Benz W196 grand prix car after the Goodwood auction: About half a century ago I was privileged to drive your new toy, and its a hoot. Just be careful about shifting gears, because the pattern is backward from what we think of as normal.

title: A Singular Mercedes Aims for Another Record
description: A 1954 Mercedes-Benz W196 grand prix car raced by the five-time world champion Juan Manuel Fangio of Argentina will go on the block Friday at the Goodwood Festival of Speed in Britain.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Cheaper Fake Followers, and Zyngas Volunteer
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Championship Pedigree
description: With breakthrough engineering and a history of competitive dominance, the 1954 Mercedes W196 grand prix car may set an auction record.

title: The Kumbaya Connection for Grown-Ups
description: Digital Detox isnt the only organization offering camp for adults, which seems to be an increasingly popular American summer pastime. Below, four retreats that bring grown-ups together, often requiring them to disconnect from technology that dominates their lives.

title: Is This BMW the Ultimate Maxiscooter?
description: Of all the head-of-the-class vehicles one might expect from the wizards at BMWs research and development works, a high-performance scooter would probably be well down the list. If it made the list at all.

title: State of Siege in Syrian City Is Blocking Humanitarian Aid, Health Officials Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian forces bombarded the city of Homs for a sixth day in a row on Friday, while government soldiers backed by Hezbollah fighters clashed with rebels on the outskirts of the citys besieged Khalidiya neighborhood amid warnings from international health officials that fighting was increasingly preventing humanitarian aid from reaching those most in need.

title: A Trip to Camp to Break a Tech Addiction
description: There was a phantom buzzing in my shorts. I had carried my iPhone in my left front pocket for so many years that my jeans have permanent rectangular fade marks over my thigh. By now the phone is almost an extension of my nervous system; even without the thing on my person, I could still feel it tingle like a missing limb.

title: Israel Sees a Chance for More Reliable Ties With Egypt and a Weakening of Hamas
description: JERUSALEM  After Mohamed Morsi, an Islamist, was elected president of Egypt a year ago, he refused any contact with Israelis, raising deep anxiety here and concern about the future of the Israel-Egypt peace treaty, a cornerstone of regional stability for decades.

title: Pyrenees Bring In Some of Tours Most Passionate Fans
description: ALBI, France  Juan Jos Oroz worked furiously in the breakaway on Friday, the ikurria, the red-green-and-white Basque flag, on the backside of his jersey shining brightly in the sun. Though he was eventually collected by the peloton in the final two miles of Stage 7, won in a sprint finish by Peter Sagan, the flag was a reminder that Oroz and his Euskaltel-Euskadi team would not be too disappointed: the 100th Tour heads into their home turf, the Pyrenees, this weekend.

title: Lifting Britains Hopes, Murray Returns to Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  After all the weirdness and wackiness at this Wimbledon, the mens final Sunday will be the one most people expected: No. 1 Novak Djokovic versus No. 2 Andy Murray.

title: A Strategic Recipe for a Summer Rental
description: In this weeks video and column, I demonstrate how to grill radicchio and sausages. Its a ridiculously easy summer meal, with minimal ingredients, that is ideal for taking on the road. The sausages come pre-seasoned and dont need any condiments, so they can be the centerpiece of a great portable dish, whether youre vacationing in a rental house or picnicking at the beach.

title: A Russian Museum Feud With Putin in the Middle
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia  The resignation this week of Irina Antonova as director of the State Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow would seem to be connected to her age. After all, Ms. Antonova, the Pushkins director since 1961 and the grande dame of the Russian museum world, is 91.

title: F.C.C. Clears Sprint Deals With SoftBank and Clearwire
description: The Federal Communications Commission on Friday cleared the way for the $21.6 billion purchase of Sprint by SoftBank of Japan. The approval ends months of posturing and uncertainty about the deal, as a rival, Dish Corp., had challenged the deal on national security grounds and tried to mount a rival takeover bid.

title: A Nation of Wineries
description: Comparing different regions of the United States wine industry over time.

title: Battle Continues in a Documentary Sequel on the Perils of Fracking
description: Muckraking documentaries dont often spawn sequels, but a lot has happened in the world of hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, since Josh Fox released Gasland in 2010.

title: Bill Cunningham | Full Salute
description: From parties to fireworks over the Hudson, New York is red, white and blue.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: A weight-loss drug copes with sluggish sales, Greece works for its next batch of bailout aid, and Europes Parliament approves an emissions trading plan.

title: Preservation Hall Jazz Bands Goal: Keep History and Make It
description: At the recent Bonnaroo festival in Manchester, Tenn., the Preservation Hall Jazz Band ran a musical marathon.

title: Staten Island Man, 55, Is Killed by a Falling 15-Foot Pipe
description: A 55-year-old man was killed in a construction accident Friday morning on Governors Island, the police said. The worker, Abbas Behnam-Bakhsh of Staten Island, died after a 15-foot length of pipe fell from a forklift as it was being unloaded from a truck, the authorities said. The pipe was to be used for a storm sewer. The accident occurred at 8:26 a.m. on the southern portion of the island.

title: Tale of Glorious Art and Not So Glorious Thieves
description: PERUGIA, Italy  As tomb heists go, it was an odd job.

title: 6 Smartphones to Rival Apple in China
description: More and more phones are being designed for consumers in emerging markets, who are expected to account for most of the growth in smartphone sales in the coming years.

title: Using E-Mail Data to Connect the Dots of Your Life
description: The Obama administration for over two years allowed the National Security Agency to collect enormous amounts of metadata on e-mail usage by Americans, according to one of the latest leaks of government documents by the now-famous whistle-blower Edward J. Snowden.

title: The Week in Pictures, July 5
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Staten Island Ferry parties, the reopening of the Statue of Liberty and bits from the Weiner campaign.

title: That Ballroom Under the Stars
description: It was supposed to be a summer fling. In 1989 Lincoln Center celebrated its 30th birthday by staging a big-band dance party on the plaza for 20 nights. (There wasnt enough money for 30 nights.)

title: China Taps a Growing Phone Market
description: Last year, when China quietly passed the United States as the largest smartphone market, the dynamics of global phone making shifted.

title: Implications for Monetary Policy
description: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland, and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

title: Dancing the Night Away
description: Lincoln Center's Midsummer Night Swing celebrates its 25th anniversary season.

title: Friday Night Music: First Aid Kit Covers Patti Smith
description: My process for getting into a band I didnt know before always seems to involve a gateway performance  something that clicks with me, and leads me on to the rest of their work. The gateway performance doesnt necessarily remain my favorite; Arcade Fire doing Haiti at the Reading Festival was crucial to my getting the band, but these days its only one of dozens of their performances I watch over and over.

title: Social Media Updates on Clashes in Cairo
description: Chaotic clashes broke out on Friday night between supporters and opponents of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, in a riverside neighborhood of downtown Cairo near Tahrir Square, drawing thousands of people into the streets and shutting down a major bridge spanning the Nile.

title: Judge to Hear Accusations Against Police by an Inmate
description: A Brooklyn man who has been in prison for 25 years for two murders he says he did not commit has been granted a hearing by a judge to review new evidence and to determine whether a detective had manufactured a confession.

title: Venezuela Offers Asylum to Snowden
description: President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela said Friday that he would offer asylum to the fugitive intelligence contractor Edward J. Snowden, who has been stranded in a Moscow airport searching for a safe haven.

title: Venturing Way Beyond Burritos
description: Just a few years back it was a struggle to find good Mexican food in Westchester County. Today, while the cuisine still is not ubiquitous, there are strong choices  from takeout taquerias to casual family restaurants to sophisticated spots that go way beyond enchiladas and burritos.

title: A Thief Tells How He Steals, and Where He Likes to Eat
description: The end came outside a chicken-wing joint in the Bronx in late May. Cory Christopher, waiting for his order, looked out to see a van filled with plainclothes passengers looking right back.

title: Taylor Townsend Makes Girls Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Stepping back into the junior ranks has allowed Taylor Townsend to make some significant progress.

title: A Vibrant Spot for Mexican Fare
description: Milagro Caf sits in the heart of Stonington Borough, its bold turquoise exterior standing out amid the stately white buildings of Water Street, promising a vibrant alternative to Yankee fare. Inside, half-timbered beams are set in rough-plastered walls painted Halloween orange; mirrors struggle to amplify a truly tiny space. At the bar, we drank margaritas made with homemade tequila infusions ranging from hibiscus to habanero to beet, poured from shakers fashioned out of Kahlua bottles.

title: A Great Vintage for Merlot Grapes
description: Long Islands terrific 2010 vintage helps make the argument that merlot, in single-variety wines or dominant in red blends, should be accepted as the regions signature red grape.

title: Text of Navalnys Closing Remarks in Russian Court
description: MOSCOW  Aleksei A. Navalny, Russias most prominent political opposition leader, delivered an emotional speech on Friday in response to a prosecutors closing arguments demanding that Mr. Navalny be convicted on embezzlement charges and sentenced to six years in prison. A co-defendant, Pyotr Ofitserov, faced a five-year sentence. With the court proceedings in Kirov, a regional capital, streamed live on the Internet, Mr. Navalny delivered a rhetorical broadside against the Kremlin, in which he said his opposition work would not stop, and sought to rally public support. I cannot run away from myself, he said. I have nothing else but this. The judge said a verdict would be issued on July 18.

title: Watching a Drama Play Out in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Seafood Leads the Way
description: Theres a lot of experience behind Madison and Main, which opened in Sag Harbor in April. Michael Gluckman, an owner, has opened and later sold a number of East Hampton restaurants: Bamboo, the Lodge and the Boathouse (all since closed). His partner, Eric Miller, who is also the executive chef, has an impressive rsum that includes City Cafe in Manhattan and Cavo in Queens. Helping out in the kitchen this season is Keith Rennie, who once cooked at Pisces and at Mad Fish, also in Manhattan.

title: On Feeling the Distress of the Unemployed
description: To the Editor:
