description: To the Editor:

title: A Bees Prickly Dream
description: The flowers of the prickly pear cactus (Opuntia humifusa) are evolutions answer to a bees dreams. They are filled with pollen, abundant in season, and easy to locate. For humans, they are also stunningly beautiful, if ephemeral. Each satiny yellow bloom lasts about a day, opening broadly in the first hours of the morning when temperatures are still relatively cool, and closing again as the sun sets. A good-sized plant displays up to a dozen two-inch flowers every day from mid-June through early July in and around New York City.

title: Nazi-Looted Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Pizza, Pasta and Room to Dance
description: Porta, the Neapolitan pizza restaurant and dance club in Asbury Park, is a good time. The real surprise is that you can eat well at Porta: Even its non-pizza dishes are better than those at more celebrated and expensive restaurants in the area.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: The High-Water Mark of the Confederacy
description: After two days of indecisive conflict, the Union Army sealed its victory at Gettysburg on July 3, 1863, by repulsing a Confederate attack over nearly a mile of open ground, directed at the center of the federal defense. The attack involved 13,000 soldiers from five states under the command of Gen. James Longstreet, but lives historically as Picketts Charge. The attack is one of the most infamous in military history, yet most people know little about it. What happened, exactly, on that afternoon in July?

title: Shifting Stance to Back Immigration Overhaul, Reid Reaps Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Harry Reid was as outspoken on the need for new immigration laws 20 years ago as he is today. But his viewpoint was markedly different.

title: 1980s Child Sex Case Is a Cause He Cannot Drop
description: If someone ever decided to make a documentary entitled Capturing the Jareckis, the family in question would look a lot more like a 1970s version of J. D. Salingers Glass family than the Friedmans. It would feature a brainy group of serial overachievers, a commitment to film and social justice and a politically engaged soundtrack by Pete Seeger, Bob Dylan and Phil Ochs.

title: With Coach Gone, Butler Seeks One Just Like Him
description: Four months after reaching the Round of 8 in the N.C.A.A. tournament, in July 1999, Gonzaga found itself scrambling to replace the coach who led them into college basketball relevancy, when Minnesota hired away Dan Monson.

title: How One Months Jobless Fare a Month Later
description: Fridays jobs report was good, but its worth remembering that people already unemployed are still having a terrible time finding work. This is particularly evident from the Labor Departments flows data, which track the labor force status of individuals from one month to the next. Heres a chart showing the flows for unemployed workers  that is, if a worker was unemployed last month, what is his or her labor status this month?

title: Learning What to Say in a Second Language
description: Some dread having to produce an authentic-sounding buenas noches before crowds in East Harlem. Others take pride in belting out flawless renditions of La Borinquea, Puerto Ricos official anthem, at parades.

title: A Tornado of Issues in a Kansas Biology Class
description: It is plain a cataclysm has occurred outside the makeshift classroom in Catherine Trieschmanns recent play How the World Began at the Penguin Rep Theater. Exposed flooring and splintering posts frame James J. Fentons troubling set with allusions to devastation, and the back windows look out on a blasted tree amid an incongruous stand of grain.

title: In Okinawa, Talk of Break From Japan Turns Serious
description: NAHA, Japan  In a windowless room in a corner of a bustling market where stalls displayed severed pigs heads and bolts of kimono silk, Okinawans gathered to learn about a political idea that until recently few had dared to take seriously: declaring their island chains political independence from Japan.

title: The Legacy of the Boomer Boss
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  OVER the next decade millions of business owners born during the baby boom will retire. Many, with no obvious succession strategy, will simply sell their companies, the backbone of Main Street economies across the country, to large corporations. All too often the result will be consolidations, plant closures and lost jobs for the people who helped build and sustain their companies for decades.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Weiners Surprising Rebound From Scandal
description: Angela Curtis, 47, a former prison officer, was angry when she heard that Anthony D. Weiner would be speaking at her daughters high school graduation in Queens. As a congressman, he had lied to the public and embarrassed his family, she thought. What more did he have to say?

title: Lincolns Surveillance State
description: COLCHESTER, Vt.  BY leaking details of the National Security Agencys data-mining program, Edward J. Snowden revealed that the governments surveillance efforts were far more extensive than previously understood. Many commentators have deemed the governments activities alarming and unprecedented. The N.S.A.s program is indeed alarming  but not, from a historical perspective, unprecedented. And history suggests that we should worry less about the surveillance itself and more about when the war in whose name the surveillance is being conducted will end.

title: The Plaza Hotel Goes Into Hiding for a Face-Lift
description: Angeline Blom biked to the southern half of Grand Army Plaza, between West 58th Street and Central Park South in Manhattan, and pulled out her camera. She snapped the Apple store across Fifth Avenue but not the Plaza Hotel, even though it was right in front of her.

title: Missile Defense Interceptor Misses Target in Test
description: WASHINGTON  A test launching of an advanced missile-defense interceptor failed to hit its target high over the Pacific Ocean, the Pentagon said on Friday, four months after the Obama administration announced that it would spend $1 billion to increase the number of interceptors along the West Coast in response to verbal threats from North Korea.

title: The Undying Influence of Ancient Egypt
description: YOU WILL NOT FIND RECENT EXAMPLES of Egyptomania  the Bangles Walk Like an Egyptian, say, or the street-dance known as Tutting  in the Echoes of Egypt exhibition at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History. But the long reach of Egyptian civilization comes through nonetheless, in nearly 100 fascinating and diverse objects documenting both the culture of ancient Egypt and the way it has reverberated in the West and in Islam through the ages.

title: Obamas Remarks Offer Hope to Opponents of Oil Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The political ground may be shifting under the Keystone XL pipeline.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: In Australia, Misogyny Lives On
description: SYDNEY

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Kinder, Gentler Way to Thin the Deer Herd
description: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  When Mayor Peter Swiderski took office, he vowed to fulfill a campaign promise to do something about the deer, which are seemingly everywhere in this Hudson River village.

title: Lets Make a Deal
description: At this point in the long holiday weekend, Im ready to kick back and discuss immigration reform. Its a very important issue. Plus, I have found it difficult to keep a dinner party conversation going with the farm bill.

title: Womens Final Is Appropriate Conclusion to Illogical Tournament
description: WIMBLEDON, England  A pair of unlikely hands will hoist perhaps the most coveted prize in womens tennis Saturday, when one of the most unpredictable Wimbledon tournaments in memory culminates with a final between No. 15 Marion Bartoli of France and No. 23 Sabine Lisicki of Germany.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 5, 2013

title: The C.I.A. and the N.Y.P.D.
description: A newly disclosed report by the C.I.A. inspector general about the agencys relationship with the New York Police Department after Sept. 11, 2001, deepens concerns about the dangers to civil liberties posed by domestic spying. The inspector general concludes that the agency did not break a federal law barring it from domestic spying. The report also shows, however, that agency officers who were embedded in the Police Department after Sept. 11 were poorly supervised, suggesting that no one at the agency knew fully what they were doing.

title: A Green, Rustic Setting for Shakespeare
description: ALL THE RAINY WEATHER of late has made for lush greenery surrounding the Greek Theater at the College of St. Elizabeth in Morris Township, where the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey is offering an agreeable outdoor production of As You Like It. (And the mosquitoes on a recent night were out in force.)

title: Designing Dashboards With Fewer Distractions
description: DETROIT  The engineers working on Hondas new Acura MDX luxury sport utility vehicle were obsessed with giving customers more  more space in the rear seat, more fuel economy from a high-tech engine, and above, all, more apps, maps and connectivity.

title: Sabotage at the Election Commission
description: The Federal Election Commission is already in a state of wretched dysfunction, but it will only get worse if Republican members succeed in crippling the agency further when the commission meets on Thursday. The three Republicans on the commission appear ready to take advantage of a temporary vacancy on the three-member Democratic side to push through 3-to-2 votes for a wholesale retreat from existing regulations.

title: After Ruling, States Rush to Enact Voting Laws
description: State officials across the South are aggressively moving ahead with new laws requiring voters to show photo identification at the polls after the Supreme Court decision striking down a portion of the Voting Rights Act.

title: Dont Punish Student Borrowers
description: With the student debt crisis already hurting the economy and hobbling the young, the last thing the country needs is a federal policy that makes college even more costly. But thats what the country got earlier this week when Congress allowed the interest rate on the subsidized federal loans to double from 3.4 percent to 6.8 percent.

title: A Naughty Squirrel, and Other Puppet Mischief
description: ASKED TO NAME a few highlights of the Puppets Take Long Island festival, starting tomorrow and running through Aug. 31, Liz Joyce, founder of Goat on a Boat Puppet Theater in Sag Harbor, put a performance by the Boston puppeteer Bonnie Duncan near the top of her list.

title: Titanium Fills Vital Role for Boeing and Russia
description: VERKHNAYA SALDA, Russia  Boeing needs to make its airliners lighter, and for that it needs titanium. And for that lightweight and strong metal, the American aircraft maker comes to this small city in the Ural Mountains.

title: Davis Shows Off Swing in Rousing Mets Win
description: MILWAUKEE  The Mets clubhouse felt like a changed place  less colorful, perhaps a tad quieter  after Ike Davis was sent to Class AAA a month ago to disentangle his swing and unclutter his head.

title: Homes Keep Rising in West Despite Growing Wildfire Threat
description: The death of 19 firefighters in Arizona this week highlights what has become a fact of life in the West: Every summer, smoke fills the big skies yet people continue to build in the places that burn most. More people live in these areas, and many balk at controls on how and where to build.

title: Reining In the Regulators
description: For all its rabid partisanship, Congress has shown time and again that it is willing to come together to deregulate corporate America. The latest example is a new bill in the Senate that would effectively end the independence of independent regulatory agencies, including the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the Consumer Product Safety Commission and the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Chile: Rape Ignites Abortion Debate
description: The case of a pregnant 11-year-old girl who was raped has set off a national debate about abortion in one of the most socially conservative countries in Latin America. State television reported that the girl, known only as Belen, is 14 weeks pregnant. Police arrested her mothers partner, who confessed to abusing the fifth grader. Doctors say her life and that of the fetus are at high risk. But ending the pregnancy is not an option. Chile allowed abortions for medical reasons until they were outlawed in 1973 by the Pinochet dictatorship. The current government of President Sebastin Piera has opposed any loosening of the prohibition. Many Chileans were venting outrage about the case on social media on Friday. (AP)

title: Howard Joining Rockets After Rejecting the Lakers
description: Dwight Howard soared into Los Angeles last summer as a flawed but celebrated savior, a smiling, muscle-bound, mischievous superstar who could dominate the court and carry the Lakers into another glorious era.

title: Mapping Protests in Cairo
description: Thousands have taken to the streets of Cairo to protest or support deposed President Mohamed Morsi.

title: Davis, Drafted by Yankees, Breaks Out With Orioles
description: There were 1,498 players picked in the 2004 amateur draft. The 1,496th was a high school slugger from Longview, Tex., named Chris Davis. The Yankees used their 50th-round choice that summer on Davis, just in case he changed his mind about attending the University of Texas.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 6, 2013
description: We will bring him back bearing him on our necks, sacrifice our souls for him.

title: Where Mandela Kept Hope, Guide Tells Their Shared Saga
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa  As Ahmed Kathrada led President Obama and his family recently through the prison on Robben Island where Mr. Kathrada had spent much of his life, he explained how the rules of apartheid had granted him, because of his Indian ancestry, long pants and socks. One of his fellow inmates, Nelson Mandela, as a black man, received short pants and no socks.

title: For Mets Draft Class, Dreams Didnt Last Long in Minors
description: A year ago, with the sun high in the sky and the air thick with heat, Michael Moras led a group of young players across a weed-dotted Little League diamond adjacent to a noisy day care center in Easton, Conn. His shoulder blades protruded through the back of his old Mets T-shirt as he gripped a baseball in his meaty right hand and watched his players dart across the outfield grass.

title: In Oregon, a Demand for Safety, but Not on Their Dime
description: GRANTS PASS, Ore.  It might be well established by now that money cannot buy happiness. But can it buy public safety?

title: Bodies of 2 Jet Ski Riders Are Found at a Marina
description: Two people, missing since they fell into the water while riding a Jet Ski during Fourth of July celebrations, were found dead at a nearby marina on Friday, the police said.

title: Egyptian Protests Explode Into Violence
description: Islamist supporters of Egypts ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, engaged in sometimes deadly clashes on Friday with security forces and anti-Morsi demonstrators.

title: Corrections: July 6, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Intro to Chemistry
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Its hard to build quad stacks. Its hard to stack any words or phrases in a puzzle grid, come to think of it. I dont think thats a secret, but if youve never thought about it, lets talk about it now.

title: Flurry of Moves Opens N.H.L. Free Agency
description: A lower salary cap for N.H.L. teams did not hamper the usual flurry of summer free-agent spending.

title: The Spirit of Surfing, Caught on Camera
description: Early one March morning in 2007, John Beattie woke to discover that his right arm and leg were numb. When his wife asked what was wrong, he told her, I think Im having a stroke.

title: Knicks Lose Copeland to Pacers
description: Chris Copeland, who became a valuable reserve for the Knicks last season, agreed to a two-year, $6 million deal with the Indiana Pacers on Friday.

title: Egypt Crisis Finds Washington Largely Ambivalent and Aloof
description: WASHINGTON  In polo shirt, shorts and sandals, President Obama headed to the golf course Friday morning with a couple of old friends, then flew to Camp David for a long weekend. Secretary of State John Kerry was relaxing at his vacation home in Nantucket.

title: Former Mets Pitchers Facing Off in Toronto
description: MINNEAPOLIS  When R. A. Dickey blew a tire on his bicycle at 7:30 one morning in spring training, the person he called to rescue him was Mike Pelfrey. When Pelfrey was out to prove that he could kick a 50-yard field goal in Port St. Lucie, Fla., the same year, the person he took along to verify the result and share in the fun was Dickey.

title: In One Quick Game, Murray Changes Pace of a Match
description: Jerzy Janowicz was feeling it. After breaking Andy Murray early in the third set of their Wimbledon semifinal Friday, he held serve with authority, thumping an ace to go up, 4-1. With the light beginning to dwindle, he was two games from taking a two-sets-to-one lead, and he knew the roof over Centre Court would have to be closed for the match to continue. To that point, Janowicz was weaving a potent spell of powerful serving, aggressive baseline play and deft drop shots to keep Murray from finding a rhythm.

title: Michigan: Detroit Sues Insurer Over Casino Money
description: Detroit has sued a bond insurer, Syncora Guarantee Inc., blaming it for the withholding as much as $11 million a month in casino revenue, Kevyn Orr, the citys emergency manager, said Friday. Mr. Orr was appointed in March to lead the city out of a fiscal crisis that has put it on the brink of bankruptcy. Detroit seeks a court order barring Syncora and other defendants from limiting its access to money from its three casinos. Syncora insures some of the $1.4 billion in certificates of participation issued by the city to shore up two public employee pension funds as well as swap agreements through which the city hedges interest rates payable on some of the certificates. Casino-derived revenues were pledged to secure the swaps, Mr. Orr said.

title: Finding the Perfect Spot to Shoot
description: A member of the Teamsters union and the Directors Guild of America, Kevin Breslin is a filmmaker and a location scout for commercials. Over 20 years, he has maneuvered crews through the city and arranged thousands of shoots, including the New York Lotterys If I Had a Million Dollars and Verizons Can You Hear Me Now? spots. Mr. Breslin, 56, lives in Belle Harbor, Queens, with his wife and youngest son.

title: Good Friends, Big Helpings
description: Alchemy, Texas, a barbecue joint that opened in the back of a sports bar in Jackson Heights, Queens, on April 1, has a solid pedigree  its a spinoff of the highly rated John Brown Smokehouse in Long Island City  and enviable early love from the foodie nation, including the Village Voice, which called the prime rib nothing short of spectacular. And yet it still hasnt quite caught on with the citys barbecue-obsessed. Its weird out there, said Josh Bowen, the chef and one of the owners, adding that the restaurant was not permanently committed to the site. One night well sell out, and the next therell be no one there. On a rainy night last week (was there any other kind?), three of the six tables were empty, in contrast to the robust trade at the Legends sports bar in the front. Meats were served by the pound, on paper plates, and plastic checked tablecloths and paper towels caught the overflow of good stuff, which Mr. Bowen said combined Texas tradition with the neighborhoods South Asian spices, plus touches that belonged to neither school. The next night, Mr. Bowen said, he would feature frog legs on the chalkboard menu. This is a place to experiment, he said. Hence the name.

title: Looking for Fun in All the Queens Places
description: There are almost too many events to keep track of in Queens this summer. The usual draws, including the MoMA PS1  Warm Up  dance parties and the U.S. Open tennis tournament, remain as enticing as ever. And then theres the Major League Baseball All-Star Game, which takes place at Citi Field on July 16. Add in the  Thunderbird Intertribal Powwow  and the annual Hot Jazz/Cool Garden concert series, and it seems as if a trip to the citys largest, most diverse borough is inevitable.

title: Assessing the Womens Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Wimbledon 2013 was supposed to be the Serena Williams show. Two weeks ago, all the talk was about the supposedly near-impossible task of stopping the indomitable American from claiming her sixth title at the All England Club.

title: China: Anti-Japan Violence Punished
description: A court in China convicted and sentenced a man to 10 years in prison for battering the owner of a Japanesecar with a motorcycle lock during anti-Japanese protests that swept the country in September, official news media said Friday. It was an assault that prompted debate about violent undercurrents of popular nationalism in China. The attacker, Cai Yang, was among 12 men sentenced by courts in Xian, a city that experienced violent protests after a territorial dispute with Japan flared, Xinhua, the state-run news agency reported. The dispute has brought an upwelling of public anger that also draws on bitterness over the Japanese invasion and occupation of China in the 20th century.

title: Piano Man of a Silent Screen
description: On Wednesday evening, Steve Sterner, 62, walked into the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Harvey Theater and sat at an upright piano with a sliver-view of the screen.

title: Before the Songs, a Precisely Made Chai
description: Chandrika Krishnamurthy Tandon, a financial adviser and a New York University trustee, is also a Grammy-nominated musician who released her third album, Soul March, in April. Her albums are produced under a nonprofit label that donates the proceeds to various causes. Ms. Tandon, 58, who was born in Madras, India, and came to New York in 1979, lives on the Upper East Side with her husband, Ranjan, 62, a hedge fund manager. They have a daughter who lives in Washington, D.C., and visits often on weekends. On Sundays, Ms. Tandon leads a choir at the Ganesh Hindu Temple in Flushing, Queens.

title: The Girls Who Havent Come Home
description: The last time they took Vernice Hills children away, the time they didnt give them all back, was the afternoon she went to see her neighbor. Ms. Hill lives in a hulking building on East 188th Street, in a frayed neighborhood in the Bronx. It was May 1, 2005.

title: Police Cut Back, and Volunteers Try to Fill the Gap
description: As a result of budget cuts in the Sheriffs Department in Grants Pass, Ore., citizens are starting to patrol the streets themselves.

title: Egypts Leadership Void
description: Violence and political clashes on the streets of Egypt are rooted in the countrys history. Former leaders have had little success creating consensus among disparate groups.

title: Gentrifying Into the Shelters
description: This past week, The New York Post reported on the sale of a two-bedroom loft in Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn to a couple in exodus from what they regarded as the oppressive trendiness of the Lower East Side. The loft, just under 1,600 square feet, sold for what the paper said was a record-setting $1 million, the highest price, apparently ever, for the sale of an apartment in a neighborhood that two decades ago could claim one of the highest murder rates in the city.

title: Remembering Robben Island
description: Ahmed Kathrada recalls his time in prison on Robben Island with Nelson Mandela.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 7:20 P.M. (Starz) PREMIUM RUSH (2012) A New York bicycle messenger (Joseph Gordon-Levitt, above) races from uptown to down on a fixie, with only a single gear and no brakes, while avoiding cars, buses, trucks and pedestrians  and a very crooked cop (Michael Shannon)  in this thriller from the director David Koepp. Pushing pedal to the mettle and its breezily thin, goofy story to the breaking point, Premium Rush provides just about all the late summer air-conditioned relief you could hope for, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Its buoyant dumb-fun, a ticking-clock thriller, she added. Stuffed with zingers and zippy stunts, it comes with pretty young things of all hues and hair types  few prettier than Mr. Gordon-Levitt  and start-to-finish clever special effects, none more clever or special than Michael Shannon. If you want to see a political undertow in its urban band of multicultural renegades, theres that for the taking too.

title: Korean Pact on Factories Could Lead to Reopening
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North and South Korea agreed on Sunday to allow factory managers from the South to return to a jointly operated industrial park in the North for the first time in two months, but they said more talks were needed before the park, a symbol of inter-Korean cooperation, could be reopened.

title: Cracks Emerge as Egyptians Seek Premier
description: CAIRO  Egypts new leaders struggled to put together a new government on Saturday, with disagreements over who should be the interim prime minister spilling out into public view and showcasing the divisions among those who had endorsed the overthrow of the countrys first democratically elected president.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Bartoli Wins Womens Wimbledon Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The 28-year-old Marion Bartoli of France claimed her first career Grand Slam title in dominating fashion, routing a flat Sabine Lisicki 6-1, 6-4 in one hour 21 minutes.

title: Lifestyles of the Rich and Something or Other
description: A very New York piece in todays Times about trendy, wealthy New Yorkers who have been acquiring pied-a-terres in newly fashionable Lower Manhattan. You have to read a bit carefully to realize that these are, for the most part, people with apartments on the Upper East Side; their downtown bolt-holes are to avoid the need to trek uptown after a night out.

title: Sunderland Makes a Deal for Altidore
description: Jozy Altidore is going back to the Premier League in England.

title: Potential Mistakes (Wonkish)
description: Update: I should have mentioned that the CBO doesnt use the filtering method in its estimates for the US; as best I understand it, it uses a production function approach that is much less likely to interpret a prolonged slump as a decline in potential output. And thats a very good thing.

title: Virginia, for Wine Lovers
description: At Barboursville Vineyards, an 870-acre vineyard and winery in Barboursville, Va., an Italian winemaker is bent on making world-class wines.

title: Virginia Wines: In the Old Dominion, a New Terroir
description: ON a humid afternoon in late May, Luca Paschina, a winemaker born in northern Italy, made his pitch to the owner of a wine shop on Long Island. Pouring a cabernet franc reserve and a Bordeaux-style blend, he described how the red wines were aged for more than a year in French oak. And he recounted the history of Barboursville Vineyards, the 870-acre property in central Virginia where the wines were made.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (6) vs. Guatemala (0)
description: In its only exhibition before Tuesdays Gold Cup opener, the United States national team cruised to a lopsided win over Guatemala in a game that was a tale of two halves Friday night in San Diego.

title: Mexicos Election Violence Is Said to Be Worst in Years
description: MEXICO CITY  Running for public office in Mexico has long been perilous, with threats, assaults and sometimes outright killings by criminal gangs, political rivals and other opponents.

title: A Popular Reds Owner (Its About Time)
description: Some fans never get to choose their favorite baseball team, and that means they never get to choose their favorite teams owner. My father grew up in southern Indiana, rooting for the squad on the other side of the Ohio border, the Cincinnati Reds. My mother grew up in a suburb of Cincinnati, convinced she would one day marry Johnny Bench.

title: All-Star Wonder Is Not All Fun and Games
description: Justin Verlander squirmed in his chair at the AT&T Park interview room Oct. 23. He was there to talk about his assignment the next night in Game 1 of the World Series. He did not want to rehash his poor start in the All-Star Game, which was a big reason his Detroit Tigers were opening the World Series on the road in San Francisco.

title: Software and iPad Put Video and Statistical Database a Tap Away
description: One of the many routines that baseball players follow before a game is to wander into the video room at a stadium. There, hitters can watch video of their recent at-bats, and pitchers can get a look at the tendencies of coming opponents.

title: An Orange Blossom in the Devils Den
description: Nancy and George Hoover looked on as rebels traipsed through the couples modest Pennsylvania farm during the days immediately following the Battle of Gettysburg. The disappointed, yet still defiant, Confederates camped in the fields around the Hoover homestead near Waynesboro, about 20 miles west of the battlefield.

title: Variety: Marching Bands
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  You dont need me for this.

title: Train Derails and Explodes in Canada
description: A train carrying petroleum products derailed and exploded Saturday morning in a town in Quebec. Videos, apparently shot by witnesses, show billowing flames and secondary explosions.

title: Weighing Changes to the Business Side After Doping Scandals
description: NICE, France  When cycling was still a provincial affair in which riders changed clothes behind middle schools before races, the news that its most recognizable star had doped to win the Tour de France would probably not have mattered. And it would have been unthinkable to imagine an investigation, undertaken in the United States, no less, revealing the sport to be in structural disarray, ruled by dysfunctional leadership and a code of silence.

title: Bartoli Vanquishes Nerves and Lisicki in Wimbledon Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England  There are many ways to count how long Marion Bartoli waited for her first Grand Slam title. This years Wimbledon was her 47th major tournament. She reached her first Grand Slam final here six years ago but did not play another until Saturday. She had not won a tournament since October 2011.

title: July 6: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Trying to End Rifts, Syria Opposition in Exile Elects President
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The main Syrian exile opposition group elected a new president on Saturday, the bodys latest bid to end months of squabbling and show that it can unite, organize and arm the fighters battling Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad.

title: The Search for Clues in the Yarnell Hill Fire
description: Investigators in the Yarnell Hill fire are now beginning the months-long task of unraveling the deadliest day for wildland firefighters in 80 years.

title: Hernandez Among Many Who Found Trouble at Florida in the Meyer Years
description: As the University of Florida dominated college football for the better half of a decade under Coach Urban Meyer, the Gators accumulated numbers  of victories and accolades and championships  at dizzying rates. In six seasons, they won 65 games, two Southeastern Conference championships and two national titles.

title: Morsi Spurned Deals, Seeing Military as Tamed
description: CAIRO  As President Mohamed Morsi huddled in his guards quarters during his last hours as Egypts first elected leader, he received a call from an Arab foreign minister with a final offer to end a standoff with the countrys top generals, senior advisers with the president said.

title: The Athletics Sweet Smell of Victory
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Oakland Athletics do not stink. But their stadium did. On a Sunday last month, the As and the Seattle Mariners ended a game to find that sewage had backed up through the drains of the team clubhouses and the offices of coaches and umpires, who surely called it foul.

title: New Zealand Skipper Adapts and Thrives in a Multihull World
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Dean Barker has been the helmsman for Team New Zealand in the Americas Cup. He has been the helmsman for New Zealand in the Louis Vuitton Cup. He has raced in the MedCup, the Congressional Cup, the world match-racing championships, even the Olympics.

title: Donovan Hopes to Play His Way Onto a Fourth World Cup Team
description: What a difference two years makes.

title: Ken Lombard, on Staying a Student of Business
description: This interview with  Ken Lombard, partner at Capri Capital Partners, a real estate investment and development firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Rationality and the Euro
description: Simon Wren-Lewis, for once, has a happy story to tell. He looks back at Britains fateful decision, ten years ago, not to join the euro, and argues that the decision was made on the basis of  gasp!  actual analysis. Gordon Brown (who deserves a much better rap than he gets) brought in real economic experts, who used a real economic framework  optimum currency area theory  and concluded that the case for euro membership was not good.

title: Letters to the Sports Editor
description: At Ballpark, a Hefty Price Tag

title: From the Fed, Mixed Signals for Main Street
description: PRICES of stocks, bonds and other investments sank toward the end of the second quarter as the Federal Reserve signaled that it might begin what Wall Street has called the taper  the reduction and then the possible reversal of bond purchases that the Fed has used for years to support the economy and markets.

title: The Yarnell Hill Fire
description: A group of firemen perish while trying to contain the Yarnell Hill fire.

title: Yarnell Flyover
description: An aerial view of the Yarnell Hill Fire.

title: When Weak Balance Sheets Outperform the Strong
description: MANU DAFTARY, manager of the Quaker Strategic Growth fund, says he learned a valuable lesson in 2009. He avoided companies like the American International Group, Bank of America and Citgroup, which, to one degree or another, were damaged by the subprime mortgage crisis and benefited from the help of the Federal Reserve. His portfolios performance suffered, though, as he minimized investments in such companies.

title: In Brazil, a Reminder of Emerging-Market Risks
description: THE protests in Brazil last month were the latest vivid reminder of the perils of investing in emerging markets. Tens of thousands of demonstrators thronged the streets of So Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and other cities, incited partly by a rising cost of living and a slowing economy. Cars burned. Tear gas billowed. And the Brazilian stock market sank.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Cycling in the City
description: Readers discuss the pleasures and problems of bike sharing.

title: Want Your Data Back? Pay Me
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, my laptop died. My stomach churned as I realized that a full days worth of work had vanished.

title: The Song of the Suburbs
description: WHEN I was a boy growing up in Mississippi, my father liked to drive around looking at houses. That was his expression. We lived in the very center of Jackson, a block from the Capitol building; it was the 50s, I was 6 and on. I dont know what my father felt about owning the small red-brick duplex in the older part of town  if he liked it much or didnt. It is the inner city now, but it was our home then, a place hed bought so I could be born in it. It was what he could afford.

title: Slowly, Cuba Is Developing an Appetite for Spending
description: HAVANA  When a 3-D movie theater opened in his neighborhood two months ago, Manuel Alejandro snapped up tickets. It was no IMAX, just a small lounge in a converted apartment with a 55-inch television and an M&Ms dispenser in the corner. But for $3 a person, Mr. Alejandro and his friends donned special glasses and watched the movie of their choice.

title: Robert A.G. Monks, Crusading Against Corporate Excess
description: AT age 79, many people who can afford to do so are done working. Not Robert A. G. Monks. He is still hard at work, trying to change corporate America.

title: PETA Finds Itself on Receiving End of Others Anger
description: NORFOLK, Va.  Even some supporters do not know what to make of it.

title: PETA Under Fire From No Kill Groups
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals euthanizes an average of about 2,000 dogs and cats in its Virginia animal shelter every year, but the trend nationwide is to reduce shelter kills.

title: Golds One Certainty: Its Decline Has Been Swift
description: GOLD and trouble go together, because the metal is often seen as a haven in times of economic distress.

title: A Dimming Outlook for Bonds May Require Some Rethinking
description: FOR three years, the warnings that bonds were primed for a downfall smacked of crying wolf. Bond funds generally did just fine, thank you. That is, until May.

title: Stuck in Traffic, Dying of Thirst
description: I DO not know how to drive a car.

title: A Painful Mix of Fire, Wind and Questions
description: PRESCOTT, Ariz.  They trained their eyes on the mountain that smoldered in the distance as they carved a path through a forest choked by fire and drought. The ground crackled underfoot. Packs sagged from their backs, heavy with the gear frontline firefighters must carry: pickaxes, temperature gauges, spades, radios, plenty of water.

title: Trouble on Wheels
description: IT was after midnight, the summer of 2002, and I had just casually placed a hundred eggs and a pineapple in front of the register at a 24-hour grocery in metro Atlanta. The eggs were for throwing at houses. The pineapple was for throwing off the cashier. A hundred eggs by themselves lead one to suspect impending delinquency. Add in a pineapple and all one suspects is an interesting omelet.

title: In New Books,  Paths to Investing and Spending
description: FINDING good, out-of-favor stocks can make you rich. But how do you find those stocks  and, assuming that you can, how can you best spend your newfound riches to make yourself very happy?

title: Mutual Funds That Made Sense of a Confusing Market
description: IN a hurly-burly quarter, with some stock-market sectors sagging and others surging, managers of three of the top-performing mutual funds managed to find rising returns in places as varied as restaurants, roadsters and robots.

title: Ahead of the Market
description: How three of the top performers of the second quarter of 2013 fared against the market  and against their peer groups of funds.

title: Train Blast Kills at Least One and Forces Evacuations in Canada
description: OTTAWA  A runaway train exploded Saturday, killing at least one person and forcing more than 1,000 people to evacuate from a town in the province of Quebec, the police said. The 73-car train, which included tank cars carrying petroleum, destroyed much of downtown Lac-Mgantic, a town of about 6,000, in a blaze that continued through the day.

title: A New Anti-American Axis?
description: THE flight of the leaker Edward J. Snowden from Hong Kong to Moscow last month would not have been possible without the cooperation of Russia and China. The two countries behavior in the Snowden affair demonstrates their growing assertiveness and their willingness to take action at Americas expense.

title: Java Jive, 2013
description: The coffee you are about to enjoy was brewed the old-fashioned way, in a slow-drip machine powered by a mustachioed man pedaling a penny-farthing bicycle. Stop for a moment to admire the sumptuous curvature of our coffee makers gold-hued cylinders, crafted by Japanese artisans who reside, for reasons unknown, within the central vent of an active volcano. Have you witnessed such glory outside the walls of a major citys museum?

title: Fighting Wildfires, Processing Death
description: WHY young men from the country become firefighters is hard to explain to people who are not from the country. For most of us, its not about the rush, which fades with time, or the paycheck. We could earn more working for the railroad or a car dealership. I figure its about the land. Its what we know best  these woods, dirt roads, small towns  and if given the chance to make a living outside with our backs, under a blue, hot sky, then by God yes were going to take it.

title: A Hidden Consensus on Health Care
description: TO follow whats happening with the new health care law right now, you have to understand that for all the deep divisions on the issue, theres actually a real bipartisan consensus about how the American health care system ought to be reformed.

title: The Churchs Errant Shepherds
description: BOSTON, Philadelphia, Los Angeles. The archdioceses change but the overarching story line doesnt, and last week Milwaukee had a turn in the spotlight, with the release of roughly 6,000 pages of records detailing decades of child sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests there, a sweeping, searing encyclopedia of crime and insufficient punishment.

title: Can Egypt Pull Together?
description: ANYONE who has followed Middle East politics knows that this is a region where extremists tend to go all the way and moderates tend to just go away.

title: Goodbye Old World, Bonjour Tristesse
description: PARIS  VERSAILLES lived again at haute couture week, as designers paraded their let-them-eat-cake creations, hand-stitched with gilt embroidery and trimmed with guiltless fur  frousfrous that no real women can wear and few can afford.

title: Letting Go of Our Nukes
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  PRESIDENT OBAMA recently called on Russia to join with the United States in negotiating a mutual reduction in strategic nuclear warheads that would leave each country with slightly more than 1,000. The number would be up to one-third less than what both countries agreed to deploy in the New Start treaty, reached in the presidents first term.

title: Susan Kare
description: Susan Kare is an independent digital designer whose ubiquitous on-screen icons are clicked by countless users every day. Known for her minimalist, intuitive and often witty designs, she started her career at Apple when Steve Jobs selected her to create the graphics and fonts for the original Macintosh computer.

title: Has Caucasian Lost Its Meaning?
description: AS a racial classification, the term Caucasian has many flaws, dating as it does from a time when the study of race was based on skull measurements and travel diaries. It has long been entirely unmoored from its geographical reference point, the Caucasus region. Its equivalents from that era are obsolete  nobody refers to Asians as Mongolian or blacks as Negroid.

title: Eyeball of Providence
description: Oh, thats very nice, I say, as the mild sedative takes hold just before Dr. Nagel performs cataract surgery on my left eye in the ambulatory-surgery facility at Mount Sinai Hospital. I can see why people become addicts, I add, beginning the Sedative Gabble, which I will approximate here. Do you know where the word cataract comes come  from? I mumble. Probably from the Latin cataracta, but not what thu yink. You think. Not for like a waterfowl  fall. From  and here the sedative makes me pause for at least 30 seconds and then take a deep breath  from a meaning of Latin of gate meaning portcullis like a castle thing that you can see through a little but barrier.

title: The Joy of Old Age. (No Kidding.)
description: LAST night I dreamed about mercury  huge, shining globules of quicksilver rising and falling. Mercury is element number 80, and my dream is a reminder that on Tuesday, I will be 80 myself.

title: To Tennis Fans, From Djokovic and Del Potro
description: Thats as good as it gets.

title: Why I Donated My Stool
description: This spring I saved a friend from a terrible illness, maybe even death. No, I didnt donate a kidney or a piece of my lung. I did it with my stool.

title: Qaeda Rebels Are Gone. Death Isnt.
description: TIMBUKTU, Mali  ITS time for my annual win-a-trip journey, in which I take a university student with me on a reporting trip to Africa. So Im here in Timbuktu, the ancient crossroads of the Sahara, with Erin Luhmann, a journalism student from the University of Wisconsin, navigating roadblocks and jittery soldiers in a city that Islamist militants ruled until early this year.

title: Bryans Capture Missing Piece at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Their strings and nerves were tighter than Bob and Mike Bryan would have liked at the start of the Wimbledon mens doubles final on Saturday, but there was ample time to make the necessary repairs.

title: Rising Dangers of Hunger
description: Many Malians are on the edge of starvation, and the fighting and insecurity have pushed some over the bring.

title: Murray Has Won a Tournament at Wimbledon, but Not This One
description: WIMBLEDON, England  As is now well established, it has been a through-the-looking-glass Wimbledon.

title: 2 Die and Many Are Hurt as Plane Crashes in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  An Asiana Airlines passenger jet traveling from Seoul, South Korea, crashed while landing Saturday at San Francisco International Airport, smashed into pieces and caught fire, killing at least two people and injuring more than 180 others.

title: A New Education Mayor
description: The next mayor of New York City will assume control of the countrys largest school system at an especially challenging moment. That person will oversee installation of the rigorous new Common Core learning standards. This ambitious set of academic goals, which has been adopted by all but a handful of states, is intended to move schools away from rote learning and memorization toward a writing-intensive curriculum that cultivates reasoning skills required by the new economy.

title: Bencic Adds Wimbledon Title to Successful Season
description: WIMBLEDON, England  For a while Saturday afternoon at Wimbledon, Belinda Bencics dream ticket appeared to be slipping away. She won the French Open girls title last month, but that final was played on a back court at Roland Garros in front of a smattering of spectators. Wimbledon, on the other hand, offers the juniors a bigger stage, and a slightly star-struck Bencic, 16, walked out onto a packed Court 1 to face the big hitting 17-year-old Taylor Townsend.

title: Payback on the L.I.R.R.
description: For a working schlub who commutes from the suburbs, the Long Island Rail Road disability scandal of 2008 was powerful evidence that the game of life is rigged.

title: Europes Delayed Banking Union
description: Last year, European officials laid out an important proposal for a banking union that would resolve failed institutions; provide strong, central supervision of banks; and give depositors a solid guarantee that their money was safe. If carried out fully, the plan could help restore health to the Continents depressed economy.

title: From Gypo to Whitey
description: Is there such a thing as Irish omert? The insistence that there is a code of honor for an Irish-American hoodlum that would stop him from ever becoming an F.B.I. informer is the most intriguing part of the criminal defense being offered by James (Whitey) Bulger in his trial in Boston. Mr. Bulger stands accused of a raft of violent crimes from his years as an underworld boss, including involvement in 19 murders. Yet it is the prosecutions spelling out his role as an alleged informer who turned on his own kind in South Boston that seems most stinging for him  to the point of his snarling expletives at people who say so on the witness stand.

title: The Farm Drawer
description: The other day, a question arose: How deep is my well? Thats the kind of number I should know by heart, if only because its so interesting to talk about wells with other well owners  a conversation that barely gets off the ground if you dont know how deep your well is. I remember having work done on my well ages ago when a check valve failed. Surely on the bill someone had written the depth in feet. All I had to do was find the bill.

title: Going the Distance, With Sports Analogies
description: MY boss, Edward Mady, general manager of the Beverly Hills Hotel, cant get enough of sports. His office walls are lined with souvenir baseballs and photographs of him posing with famous athletes. His corporate lingo is laced with sports metaphors and analogies.

title: A Writers Mommy Guilt
description: Im reading your book, and now Im worried about you, an acquaintance told me about my (fictional) novel, which concerns the (fictional) misadventures of a (fictional) depressed mother. My whole head flushed. My immediate response was anger, then denial, then guilt. I was practically going through stages of mourning, and maybe I was in mourning, mourning for the simpler vision of myself I was able to project on Facebook, or you know, in person or whatever.

title: New Momentum for Change in Corporate Board Elections
description: SHAREHOLDER efforts that actually succeed in changing dubious corporate governance policies are so rare that when they happen, it makes you sit up and take notice. So its worth examining the results achieved so far this year by the Shareholder Rights Project, a program operating at the Harvard Law School. And with any luck, its success might shame do-nothing investment managers, like those running many mutual funds, into action.

title: Austerity Wont Work if the Roof Is Leaking
description: I RECENTLY spent a week in Berlin, where the entire city seemed under construction. In every direction, cranes and other heavy equipment dominated the landscape. Although many projects are in the private sector, innumerable others  including bridge and highway repairs, new subway stations and other infrastructure work  are financed by taxpayers.

title: A Glaxo Executive, Seeing Through a Sales Reps Eyes
description: I WAS born and raised in San Juan, one of nine children of an Irish-American father and a Puerto Rican mother. They met at the chapel of Bellevue Hospital in New York when they were taking care of relatives who were patients there.

title: Yankees Rescue Uneven Pettitte for 6th Straight Win
description: In a tumultuous 2013 season, Andy Pettitte has spent time on the disabled list, won his 250th game and set a Yankees strikeout mark, but over all, it has been a subpar year by his standard. At times, he has struggled to find his command and has even acknowledged losing the feel for his signature cutter. Worse, he has struggled to find answers.

title: Class Struggle in the Sky
description: The choice of snacks on some recent flights Ive taken include blue potato chips, a cranberry-almond bar, a packet of trail mix and  a selection I havent been offered before  popcorn. But it makes sense: the cabin already feels like a movie theater at the end of a showing, even though we still have an hour to go. The floor is strewn with candy-bar wrappers and broken headsets, crumpled napkins and cracked plastic glasses. Theres so little legroom that I have to push my knees against the seat in front of me as if Im doing crunches. Welcome to economy.

title: A Sports Agent With Hollywood in His Blood
description: PRETTY much forever, one question has hovered over Casey Wasserman: Would he ever be the power hitter that Grandpa Lew was?

title: Pedal-Powered Delivery
description: A Portland company moves freight using six electric-assisted tricycles and strong riders in lieu of trucks.

title: In Cargo Delivery, the Three-Wheelers That Could
description: ITS well-known that Portland really likes its bicycles. But its embrace of bike culture goes beyond its catering to commuters, leisure riders and athletes. So bike-centric is Portland that its residents can have any of the following delivered to their doorsteps by cycle: a pizza, a keg of pilsner, plumbing services or a hot tub. And the list grows from there.

title: Regions of Derpistan
description: Josh Barro has made a very useful contribution to policy discussion by adapting the term derp for a certain kind of all-too-prevalent stance in economic debate, which Noah Smith somewhat euphemistically describes as the constant, repetitive reiteration of strong priors. In other words, people who take a position and refuse to alter that position no matter how strongly the evidence refutes it, who continue to insist that they have The Truth despite being wrong again and again.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, July 7
description: With tensions mounting in Egypt after the removal of President Mohamed Morsi,the news broke Saturday that Mohamed ElBaradei, a Nobel Prize-winning diplomat who is an opponent of Mr. Morsi, would be named the countrys interim prime minister. NBCs Meet the Press will have an interview with Mr. ElBaradei about the transition to a new government.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Raw Footage: San Francisco Plane Crash
description: A Boeing 777 operated by the Korean airline Asiana crashed while landing Saturday at San Francisco International Airport, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Activist Who Documented Syrian Wars Toll Became Its Victim
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Even as the Syrian war took bigger and bigger bites out of his life, Fidaa al-Baali never stopped trying to document the conflict  not when his brother, a rebel fighter, died in battle; not when security officials, trying to pressure him, arrested his father; not even when the rebel battalion he was embedded with unleashed a mortar attack that killed his fiance.

title: Bonus Features
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  True Confession: Making infomercials might be O.K. for Ron Popeil, but, in another lifetime, I was hired to make the worlds most embarrassing appearance on QVC to sell knitting machines and Im still not over it. It was an unmitigated disaster, due in part to bad planning, a klutzy account executive who knocked the knitting off the machine five seconds before airtime and the program managers relegating my spot to midnight, when the only people awake to see it were either insomniacs or burglars.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, July 7
description: Come on already.

title: Have a Workplace Worry? Ask the Workologist
description: The C.E.O., the cubicle dweller, the summer intern, the Starbucks-telecommuter  everyone in the modern workplace has something in common: We all need advice sometimes.

title: Where Asiana Flight 214 Came to Rest
description: Diagram of the debris field left when the plane crash landed.

title: Texas Transportation Department Hits Hurdles in Seeking Financing
description: When this years first special session concluded dramatically in the Texas Senate last month with an energized crowd shouting to block the passage of a contentious abortion bill, proponents of the measure were not the only ones who were upset.

title: Perrys World Will Go On, With or Without Him
description: Its a little odd to think about a Texas government without Rick Perry.

title: Why Keeping It Simple Worked for Bartoli
description: Marion Bartoli swept through the Wimbledon fortnight without dropping a set. In the final Saturday, she used her superb return to blunt the powerful serve of Sabine Lisicki, but she also showed vastly improved court coverage, a willingness to attack the net and just enough variety in her shot selection to keep Lisicki off balance.

title: A Bicultural Writer Whose Westerns Draw Enthusiastic Praise
description: When book critics gather around the campfire to list Texas best authors of contemporary Westerns, one name jumps out among those of the usual suspects like Cormac McCarthy, Larry McMurty and Elmer Kelton: James Carlos Blake.

title: Onetime Dewhurst Ally Turns Rival in Race for Lieutenant Governorship
description: A year before State Senator Dan Patrick announced he would challenge Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst in the 2014 primary, the Houston Republican, who is also a radio host, vigorously defended Mr. Dewhursts record on the airwaves and on his Facebook page.

title: Service Brings Scorn to Israels Ultra-Orthodox Enlistees
description: JERUSALEM  They have been labeled Hardakim, a derogatory term that combines Haredim, the name commonly used here to denote ultra-Orthodox Jews, with the Hebrew words for insects and germs.

title: Blast at Pakistan Bazaar Kills 4 and Injures Dozens
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  At least four people were killed and 38 injured on Saturday night when a timed explosive detonated amid a busy bazaar of food merchants and restaurants in the eastern city of Lahore, the police said.

title: In Secret, Court Vastly Broadens Powers of N.S.A.
description: WASHINGTON  In more than a dozen classified rulings, the nations surveillance court has created a secret body of law giving the National Security Agency the power to amass vast collections of data on Americans while pursuing not only terrorism suspects, but also people possibly involved in nuclear proliferation, espionage and cyberattacks, officials say.

title: Video Shows Street Violence in Egypt
description: As Ben Hubbard, a colleague in Cairo, reports, Egyptians struggled on Saturday to come to terms with an explosion of violence in Cairo and other cities that left more than 30 dead and 1,400 injured as opponents and supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, clashed two days after he was removed from office by Egypts military.

title: In Wyoming, a Cheney Run Worries G.O.P.
description: LUSK, Wyo.  A young Dick Cheney began his first campaign for the House in this tiny village  population 1,600  after the states sole Congressional seat finally opened up. But nowadays, his daughter Liz does not seem inclined to wait patiently for such an opening.

title: Press Conferences on Flight 214 Crash
description: The San Francisco International Airport and the National Transportation Safety Board both issued statements on the crash of Flight 214.

title: Mets Wright Earns Start in All-Star Game
description: MILWAUKEE  David Wright acknowledged that this years All-Star Game carried more significance to him than his previous six combined.

title: Conservatives Aggressive Ad Campaign Seeks to Cast Doubt on Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Though many of its rules will not take effect for months, President Obamas health care law is already the subject of an aggressive advertising campaign by Republicans to sow doubts about how it will work.

title: Doubling Down on Gambling in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Known simply as Revel, the newest addition to this gambling city was going to be different.

title: Egypts New Leaders Press Media to Muzzle Dissent
description: CAIRO  As soldiers and policemen opened fire on supporters of President Mohamed Morsi outside an army officers club on Friday, killing at least four people, one of Egypts state television channels broadcast a religious show that advised viewers to respect the elderly.

title: Russian Official Says Venezuela Is the Best Solution for Snowden
description: MOSCOW  A senior member of the Russian Parliament said Saturday that political asylum in Venezuela would be the best solution for Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor who is on the run from the American authorities.

title: Refrain for Many Chess Players: Meet Me in St. Louis
description: Rex Sinquefield has almost single-handedly turned St. Louis into the American chess capital.

title: Patriots Store Takes Back Unwanted Hernandez Jerseys
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The doors to the New England Patriots team store opened 30 minutes ahead of schedule Saturday. That was not the plan, but there was really no choice.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 6, 2013

title: Navigating Soldiers and Hunger in Timbuktu
description: My Sunday column is from my annual win-a-trip journey, and looks at Mali in the aftermath of the fighting there to evict the Al Qaeda affiliate in north Africa. We found a fragile stability and the fighting over, although everyone is very tense, but starvation is now killing more people than warfare ever did. The problem, of course, is that the fighting and Al Qaeda generate news coverage, while there has been little global interest in the hunger in Mali.

title: With Howard Leaving, Lakers Face Rare Task: Getting Over Breakup
description: LOS ANGELES  Leave it to Kobe Bryant to have the last word. After Dwight Howard phoned Mitch Kupchak, the Lakers general manager, late Friday with the news that he was signing with the Houston Rockets  for $30 million less than the Lakers could offer  Bryant took to Twitter with a gesture that spoke more forcefully than any 140 characters could.

title: Seeking to Repair a Rift in Portugals Ruling Coalition
description: Threatened with the collapse of his government, Pedro Passos Coelho, Portugals prime minister, promoted on Saturday the head of the junior coalition party to be his deputy.

title: After Legal Marathon, Britain Deports Terrorist Suspect
description: LONDON  A 10-year court battle to deport the militant Islamic cleric known as Abu Qatada to face terrorism charges in his native Jordan ended early Sunday, when an aircraft chartered by the British government left a military airfield outside London with the cleric aboard, bound for a prison near the Jordanian capital, Amman.

title: Mets Marcum Returns to Site of Success, With Little Success
description: MILWAUKEE  Shaun Marcum was effective for two years here while pitching for the Milwaukee Brewers, but a return to his old ballpark on Saturday could not resuscitate him from a prolonged funk.

title: Yankees Jeter Enjoys Visit to Mountains but Hopes for Short Stay
description: MOOSIC, Pa.  Derek Jeter was here once before, at this diamond nestled in a mountainside in the coal region of northeast Pennsylvania. He batted second in the 1995 Class AAA All-Star Game, in a lineup with Jeromy Burnitz, Luis Lopez and others who long ago faded from the stage.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 7
description: This is how it is with a revolution. You have to bear with us.

title: Jeneca Parker, Robbyn Tongue
description: Jeneca Allyse Parker and Robbyn Lee Tongue were married Saturday at Oak Lodge, an event site in Stahlstown, Pa. The Rev. Charlene Han Powell, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Lucy Whidden, Jon Hampton
description: Lucy Chadbourne Whidden, a daughter of Anne Derry Whidden and Roger G. Whidden of New York, was married Saturday to Jon Knox Hampton, a son of Molly McCalla Hampton and E. Kennon Hampton of Rosemark, Tenn. The Rev. Margaret A. Thomas performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Castine, Me.

title: Rachel Weitzner, Philip Ellenbogen
description: Rachel Emma Weitzner, the daughter of Susan Curtis Weitzner and Stuart B. Weitzner of Old Bridge N.J., was married Thursday evening to Philip Michael Ellenbogen, the son of Gloria DePaolo Ellenbogen and Edward Ellenbogen of Plainview, N.Y. Rabbi Dennis Tobin officiated at the Crystal Plaza, an event space in Livingston, N.J.

title: Across the Street and Into a Relationship

Janet P. M. Sentance, a ceremony officer from the Rushcliffe Registration Office, also in Nottingham, officiated. Following the ceremony, the Rev. Canon John Bentham, an Anglican priest performed a blessing of the marriage at St. Edmunds Church in Nottinghamshire.
