title: Follow This Advice
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Hey, a Friday puzzle with a theme! Just the thing to pick us up as we sail into the weekend. I do love a good themeless puzzle, but a themeless with a surprise theme just makes my day.

title: Difficult Spot for Obama on Immigration Push
description: WASHINGTON  As opposition to an overhaul of the immigration system hardens in the Republican-controlled House, President Obama is trapped between the need to promote what could be a legacy piece of legislation and the reality that being out front might be counterproductive at best.

title: Documentary Uncovers Detectives Persistence in Boston Strangler Case
description: Four years ago, Myles David Jewell, a 31-year-old filmmaker, began combing through his late grandfathers old police files on the Boston Strangler case from the early 1960s. Working closely with his uncle John DiNatale, they uncovered details showing Detective Phil DiNatales dogged persistence, as well as his frustration that the investigation had never led to the prosecution or conviction of Albert DeSalvo.

title: Alan Rosenthal, Who Reshaped Legislatures, Dies at 81
description: Alan Rosenthal, a political scientist whose ardent belief in representative democracy led him to help reshape and strengthen state legislatures across the country and to criticize their excesses and ethical infirmities, died on Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 81.

title: Knicks Try to Keep Pace in Beefed-Up Eastern Conference
description: LAS VEGAS  Knicks General Manager Glen Grunwald recognizes that the landscape of the Eastern Conference has changed.

title: Key Moments in a Death Penalty Case
description: A look back at the pivotal events in the arrest and trial of Ronell Wilson.

title: Midwest Floods
description: The last thing Cedar Rapids, Iowa, needed was more rain, deluged as it has been this week by record-breaking floods. But the city was pummeled with more rain overnight. Some relief was in sight, with forecasters saying the water would recede over the weekend.

title: City in Iowa Rebuilds From Flooding but Remains Vulnerable
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  Five years after record flooding drowned this manufacturing town and caused billions of dollars in damage, city officials and private investors are rebuilding homes and businesses on the Cedar River banks. But some people here are troubled to see structures rising in places where, not long ago, entire first stories were underwater.

title: Toshi Seeger, Wife of Folk-Singing Legend, Dies at 91
description: Toshi Seeger, who was a driving force and partner in a variety of musical and environmental endeavors with her husband, the folk singer Pete Seeger, died on Tuesday at their home in Beacon, N.Y. She was 91.

title: Chuck Foley, Co-Creator of the Game Twister, Dies at 82
description: Chuck Foley, a game designer who helped inaugurate a craze that rivaled the hula hoop, scandalized the puritanical and drove chiropractors wild with delight, died on July 1 in St. Louis Park, Minn. Mr. Foley, an inventor of Twister, was 82.

title: Decade Later, Still Seeking a Rare New York Execution
description: The government has spent more than a decade trying to put Ronell Wilson to death.

title: North Carolina House Passes New Restrictions on Abortion
description: Legislation that would impose new restrictions on abortion clinics moved out of the North Carolina House of Representatives on Thursday in a form that would give wide power to Gov. Pat McCrorys administration.

title: For Pakistani Girls, Just Going to Class Is a Risk
description: Months after an attack on a Pakistani girl who campaigned for education rights, the Taliban war on girls schooling continues unabated.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft Revamps Its Corporate Structure
description: Microsoft said it would dissolve its eight product divisions, satirized by followers of the technology industry as being in a state of perpetual war with one another, in favor of four new ones arranged around broader themes, Nick Wingfield reports in The New York Times.

title: Nets Are Said to Have Struck a Deal With Kirilenko
description: Rejected twice in eight days, the Nets finally landed a small forward on Thursday  and remarkably, he is better than the two players they lost.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Cost of Withholding Information as Brooklyn Murder Cases Are Reviewed
description: The Brooklyn district attorney has claimed that he does not have to say what murder cases a retired detective testified in, even though the detective gave evidence in public trials, juries reached guilty verdicts and judges pronounced sentences.

title: Yankees Pettitte Is Looking Wobbly, but He Is Still Winning
description: It is in the moments, perhaps, when Andy Pettitte does all he can  when he makes the correct pitch, the correct decision  and still fails, that he is reminded of his age, his limitations. A perfectly placed bunt can drive him mad, as it did twice Thursday, the ball trickling away from him, an easy out just out of reach.

title: Theyve Stayed at the Party So Long
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Spitzer Submits Signatures, but Challenges Are Expected
description: After a four-day petitioning blitz, Eliot Spitzer turned in 27,000 signatures Thursday night to claim a spot on the Democratic primary ballot for New York City comptroller.

title: Renewed Push to Raise Age of Being Tried as Adult
description: Democratic state lawmakers, community leaders and rights advocates on Thursday renewed a push to raise to 18 the age at which a defendant can be tried as an adult in New York.

title: Ciudad Jurez Weighs a Neglected Notion: Hope
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  The scars of years of fighting in this city across the border from El Paso, Tex., can be seen in the faded missing-person fliers posted years ago or in the far-off stares of residents at the plaza.

title: Texas Democrats, Seeking Resurgence, May Struggle for Footing in 2014
description: When Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican, announced this week that he would retire from statewide politics after more than a dozen years at the helm, a cheer went up in the office of the Dallas County Democratic Party.

title: GTT
description: AUSTIN

title: Mayor of San Diego Apologizes Over Treatment of Women
description: Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego apologized Thursday for his treatment of women who had worked in his office, but he refused to resign in response to sexual harassment accusations leveled by prominent allies. I am embarrassed to admit that I have failed to fully respect the women who work for me and with me, and that at times I have intimidated them, Mr. Filner, 70, a Democrat in his first year in office, said in a video statement. I have begun to work with professionals to make changes in my behavior and approach, he said, adding that he and his staff will participate in training about sexual harassment. Donna Frye, a former city councilwoman who worked for Mr. Filner until April, had asked him to resign, saying she had credible evidence he had sexually harassed numerous women. KPBS, a public radio affiliate, reported that women in Mr. Filners office said they had been groped, kissed and grabbed.

title: Foreign Students Fill Science Ranks at Universities in United States
description: International students make up 70 percent of the full-time electrical engineering graduate students in the United States, 63 percent of those in computer science, and more than half in industrial engineering, economics, chemical engineering, materials engineering and mechanical engineering, according to a new report by the National Foundation for American Policy. The report said the American economy would benefit from welcoming such students and allowing them to remain in the United States when they complete their studies. Stuart Anderson, the executive director of the foundation, said policy makers spend too much time talking about who we dont want to come to this country and not enough about who should be welcomed.

title: Modest Debut of Atlas May Foreshadow Age of Robo Sapiens
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  Moving its hands as if it were dealing cards and walking with a bit of a swagger, a Pentagon-financed humanoid robot named Atlas made its first public appearance on Thursday.

title: Anxiety Lingers Long After Cancer
description: From the shock of the cancer diagnosis onward, depression can take its well-documented toll on patients. Even patients who appear to pack away their fears during the grinding treatment journey to becoming cancer-free concede that when the regimen ends, they unspool emotionally.

title: Word of the Day | dulcet
description: dulcet \dl-st\ adjective

title: New Limits for Arsenic Proposed by F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly two years after an outcry about arsenic in apple juice touched off by a segment on The Dr. Oz Show, the federal Food and Drug Administration is proposing a new limit on acceptable levels.

title: Behind Citys Painful Din, Culprits High and Low
description: The first helicopter thundered overhead at 8:05 a.m., as Christine Reekie was sipping her morning coffee. Another one came a minute later, and another, and another, and yet another, swooping so low she feared it would not clear the transmission lines. Ms. Reekie had suffered a small stroke two years earlier, and now she shakily began noting each flyover in writing. By noon, she had counted 14, as they jetted to and from the Hamptons right over her home in Floral Park, just over the border from Queens on Long Island.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9:30 A.M. (Showtime 2) LIBERAL ARTS (2012) Josh Radnor (How I Met Your Mother), who wrote and directed this film, stars as Jesse, a 35-year-old admissions counselor at a New York City university who returns to his Ohio alma mater, where he encounters his two favorite teachers. The first is Judith (Allison Janney), a bitter, cynical professor of romantic literature, who seduces him, then throws him out of her bed. You didnt think we were going to cuddle while I read you Wordsworth, she says. Put some armor around that gooey little heart. The second is Peter (Richard Jenkins), who is ending a 37-year career at the place he describes as a prison. Then Peter introduces Jesse to Zibby (Elizabeth Olsen, above with Mr. Radnor), an intellectually precocious 19-year-old drama student, and something clicks over the strains of Beethoven, Wagner, Vivaldi and Massenet. Liberal Arts is a much stronger, more deeply felt film than Mr. Radnors debut, Happythankyoumoreplease, Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, but, to quote the hard-boiled Judith, Mr. Radnors Jesse is gooey. The harder Mr. Radnor strains to make you love his alter ego, the more resistant you become. The last thing in the world you want to hear is Jesse congratulating himself for growing up, but toward the end of the movie thats exactly what he does, with a gooey happy ending in sight.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 12, 2013
description: It was like getting a note saying youll be executed at dawn.

title: News Quiz | July 12, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Indonesian Prison Riot Allows Inmates to Flee
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The Indonesian authorities, including an elite police counterterrorism unit, were scouring the northern city of Medan on Friday for dozens of inmates, including convicted terrorists, who escaped from a penitentiary the night before during deadly rioting that killed five people.

title: In Kerala, Rehabilitated Killer Nurtures Mentally Challenged
description: Vasudeva Panicker, 61, is a mild-mannered watchman of a shelter for the mentally challenged at Punnapra, in Alappuzha district in southern Kerala. In his youth, Mr. Panicker was a soldier in the Indian Army. One day he returned home from his battalion to discover that his wife had run away with a lover. Enraged, Mr. Panicker stabbed his mother-in-law to death. He served 14 years in prison for the murder.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, July 12, 2013
description: The question was written by Michael Gonchar. It comes from the article Hes Acting Out; Its on Purpose.

title: Snowden Renews Plea for Moscow to Grant Asylum
description: MOSCOW  In a high-profile spectacle that had the hallmarks of a Kremlin-approved event, Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American intelligence contractor, broke his silence after three weeks of seclusion on Friday, telling a handpicked group of Russian public figures that he hoped to receive political asylum in Russia.

title: Student Crossword | The Human Brain
description: Learn more about the human brain by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Posing for Pictures With Tigers and Bears
description: In the article, Step Right Up, Kids, the Predator Is Ready, Andrew E. Kramer writes about how Russian circuses routinely allow children to have their picture taken with dangerous animals.

title: Dog Food for the Mind and Soul
description: We highly recommend viewing the slide show in full-screen mode.

title: U.S. Seeks Expanded Role for Military in Philippines
description: MANILA  The United States is negotiating an agreement to allow it to position military equipment and rotate more personnel into the Philippines while avoiding the contentious issue of re-establishing American bases in the country, according to officials from both countries.

title: Fast E.V. Charging Ramps Up in the Netherlands
description: Sales of electric cars in Europe have been stuck in the slow lane, but could that change as governments and private companies become more involved in providing public charging there? On Monday, ABB, the Swiss electric engineering and power grid company, announced that it would install a national network of 201 fast-charging stations in the Netherlands.

title: New York Today: 114 Candles
description: Updated, 12:23 p.m. | Susannah Mushatt Joness birthday party today is a little late. But whats a few days when youre 114?

title: Atlas Goes Public
description: A Pentagon-funded humanoid robot named Atlas made its first public appearance Thursday.

title: Racial Makeup of Red and Blue America
description: As the House of Representatives considers an overhaul of immigration laws, it is clear that the members represent very different slices of the country, depending on their political party. Districts represented by Democrats are, together, only slightly more than half white and nearly one quarter Hispanic. Republican districts are roughly three-quarters white, and only one in nine residents is Hispanic.

title: My Competitors Dont Seem Interested in Coopertition
description: I recently had a conversation with a man from Spain whose wife runs an e-commerce company that is based here in the United States but serves the Spanish market. The business sells car accessories. He was telling me about a time when she ran out of a particular item and called up her competitors, who supplied the inventory she was missing.

title: JPMorgan and Wells Fargo Feel First Chill of Rising Interest Rates
description: Even as two of the nations largest banks reported record profits on Friday, beneath the rosy earnings were signs that a sharp uptick in interest rates could spell trouble ahead for Wall Street and the broader housing market.

title: Summer Reading Contest | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In The Times this week: The Trayvon Martin murder trial, in which the jury could begin deliberations as early as Friday morning.

title: Rare Protest in China Against Uranium Plant Draws Hundreds
description: BEIJING  Hundreds of people took to the streets of a city in Chinas southern Guangdong Province on Friday to protest a proposed uranium processing plant that would be the nations largest when completed.

title: Wall Street Feigns Modesty
description: The Timess David Gillen explains why companies continually forecast lackluster earnings despite a healthy position.

title: Confessions From the Cultural Revolution
description: SHANGHAI  He beat his teachers, terrorized his neighbors, spat on his enemies. But last month, nearly four decades later, the former Red Guard Liu Boqin published in a progressive magazine an apology to nine of his victims. Liu was in junior high school at the start of the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution and, like the rest of the nations youth, was encouraged by Maos government to turn on intellectuals, teachers and others in positions of authority.

title: If Gulliver Were a Conceptualist ...
description: Buffalo  On a recent afternoon at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery here, workers were struggling to mount a huge metal sculpture high on a wall. The piece looked like a Looney Tunes black cloud, with oversize spigots poking out of its sides. Youd imagine it raining bad luck on Porky Pig. It seemed to be jinxing its installers as well, as time and again their forklift refused to heave it to the right spot.

title: Therriens Large Works on Display
description: Robert Therrien is the subject of a solo exhibition at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo.

title: JPMorgan Beats Expectations
description: JPMORGAN EARNINGS SURGE 31% | JPMorgan Chase reported a 31 percent increase in second-quarter earnings on Friday, helped by strong gains in its investment banking business, its credit card operations and in its mortgage lending division. Net income of $6.5 billion, or $1.60 a share, exceeded analysts expectations of $5.47 billion, or $1.44 a share. Revenue was $20 billion, compared with $26 billion in the period a year earlier.

title: Friday Reading: What Parents Mean by Part-Time Work
Les Not So Miserables
description: Update: a hint for all those readers demanding data for other countries: those things with blue lines underneath are hyperlinks, and in this case lead you right to the full dataset.

title: Wells Fargo Profit Jumps 19 Percent
description: Wells Fargo, the nations largest home lender, posted a 19 percent increase in second-quarter profit on Friday as it overcame a drop-off in the mortgage market on its way to record earnings.

title: A Bike-Lane Scam
description: Dear Diary:

title: Spitzer
description: I was on the Upper West Side yesterday, and you had to walk carefully to avoid the teeming masses of people trying to get you to sign up to get Eliot Spitzer on the ballot for comptroller. And it looks as if the effort succeeded.

title: This Weeks Movies: Pacific Rim, Fruitvale Station and Crystal Fairy
description: In this weeks video review, Times critics evaluate Pacific Rim, Fruitvale Station and Crystal Fairy. See all of this weeks movie reviews here.

title: Gender Gaps Appear as Employment Recovers From the Recession
description: ALL the jobs lost by women during the Great Recession have been recovered, at least in the private sector. But men still have a way to go before that happens.

title: Off the Charts: Women in the Workplace
description: The number of private sector jobs held by women rose to a record level in June, surpassing the previous record set more than five years earlier in December 2007.

title: Zimmerman Case Goes to Jury, With Defense Urging It to Remove Emotion
description: SANFORD, Fla.  In his three-hour closing argument on Friday, a lawyer for George Zimmerman said that his client was guilty only of protecting his own life when he fatally shot Trayvon Martin, and he chastised the prosecution as having filled jurors heads with guesswork, not evidence.

title: Updates on Snowdens Meeting With Rights Groups in Moscow
description: Last Updated, Saturday, 1:08 p.m. As my colleague Ellen Barry reports on Twitter from Moscows Sheremetyevo Airport, Human Rights Watch released the first image of Edward Snowden in Russia, taken at a meeting with rights groups on Friday.

title: How the Rich Get a Big Real Estate Tax Break
description: The rarefied few who can afford to shell out tens of millions of dollars for an apartment in one of the gleaming new condominiums being built across New York City may be searching for luxury, but in some cases they will find an unexpected perk: a break on real estate taxes that can mean tax bills as low as $96 a month.

title: Those Wordy Contracts We All So Quickly Accept
description: THIS past month Ive been agreeing to contracts like crazy. I clicked yes on Verizons terms and conditions when I paid my bill; ditto on iTunes when I was installing it on my computer. I even signed a waiver agreeing not to sue a white-water rafting company if anything went wrong when I spent a day on the Hudson.

title: Napolitano Stepping Down as Homeland Security Chief
description: WASHINGTON  Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, announced Friday that she was stepping down, setting off a search to fill one of the most challenging positions in government at a time when the Obama administration is struggling to get a team in place for the presidents second term.

title: In Jersey City, First on the Block With a Rooftop Lounge
description: Nearly three decades after the LeFrak Organization began transforming a rail yard along the Jersey City waterfront into a planned community of glassy office towers and soaring residences, it has built the neighborhoods first luxury high-rise, a blue-glass-and-steel tower that overlooks the Hudson.

title: The Buddha Is Smiling in Bodh Gaya
description: In Bodh Gaya in Bihar, the Buddha sits inside the Mahabodhi Temple with a brilliant crystal bowl in his lap. The Buddhas gilded figure is placed on a plinth, inside a glass enclosure, rising more than seven feet above human height. His beautiful hooded eyes are downcast, his eyelids and irises lined with a shade that is the blue of water and bright skies. And his full lips are painted pink and fixed, for all eternity, in a quiet, imperturbable smile.

title: An Illegal Marriage That Benefits Society?
description: I know a woman, an undocumented immigrant, who wishes to get married in order to be able to return to Brazil to see her children (after an absence of nearly seven years). She works at a chain store and seems to be there 60 to 80 hours a week. She sends most of her money home to her children. She is always kind, decent and helpful to others. Ive known her for three years and believe she would be an exemplary American citizen. She has saved money in order to pay someone to marry her; I believe this would be wrong. If I were to marry her, Id expect nothing. I live alone, have no girlfriend and think this marriage thing would be the morally correct thing to do. What do you think? BOB, MASS.

title: Those Who Cant Teach
description: When mentioning her to friends, I called her my tutee, a pretentious word Im pretty sure Ive never heard anyone else use, though it was technically accurate: I was tutoring her. Specifically, I was trying to help her prepare for the English section of the G.E.D. test, which in the past she failed repeatedly.

title: Theres No Genius More Unknown Than the One Who Never Was
description: Youve probably never heard of the movie that Im most excited to see this summer. Its titled Thumbscrew, and was directed by a shadowy auteur named Stanislas Cordova, a secretive genius whose dark art films are intensely studied by rabid fans known as Cordovites. Thumbscrew is about a woman who suspects her college-professor husband might be murdering young boys, and by all available accounts, its one serious creepfest. According to one person who has seen it, Thumbscrew is an ominous tale of suspicion, paranoia, marriage and the inscrutability of the human psyche. Cordovas extensive filmography is so unnerving that theres even speculation about whether his movies capture actual crimes rather than staged acts of violence.

title: BuzzFeeds Chairman, Ken Lerer, Doesnt Mind Nepotism
description: Last month you announced your own media aggregator, Stop the N.R.A. Are you applying the BuzzFeed model to your campaign against the National Rifle Association?  I actually did the Web site 12 years ago. We just posted our first piece of original content. We looked at the 2012 U.S. Senate campaigns in which the N.R.A. ranked one candidate over the other; and in 26 races, 20 candidates with the lower N.R.A. rating won. All you have to do is put a crack in the wall, and the wall could come tumbling down.

title: Who Made That Turn Signal?
description: A car to me is something that is almost human, something that responds to kindness and understanding and care, just as people do, the actress Florence Lawrence told a reporter in 1920, when driving had become a symbol of womens liberation. The average woman does her own repairing. She is curious enough to investigate every little creak and squak of her car, and to remedy it. Lawrence herself addressed more than squaks: in 1914, she developed an early version of the turn signal. I have invented an auto-signaling arm, which, when placed on the back of the fender, can be raised or lowered by electrical push buttons, she told The Green Book Magazine. The one indicating stop works automatically whenever the foot brake is pressed.

title: Somalias Somewhat Friendly Skies
description: One recent morning at the start of the Kenyan rainy season, I boarded a shuttle bus at Nairobis Jomo Kenyatta International Airport. At a distant corner of the tarmac, we stopped before an aging Boeing 737. The logo of Jubba Airways, the unofficial national carrier of Somalia, was painted on the fuselage: three horizontal stripes, each a different shade of blue, and the slogan: THE HAPPY WAY TO FLY.

title: New Yorks War on Noise
description: Browse archival photographs, video and articles chronicling the citys quest for quiet.

title: July 12: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: A Humbling Day for Jeter and Puig
description: Baseball is an inherently humbling game with an expanding repertory of humility delivery devices. Thats what tied two of its brightest stars together Thursday, baseball reality checks that do not discriminate. You can be a 39-year-old shortstop with devotees sketching out your Hall of Fame plaque and be firmly reminded that you are overstaying your time in a young mans game. Or you can be a 22-year-old who defected from Cuba and stumbled into stardom in Los Angeles and be swatted back by an army of All-Star-voting fans wielding smartphones. Its always something.

title: No More Mr. Nice Guys
description: Many years ago, in an era when the phrases boob tube, idiot box and vast wasteland went unchallenged as television descriptors among the Discerning Classes, I sat in a pool of prospective jurors on a case involving a fancy jeweler. Aiming, apparently, to assess whether we were likely to confuse the actions of real-life rich people with those on Dynasty, the defense lawyer asked each of us, Do you watch TV? Nah, swore a majority of my exceptionally discriminating citizen peers. Just a little. Maybe some Nova from PBS on a black-and-white TV.

title: Bright Young Things
description: The data are in. All precincts have reported. Its official: men suck. At least when it comes to relationships, they do. Men are sex-obsessed and self-absorbed, shallow, callow, capricious and cruel. I wouldnt date us if we were one of the last two genders on earth.

title: Second and Third Chances
description: The clock is always ticking in Andrew Sean Greers Impossible Lives of Greta Wells. Elegiac in tone, this tale of time travel, loss and compromise is as precisely engineered as a Swiss watch. The premise is deceptively simple. It is 1985, and Greta Wells, a photographer living in Greenwich Village, has just suffered two devastating losses: Her twin brother, Felix, has died of AIDS and her lover, Nathan, has left her for another woman. Thrown into a deep depression, she consults a psychiatrist, who in turn sends her to Dr. Cerletti, an advocate of electroconvulsive therapy. Will it change me? Greta asks, before her first session. Not at all, Miss Wells, he replies. What has changed you is your depression. What were trying to do is bring you back.

title: Rites of Passage
description: The British author Tim Parks has lived in Italy since 1981, commuting on his adopted countrys vast, various and ever changing networks of trains from Verona (where he first made his home) to Milan (where he now lives and still teaches). Parks was for many years married to an Italian and has three children, all born in Italy. He has written more than a dozen novels and 10 other books, including a handful of funny, appreciative and grousing memoirs about the particolari of daily life, Italian style. In the first of these, Italian Neighbors, he asked the reader to picture him as a busy but inexpert fellow dashing about the narrow confines of his territory waving a net on the end of a long stick. A huge net, he added. What did he hope to catch? National character, a sense of place, the feeling people, place and weather generate. In his new memoir-cum-travelogue, Italian Ways, Parks enlarges this net to fantastical dimensions in order to bag Italys sprawling, convoluted and (in a way) stupendous railway system and subject it to his scrutiny  on the theory, he explains to skeptics who dont share his train mania, that any culture manifests itself entirely in anything the people of that culture do.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: HABITS OF THE HOUSE  By Fay Weldon  St. Martins, $25.99.

title: Editors Choice
description: MY FATHERS GHOST IS CLIMBING IN THE RAIN,  by Patricio Pron. Translated by Mara Faye Lethem. (Knopf, $24.) In Prons haunting novel about Argentinas Dirty War and its aftermath, an exile attempts to solve the puzzle of his fathers cloudy life.

title: Paperback Row
description: ON SAUDI ARABIA: Its People, Past, Religion, Fault Lines  and Future,  by Karen Elliott House. (Vintage, $16.95.) House, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who has been reporting on Saudi Arabia for more than 30 years, unveils this inscrutable oil-rich country  where Saudis endlessly maneuver through winding paths between high walls of religious rules, government restrictions and cultural traditions  and compares its calcified regime to the Soviet Union in its final days.

title: Hip-Hops Old Themes and New Frontiers
description: Ben Ratliff, Jon Caramanica and Jon Pareles look at the three big hip-hop hit albums of the summer: Kanye Wests Yeezus, J. Coles Born Sinner and Jay-Zs Magna Carta Holy Grail.

title: Teaching (and Learning) the Meaning of Consequences
description: Two-year-old Luka, still wobbly on uncertain toddler legs, launches himself at his 5-year-old brother, whose modern Lego masterpiece (four bedrooms, rooftop terrace, towering staircase to nowhere) hed torn down a few hours before with gleeful abandon.

title: Staying Afloat
description: The violent history of postwar Croatia, from 1945 until the turn of the millennium, created three generations of dislocated people. Some were dislocated from home and roots: many thousands fled their homeland during the years of Yugoslav Communism, with its informers, eliminations and prison camps. Others, who stayed on, were dislocated from their history as the Communist authorities rewrote the past, a process that continued during the bloody Balkan wars of the 1990s. And dislocation, as always, extended into the psychological realm: timeless ideas of value and even truth were warped by decades of lies.

title: Candid Camera
description: Bluebell Gadsby is the kind of heroine who brings to mind Cassandra Mortmain in I Capture the Castle or Harriet the Spy: awkward, lonely and always off to one side, scribbling, or  in the latest iteration of the teenage journal  filming. Stop creeping up on people! exclaims her elder sister, Flora. And stop looking at everyone through that stupid camera.

title: Furry Courage
description: Kathi Appelt can tell a story. She has published over 30 childrens books, for everyone from toddlers to teenagers, and won awards, including a Newbery Honor, along the way. In The True Blue Scouts of Sugar Man Swamp, aimed at middle-grade readers, Appelt returns to the folksy narrative voice of her beloved picture book, Bubba and Beau, Best Friends. Her mastery of pacing and tone makes for wonderful reading aloud, even to children who would happily take on a relatively long novel on their own. There is music in her prose: For as long as raccoons had inhabited the Sugar Man Swamp, which was eons, they had been the Official Scouts, ordained by the Sugar Man himself back in the year Aught One, also known as the Beginning of Time.

title: Making Waves
description: Summer is here, and with it the search for the perfect beach book, a pithy, plotty page turner that can be discussed with confidence at any cookout or party since everyone seems to be reading the same thing. Best of all is stretching out on the sand with a beach book that is actually set at the shore; somehow it heightens our delight in the transient joy of summer. Sarah Dessen, a seasoned young adult author, and the bold newcomer Leila Howland present readers with two different visions of sun and surf. While each features a young woman struggling to make the right decisions about life and love, one reads as smoothly as a rowboat ride across Central Park Lake while the other tumbles you like a rolling Coney Island wave.

title: Beautiful Minds
description: When I was a kid, I could multiply two-digit numbers in my head. Take 48 and 54, for example. (The answer is 2,592.) I would visualize the numbers as though I were solving the problem in longhand. And I would almost always get the answer right. Its a feat of concentration I find almost impossible today. There are just too many adult distractions: the flight I havent booked, the laundry I havent done, the out-of-town visitors I havent arranged for. Multiplication  isnt there an app for that?

title: Dia Foundations Plan to Sell Some Artworks Draws Criticism
description: News that the Dia Art Foundation is planning to sell a group of artworks at Sothebys this fall to raise money to create an acquisitions fund has been met with opposition, according to a report by Tyler Green in his blog, Modern Art Notes.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: New picture books include Aaron Beckers Journey, in which a lonely little girl draws a door on her bedroom wall and opens it to find a lushly detailed imaginary world.

title: Bookshelf: Up, Up and Away
description: PLANES FLY!  By George Ella LyonIllustrated by Mick Wiggins  40 pp. A Richard Jackson Book/Atheneum. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

title: Orsons Archives
description: This weeks Inside The New York Times Book Review podcast features exclusive audio clips from conversations between Orson Welles and Henry Jaglom, as recounted in My Lunches With Orson, reviewed by Maureen Dowd on our cover.

title: Popcast: Hip-Hops Old Themes and New Frontiers
description: This week we look at the three big hip-hop hit albums of the summer, which appeared in a clump: Kanye Wests Yeezus and J. Coles Born Sinner, released June 18, and Jay-Zs Magna Carta Holy Grail, released July 4, with a million copies pre-sold to Samsung as part of a promotion for its Galaxy smartphone. (The Recording Industry Association of America quickly certified Magna Carta as platinum; Billboard magazine is withholding that designation until the record sells a million the old-fashioned way.)

title: Life and Death, Then Living
description: Given a diagnosis of H.I.V. in 1991, Michelle Lopez was sure she and her daughter were dying. Her life was turned upside down when she realized new treatments were allowing them to live.

title: A Day of Friction Notable Even for a Fractious Congress
description: WASHINGTON  Even in a Congress where bipartisanship and comity are now officially the exceptions to the regular order, the near implosion on Capitol Hill on Thursday was notable, as both chambers erupted in a furor that went on for much of the day.

title: The Farm Bill and the Common Good
description: Now that my colleague Paul Krugman has taken up the subject of libertarian populism, Im hoping to say something more, at greater length, about that visions strengths and weaknesses in the near future. But for now, a quick rant about conservatism and the farm bill, in which libertarian populism will make a brief appearance.

title: Salma Hayek Goes Graphic
description: The Girl: The actress, who stars in Grown Ups 2, which opens today in theaters, hits the streets of New York in a resort look that mixes prints and color blocking.

title: A Family That Began Online Sticks With It
description: Cory Zacker and Stephen Feldman met online when America Online was the Internet, said Mr. Feldman, now 53.

title: The Industry Speaks
description: Insiders reflect on whether buying real estate makes you happier.

title: Amazon to Publish Comics
description: Watch out, comic book industry. Amazon has its eye on you. This week, Amazon Publishing announced the start of Jet City Comics, a new imprint devoted to comics and graphic novels.

title: The 6.30.13 Issue
Inside The New York Times Book Review: Lunches With Orson Welles
description: This week, Peter Biskind and Henry Jaglom discuss My Lunches With Orson; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Brett Martin talks about Difficult Men, his book about TV antiheroes; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Lunches With Orson Welles
description: This week, Peter Biskind and Henry Jaglom discuss Orson Welles, and Brett Martin talks about TVs antiheroes.

title: After H.I.V. Diagnosis, a Life Devoted to Outreach
description: For National H.I.V. Testing Day last month, Michelle Lopez took to the streets. She walked around Fulton Mall in Downtown Brooklyn and tried to convince passers-by to take a rapid H.I.V. test. If they needed moral support, she walked them over to the Brooklyn clinic where she is director of H.I.V. programming.

title: As Promised, Icahn Adds to His Bid for Dell
description: Carl C. Icahn lived up to his word on Friday, offering a sweetener to his alternative to a $24.4 billion leveraged buyout of Dell Inc. by adding a warrant to his stock buyback plan.

title: Secret Origin: Comics Made the Man
description: Comic books were just comic books once upon a time  humble 10-cent gateways to the fantastic, the astonishing. They werent paper-and-ink scaffolds for the multibillion-dollar entertainment franchises that some characters have become, franchises (and would-be franchises) that will be celebrated this week in San Diego at the annual multimedia orgy thats Comic-Con International.

title: A Festival Where Anything Can Happen
description: BERLIN  The lights dimmed as usual as the audience took its seats. Then they went out entirely. A light gleamed briefly as a door opened at the back of the stage, and a figure entered. Then it was as dark as tar again, and the first strains of Bachs Partita No. 2 in D minor sounded. For some 20 minutes, the violinist Amandine Beyer played, and the audience listened to the pure sound.

title: A Movies Killers Are All Too Real
description: Early in The Act of Killing, Joshua Oppenheimers startling new documentary about mass murder and impunity in Indonesia, a death squad leader named Anwar Congo, dapper in white pants and a lime-green shirt, demonstrates how he strangled hundreds of people with wire. It was quicker and less messy than beating them to death, he explains matter-of-factly, then breaks into a dance routine, performing the cha cha cha for the camera.

title: Reincarnated and Clad in Humble Garb
description: SEATTLE  During a recent rehearsal here of the new musical Stu for Silverton, the director, Andrew Russell, asked the people in the room to introduce themselves. Several of the actors were students and recent alumni of Cornish College of the Arts, while crew members described themselves as interns. Mr. Russell himself was boyish at 30, tying his long black hair into a knotted ball, and offering zippy superlatives after each scene: Nice nice nice nice and Good good good and High five high five.

title: A Writer Hitching Her Star to a Star
description: There has been a lot of debate over the last two years about what the blockbuster Bridesmaids did for films written and driven by women. That discussion was less theoretical for the actress and writer Michelle Morgan. The films box office blowout simply meant that her script Imogene, which Kristen Wiig had expressed an interest in starring in years earlier, was about to benefit from the overnight minting of Ms. Wiig as a woman who could get a movie greenlighted.

title: Songs for a Summer Breeze and for Firing Up the Party
description: Court Yard Hounds

title: Hanging In With a Demanding Composer
description: Over the course of his prominent career, the German composer Karlheinz Stockhausen took on myriad guises. To the European postwar establishment, he was an enfant terrible, embracing the objective rigor of total serialism and the uncharted vistas of electronic music and happenings. For adventurous jazz and rock musicians like Miles Davis, the Beatles and Frank Zappa, he was a Promethean figure who delivered unto the world techniques for fashioning mind-altering sounds.

title: Cultivating Class, Helped by Celebrity
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  In the coming mini-series A Young Doctors Notebook, Daniel Radcliffe plays a man fresh out of medical school who is sent to run a hospital in a remote Russian village in 1917. He is called upon to saw off limbs, deliver babies and prescribe salves to a never-ending queue of syphilitic peasants, but this inexperienced doctor has help: His older self, played by Jon Hamm, pops in from time to time to offer medical advice and swipe morphine from the dispensary. Their relationship, if one can call it that given that theyre the same person, is a strained one, shifting between combative and testy to Oedipal. At one point, the two share a tub.

title: Back to Work, Armed With a Gavel
description: Hi, its Andie, comes the voice on the phone, conjuring up Southern peaches and silk lingerie, and you cant help feeling a little intimidated.

title: Girl Shot by Taliban Addresses the U.N.
description: Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani student who was shot in the head by the Taliban after speaking out for education rights for girls, spoke to the U.N. Youth Assembly on her 16th birthday on Friday.

title: Homeownership, the Key to Happiness?
description: If trying to buy an apartment in New York City has been making you miserable, consider this: actually getting that home may not make you happy.

title: Bid for Invensys Gives Investors Appetite for More
description: LONDON  Invensys, the British maker of industrial control products and software that has long been the subject of takeover speculation, is in talks to be acquired by Schneider Electric of France for about $5 billion. But investors are indicating that they expect a competing offer.

title: What Inspired You to Work in Classical Music?
description: Update: We highlighted a handful of the best submissions alongside Mr. Tommasinis essay.If you have a job that revolves around classical music, we want to hear about the piece, performance or other experience that inspired you to dedicate your career to the art form. Please share your story in the comments below.

title: Image of the Day: July 12
Inside the List
description: USETH THE FORCE: A couple of weeks ago in this space, I wrote about Jeffrey Browns Star Wars-based parenting books, which were enjoying a run on the advice, how-to and miscellaneous list. Now another Star Wars spinoff is making noise: William Shakespeares Star Wars, by Ian Doescher, is new at No. 12 on the hardcover fiction list. The book recasts the story of Luke and Leia and Darth Vader as a five-act play in iambic pentameter  because why not?  and its more entertaining than you might guess. (Heres a sample couplet from the prologue: In time so long ago begins our play / In star-crossed galaxy far, far away.) In a phone interview, Doescher told me he came up with the idea last year, after watching the original Star Wars trilogy and attending the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in quick succession. People ask me whether I see Star Wars as a comedy or a tragedy, he said, but its really neither  its partly a history, like Henry V, and partly a fantasy, like The Tempest.  He added that he was gratified, but not entirely surprised, by the books success: Shakespeare is a popular market, and Star Wars is a popular market, he said. Its not like I was writing Geoffrey Chaucers Ishtar.

title: Of the DHondt Method With a Barrier
description: ISTANBUL  Demonstrations across Turkey over the past couple of months have sparked a debate over what democracy here should look like. The prime minister seems to think that, because he was elected and re-elected, he now has the authority to override objections to, say, his plans to destroy a park or build a mosque in the center of Istanbul. The opposition calls this majoritarianism and argues that democracy creates an obligation for the government to consult the minority, not a license to trample it.

title: The Spitzer Blitz
description: Never underestimate what a man can do when he has energy, drive and a ton of money.

title: Your Outside-the-Box Bridesmaid Dresses
description: A selection of readers photos.

title: Considering the Horror of Zuckerbergian Dystopias
description: I wasted a substantial portion of a recent Friday night engaged in an argument with a data scientist I met at a strange party in Brooklyn. He was, naturally, working on something that struck me as being of questionable social and economic value, which was already being done by someone else: an algorithm that recommends Y.A. novels to young adults, or whomever, based on Y.A. novels they have already read. Eventually, somehow, the conversation turned to a discussion of whether technology is hollowing out the middle class and would continue to displace higher-skilled workers without generating enough economic growth to make up for the disruption. He found my concerns to be amusing. People can get work creating SEO-optimized niche blogs, he said. Or they can learn to code. And anyway, it wont matter if software puts everyone out of work because poor people already dont have to pay for anything  one of many fascinating, Randian canards he introduced to our conversation, which by this point had become less than civil.

title: London Theater Journal: Change in the Air
description: Nobody ever said the revolution was going to be tidy. This week I spent time in two worlds, separated by more than half a century and thousands of miles, in which the tremors of cataclysmic change were causing folks to make thorough messes of their lives. In the case of Maxim Gorkys Children of the Sun (1905), at the National Theater, the setting is a roomy estate at the edge of a village in imperial Russia; in Pam Gemss Dusa, Fish, Stash and Vi (1976), at the Finborough Theater, its a cramped London apartment in which four women consider lives with and without men.

title: Native American Reservations and Sequestration
description: Budget cuts have started to deliver a body blow to hundreds of Americas most deeply impoverished communities.

title: Big Ticket | At $23.4 Million, a Condo With Space for Big Art
description: A striking West Village triplex at the Abingdon, a 10-unit luxury condominium conversion of a six-story 1906 building on Abingdon Square Park that had been used as a nursing home, sold for $23,419,750 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The 9,600-square-foot dwelling, No. 2, has its own entry west of the main lobby at 320 West 12th Street, at Hudson Street.

title: Pain on the Reservation
description: PINE RIDGE, S.D.  The Red Cloud-Bissonette family needs a new trailer. Frank, who is disabled, and Norma, his wife, are members of the Oglala Sioux Tribe who live on the sprawling grasslands of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. Despite their constant efforts to patch the seams of one of their trailers that was hauled here in 1988, rot and mold continue to climb up the walls.

title: Cutbacks on The Rez
description: At Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, one of the poorest parts of the United States, the budget cuts known as sequestration have slashed millions of federal dollars in funding.

title: Texas Democrats, Energized, Face Hurdles in Turning a Red State Blue
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  State Senator Wendy Daviss marathon filibuster against new abortion restrictions in Texas ended two weeks ago, but the enthusiasm she has ignited among Democrats was still going strong on a steamy morning here this week.

title: Blaming the Patient, Then Asking Forgiveness
description: Dr. Peter Attia thinks about his former patient often, the woman who came to him in the emergency room at Johns Hopkins Hospital one night seven years ago.

title: Paths Interlaced, Like Wisteria Vines
description: Growing up, Stephen Miller Neidich spent summers at Camp Neidich, his familys idyllic and idiosyncratic home in the Georgica Association, a private community in Wainscott, N.Y.

title: An Orchid Disguised as a Weed
description: For those of us old enough to remember giving or receiving an orchid corsage, the concept of a weed orchid seems odd. First discovered in 1879 near Syracuse, the helleborine (Epipactis helleborine) was first thought to be a new species of North American orchid. This caused quite a stir among 19th-century botanists and orchid enthusiasts, but the plant was later identified as a Eurasian native with a history dating to mid-16th-century herbal lore as a cure for gout.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Germany and Norway
description: German Fairytale Route, Germany Germany is celebrating the 200th anniversary of Childrens and Household Tales, folk tales collected by Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm. Events are planned throughout 2013. Many are along the German Fairytale Route, stretching some 375 miles from Hanau in the south to Bremen in the north, winding through villages where the Brothers Grimm lived and worked, and passing settings  a castle where Sleeping Beauty may have awakened or a house fit for Little Red Riding Hood  that inspired the stories. Travelers can relive their favorites at open-air plays, puppet shows, festivals, concerts, exhibitions, guided walking tours and medieval feasts. A musical Grimm fairy tale will be performed in a park in Kassel July 18 to Aug. 18.

title: Mercedes Grand Prix Car Smashes Auction Records
description: CHICHESTER, England  A record for the highest price ever paid for a car at auction was set Friday at the Goodwood Festival of Speed, an annual motorsports celebration here in West Sussex at the ancestral country estate of the Duke of Richmond.

title: Book Review Podcast: Orson Welles Speaks
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Maureen Dowd reviews two new books that unearth vintage conversations with the Hollywood legends Orson Welles and Ava Gardner. Ms. Dowd writes about My Lunches With Orson:

title: Boeing 787 Catches Fire in London
description: Just two months after Boeing seemed to have left the problems with its 787 Dreamliner behind, it suffered another setback on Friday, when a fire broke out inside an Ethiopian Airlines 787 parked at Heathrow Airport in London.

title: Chinas Answer to Charles Keating
description: It had been a long time since I thought about Charles H. Keating Jr., who was perhaps the most notorious executive in the savings and loan crisis of a quarter-century ago.

title: Lionsgate Entertainment Statement About Enders Game
description: As proud longtime supporters of the LGBT community, champions of films ranging from Gods and Monsters to The Perks of Being a Wallflower and a company that is proud to have recognized same-sex unions and domestic partnerships within its employee benefits policies for many years, we obviously do not agree with the personal views of Orson Scott Card and those of the National Organization for Marriage. However, they are completely irrelevant to a discussion of Enders Game. The simple fact is that neither the underlying book nor the film itself reflect these views in any way, shape or form. On the contrary, the film not only transports viewers to an entertaining and action-filled world, but it does so with positive and inspiring characters who ultimately deliver an ennobling and life-affirming message. Lionsgate will continue its longstanding commitment to the LGBT community by exploring new ways we can support LGBT causes and, as part of this ongoing process, will host a benefit premiere for Enders Game.

title: Malala Yousafzai, Girl Shot by Taliban, Makes Appeal at U.N.
description: Last Updated, Saturday, 11:19 p.m. In a speech at the United Nations on her 16th birthday, Malala Yousafzai, who was shot in the head by the Taliban for promoting education for girls in Pakistan, called on world leaders to provide free, compulsory education for every child.

title: Movie Review: 'Fruitvale Station'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Fruitvale Station."

title: Public Advocate Questions Library Plan to Renovate Fifth Avenue Branch
description: Public Advocate Bill de Blasio, a Democratic candidate for mayor, expressed concern on Friday about the New York Public Librarys proposed renovation of its Fifth Avenue flagship.

title: Snowden Makes Appeal From Airport
description: Video of Edward J. Snowden with international rights activists in Moscow on Friday was posted on the Russian news site Life News.

title: Echoes From the Roman Ghetto
description: The Portico dOttavia is one of those chunks of urban surrealism that you come across only in Rome. From a cavity about 20 feet below street level, the ruin of a massive 2,000-year-old portico thrusts its crumbling marble geometry into the present. The dome of a Baroque church, Santa Maria in Campitelli, peers down from the next piazza like a nosy matron.

title: Holder Tightens Rules on Getting Reporters Data
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who has been criticized for the Justice Departments aggressive tactics in secretly obtaining phone logs and e-mails of reporters as part of leak investigations, announced new guidelines on Friday that would significantly narrow the circumstances under which journalists records could be obtained.

title: Moving to the Rhythms of Rio
description: It was going to be a very short trip: into Rio de Janeiro on a Thursday, back to New York by Tuesday. The uprising that has shaken Brazil was still a month or so away, and politics was the last thing on our minds. My wife and I had never been to Rio, and we had a rather more prosaic agenda. Hers was to soak up the warmth and beauty of Rios beaches. Mine was to listen to music. Others can describe the glories of the beaches. Let me tell you about the music.

title: Meades Army Annihilated!
description: Outside, a heavy summer rainstorm thrashed the streets of Richmond, Va. Inside Libby Prison that afternoon  July 8, 1863  hundreds of captured Union officers sprawled across the bare wooden floors of the converted tobacco warehouse, picking lice out of their underwear and passing around copies of Richmond newspapers. The news was grim for the Yankees: Gen. Robert E. Lees Confederate army had defeated Gen. George Meades Union troops at a Pennsylvania town called Gettysburg.

title: A Church That Embraces All Religions and Rejects Us vs. Them
description: LYNNWOOD, Wash.  Clad in proper Pacific Northwest flannel, toting a flask of rocket fuel coffee typical of Starbucks home turf, Steven Greenebaum rolled his Prius into a middle school parking lot one Sunday morning last month. Then he set about transforming its cafeteria into a sanctuary and himself into a minister.

title: S-and-Marketing
description: Designers talk about the challenge of creating a poster for the play Venus in Fur.

title: Marrying a Veteran Was Cool. Then It Got Difficult.
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Hardening Split in Egypt as Islamists Stage Huge Demonstrations
description: CAIRO  Hundreds of thousands of Egyptian Islamists and other supporters of Mohamed Morsi, the countrys first freely elected president, who was ousted and detained by the military last week, filled public squares in Cairo and other cities on Friday in an intensified campaign aimed at returning him to power. The United States also dialed up its criticism, calling on Egypts interim authorities to release Mr. Morsi.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: To Court Your Ex, Try a Reality Show
description: Lately its been possible  if not always pleasurable  to turn on the television and watch musical theater, after a fashion. The guilty pleasures of  Smash are now fading memories, but the long-running Glee still carries the torch. Now theater is returning the favor by squeezing a little of the tube onto the stage: Nobody Loves You, a musical at Second Stage Theater, is a semi-affectionate spoof of matchmaking reality television shows like The Bachelor, in which contestants bare their souls while eliminating suitors for their love.

title: So, Mikes a Fraud. Get Over It.
description: After Mike Ross (Patrick J. Adams) revealed to Rachel Zane (Meghan Markle) in the Season 2 finale of Suits that he couldnt write her a recommendation to Harvard Law School because he hadnt actually gone there  Im a fraud, he said  the result was not one but two swift slaps to his face, followed by steamy sex among the copying-room shelves.

title: New Insight Into Hopper in a Girlfriends Letters
description: A stash of letters written by a secret girlfriend and unearthed a century later is a tantalizing discovery. When the recipient of those letters was a reclusive American painter whose work explored alienation and loneliness, such a find can shed new light on an entire oeuvre.

title: No Innocence for the Watchful
description: Its not easy being Skunk. Eleven years old and living in a nondescript circle of middle-class houses in England, she faces a battery of challenges. Theres her Type 1 diabetes; the teenage boy (George Sargeant) who meets her at a junkyard for flattery and flirtation; her au pairs on-and-off boyfriend (Cillian Murphy), who also happens to be Skunks new teacher; and the family on her block whose mentally impaired son (Robert Emms) has been unfairly accused of molesting a neighborhood girl. In Broken, opening on Friday, Skunks circumstances might prove overwhelming were it not for a luminous performance by Eloise Laurence, who in her film debut conveys the characters dimensions with remarkable range and nuance.

title: Hip-Hop Titans, Still Going Strong
description: On Friday night in the Bronx, the hometown king Jay-Z will take over Yankee Stadium for the first of two nights, a tag-team event with an again-ascendant Justin Timberlake. Its a gimme, as these things go, an event too big to fail. By comparison, whats taking place out at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater on Long Island the same night  the "Americas Most Wanted Festival"  might feel small, but its the more intriguing statement about hip-hop now. The headliner is Lil Wayne, whose failures are more intriguing than Jay-Zs and whos been the more challenging hip-hop star over the last decade. That he has managed to continue making successful records even as his interest in rap has been in decline is a testament to his stubborn natural talent. Hell be joined by, among others, T.I. and 2 Chainz, representing two generations of Atlanta-based hip-hop success. (A 6 p.m., 1000 Ocean Parkway, Wantagh, N.Y.; 516-221-1000, jonesbeach.com.)

title: Performance Art Without Longueurs
description: For their series TAB, Stephanie Browne, a visual artist, and Kay Ottinger, a dancer, focus on a facet of a show that some producers of performance art ignore: the audience. It came out of being tired of performances that were really hard to watch, Ms. Ottinger said in an interview. We wanted to make an enjoyable way for people to watch artists work that is in progress. The latest installment, part of the Brooklyn International Performance Art Festival, takes place at Brooklyn Fire Proof, with two free shows on Saturday. Audience members are led from one performance area to the next as several artists, including Kaia Gilje, Paige Fredlundand Leeza Meksin, show static and movement-based work. The series, which started last fall, makes watching experimental art a pleasure. But for its producers, TAB is also a research project dealing in perception: How does one guide others into watching multiple art forms at once? They have a magic touch. TAB, unpretentious and refreshing, is every bit a summer tonic. (Saturday, 4 and 6 p.m., doors open at 3; 119 Ingraham Street, at Porter Avenue, Bushwick; tabartbrooklyn.com.)

title: Let Us Now Praise a Pioneering Show
description: Seventy-five years ago, the Museum of Modern Art presented its first solo photography exhibition, a show of pictures by Walker Evans titled American Photographs. Maybe Evans was the obvious choice to inaugurate MoMAs photography programming, or maybe not. But its hard to think of many others who would have stood the test of time as well.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: A Festival Tunes Up for Recitals Galore
description: For those who love piano music, piano recitals and everything about the piano, Mannes College the New School for Music is again ready to gratify you. Sunday night is the kickoff of the popular two-week International Keyboard Institute and Festival, marking its 15th anniversary with daily recitals as well as lectures, master classes and a mini-competition. The opening recital features the institutes founding director, Jerome Rose, who will play three favorite Beethoven sonatas: the Pathtique, the Waldstein and the Appassionata.

title: Hulu Owners Call Off Sale, Instead Pledging to Invest to Take On Rivals
description: The owners of Hulu, having plotted a breakup twice now, have decided again to stay together  and as in many relationships of this sort, they are putting on a happy face and promising to work harder this time.

title: The Sweet Spot: Movie Oopsies
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott dissect those much-ballyhooed and hyped movie blockbusters that somehow wind up bombing at the box office.

title: Stephen Kings Economic Horror Stories
description: Stephen D. King, chief economist at HSBC, was paged at an airport a few years ago. When he showed up at the information desk, the obviously disappointed attendant said, Oh, youre not the Stephen King that writes books.

title: On Immigration Reform: Let Them Stay
description: A few numbers jumped out of the new Quinnipiac poll today that suggested David Brooks was right when he said that Republicans in the House may be committing political suicide by refusing to support a compromise Senate bill on immigration reform that does virtually everything they claim to want.

title: In the Abstract, a Coastal Scene Materializes
description: Like many another fishing village set amid craggy hills and picturesque coves, St. Ives, on Englands Cornish coast, reels in tourists. But unlike most of the others, St. Ives has made a specialty of tourists with paintbrushes and carving tools. And in a small but telling show at the Yale Center for British Art, Art in Focus: St. Ives Abstraction, the museum examines nearly two dozen works made in the middle of the last century in St. Ives, during the height of its fame as an artists colony.

title: Death Toll at 31 From Flooding in Southwest China
description: BEIJING  Five days of torrential rain in Chinas southwest has killed 31 people and left more than 160 others missing, the state news media reported on Friday. Most of those affected are in a mountainous stretch of Sichuan Province that only recently recovered from the 2008 earthquake that left 87,000 people dead or missing.

title: A Secret Food Satirist Comes Out of the Pantry
description: It has been one of the most vexing questions facing the food world. Not who makes the best risotto, or where to forage for chanterelles, but this:

title: That Bland Annuity Notice May Be Anything but Routine
description: FOR owners of variable annuities, reading letters that may look like routine notices from an insurance company might be the difference between receiving the payment they expect and one that is significantly lower.

title: Fair Play Measured in Slivers of a Second
description: On Friday morning, Thomson Reuters released the latest University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index, as it does twice a month. But this time was different. As a result of a settlement Thomson Reuters reached this week with New Yorks attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, a select group of its customers didnt get the two-second advance release theyd been buying.

title: A Long Day at the Diamond
description: Managing a baseball team, says Rich Donnelly, is like being the plate spinner on the old Ed Sullivan Show  running from one precariously wobbly plate to the next, trying to avert the crash of china. What better way to spend a summer Sunday? Mr. Donnelly, 66, is in his third year as the manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones. They are a farm team for the Mets, who will host the Major League Baseball All-Star Game on July 16 at Citi Field. Before joining the Cyclones, Mr. Donnelly, a former minor league catcher, worked 28 years in the major leagues, mainly coaching third base. He is, he said, a creature of habit. From June to early September, Mr. Donnelly leaves behind his family in Steubenville, Ohio, for temporary accommodations in Gravesend, Brooklyn, and the delights of baseball in Coney Island.

title: The Monetary Debate: Enter Chewbacca
description: The debate over monetary policy has grown increasingly surreal as time goes by. Initially, it was about a fairly straightforward and  crucially  falsifiable position: the claim by monetary hawks like Allan Meltzer and Martin Feldstein that quantitative easing would lead to a major acceleration of inflation. If that inflation had happened, I like to imagine that doves like me would have conceded that we got it wrong, and reconsidered our position.

title: What It Takes to Fully Engage Your Employees
description: Over the 15 years Ive been consulting in the corporate world, Ive only met a handful of senior leaders who had as a primary goal for their companies making a positive difference in the world.

title: Htel Lambert in Paris Is Damaged by Fire
description: The Htel Lambert, a famous mansion in Paris once frequented by Voltaire and Chopin, caught fire on Wednesday, and details are now emerging about the extent of the damage. The Art Newspaper reports that the blaze destroyed a series of 17th-century frescoes by Eustache Le Sueur and that important works by Charles Le Brun were also severely damaged by smoke and water.

Women were just beginning to participate in sports like golf and tennis. And an active contingent of women and a few men attended teas, lunches and other meetings to promote womens right to vote.

description: A Girl Scout was molested in Grosvenor Square last night, Julia Sterroll announces, looking up from the pages of The London Tatler, in the first scene of Nol Cowards Fallen Angels, the Shakespeare Theater of New Jerseys newest indoor production. (As You Like It is playing on the companys outdoor stage.) Again? her husband asks casually. She corrects him in a tone that suggests he is a silly old dear. Last time it was a Boy Scout.

title: Architects on Southern California Architecture, at MOCA
description: A New Sculpturalism, the current exhibition at the Geffen Contemporary at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, is a sweeping survey of the last quarter century of architectural innovation in Southern California. The show includes noteworthies like Frank Gehry, Thom Mayne and Greg Lynn and ranges from a set of industrial artists lofts in Santa Monica to the Cahill Center for Astronomy and Astrophysics in Pasadena. To celebrate, MOCA interviewed 36 of the featured architects about their practices. One of the most telling responses was to the question Why did you become an architect? The video above compiles some of the best answers.

title: Cavendish Gets Back to the Podium as the Tour Tightens
description: ST.-AMAND-MONTROND, France  A year ago, if someone had asked which would be more likely, Mark Cavendish losing three straight sprint finishes at the Tour de France or the earth spinning off its axis, one might have been forgiven for pausing to consider.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A TriBeCa penthouse with a planted terrace, a Lenox Hill apartment in a prewar brownstone, and a Park Slope home with a den. All three have two bedrooms.

title: Porchetta-Style Pork Chops
description: Melissa Clark prepares a streamlined take on an Italian porchetta with garlic, rosemary, and fennel stuffed into thick-cut pork chops.

title: This Little Piggy Took a Shortcut
description: The first ingredient of a traditional porchetta recipe is a small whole pig. This alone explains why Ive never tried the dish at home, despite my deep affection for it.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) CELESTE AND JESSE FOREVER (2012) Rashida Jones portrays Celeste, and Andy Samberg (above, with Ms. Jones) is Jesse, a young married couple in Los Angeles who have split up without moving on or out in this wistful romantic comedy for which Ms. Jones wrote the screenplay with Will McCormack. She plays a hard-driving trend forecaster who lives in the house they once shared; he is a laid-back artist who now flops in the backyard studio. Though they are best friends bound by the same adolescent humor, Jesses lack of ambition doesnt allow the focused Celeste to stay with him. But she cant quit him, either  until suddenly she must. While Celeste and Jesse is decidedly conventional in most respects, its pretty swell as an exploration of a relationship between a man and a woman thats no longer predicated by mutual desire, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Once upon a studio time, screwball comedy was where men and women redefined gender relations, she added. Equality between the sexes, or so it seems, turned out to be a joke killer, one reason bromances exist: if you cant imagine women as equals, just sidestep them. Here, she said, Ms. Jones and Mr. McCormack have righted the sex imbalance of the bromance with a story about two people who, together and alone, express an ideal rarely seen in American movies: a man and a woman whose equality is burnished in friendship, not just in bed and marriage.

description: BEIJING  In an unusually vigorous rebuttal to Japans latest accusations that China is using aggressive tactics to expand its maritime reach, the Chinese Defense Ministry said Japan was undermining stability in the region with its claims to disputed islands known as the Diaoyu in China and the Senkakus in Japan.

title: Robert L. Hardesty, Speechwriter for Johnson, Dies at 82
description: Robert L. Hardesty, who wrote speeches for President Lyndon B. Johnson, helped write and edit Johnsons memoirs and served as president of Johnsons alma mater, died on Monday in Austin, Tex. He was 82.

title: Bloombergs Traffic Ideas: First the World, Then, Maybe, the City
description: The roads may soon teem with miles of new bike lanes, made possible by Michael R. Bloomberg. In Turkey.

title: Israel Airstrike Targeted Advanced Missiles That Russia Sold to Syria, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  Israel carried out an air attack in Syria this month that targeted advanced antiship cruise missiles sold to the Syria government by Russia, American officials said Saturday.

title: Turkish Lawmakers Move to Curb Armys Political Power
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish Parliament on Saturday amended an army regulation that had paved the way for military intervention in politics  another step in years of attempts by the pro-Islamic government to rein in the power of an army once prone to staging coups.

title: 2 Killed by U.S. Drone Strike in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD  At least two people were killed Saturday in an American drone strike in a northwestern tribal region of Pakistan, according to intelligence officials.

title: Drugs Said to Be in System of Girl Who Fell Six Stories
description: A 7-year-old girl who plunged six stories from the window of a Brooklyn apartment building had drugs in her system, including cannabis, methadone and amphetamines, a person with knowledge of the investigation said on Saturday.

title: John Hightower, Besieged Art Museum Director, Dies at 80
description: John Hightower took charge of the New York State Council on the Arts in 1964 and transformed a wisp of a government agency into a cultural force in theater, music and dance. It was the first of its kind, and a model for government support of the arts throughout the country.

title: Lottery Numbers
Barbara Robinson, Childrens Book Author, Dies at 85
description: Barbara Robinson, a childrens author whose beloved and irreverent novel The Best Christmas Pageant Ever describes how a church play is hijacked by a Scripture-ignorant and all-around troublesome set of six siblings, died on Tuesday at her home in Berwyn, Pa. She was 85.

title: Player Suspected of Cheating Is Suspended for 4 Months
description: The Bulgarian player many people suspect of cheating in tournaments over the past year  though the accusations have never been proved  has been suspended from playing for four months by his national federation.

title: Zimmerman Is Acquitted in Trayvon Martin Killing
description: SANFORD, Fla.  George Zimmerman, the neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager, igniting a national debate on racial profiling and civil rights, was found not guilty late Saturday night of second-degree murder. He was also acquitted of manslaughter, a lesser charge.

title: Player Ratings: United States (4) vs. Cuba (1)
description: The United States fell behind early but responded with a dominant second half to roll past Cuba and earn a spot in the quarterfinals at the Gold Cup.

title: Orphans, Drug Wars and Other Mysteries
description: The state of Texas has long been a hotbed for crime fiction, as evidenced by the enduring reputations of two the greatest noir novelists of the 20th century. Patricia Highsmith was born in Fort Worth in 1921 and set much of her debut novel, Strangers on a Train (1950), in the state; Jim Thompson spent his high school years in Fort Worth in the 1920s and explored the rotting underbelly of small-town Texas in books like Pop. 1280 (1964) and The Killer Inside Me (1952).

title: High School Diplomas Become Less General
description: Some Texas high school students who failed state standardized exams this spring were given a reprieve under the comprehensive education bill that Gov. Rick Perry signed in early June.

title: Pirates Claw Back to Spoil Start by Mets Torres
description: PITTSBURGH  Andrew McCutchen twirled his right arm like a windmill as he rounded the bases after hitting a game-tying home run early Saturday night. One inning later, he took a mighty hack at a low slider, pulling it into left field to send home the go-ahead run.

title: Health Providers Bracing for Medicaid Enrollment
description: Under Gov. Rick Perrys leadership, Texas will not expand Medicaid eligibility to poor adults. But enrollment in the states health program for indigent children and the disabled will still swell in 2014 under new rules created by the federal Affordable Care Act.

title: The Policy and the Politics of the Abortion Debate
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

Graham, both of Sedona, Ariz. The Rev. Frederick Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the country home of the brides parents.

description: Charlotte Josephine Woolley and William Augustus Blount Stewart III were married Saturday at the Washington National Cathedral in Washington. Bishop Eugene Taylor Sutton of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland performed the ceremony.

Remaley Jr., were married Saturday at the home of Mr. deBarys parents. Linda Doyle Lavery, a justice of the peace in Greenwich, Conn., officiated.
