title: A Fathers Wrath: Tom Kizzia Talks About Pilgrims Wilderness
description: Not since The Shining has family life off the grid seemed as terrifying as it does in Pilgrims Wilderness, by Tom Kizzia, but this time the chills come from nonfiction. Mr. Kizzia tells the story of Robert Hale, a Texan who went on to call himself Papa Pilgrim as the patriarch of 15 children. Pilgrim eventually landed in Alaska on protected land, where several local allies adopted him as a heroic pioneer-antagonist of the National Park Service. Others bristled at Pilgrims self-styled messianism, and all the while his children suffered greatly under his rule. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Kizzia discussed whether he ever felt in danger while reporting the book, the keys that helped him unlock the full story and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Motion Control
description: The Timess David Pogue examines the Leap Motion Controller, which gives users the ability to control computers with gestures.

title: Leap Motion Controller, Great Hardware in Search of Great Software
description: By now, we all know what the future will be like; movies and TV shows have described it in detail. We know about the flying cars (thank you, Blade Runner), holograms (thank you, Star Trek) and robot butlers (thank you, Jetsons).

title: Maria Baibakova Is Finding Her Place in the Art World
description: On the first day of the Frieze New York art fair in May, Maria Baibakova hosted a dinner party at an Upper East Side house that was attended by billionaire collectors like Alejandro Santo Domingo and art players like Simon de Pury.

title: The Sun Is Beside the Point When Shopping for Sunglasses
description: THE THING ABOUT SUNGLASSES is they get in the way  more hater blockers than sun blockers, and more emotional-connection blockers than both combined.

title: U.S., in Sign of Displeasure, Halts F-16 Delivery to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, in his first punitive response to the ouster of Mohamed Morsi as president of Egypt, has halted the delivery of four F-16 fighter planes to the Egyptian Air Force.

title: The Plan to Swallow Midtown
description: Is New York falling behind Shanghai and Chicago? It will, the Bloomberg administration argues, unless the city replaces aging commercial buildings with giant new office towers in East Midtown  a 73-block area around Grand Central Terminal, up to 57th Street, between Madison and Third Avenues. An ill-conceived rezoning proposal, now wending its way through the approval gantlet, is a parting attempt by the administration to remap this large swath of Manhattan before Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs term ends in December. Transit advocates; various elected officials, among them Daniel R. Garodnick, a City Council member from the area; along with design and preservation groups and an alliance of seven community boards, have all raised concerns about the plan.

title: Obamas View of the Economic Challenge
description: President Obamas speech in Galesburg, Ill., is more a description of how things are than a plan to get them to where they should be. It lays out Mr. Obamas vision of how the economy has changed to the detriment of American workers, if not American businesses and executives, over the last 30 years or so, since long before the recession hit:

title: Revelations by Rowling
description: Nearly everything about the publication of The Cuckoos Calling, a detective novel released by Little, Brown & Company in April, has been a little mysterious.

title: No Comment Necessary: Drug Mules
description: Via The Maddow Blog

title: Jay Zs Magna Carta Holds at No. 1
description: As overall album sales continued to slide, the rap tycoon Jay Z remained on top of the Billboard 200 chart for a second week with Magna Carta  Holy Grail, (Roc Nation) selling 129,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Jay Z has sold 657,000 albums in two weeks, though that number does not include about 1 million copies Samsung bought to give away to its cellphone owners in a marketing deal some people in the music industry see as a blueprint for the future.

title: Federal Judge Halts Legal Challenges in Detroit Bankruptcy Case
description: DETROIT  A federal bankruptcy judge on Wednesday cleared the way for Detroits case to go forward without legal challenges.

title: Half Empty but Full of History, Brill Building Seeks Tenants
description: If ghosts paid the rent, Eric Hadar would have an all-star tenancy: Freddy Bienstock, Johnny Burke, Cab Calloway, Nat King Cole, Tommy Dorsey, Duke Ellington and Jimmy Van Heusen, to name a few. Not to mention J.J. Hunsecker and Danny Rose.

title: Dad Jeans Are Making a Comeback
description: Dont donate those Jerry Seinfeld jeans to the Salvation Army just yet.

title: Court Upholds Ruling on Dish Networks Hopper
description: Efforts by television networks to stop the Dish Network from supplying its customers an automatic ad-skipping device were dealt another setback on Wednesday when a federal appeals court declined to issue a preliminary injunction against Dish.

title: Strongest Since 1999?
description: So said President Obama in a speech in Illinois on Wednesday. And by one measure he has the facts to back him up, at least for now. But those facts could easily be revised away next week, when the July jobs report comes out. And no one reading that statement should overlook that he said private sector. If you talk about all jobs, the record is not nearly so impressive.

title: Newly Released Books
description: This month, six female authors take a dark view of things. In three story collections and three debut novels, they write about exploitation, sadness and murder. Luckily, love makes the occasional cameo.

title: Manon, a Vast, Ornate Club in the Meatpacking District
description: A quieter, less outr meatpacking district? Not at Manon, a vast and ornate trilevel club that opened in May, where the music is loud, the drinks are expensive and the crowd likes to flaunt its wealth.

title: Listen Up | The Strange Soul Circus of King Khan and the Shrines
description: The surreal stop-motion video for the song Darkness by the psychedelic soul band King Khan and the Shrines, which has its world premiere here, deals with some heavy issues: life, death, what its like to be shot out of a cannon. For Arish Ahmad Khan, the bands Berlin-based, Montreal-born, Indian frontman, the themes and aesthetics of the clip, created by the five-person German animation collective Hylas, were a perfect match for his own. I would go in their workshop and watch them film three seconds in eight hours, he said. It was fascinating. Hylas adapted the video, which features a strongman with a mohawk and a mysterious Native American shaman in addition to the human cannon fodder, from their continuing stop-motion series called Circus, about a traveling circus trapped in a strange place. They first shot the piece as an experiment for another project, Khan explained. When they showed it to me I fell in love with it, so we added another 30 seconds and made into the music video.

title: Reddits Wide Audience Drives the Interview
description: Snoop Dogg was asked how much marijuana he has smoked in his life. (how big is mt rushmore? he replied.) Seth Rogen was asked if had luck with the ladies in high school. (No, he said.)

title: Would Pop Music Be Different if Van Dyke Parks Had More Hits?
description: Van Dyke Parks has long been one of pop musics most esoteric and elusive talents. Allan Kozinns excellent interview with him in The Times Monday proves that this is still as true about Parks now at age 70 as it was in the 60s when he was Brian Wilsons collaborator on the Beach Boys fabled Smile album.

title: Pop-Ups, Sales and Events for the Week of July 25
description: Pop-Ups

title: MoMAs Rain Room Will Stay Open Late on Sunday
description: Sunday is the last day to experience Rain Room, that field of falling water digitally programmed to create a carefully choreographed downpour, using motion detectors to create a dry path for viewers. To accommodate as many people as possible, the Museum of Modern Art has decided to extend its hours  just on Sunday, and just that room  keeping it open until midnight, rather than 5:30 p.m. Since it opened on May 12 at a vacant lot to the west of MoMA on 54th Street, Rain Room has attracted about 65,000 visitors, some of whom have waited in line for up to nine hours.

title: New Polls Are Bad News for Obama, and Worse for Congress
description: Several new national polls find that President Obamas job rating is slumping, that fewer than half of Americans approve of the way he is handling the economy and that broad majorities feel the country is on the wrong track, underscoring the challenges he faces as he begins a campaign-style tour addressing the economy.

title: Gazas Economy Suffers From Egyptian Militarys Crackdown
description: JABALYA, Gaza Strip  The only sound that could be heard on a recent weekday at Abu Eidas concrete-mixing plant in the north of Gaza was birdsong. The pumps, mixers and other heavy vehicles had been idle for days.

title: Baltimore Symphony Extends Directors Contract
description: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra said on Tuesday that Marin Alsop, the orchestras music director since 2007, has signed a new contract that will keep her on the ensembles podium until 2021. Ms. Alsop, 56, is also the music director of the So Paulo State Symphony Orchestra, which upgraded her title from principal conductor this month.

title: The Multinational Equation on Jobs
description: In his speech on Wednesday, President Obama said:

title: Ultra-Orthodox Candidates Elected as Israels Chief Rabbis
description: JERUSALEM  In a victory for the ultra-Orthodox political parties that were shut out of Israels governing coalition this year, two candidates they backed were elected as Israels chief rabbis on Wednesday, defeating a rabbi who had promised, in an unusually aggressive campaign, to transform the troubled rabbinate.

title: Ivory Culprit in Kenya: Ex-Official From U.S.
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  It was not a major arrest by ivory smuggling standards. A traveler bound for Amsterdam was stopped at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport here on a Saturday night last month with a little less than two pounds of ivory, in the form of five bangles, seven rings, seven pendants and two figurines.

title: Facebook Is Erasing Doubts on Mobile
description: If Facebook were a car, it just went from zero to 60 mph in six seconds.

title: More Battles to Come, but First a Sunny Interlude
description: PHILADELPHIA  No matter what the title of the show promises, the skies over this location shoot for Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia had offered only thunderstorms broken up by occasional periods of mugginess. Maybe that was typical weather for this recent summer morning, or maybe it was the influence of the authors of the scene about to be filmed, who were thousands of miles away, busy with their regularly foreboding duties.

title: Six Steps of Life, Measured by Syllable
description: Anapestic tetrameter is a much cheerier form of verse than its name suggests. Yes, each line has four feet, and each foot has three syllables, two unstressed and the third delivered with a beat. It is less solemnly known as the singsong meter from Twas the night before Christmas, and all through the house and Dr. Seusss Yertle the Turtle, and it is playful almost by definition. This is a way of saying that David Rakoffs first novel, completed only weeks before he died last year at 47, is much sunnier and more heartening than it has any right to be.

title: In Real Time, Calling for Anthony Weiner to Step Out of the Mayors Race
description: Weve all heard of fast-breaking stories but something relatively new in the newspaper world is the fast-breaking editorial.

title: Dell Considered Novel Tax Strategy in Buyout
description: In the proposed buyout of Dell by its founder, the company considered but rejected as too risky a novel strategy that tweaks the now-curbed practice of corporations moving overseas to take advantage of lower taxes.

title: LaHood Says Companies Must Wake Up to Distracted Driving
description: When Ray LaHood was transportation secretary, he wasnt one to mince words about the risks of driving with a cellphone. But in an interview this week, just a few weeks after leaving the cabinet, he put a particularly fine point on his concerns, saying that car companies and technology companies must wake up to the deadly dangers their products can pose.

title: Manning Up in the Heat
description: Unlike showy thunderstorms that grab you by the lapels and shout Wear your galoshes! heat waves are like wolves in wool clothing, causing hellish discomfort in the disguise of a sunny summer day. Some of us are fooled: we put on a brave face, our usual clothes, and go to work, where we arrive in a damp, disheveled heap. But gaming a heat wave is no walk in the park. The usual codes of summer style go right out the window (if youre daft enough to have left it open). At a certain point (say, 90 degrees), a new set of objectives takes over. Questions like What would look sexy? or What would look proper? are brushed aside, leaving one desperate quest: how to get through the next 12 hours with the least amount of suffering.

title: Young Innocence? Been There, Done That
description: Teen stardom is about being special: one kids talent and dreams standing in for millions. But the adult world affords fewer favors. How former child stars transition into adulthood has evolved over the decades, but theres still no one true path to success.

title: Winning Team at Senior Trial Advances to World Championship
description: Carolyn Lynch, Mike Passell, Roger Bates, Garey Hayden, Marc Jacobus and Eddie Wold won the concluding 90-board match of the nine-day senior trial last Friday and Saturday in Orlando, Fla. They thus became the USA-2 team in the dOrsi Senior Trophy world championship in Bali, Indonesia, in September.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Chromecast and Painting With Windows 95
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: A Spirit Guide Leads an Exploration of a Devilish Place
description: The Ed Bullins and Mildred Kayden musical Storyville may begin with a funeral procession, but in this revival at the York Theater, the mood is not mournful. Though Countess Willy Danger (the Broadway veteran Ernestine Jackson), a hostess and spirit guide of sorts for the audience in top hat and tails, looks back wistfully to events in New Orleans in 1917, this production, directed by Bill Castellino, is tirelessly exuberant.

title: Rodriguez and Yankees Clash Again Over His Status
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  No one is exactly sure what will become of Alex Rodriguez in the next few days, months and years, but in the interim he continues to anger and mystify the Yankees for what they see as his ham-handed challenges to the teams medical evaluations.

title: The Middle Class at Center Stage
description: Washington is a city of sideshows, full of people who consider it their job to create distractions from the nations most serious problems. Politicians would rather argue about nonexistent scandals or plot to undermine each others programs than come up with ways to create jobs or elevate the hopes of the next generation.

title: Los Angeles Architecture, As It Might Have Been
description: Los Angeles is known as a place where anything is possible. But Never Built: Los Angeles, an exhibition that opens Sunday at the A+D Museum, reveals that for all the architectural gems built in the city, there were plenty of innovative projects  buildings, master plans, transportation schemes and more  that didnt make it past the drawing board. Using renderings, blueprints, models and drawings (many of which will also appear in a companion book from Metropolis, out July 31) the shows curators, Sam Lubell and Greg Goldin, paint a vivid picture of what might have been. Here, the five projects I most wish had been built.

title: Obama Speaks in Illinois
description: The president spoke about the countrys economic progress and his vision for the rest of his presidency.

title: For Pippa Middleton, the Medias Love Sours
description: It was the derrire that launched a thousand photos. As she gracefully carried the brides train up the steps of Westminster Abbey on April 29, 2011, no one could have predicted younger sister Pippas sheathed bottom would steal the show from Kates veiled face.

title: Testimony of Willie Louis
description: Mr. Louis was named Willie Reed when he testified in the 1955 trial of two men in the murder of Emmett Till, who was killed following his interaction with a white woman. His death galvanized the civil rights movement.

title: With Horns and Lasers, Fighting to Be Noticed
description: It has happened to many a bicyclist: the car beside you suddenly cuts into your path or passes close enough for you to feel the heat of its exhaust on your leg.

title: Does Weiner Deserve a Second Chance?
description: The Timess Corey Kilgannon talks to residents of the former Congressional district of Anthony D. Weiner, now a mayoral candidate, to see if they could forgive him after revelations of a new scandal.

title: Room With a Bike
description: As bike-friendly cities and bike share programs proliferate, the hospitality industry is doing its part to encourage two-wheel travel. Earlier this month Kimpton Hotels and Restaurants  began a bike program in partnership with Public bikes. All 60 Kimpton hotel properties nationwide offer guests complimentary use of bicycles.

title: Corporations on the Losing End in Court
description: Here are some prominent cases in recent years in which prosecutions of companies ended in convictions or guilty pleas.

title: On a Move Toward Pop, and Denser Rhythms
description: You may have heard that its hard for a jazz musician to find respect beyond what seems like a fixed number of close followers and students. Musicians can ignore that situation, or respond to it. Etienne Charless new recording, Creole Soul, on his label Culture Shock Music, is a smart response.

title: Apps for Arts and Crafts Projects for Families
description: My home grows a little noisier this time of year because my children are on their summer break from school. You might be in the same boat.

title: Obama Nominates Caroline Kennedy to Be Ambassador to Japan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday nominated Caroline Kennedy to be ambassador to Japan, moving to give a scion of Americas most enduring political dynasty a diplomatic post that has often gone to political heavyweights.

title: Killer of Two Undercover Detectives Is Sent Back to Death Row
description: Ronell Wilson, whose first death sentence for killing two undercover police detectives was overturned, was sentenced again on Wednesday to die by a federal jury that heard gripping testimony about his time in jail, where he roamed freely after the shootings, intimidated fellow inmates and fathered a child with a guard.

title: Elder Bush Is Baldly Supportive of Leukemia Patient
Marble: Luxury in the Raw
description: For many, Kelly Wearstlers name brings to mind a style that might be described as Hollywood glamour, an aesthetic that involves the liberal use of mirrors and brass, black and white, and pops of color. But dont get the wrong idea: the Los Angeles designer has a down-to-earth side, too. She loves marble.

title: Believe It or Not, Truman Capote Slept Here
description: Ross Bleckner exorcises the ghost of his homes previous owner.

title: Ross Bleckner Wipes the Canvas Clean
description: All was quiet at Ross Bleckners house last week, if you didnt count the four yappy dachshunds gnashing their teeth in a downstairs window. Strange, because the renowned artist had an appointment to show a reporter around the place.

title: Sweet Summer Water
description: People seek refuge from the summer heat, and a little excitement, among the pools and cliffs of three upstate New York swimming holes.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Indonesia, the Philippines and Spain.

title: The Storm Erases, the Drawing Board Replaces
description: Its hard to be optimistic when youre restoring a landscape after a major storm. Trucks tear up your lawn, workers drag fallen logs across your shrubs, the ground cover you carefully nurtured is buried in wood chips, and contractors empty your bank account. Its enough to keep a gardener indoors with the shades drawn. What to do?

title: New Uses for Rescued Timber
description: Last year, Aaron Poritz, 28, an architect and Massachusetts native, was visiting a friend in Nicaragua when he stumbled upon a source of guilt-free exotic wood. I found that people were legally pulling lumber out of the region affected by Hurricane Felix, he said. The trees are hundreds of years old, they fell naturally, and were just rotting. Until then, Mr. Poritz had designed furniture as a hobby, but now he was emboldened to start a business. This month, he introduced a 20-piece wood furniture collection made in Nicaragua by local workers. The line, which he said is meant to express a balance between beauty and form and functionality and comfort, includes chairs, stools, tables, desks, beds and a sofa. Prices range from $190 for a toolbox to $3,095 for a dining table. Information: (917) 755-2948 or aaronporitz.com.

title: The Tile House
description: The home of George T. McDonald, Republican candidate in the New York City mayoral race, was built by Rafael Guastavino Jr., whose tiled vaulting system was used in Grand Central Terminal.

title: A Mayoral Candidate Reflects on the Mosaic of His Life
description: BAY SHORE, N.Y.  Everything that has mattered most to George McDonald has happened in Grand Central Terminal.

title: Water From a Stone to Refresh Your Plants
description: Watering plants is a chore normally left to neighbors or colleagues when the plant owner is away. But now it can be done by Water from a Stone, a handblown glass container from which water seeps through a tiny hole. Place the stone in a pot or planter, and it will dribble refreshment for three to four days.

title: Heading Upstate in Search of a Watery Eden
description: Rene Denis, a college student from Lyndhurst, N.J., was standing with a few friends just inside a guard rail on a remote stretch of Route 23A in the Catskills on a recent summer day when a black car, stereo blasting, sped around the corner. It slowed to a halt, and a young man wearing sunglasses leaned out the window and called, You know how to get to Fawns Leap?

title: Bathed in the Glow of Splashing Water
description: As much theatrical designer as interior designer, Tony Duquette occupied a studio on Robertson Boulevard in Los Angeles that featured a tray ceiling made of gold plastic trays. In 1956, five years before he won the Tony Award for his costumes for Camelot on Broadway, he created the exuberant Splashing Water chandelier for the space. That was an interesting challenge for us, to find a way to retain the lightness of the original fixtures made by hand, but make them consistent, said Alix Calligeros, an owner of Remains Lighting, in Brooklyn, which licensed the chandeliers from Mr. Duquettes estate. Splashing Water is $7,125 to $10,495, depending on size (37 inches or 54 inches in diameter) and material (the example shown is powder-coated steel; other versions come in brass in a variety of finishes). Available at Remains showrooms. Information: remains.com.

title: Audiophiles Wishlist
description: Geek gear for the golden ear.

title: The New Audio Geeks
description: In his bachelor days in the late 80s, Philip Elias lived in a town house in Pittsburgh wired for jaw-dropping sound.

title: Sales at Angela Adams, Cristina Dos Santos and More
description: All items on Angela Adamss Web site are 20 percent off, through Sunday (a 5-by-8-foot Waves wool rug, usually $1,200, is $960); (800) 255-9454, angelaadams.com.

title: Los Angeles, We Never Knew You
description: Pereira & Luckmans original design for Los Angeles International Airport was a single, giant glass-domed terminal (shown). The 1952 scheme never got off the ground. And thats a pity, said Greg Goldin and Sam Lubell, the organizers of Never Built: Los Angeles, a show of doomed visionary architecture that opens Sunday at the citys A+D Museum. Given Pereira & Luckmans local influence and the symbolic value of airports, this one could have set the tone for public architecture afterward in L.A., said Mr. Lubell, who is the West Coast editor of The Architects Newspaper and who has written for The New York Times.

title: Taking a Load Off, Together
description: Francis Cape is a British-born master woodworker and sculptor, who for the past few years has been building and exhibiting benches inspired by examples from 19th-century intentional communities, both religious and secular.

title: Sudeikis Says He Will Leave Saturday Night Live
description: Jason Sudeikis, a writer and performer on Saturday Night Live' for 10 years, confirmed Wednesday what had long been rumored: he will not be back on the show this fall.

title: Hezbollah Leader Assails European Sanctions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollahs leader on Wednesday criticized the European Unions decision to blacklist his organizations military wing as a terrorist group, saying the move gave Israel legal cover to wage war against Lebanon.

title: Weiner Scandal Continues to Unfold
description: Anthony D. Weiner entered the race for mayor of New York as a man who had learned from his mistakes. But new revelations reveal that the online behavior that led to his resignation from Congress persisted long after he stepped down.

title: With New Device, Google Tries Again on Internet TV
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is trying again to tackle the television.

title: Boeing Profit Is Up 13%, Exceeding Expectations, and Its Forecast Rises
description: Boeing topped analysts expectations with a 13 percent increase in second-quarter profit, thanks to growing sales of commercial airplanes and exports of military equipment, the company reported Wednesday.

title: Senate Approves College Student Loan Plan Tying Rates to Markets
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday approved a bipartisan plan that would tie interest rates for college student loans to the financial markets, bringing Congress close to finally resolving a dispute that caused rates to double on July 1.

title: Drug Companies Promise More Data Transparency
description: Representatives of the worlds biggest pharmaceutical companies pledged on Wednesday to release detailed data about their drugs to outside researchers, a move that was applauded by some but also seen as an effort to head off more extensive disclosure requirements that are under review in Europe.

title: House Defeats Effort to Rein In N.S.A. Data Gathering
description: WASHINGTON  A deeply divided House defeated legislation Wednesday that would have blocked the National Security Agency from collecting vast amounts of phone records, handing the Obama administration a hard-fought victory in the first Congressional showdown over the N.S.A.s surveillance activities since Edward J. Snowdens security breaches last month.

title: North Carolina: Budget Pays Eugenics Victims
description: State lawmakers have agreed to compensate victims of a eugenics program that for decades forced people who social workers said were developmentally disabled to undergo sterilization. Although 32 states practiced eugenics, thought at the time to strengthen the gene pool and reduce poverty, North Carolina is the first to pay victims. Lawmakers on Wednesday passed a budget that includes $10 million for victims. A state board ran the program from 1933 to 1977, sterilizing about 7,600 people. Only about 200 have been identified, though others are likely to come forward. Its the most egregious taking that government could possibly be guilty of, said the House speaker, Thom Tillis, a Republican. It was critical to close this chapter in our history.

title: My Other Self
description: I was 6 years old when I first heard I had a twin brother. My family  my father, my mother and I  had recently crossed the border from Mexico to settle in Brownsville, Tex. My maternal grandmother, Mam Concha, lived there, too, in a little house of her own. I was always left in her care when my parents went out for a late night.

title: Polar Thaw Opens Shortcut for Russian Natural Gas
description: YURKHAROVSKOYE GAS FIELD, Russia  The polar ice cap is melting, and if executives at the Russian energy company Novatek feel guilty about profiting from that, they do not let it be known in public.

title: Sign of Hope Seen in House for Immigration Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  As House Republicans took a tentative step forward on an immigration overhaul this week and raised the possibility of citizenship for those brought to the United States illegally as young children, immigration advocates found themselves pondering a new question: Is the potential concession as far as many House Republicans are willing to go, or are they slowly inching their way toward a broader compromise?

title: The Third Man on Snowdens Reading List
description: Last Updated, Thursday, 2:30 p.m. As my colleagues in Moscow report, when Anatoly Kucherena emerged from the transit zone of Moscows Sheremetyevo airport on Wednesday after meeting with Edward J. Snowden, Mr. Kucherena  the Russian lawyer helping the former intelligence contractor with his asylum request  was asked to explain what was in the brown paper shopping bag he had left behind.

title: Dont Shift Payments by Medicare, Panel Says
description: WASHINGTON  Adjusting Medicare payments to reward doctors and hospitals in regions that provide high-quality care at low cost would be a bad idea, the National Academy of Sciences said Wednesday.

title: M.T.A. Says Hurricane Sandy Put Budget Into Flux
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Wednesday outlined its $13.7 billion preliminary budget for 2014, cautioning that its finances remained fragile, but sounding an optimistic note given that the agency is only three years removed from deep service cuts and nine months past a devastating hurricane.

title: For SAC, Indictment May Imperil Its Survival
description: Is SAC Capital Advisors going to be the next Arthur Andersen, a company destroyed by an indictment?

title: Many New York Women Are Baffled at Loyalty Shown by Weiners Wife
description: Sipping sparkling water by the bustling patios of Bryant Park on Wednesday afternoon, the young women touched on the usual topics of lunchtime gossip: men, work, relationships.

title: Harrisburg Sees Path to Restructuring Debts Without Bankruptcy Filing
description: Less than a week after Detroit filed its $18 billion federal bankruptcy case, the capital of Pennsylvania said it had found a way to restructure crushing debts without a costly and contentious trip to bankruptcy court.

title: The Political Endangered Species List
description: On Election Day 2012, Patrick Murphy emerged as a liberal hero. The 29-year-old political novice, a Democrat, defeated Allen West, the notorious Republican Congressman from Florida who once described President Obama as a low-level socialist agitator, before suggesting on another occasion that his supporters were a threat to the gene pool.

title: Madison Square Garden Is Told to Move
description: Madison Square Garden, home to the Knicks, the Rangers, the Ice Capades, the circus and the Fight of the Century between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier in 1971, received an eviction notice of sorts on Wednesday.

title: Trader and S.E.C. Lawyer Spar Over E-Mail
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission waited more than three years to have a chance to shred the credibility of Fabrice P. Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader, in front of a jury. It finally got its chance on Wednesday.

title: Police Take On Family Violence to Avert Deaths
description: As the number of homicides in New York has reached historically low levels, the Police Department has intensified its efforts to combat a particularly stubborn and daunting source of murders: domestic violence.

title: New Support for Military in Sex Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Senates leading Democrat on military issues released two letters from the Pentagon on Wednesday to argue that allowing military commanders to retain their authority over sexual assault cases will protect victims and battle what has been described as a scourge of sexual assault across the armed forces.

title: Heres How Jets Can Be Contenders. Hypothetically.
description: The Jets descend again Thursday on Cortland, N.Y., where they were last spotted not knowing what to do with Tim Tebow. Of course, Tebow is gone, and so, too, after a failed experiment in a failed season, are the general manager, the 3 coordinators, 7 other coaches and 10 starters, including the best cover cornerback in the league.

title: Scores Reported Dead as Train Derails in Spain
description: A high-speed passenger train that was reportedly traveling at more than double the speed limit derailed just outside a station in northwest Spain on Wednesday evening, killing at least 60 of those on board, according to local news reports.

title: Letter From Ethiopias Gulag
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  I AM jailed, with around 200 other inmates, in a wide hall that looks like a warehouse. For all of us, there are only three toilets. Most of the inmates sleep on the floor, which has never been swept. About 1,000 prisoners share the small open space here at Kaliti Prison. One can guess our fate if a communicable disease breaks out.

title: Justices on the Job
description: After Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. took his seat on the Supreme Court in January 2006, replacing Justice Sandra Day OConnor, the court for the first time in its history was composed entirely of former federal appeals court judges. Justice Elena Kagans arrival in 2010 changed that; the former Harvard Law School dean had never been a judge. But the concentration of former judges is striking and, as Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. described it late last month, an historical anomaly.

title: Windsors Versus Weiner
description: I am beginning to think a royal family might come in handy.

title: Should Queen Elizabeth II Step Down?
A Focus on Age Discrimination in the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Tech, High-Risk Forensics
description: SAN FRANCISCO  WHEN the police arrived last November at the ransacked mansion of the millionaire investor Raveesh Kumra, outside of San Jose, Calif., they found Mr. Kumra had been blindfolded, tied and gagged. The robbers took cash, rare coins and ultimately Mr. Kumras life; he died at the scene, suffocated by the packaging tape used to stifle his screams. A forensics team found DNA on his fingernails that belonged to an unknown person, presumably one of the assailants. The sample was put into a DNA database and turned up a hit  a local man by the name of Lukis Anderson.

Treating Fistula

description: To the Editor:
