description: Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, the embattled president of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, will depart her post at the end of the month, the academy announced on Thursday.

title: Running on Illegal Fuel and Savage Zeal
description: Drug War, Johnnie Tos ferocious crime story, opens with bilious green smoke darkening the sky and ends with a tsunami of blood spilling onto the ground. The green billows out of an illegal meth lab that has exploded while the red pours from the dead and the dying who, throughout this excitingly directed movie, have chased one another as if to the ends of the earth. If the green smoke suggested go, the blood can only mean one thing: stop, which, taken with the surrounding human wreckage, serves as an unmistakably fierce authorial commentary.

title: This Weeks Movies: July 26, 2013
description: The New York Times movie critics on Blue Jasmine, The Wolverine and The To Do List.

title: Obama, at Florida Port, Vows to Speed Shipping and Transit Projects
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  President Obama vowed on Thursday to use his executive powers to bypass bottlenecks in Congress and accelerate infrastructure projects to bolster growth and add jobs.

title: Those Female Astronauts, Always Being Impregnated by Aliens
description: It may be time for everyone to agree that if youve seen one trapped-in-space-with-an-alien-presence movie, youve seen them all.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,237 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Angst-Ridden Artist on a Mysterious Mission
description: An exhaustingly pretentious heave of artistic self-involvement, The Time Being takes an exceptionally handsome journey to nowhere at all.

title: Halliburton Pleads Guilty to Destroying Evidence After Gulf Spill
description: HOUSTON  Halliburton has agreed to plead guilty to destruction of critical evidence after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill in 2010, the Justice Department announced on Thursday.

title: Hes Just a Cave Man in a Modern World
description: Neandertal is a valley in Germany. That meager fact is a spoiler for Neander-Jin: The Return of the Neanderthal Man, because there is virtually nothing else of value to be gained from watching this film.

title: Loss That Lingers, in Memory and Place
description: Human behavior isnt the French conceptual artist Sophie Calles only source of inspiration. In 1990, when she was in Boston for a show of her work at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Ms. Calle visited the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum. It was then that I fell in love with The Concert, she said of Vermeers celebrated canvas from 1658-60 that depicts two women and a man engaged in an at-home musicale. Every time I had a meeting I would make it in front of that painting so I could see it again, she recalled.

title: In Cambodia, Shifting Allegiances Shape a Tougher Than Usual Election
description: ANLONG VENG, Cambodia  A decade and a half after the last remnants of the Khmer Rouge capitulated in this northwestern town, the streets are festooned with images of their erstwhile enemy, Prime Minister Hun Sen, who is seeking to prolong his 28 years in power in an election on Sunday.

title: Rich American Girl Meets Poor Peruvian Boy
description: Tourism is not simple. You can say that again, and put a dissertation behind it, when wealthy traveling Americans engage with subsistence economies. In Postales, a searching and human film directed by Josh Hyde and set in Cuzco, Peru, one grim-faced local woman commodifies herself by donning traditional colorful clothes, pulling a llama along and posing for pictures outside expensive hotels. The cameras snap away. As she says, its her job.

title: Vassar Revives Garden Nurtured by Early Promoter of Native Plants
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.  On a still summer day, a day so warm that even the song sparrows and dragonflies seemed listless, Guillermo Valdez and Will Blum, who are juniors at Vassar College, tugged at the roots of porcelain berry and honeysuckle plants. Sweat trickling down their necks, they were on a mission to expel the invasive vines from a patch of campus that is better known to birders in the area than students, and replace them with native species like marsh marigolds, swamp azaleas and cinnamon ferns.

title: A Label Mr. Dolce and Mr. Gabbana Dont Like
description: MILAN  In Italy, where burlesque public anger can be its own form of fashion statement, the designers behind the Dolce & Gabbana label made their reaction to an insult high art.

title: Taliban Seize Police Force in a Hamlet
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The few hundred people of Kala Khel, a village in southern Afghanistan, on Thursday got some of the best news they had heard all year: the entire Afghan Local Police unit posted to the hamlet had disappeared the night before, apparently betrayed by two of their own and abducted by the Taliban.

title: Something Unpleasant Behind Enemy Lines
description: With a movie called Frankensteins Army, youd have every reason to expect a generous serving of cheese along with abundant helpings of gore and gunplay. And you certainly get it in this frenetic found-footage horror film set in the German countryside in 1945.

title: A Relentless Prosecutors Crowning Case
description: In recent years, Preet Bharara has prosecuted members of the powerful Latin Kings gang in Newburgh, N.Y., exposed corrupt state politicians and convicted terrorists.

title: Joking About Murder Can Have Consequences
description: Jamie Babbits golden-hued noir, Breaking the Girls, takes inspiration from Hitchcocks psychological thriller Strangers on a Train (itself based on Patricia Highsmiths novel) and updates it for the texting, its-all-about-me generation. But this film goes further, turning the tale into an erotic thriller with too many twists and back stories to count.

title: Concussion Study Makes Case for Reducing Contact Drills for Youth Players
description: Youth football players are not more vulnerable to head hits in games if they take part in fewer contact drills during practices, a new study published in the Annals of Biomedical Engineering showed.

title: Septuagenarian Strut
description: Just look at them: the graybeards and grannies smoking pot, the bodies tugged by gravity and wretched excess, all that late-age libido and feeble jump-stepping enabled by Viagra and Lipitor. Baby boomers  a stadium full of them. Is there anything worse?

title: Underwater Dream, Stymied by Drugs
description: The problems of three little people amount to even less than a hill of beans in Red Tide, a tortured-siblings movie set in a depressed town on the west coast of Florida.

title: Wall Streets Exposure to Hacking Laid Bare
description: The indictment on Thursday of a long-running hacking ring is kindling fears that rogue programmers are going beyond theft and developing the capacity to wreak havoc on the broader financial system.

title: Chinese Search for Infant Formula Goes Global
description: HONG KONG  The group of 40 mainland Chinese tourists made all the requisite shopping purchases on a recent trip to Europe: silk scarves, Swiss watches, Louis Vuitton handbags.

title: Theyll Follow Their Pal to the Bitter, Senseless End
description: The English heist movie has a history of being cheeky. From The Italian Job (1969) through Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1999), a cool, brazen wit and stylized violence mark some of the best examples of complicated robbery scenarios in British cinema. Rowan Athale does not ignore that inheritance with his dense debut feature, Wasteland.

title: Defense Tries to Show Sympathetic Side of Ex-Trader
description: Fabrice Tourre has been painted by the Securities and Exchange Commission as one of the great villains of the financial crisis, a smart Goldman trader who duped unsuspecting investors into buying toxic real estate securities he knew were doomed to fail.

title: Behind Death Sentence, Inmates Prison Conduct
description: When a defense lawyer pleaded with a federal jury in Brooklyn this week to impose a life sentence on his client, Ronell Wilson, who had killed two undercover detectives, he argued that prison would not be painless for Mr. Wilson.

title: In Boston, Violence Is Backdrop to Bulger Trial
description: BOSTON  As the trial of the crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger continues in federal court here, a rash of violence visited his home neighborhood on Tuesday. It was a rare reminder of the terror that gripped the streets of South Boston during Mr. Bulgers reign in the 1970s and 80s  although this time the neighborhood found itself petrified not by the calculated nature of many of Mr. Bulgers alleged crimes, but by a fear of the apparent randomness of the violence.

title: U.S. Prison Populations Decline, Reflecting New Approach to Crime
description: The prison population in the United States dropped in 2012 for the third consecutive year, according to federal statistics released on Thursday, in what criminal justice experts said was the biggest decline in the nations recent history, signaling a shift away from an almost four-decade policy of mass imprisonment.

title: Under Code, Apps Would Disclose Collection of Data
description: Like food packages that display nutrition labels, some mobile apps could soon display information that allows consumers to decide at a glance whether the apps are good for them.

title: Californians Consider a Future Without a Nuclear Plant for a Neighbor
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.  Residents of this quiet Orange County beach community often all but forgot about the hulking nuclear plant just south of the city limits.

title: Fast Food, Low Pay
description: Last November, following the Black Friday protests by Walmart employees, 200 workers at 30 New York fast-food restaurants walked off their jobs.

title: Wilfork Says Hernandez Case Will Test Patriots Chemistry
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The Patriots followed the example set the day before by their head coach. They talked about the sadness of a lost life. They talked about the need to move forward. The team captains Tom Brady and Vince Wilfork did not mention the full name of their former teammate Aaron Hernandez  the only topic of conversation when they addressed the news media on Thursday.

title: European Court Says Russia Did Not Persecute Ex-Tycoon
description: MOSCOW  The European Court of Human Rights ruled Thursday that Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former oil tycoon imprisoned in Russia, had not been a victim of political persecution when he was prosecuted for tax evasion and fraud in 2005.

title: SAC Case Threatens a Wall St. Cash Cow
description: Wall Street now has to contemplate life without SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund that manages billions of dollars.

title: Meals With a Century-Old View
description: A great steak knife is a wonderful thing, and Restaurant 1915 at the Bear Mountain Inn provides a terrific one. Heavy and sharp, it has a stylized bark-like design that fits right in with the Adirondack aesthetic.

title: A Faustian Pact: Generals as Democrats
description: WASHINGTON  THE luxurious officers club of Egypts elite Republican Guard sits near downtown Cairo, its pool and patios surrounded by high walls with reliefs and paintings lauding Egypts military history, going back to the pharaohs. Where a huge poster of the deposed president Hosni Mubarak once stood, a new one declares: The Army. The People. One Hand.

title: Hopes for a Fish Revival as a Dam Is Demolished
description: EDDINGTON, Me.  There is a bend in the Penobscot River here, embanked by an Indian burial ground, through which millions of fish used to make a strenuous journey upstream to spawn before returning to the sea. There were elegant Atlantic salmon, prehistoric-looking sturgeon and, most numerous of all, lowly river herring, a nutrient-rich forage fish prized by ground fish, bears and birds.

title: Come See Detroit, Americas Future
description: DETROIT  I KNOW an old woman who hasnt opened her windows in a decade, afraid that whats outside will climb inside. Inside, there is the stale odor of dead air.

title: Republican Health Care Panic
description: Leading Republicans appear to be nerving themselves up for another round of attempted fiscal blackmail. With the end of the fiscal year looming, they arent offering the kinds of compromises that might produce a deal and avoid a government shutdown; instead, theyre drafting extremist legislation  bills that would, for example, cut clean-water grants by 83 percent  that has no chance of becoming law. Furthermore, theyre threatening, once again, to block any rise in the debt ceiling, a move that would damage the U.S. economy and possibly provoke a world financial crisis.

title: Juror Says Zimmerman Got Away With Murder
description: MIAMI  A juror who said she initially wanted to convict George Zimmerman told ABC News on Thursday that he got away with murder in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin, an unarmed black teenager.

title: A Bipartisan Warning on Surveillance
description: Lawmakers have given the Obama administration a bipartisan warning: patience is growing thin with its expansive and unwarranted surveillance of Americans.

title: Inching Forward in the Mideast
description: The week that Secretary of State John Kerry said could start the revival of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks is passing without visible progress. The naysayers are chortling, but Mr. Kerry, to his credit, is undeterred. His aides insist that plans to resume the dialogue on a two-state solution that collapsed in 2010 are on track; on Thursday, an Israeli minister said that talks could begin next week.

title: The Gun Lobby Takes Vengeful Aim
description: One welcome surprise in gun safety occurred this year in Colorado, where the Democratic-led Legislature dared to defy the gun lobby and mandated universal background checks on firearm sales and 15-round limits on ammunition magazines.

title: Bait and Switch in the House
description: There is a bill in the House being pushed by the majority leader, Eric Cantor, and many of his Republican colleagues that sounds as innocent and upright as motherhood and apple pie: the Kids First Research Act of 2013. It promises more money for pediatric medical research at the National Institutes of Health.

title: A Chinese Demand for Foreign Formula
description: A tainted baby formula scandal in 2008 has Chinese parents obsessed with buying foreign-made milk powder.

title: Spy Agencies Under Heaviest Scrutiny Since Abuse Scandal of the 70s
description: American intelligence agencies, which experienced a boom in financing and public support in the decade after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, have entered a period of broad public scrutiny and skepticism with few precedents since the exposure of spying secrets and abuses led to the historic investigation by the Senates Church Committee nearly four decades ago.

title: Amid Hospitals Turmoil, a Lost Man Disappears
description: It began as the odd case of an elderly man found wandering by the side of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in June, carrying plenty of cash, a bus ticket, a baseball cap and papers attesting to his name. He seemed well kept, even healthy  apart from the fact that he could not say where, or who, he was.

title: Taken Before Harvey, Pitcher Faces an Uphill Struggle
description: ROUND ROCK, Tex.  The very moment he was drafted, in 2010, Barret Loux was buried. His team, Texas A&M, was waiting out a rain delay at an N.C.A.A. regional game in Miami, and had gathered in the weight room to watch the draft on TV.

title: Robertss Picks Reshaping Secret Surveillance Court
description: WASHINGTON  The recent leaks about government spying programs have focused attention on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court and its role in deciding how intrusive the government can be in the name of national security. Less mentioned has been the person who has been quietly reshaping the secret court: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 26, 2013
description: This is the beginning of the end of mass incarceration.

title: Lottery Numbers
Plane Landed at La Guardia Nose Gear First
description: The Southwest Airlines flight whose ill-fated landing at La Guardia Airport this week left at least 11 people with injuries hit the tarmac with its nose gear first, federal investigators said on Thursday, raising questions about the aircrafts final moments above ground.

title: Soriano Appears Headed Back to Yankees in a Trade
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Nine years after he was traded by the Yankees to the Texas Rangers for Alex Rodriguez, Alfonso Soriano appears headed back to the Bronx, while the injured Rodriguez languishes in Tampa, Fla.

title: Corrections: July 26, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Killer Notes, Low or High
description: In one sense theres little mystery surrounding the question of who pulled the fatal trigger in the new musical Murder for Two, which opened on Thursday night at the McGinn/Cazale Theater as part of Second Stage Theaters Uptown series. Only two actors are in the show, and one plays the police officer investigating the crime. So it doesnt take a Hercule Poirot, a Miss Marple or a Jackson Brodie (my current fave, from Kate Atkinsons wonderful books) to conclude that the culprit is definitely the lanky, bald fellow with popping eyes and pinwheeling limbs.

title: Dropped a Line
description: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert!: LOLLAPUZZOOLA is the best summertime crossword tournament held annually on a Saturday in August. Enjoy a full day of tournament puzzling  six original crosswords never published anywhere else, constructed by some of the best puzzlemakers in the solar system. There are separate skill divisions for superpro solvers and normal Earthlings, a unique Pairs Division if youd like to solve with a friend, and our famous At-Home Division for those who cant make it to NYC. They also have a one-of-a-kind Google Ticket system for players who need a little help along the way, an assortment of snacks and beverages, and for just an extra five bucks, you can stay for the fourth annual Ryan Hecht Pizza Social. $25 to pre-register for the whole day, $10 for the At-Home Division. Join co-hosts Brian Cimmet and Patrick Blindauer for a casual yet competitive tournament experience you wont find anywhere else. Visit bemoresmarter.com for more information.

title: Changing Makeup of Surveillance Courts
description: The chief justice of the United States picks sitting judges to serve extra duty on the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, as well as on a small review panel that hears any appeals from its decisions.

title: Batik Store, a Vestige of the Hippie Era, Will Fade Away
description: In the hippie-altered world in which Nancy Cogen plunked down her store 41 years ago, batik cloth was still an offbeat novelty.

title: A Continent Mired in Crisis Coins a Language of Economic Pain
description: MADRID  The Portuguese have a new word, grandolar, which grew out of the euro crisis and means to subject a government minister to a singing protest using a revolutionary hymn. But now, after three years of austerity, even Portuguese children grandolate their parents if they do not want to take a bath.

title: Samsungs Profit Rises, but So Does the Competition
description: TOKYO  Samsung Electronics, the worlds largest maker of smartphones, said on Friday that it expected competition to increase, even as it reported a 50 percent rise in profit for the second quarter.

title: Remade Jets Open Camp and Practice Restraint
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Unlike, say, Braylon Edwards, who appeared wearing a T-shirt that read, Sit Down and Learn From the Master, Geno Smith favored a decidedly more understated arrival to Jets training camp Thursday. He did not declare himself the favorite in the Great Quarterback Competition of 2013. He did not demand a timetable for an announcement.

title: Brooklyn Restaurateur Dies, Apparently a Suicide
description: Before everyone started flocking to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Colin Devlin was giving people a reason to do so  through his restaurants, first DuMont, and later Dressler.

title: Return of the Stingy Oddsmaker: A Response
description: This is a response by the author to readers of his recent post for The Stone, Nothing to See Here: Demoting the Uncertainty Principle.

title: Brooklyn Ink
description: Smith Street Tattoo Parlour in Carroll Gardens has become a popular tourist destination for those seeking New York-style tattoos.

title: Aid to Egypt Can Keep Flowing, Despite Overthrow, White House Decides
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has concluded it is not legally required to determine whether the Egyptian military engineered a coup dtat in ousting President Mohamed Morsi, a senior administration official said Thursday, a finding that will allow it to continue to funnel $1.5 billion in American aid to Egypt each year.

title: Lawmakers, Facing Pressure on Surveillance, Focus on Privacy
description: WASHINGTON  Facing rising pressure to limit government surveillance programs and provide more information about them, leaders of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees have begun negotiating new safeguards and privacy restrictions that they hope to turn into legislation in September, lawmakers said Thursday.

title: Touring Slum in Rio, Pope Urges Young to Fight Against Corruption
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Pope Francis on Thursday delivered some of his most politically provocative remarks since his papacy began this year, hopping from his popemobile to walk through a slum in this city before urging young people to fight against corruption, a leading grievance behind the huge street protests that shook dozens of Brazilian cities in June.

title: Science Lowers Shattering Risk at Home Plate
description: Welington Castillo smashed a double for the Chicago Cubs late in a game in the 2010 season, his bat exploding on impact with the ball. A long shard of wood flew at a teammate, Tyler Colvin, sprinting home from third base, impaling him a few inches from his heart. Though Colvin scored, his season was over.

title: Hamas Closes News Media Outlets
description: GAZA  Hamas, the Islamist militant group controlling the Gaza Strip, closed news media offices and a television production company on Thursday for what it called the spreading of false reports and working for Israeli television.

title: In Los Angeles Art Museum Arrival, a Foreshadowing of a Departure
description: When Jeffrey Deitch was named in 2010 to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, many in the citys art world expressed guarded optimism that he could turn around a museum that had come close to foundering only two years earlier.

title: Obama and Vietnams Leader Pledge Deeper Ties
description: WASHINGTON  Bearing a copy of a letter from Ho Chi Minh to Harry S. Truman, the president of Vietnam met President Obama on Thursday and pledged to deepen trade and military ties with the United States even as they tangled over human rights.

title: The Battle for the Fed
description: President Obama is nearing a decision on who should lead the Federal Reserve for the next four years.

title: HPV Vaccine Not Reaching Enough Girls, C.D.C. Says
description: The very low vaccination rate for teenage girls against the human papillomavirus  the most common sexually transmitted infection and a principal cause of cervical cancer  did not improve at all from 2011 to 2012, and health officials on Thursday said a survey found that doctors were often failing to bring it up or recommend it when girls came in for other reasons.

title: California: Outcry Against Mayor Grows
description: Four more women said Thursday that they had been subject to unwanted sexual advances by Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego, as the San Diego County Democratic Party joined the chorus of Democrats demanding his resignation. The women  who include a dean at San Diego State University and a retired Navy rear admiral  made their accusations in interviews with KPBS News. A total of seven women have said they were mistreated by the mayor. Despite crumbling support, Mr. Filner has said he would not step down. He has acknowledged inappropriate behavior but has said he is not guilty of sexual harassment.

title: Growth From the Middle Out, and How It Works
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: Knicks Re-Sign Martin to a One-Year Deal
description: The Knicks re-signed Kenyon Martin to a one-year deal. Martin, a tough, reliable forward throughout his 13-year career, will make about $1.4 million next year on a veterans minimum contract, which was all the over-the-salary-cap Knicks could offer him. The move gives the Knicks more frontcourt depth behind Tyson Chandler and Andrea Bargnani.

title: Activision in $8.2 Billion Deal to Buy Back Stake From Vivendi
description: Activision Blizzard, the worlds biggest video game publisher, has a reached an $8.2 billion deal to separate from Vivendi and become an independent company.

title: U.N. Troubled by Australias New Policy on Asylum Seekers
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The United Nations said Friday that it was troubled by Australias new policy to stem the tide of people undertaking dangerous boat journeys to seek asylum there, the latest in a series of public criticisms of the governments tough new deterrence-based approach.

title: The Crack of the Bat Is Changing Again
description: Major League Baseball and the Forest Service partnered to determine how maple bats could be made less likely to shatter.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) DANCING AT JACOBS PILLOW: NEVER STAND STILL Bill T. Jones narrates this history of Jacobs Pillow, the dance center founded in the 1930s by the choreographer Ted Shawn on a farm in the Berkshires in western Massachusetts, and its storied annual festival. The films director, Ron Honsa, intersperses performances by the likes of Chunky Move, Shantala Shivalingappa, and, above, Kellye Saunders with interviews with Suzanne Farrell, Bill Irwin, Rasta Thomas, Frederic Franklin, Mark Morris, Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Judith Jamison and Nikolaj Hubbe. The dances themselves are entertaining, and the cameras occasionally catch that electrifying moment just before a performer heads onstage, David DeWitt wrote in The New York Times about this film, now a Great Performances presentation. The rehearsals let the viewers play spy. Still, he said, this film has the everyday vibe of a bunch of friends putting together a summer camp video. Gosh, the substance of Jacobs Pillow should be a little less sleepy.

title: Video of San Diego Mayor Announcing His Plans to Undergo Therapy
description: Updated | 5:54 p.m. Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego announced on Friday that he would take a leave of absence and attend a two-week behavior clinic in response to a growing chorus of people calling for his resignation amid allegations that he made unwanted sexual advances toward women.

title: Christie Assails Libertarian Shift on National Security by Some in the G.O.P.
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Conservatives have many reasons to be suspicious of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey. He embraced President Obama after Hurricane Sandy in the final days of the 2012 race. He is a Northeasterner in a Southern-dominated party. And he has taken positions on issues like guns that unsettle the political right.

title: Iran Is Said to Want Direct Talks With U.S. on Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq told the Obama administration this month that Iran was interested in direct talks with the United States on Irans nuclear program, and said that Iraq was prepared to facilitate the negotiations, Western officials said Thursday.

title: North Korean Leader Supports Resumption of Nuclear Talks, State Media Say
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, used his meeting with the visiting vice president of China this week to stress a blood alliance with Beijing, and expressed his support for reconvening six-nation talks on ending the Norths nuclear weapons program, the official news media of the two allies reported on Friday.

title: Indias Opposition Parties Stay Together Despite Differences Over Modi
description: Uddhav Thackeray, the Shiv Sena executive president, announced last Friday that his party would support the Bharatiya Janata Party in the national elections scheduled for next year. But his support was tempered by his next remark. The country needs a strong government and a credible leader, but I cant see anyone who fits that description, Mr. Thackeray told reporters.

title: Ode to a Polish River
description: When Mikolaj Nowacki calls Polands Odra the river of history, he might as well be talking about his own life. Having grown up along the river, which is also known as the Oder, even its damp smells linger in his memory. After originally pursuing a doctorate in space law, he turned his back on that profession to become a newspaper photographer. Two years ago, he was accepted into the mentor program at VII Photo, where he has been working with Antonin Kratochvil. Mr. Kratochvil taught him his most important lesson yet: Theres only one way, and its your way.

title: Egypt Military Flexes Muscle Against Morsi Amid Rallies
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian military stepped up its campaign against the Muslim Brotherhood on Friday, as officials announced the possibility of serious criminal charges carrying the death penalty against the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and hopes faded for any sort of political accommodation with the Islamist group.

title: New York Today: The Beat Goes On
description: The thud, thud, thud of an American Indian powwow drum will boom from Queens on Friday night and all weekend.

title: China Details Allegations Against Glaxo
description: SHANGHAI  The Chinese government released more details on Friday about its accusations involving GlaxoSmithKline, which has been rocked in recent weeks by a bribery and corruption scandal at its unit in China.

title: Profit at Nomura Surges on Rally in Japanese Markets
description: HONG KONG Nomura is riding high on Abenomics.

title: The One-Page Magazine
description: THE BIG PROFILE

title: Who Made That Loofah Mitt?
Mireille Enos: The Killing  Star Avoids the Police-Procedural Trap
description: You tend toward serious roles, like the detective Sarah Linden in The Killing, which is about to conclude its third season on AMC. Do you have any desire to do something lighter?  For three years, everything Ive done has been heartbreaking. Im ready to do something that my daughter can see before shes 18.

title: My Fictional Grandparents
description: My mother was abandoned in a French orphanage in Fez in 1941. That year in Morocco, hundreds of people died in an outbreak of the plague; her parents were among the victims. Actually, no, they died in a horrific car crash on the newly built road from Marrakesh to Fez. No, no, no, my grandmother died in childbirth, and my grandfather, mad with grief, gave the baby away. The truth is: I dont know how my mother ended up in a French orphanage in 1941. The nuns in black habits never told.

title: The 7.14.13 Issue
Its More Like a Suicide Than a Sport
description: A minute before he died, Herv le Gallou stood at the edge of a cliff at Obiou, in the French Alps, with acres of thin air before him. The view that morning, June 23, 2012, was breathtaking: moonscape cliff faces, pocked with snow, that gave way to plateaus of pale grass and ashen rock, then to bottle-green pine forests in the valley below and to mountains beyond.

title: From Roving to Riches, a 44-Year Journey Together
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: E-Commerce Company Learns to Sell Directly on Facebook
description: Ashley White started her company, the Polkadot Alley, to supplement her full-time income as a high school teacher. By 2009, she had a modest profit and a new baby, which led her to quit her teaching job in Lubbock, Tex. After she got pregnant again in 2011, Ms. White found herself constantly on Facebook searching for vendors that sold baby clothes, and thats when she got the idea to turn her e-commerce Web site,which sells womens clothing and accessories, into a Facebook store.

title: What Abe Did Next
description: For Prime Minister Abe of Japan the show must go on.

title: Chipping Away at the Smartphone Leaders
description: TOKYO  As Samsung Electronics and Apple continue to slug it out across the globe for domination of the smartphone market, the South Korean maker continues to edge out the California company.

title: Summer Reading Contest | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In The Times this week: An article and interactive graphic showed that where in the United States a child is raised affects his or her odds of rising to another income level.

title: Criminal Charges Against SAC
description: SAC IS CALLED A MAGNET FOR CHEATING | Federal authorities delivered a crippling blow to SAC Capital Advisors on Thursday, announcing criminal charges against the hedge fund that could threaten its survival, DealBooks Peter Lattman and Ben Protess report. Calling SAC a veritable magnet of market cheaters, the authorities argued that the firm and its units permitted a systematic insider trading scheme to unfold from 1999 to 2010, generating hundreds of millions of dollars in profit for the firm, owned by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen.

title: Failure in Bollywood
description: The tragic suicide of the Bollywood actress Jiah Khan in June got me thinking about my own short-lived foray into Bollywood. I was 22 years old and tired of my first desk job as a research analyst at a small corporate ratings company in New York City. I decided to take some time away from the United States and was traveling through India when I decided I wanted to be a Bollywood star.

title: Japanese Minister Proposes More Active Military Presence in Region
description: TOKYO  Japan is considering the acquisition of offensive weapons and surveillance drones and will assume a more active role in regional security, the countrys defense minister said Friday, providing an early glimpse of ways the new conservative government could lead the nation farther than ever from its postwar pacifism.

title: Dont Mind Us. Well Just Watch.
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  The set here on Stage 9 at Sony Pictures Studios was a near-perfect duplicate of a suburban American home of the 1950s, with a vintage refrigerator in the kitchen and a stone fireplace in the living room, where a wife clad in a coat and housedress put down her bag of groceries and placed her arms around her hardworking husband at the end of a long day.

title: Daily Report: Proposing a Nutrition Label for Mobile Apps
description: Like food packages that display nutrition labels, some mobile apps could soon display information that allows consumers to decide at a glance whether the apps are good for them, Natasha Singer reports.

title: Steven Soderbergh Will Direct New Cinemax Series The Knick
description: If self-proclaimed retiree Steven Soderbergh continues to work any harder hes going to put himself in the hospital, which maybe was his plan all along. For his latest project since a series of declarations that he was at least stepping away from feature filmmaking, Mr. Soderbergh, the Academy Award-winning director of films like Traffic and Side Effects and a newly minted Emmy nominee for Behind the Candelabra, will direct the first 10-episode season of a new Cinemax series called The Knick, set in a New York hospital in the year 1900.

title: Black Boxes Found and Driver Arrested in Spanish Train Crash
description: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA, Spain  A veteran train driver with a zest for speed was arrested in his hospital room in northwest Spain where investigators are trying to determine whether reckless behavior caused a train wreck that left dozens of passengers dead, the authorities said Friday.

title: The Littlest Stake Holder
description: Everybodys talking about the wife.

title: New Cabby Needs Better Map
description: Dear Diary:

title: European Regulator Finds Little Risk in Diabetes Drugs
description: Regulators in Europe have concluded that there is little evidence that widely used drugs to treat Type 2 diabetes could cause pancreatic inflammation or pancreatic cancer, a finding that might reassure patients while also removing a potential sales threat for Merck and some other drug companies.

title: A Farce in Many, Many Acts
description: Its good to know that heading into a nice summer weekend, we can take comfort in the Yankees-Alex Rodriguez melodrama settling back into its usual level of farcical entertainment, the kind were used to in summer reruns. Thats after the two combatants took a deep breath and realized they are stuck with each other, so lets have a nice, smooth-everything-over teleconference, which included Rodriguezs lawyer, because dont all discussions of thigh injuries involve a lawyer?

title: Things Fell Apart
description: Ezra Klein has a good piece urging journalists to stop talking about the center  unless they first explain what they mean, which in practice would mean acknowledging that what they call the center isnt at the center of anything, except maybe the prejudices of a self-referential elite.

title: Confessions of a Mother Who Couldnt Say No
description: When my first child was an infant, the doula handed me an article that championed benign neglect. Children, the article proposed, need to be left to their own devices to work things out. Parental intervention at every little grunt discourages resilience. This made sense, so I tried. Really hard. At least until I thought the baby needed me. And then I picked that baby up.

title: Memories of 1998
description: As The War of the Fed Succession heats up, I thought it might be of some interest to recall this incident.

title: F.D.A. Says Importers Must Audit Food Safety
description: WASHINGTON  More than two years after Congress passed a landmark law meant to prevent the importation of contaminated food that sickens Americans, the Food and Drug Administration proposed rules on Friday that for the first time put the main onus on companies to police the food they import.

title: Urban Apartheid in Vietnam
description: HO CHI MINH CITY  When I returned to this city from the United States last year, I paid $25 a month to live in a single room among several that lined a fetid, often flooded alley. The row of low-slung rentals with their squat toilets and rotting walls lay on the industrial outskirts of town. But I put up with it to live near a relative whod come down from central Vietnam. I joined his circle of friends in the alley, most of whom had bonded together over their shared status as out-of-towners looking for jobs.

title: A Start-Up Aims to Bring Financial Planning to the Masses
description: Its an unfortunate fact: the people who are most in need of honest financial advice often cannot afford it, or they dont realize that their so-called adviser isnt an adviser at all, but a salesman.

title: Larry Kramer and David Webster
description: William David Webster and Larry Kramer were married Wednesday in New York. Eve M. Preminger, a retired Surrogate Court judge in New York, officiated at NYU Langone Medical Center, where Mr. Kramer was recovering from surgery.

title: Beijings Play for Porn
description: SHANGHAI  When it comes to pornography, the Chinese government is guilty of naked hypocrisy.

title: Video Reviews of Blue Jasmine, The Wolverine and The To Do List
description: In this weeks video, Times critics offer their takes on Blue Jasmine, The Wolverine and The To Do List. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Pearson Puts Mergermarket Up for Sale
description: The British publishing and education company Pearson said on Friday that it was seeking to sell Mergermarket, its deal news and data service.

title: Boost or Bust? Family Ties and the Rise of Young Drivers
description: At a touring car race two weeks ago in Germany, the winner, Matthias Ekstrom, was celebrating his victory with his team and colleagues when his father emptied a bottle of water into the pocket of his sons racing pants.

title: July 26: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Holder Letter to Russian Justice Minister About Snowden
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. assured Russia that Edward Snowden would not face the death penalty if returned to the United States.

title: Off the Charts: Ireland May Have Hit Bottom
description: Home prices rose in Ireland over the most recent 12 months, the first such gain since early 2008. Consumer expectations have climbed to the highest level since 2007. And even home-building activity may have hit bottom and started to recover.

title: Conductor, Recovering From Concussion, Is Still Scheduled for Lohengrin at Bayreuth
description: Andris Nelsons, the music director designate of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who was hospitalized last weekend in Bayreuth with what was described as a severe concussion, has been released and is continuing his recovery at his home in Bayreuth, the orchestra said on Thursday.

title: Market Report | These Pieces Are Not in Kansas Anymore
description: Girly ginghams and ruby red accessories have gone well together since Dorothy was swept off by the cyclone. But this season designers, perhaps inspired by last winters Oz prequel, have brought back the glam-picnic aesthetic in a big way. Prada updated the classic check pattern with a slim-line sheath and oversize buttons, while Opening Ceremony used it to adorn its cat-eye sunglasses. Meanwhile, Valentino released a pair of sparkly pumps that will surely make you want to click your heels together.

title: Image of the Day: July 26
36 Hours in the Hudson Valley, New York
description: The Hudson Valley is vast and varied. With hundreds of miles of sandstone and granite cliffs, cattail-lined riverbanks, former factory towns, orchards, farmland and forests, the scale of its geography and the scope of its history are daunting. To spend a weekend dropping into its musty bookstores and sizable art institutions or idling between hilltop castles, divey small-town bars and doily B&Bs is like skipping a stone into a river: you bounce along, but barely break the surface. From New York City, its a one-hour train trip to Peekskill, at the doorstep of the mid-Hudson Valley, but the region can be fully explored only on the kind of road trip that skirts one side of the river and winds down the other, hopscotchingbetween historic estates and detouring for farm stands, roadside diners and seductive swimming holes.

title: Hudson Valley Views
description: In this area north of New York City, the rural mixes with the refined.

title: Fed Chairmans Departure Casts a New Light on the Bush Legacy
description: WASHINGTON  George W. Bush hopes historians will judge his presidency more kindly than his contemporaries have, but a transition coming later this year  the departure of Chairman Ben S. Bernanke of the Federal Reserve after an eight-year tenure  already casts a different light on the 43rd presidents economic record.

title: Tending Vertical Gardens
description: Kari Katzander cradled a gray mesh pouch in the palm of her hand, examining the pale-green shoots that poked out of the clump of soil inside. She plucked a dead leaf, and dabbed at the soil to see if it was moist, a sign that the irrigation system that fed the pouch was ticking along properly. Then she reinserted the pouch into the stainless-steel grid that climbed the brick wall of the garden behind a Chelsea town house, there to join hundreds of fellow pouches.

title: Carrying On
description: In September 1939, a hastily prepared Britain declared war on Germany. A year later, after an air attack on Berlin, Hitler carried out his threat of revenge against the capital of the British Empire. The blitz, which would continue until May 1941, had begun.

title: Better Late Than Never. Sometimes.
description: The author Vikram Seth is in hot water for missing a deadline for a sequel to his 1993 novel A Suitable Boy, for which he received a $1.7 million advance. One clue for the delay might be found in the previous books length: some 1,350 pages. If the follow-up approaches that girth, the need for a bit more time sounds perfectly reasonable.

title: Flight Logs
description: Published 60 years ago this fall, Charles Lindberghs autobiography The Spirit of St. Louis was both a commercial and a literary success; it nabbed the 1954 Pulitzer Prize for biography. Indeed, the man known today primarily as the first pilot to fly solo across the Atlantic succeeded in redefining the memoir as we know it. It has, the novelist John P. Marquand observed, a timeless quality and an authentic strength and beauty that should cause it to be read by this generation and by many following  as long, in fact, as anyone is left who cares for fine writing and high courage.

title: Orson and Me
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope for Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Difficult Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Ask Jay Caspian Kang Anything  Today on Reddit
description: At noon today Jay Caspian Kang, an editor at Grantland and the author of Should Reddit Be Blamed for the Spreading of a Smear? in this weekends magazine, will participate in an A.M.A.  Ask Me Anything  on Reddit.Kang will answer your questions about his article, which examines how, in the hours after the Boston Marathon bombings, a rumor initially posted on Reddit about the identity of Suspect No. 2 gained traction in social media and the news. (It turned out to not be true.)

title: U.S. Letter Says Leaker Wont Face Death Penalty
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said in a letter sent to the Russian minister of justice this week that the United States would not seek the death penalty against Edward J. Snowden, and would issue him a passport immediately so he could travel back to the United States.

title: Inside the List
description: A.D.: Reading Zealot, Reza Aslans account of the historical Jesus and his political environment (new at No. 4 on the hardcover nonfiction list), its easy to conclude that Monty Python got a lot right in the 1979 movie Life of Brian, which likewise depicts an ancient Judea rife with messianic cult leaders and Jewish liberation groups intent on overthrowing their Roman occupiers.

title: The Presidents Men
description: Each time an American president sends soldiers, mercenaries, jets or drones to fight abroad, those of us whose historical knowledge or memories reach back to the last century recall when this nation entered into armed conflict the old-fashioned way, by declaring war on an enemy. Americans appear to have an endless appetite for stories about World War II, perhaps because it was the last war declared by Congress and the only war of the 20th century that continues to be viewed sympathetically by a majority of every segment of the population.

title: Count Your Blessings
description: In Sarah Butlers first novel, Ten Things Ive Learnt About Love, lists of 10 are laid down like landing pads between chapters: Ten things I will say to my father, Ten things in my fathers shed, Ten things I thought Id do with my life, Ten places Ive had sex. It may sound like a gimmicky approach  after all, in the world BuzzFeed and Business Insider have wrought, the list has become inescapable, manhandling written communication, making style and linguistic grace seem somehow outdated and effete. Do we really need lists in novels, too?

title: The Descendants
description: Ive always been interested in how we travel through time, David Gilbert says in a conversation included with the publicity materials for his new novel, & Sons. Given that his own authoritative father had once been painfully shy, Gilbert wondered what it would be like to meet ones father in the midst of his awkward adolescence, and therein lay a promising if problematic premise for a novel. But then Gilbert gave this screw a rather broad turn: what if ones father were a really mythical writer along the lines of Salinger, vivid on the page yet impenetrable in the flesh? If one assumes that resembling Salinger entails not only reclusiveness but also rotten parenting skills (in his case, it depends on which child you ask), then the result would be a personage like A. N. Dyer, the impenetrable writer-father at the center of Gilberts novel, who leaves at least one of his sons wondering how a man could be so funny and smart in his work, and yet such a creep in person.

title: It Takes the Village
description: A boy in a world of selfish, crazy, violent, colorful adults  thats how precocious Fin Hadley describes Treasure Island and Manchild in the Promised Land, two books he happens to be reading in Fin & Lady, Cathleen Schines bittersweet elegy for Greenwich Village in the 1960s. Its also a pretty good characterization of Schines vivid comic novel itself, and of the unconventional adventures that Fin (no relation, we are specifically told, to Huck) finds himself living.

title: Gettysburg, Readdressed
description: Scenes from the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg.

title: The Gun Report: July 26, 2013
description: Many times the news clips we peruse for the Gun Report reassure the reader that a shooting victims injuries are non-life-threatening. But living with debilitating injuries can be a pretty awful fate for victims of gun violence.

title: At Lunch With Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Eric McCormack
description: Jesse Tyler Ferguson arrived 10 minutes early for the 1 p.m. reservation at Il Cantinori in Greenwich Village, wearing sunglasses and a porkpie hat, which he quickly removed as he expressed thanks for being invited to lunch. Then, Eric McCormack texted from his car to apologize for running late. Except that he wasnt: he arrived right on time.

title: La Lucha Contina
description: One would think that Latin Americans, after all theyve suffered, from the tortures and terrors of the Spanish Inquisition to the death squads and disappearances of the cold war, would have given up on the idea that history is redeemable. But it seems that centuries of repression and struggle have had the opposite effect, searing into their political culture a kind of irrepressible Hegelianism, an ability both to recognize the dialectic lurking behind the brutality and to answer every bloody body with ever more adamant affirmations of humanity.

title: Threatening Weather
description: In his new memoir, I Hate to Leave This Beautiful Place, Howard Norman writes like a man serenely unconcerned with small matters like whether or not his readers actually keep reading. This is unexpectedly arresting. Were accustomed to memoirists working double time to keep our attention, giving jumped-up accounts of personal disasters while at the same time relentlessly trying to burrow their way into our hearts with lovable, self-deprecating personas. Memoir is a crowded genre, and memoirists too often behave accordingly. Norman  author of the National Book Award finalists The Northern Lights and The Bird Artist, as well as several other novels  writes with zero desperation. He simply plows his field, and if you want to come watch, fine by him.

title: Damaged Warrior
description: The returning military veteran is a firmly established character in American literature. Like most of the fiction that has preceded it, Roxana Robinsons new novel, Sparta, places a young man in this role: Conrad, a Williams graduate who flies back home to the United States after four years in Iraq to face the weird vagaries of his homeland. At only 26, he sees American life with new eyes  or are they old eyes, those of a damaged warrior?

title: Bubbling to the Surface
description: In her previous novels, Maggie OFarrell has often measured the distance between intimates, and the unexpected intimacy of distance  geographic, temporal, cultural. In The Hand That First Held Mine and The Distance Between Us, characters separated by many miles or many years turn out to be joined in ways they never anticipated. In other books, like The Vanishing Act of Esme Lennox and After Youd Gone, women confined to hospital wards slowly reveal secrets that both bind and unbind their families.

title: Suffer Gladly
description: A few years ago, in a craft book called The Art of Time in Fiction, Joan Silber noted: Im interested in how fates roll out over many years and am drawn to write fiction that takes on the task of compressing whole lifetimes into short stories or chapters. Ive always thought of time as creating a natural tension in fiction, but Silber posits that it actually creates content. Time draws the shapes of stories, she argues. A story is entirely determined by what portion of time it chooses to narrate.

title: Inclusion Act
description: On a June morning in 1870, 75 Celestials came to earth in North Adams, Mass. They were Chinese men  19th-century Americans knew China as the Celestial Empire  mostly teenagers, and they had just traveled for two weeks by train to New England from San Francisco to work as strikebreakers in Calvin T. Sampsons shoe factory. The infuriated strikers, members of the Order of the Knights of St. Crispin, massed at the railroad station armed with clubs and rifles. Reporters from Boston looked on warily. Hundreds of agitated townspeople spilled over into the adjoining streets, a dangerous crowd.

title: The Week in Pictures, July 26
description: Subjects include the mayoral candidates in public housing, a shark hunt in Montauk, N.Y., and a commute on Manhattans High Line.

title: U.S. to Send 2 at Guantnamo Back to Algeria, Saying Security Concerns Are Met
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration announced Friday that it was reviving the repatriation of low-level detainees from the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, which had dried up after Congress imposed strict limits on transfers.

title: Hints of a Corner Finally Turned in Ireland
description: HOME prices are rising. In Ireland.

title: Paperback Row
description: MRS. ROBINSONS DISGRACE: The Private Diary of a Victorian Lady,  by Kate Summerscale. (Bloomsbury, $17.) In The Suspicions of Mr. Whicher (2008), Summerscale used a sensational English murder case to provide insight into mid-19th-century domestic life and the rise of detective novels. Now she uses one of Victorian Englands most controversial divorce cases  centered on the diary entries of a deeply unhappy wife  to pry open a culture clinging to rigid ideas about sanity, the institution of marriage and female sexuality.

title: In Terms of Injury, Cities Safer Than Country
description: If you want to avoid death by injury, live in a large city  a new study has found they are much safer than rural areas.

title: New York Musical Theater Festival Report: Legacy Falls
description: Springfield is gone. Port Charles isnt what it used to be. But thanks to the New York Musical Theater Festival, the namesake setting of Legacy Falls can fill in for those other fictional soap-opera towns. Even if a character-killing earthquake is planned for the shows special live episode.

title: Uh, Honey, Thats Not Your Line
description: Moonlight from the window illuminated the tattoo of a phoenix covering the left side of her torso. I traced it with my finger, from just below her armpit, over the speed bumps of her ribs, to her hipbone. I had only seen tattoos like this in the movies, never in person, never this close and never in my own bed.

title: Williamsburg Homes, With Neighborliness in Mind
description: When the architect Carmi Bee first moved to Park Slope, Brooklyn, decades ago, the favored activity of his neighbors was to lounge on the stoops of their brownstones, getting to know one another.

title: A Jewish Pathbreaker Inspired by Her Countryman Mandela
description: On the Sunday in mid-June when a yeshiva in Manhattan ordained three women as Orthodox Jewish religious leaders, Nelson Mandela lay in a Pretoria hospital for the second week with a life-threatening lung infection. Six time zones and 8,000 miles separated these two events. One golden thread, however, bound them together.

title: Chris Christies Giuliani Impression
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has tried on a lot of costumes in the endless prequel to a presumed run for president in 2016. Hes styled himself as another Ronald Reagan, folksy (in a cruder, New Jersey way); a John McCain, blunt and plain spoken; a technocrat like Mitt Romney; even a uniter like George W. Bush.

title: Tunisia Says Assassination Has Links to Al Qaeda
description: TUNIS  The government on Friday blamed an Islamist extremist cell linked to Al Qaeda for the killing of a leader of the political opposition and identified the chief suspect as the person who also killed an opposition figure in February, saying he used the same automatic pistol in both assassinations.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE PANOPTICON, by Jenni Fagan. (Hogarth, $22.) In Fagans pugnacious, snub-nosed paean to the highs and lows of juvenile delinquency, readers will find reflections of Benthamite prison reform, Michel Foucault and the TV show Big Brother.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Americas Debate Over World War II
description: This week, Lynne Olson discusses Those Angry Days; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Mark Leibovich talks about This Town; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: At SAC, Rules Compliance With an Edge
description: According to SAC Capital Advisors, the wildly successful hedge fund now accused of systematic crime, the firm not only has a strong culture of compliance intended to deter insider trading, as the firm put it recently, but may also have one of the most rigorous and cutting edge hedge fund compliance programs in the country.

title: Movie Review: 'The To Do List'
description: The Times critic Neil Genzlinger reviews "The To Do List."

title: The Cohen Connections
description: How some of the insider trading cases of former SAC employees have progressed.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Americas Debate Over World War II
description: This week, Lynne Olson and Mark Leibovich.

title: One App, More Than 400 Languages
description: The Bible App, also known as YouVersion, is the only mobile application in the world that provides content in obscure languages like Eastern Bolivian Guarani, Inuktitut or Akoose.

title: Pinterest Allows Users to Opt Out of Being Tracked
description: In Silicon Valley there are hundreds of companies that track peoples habits with the hopes of offering more intrusive advertising. There are, in comparison, very few Valley start-ups that give people the opportunity to opt out of that tracking.

title: Transforming Study of the Bible
description: YouVersion, a wildly sucessful free app, is changing the way the faithful read the Bible.

title: In the Beginning Was the Word; Now the Word Is on an App
description: EDMOND, Okla.  More than 500 years after Gutenberg, the Bible is having its i-moment.

title: For Beach Scavengers, Storm Washed Away Their Treasure
description: The cool waters off Jones Beach beckoned in the summer heat and a host of toned sunbathers all but demanded a furtive glance. But Manny Ortiz fixated on a seemingly unremarkable patch of sand. Homing in. Hoping.

title: Bribery Charges Withdrawn in Czech Corruption Case
description: Czech prosecutors withdrew bribery charges on Friday against three former members of Parliament, dealing a blow to a sweeping anticorruption case that forced the collapse of the government last month.

title: Movie Review: 'The Wolverine'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Wolverine."

title: What Inspired You to Work in Pop Music?
description: This summer, The New York Times is publishing essays by its critics about the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts, along with stories from readers about their own epiphanies. Previously we heard from readers who work in television, classical music and dance.

title: Cleveland Man Admits to Abductions
description: The Cleveland man accused of holding three women captive in his home for a decade entered a guilty plea on Friday in order to avoid the death penalty.

title: Vivendis Reinvention Takes Shape
description: Vivendi has compromised to get shot of Activision Blizzard.

title: Movie Review: 'Blue Jasmine'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Blue Jasmine."

title: Stare at the Sun
description: A version by Eleanor Friedberger.

title: Chaste Ascetic? A Letter Details Mahlers Love Life
description: Though musicologists who specialize in Gustav Mahler have long taken the memoirs of his wife, Alma, with a grain of salt, most of them have accepted her portrait of him as a fairly chaste ascetic who had few romances before he met her. Now, two scholars say a recently discovered letter from a Mahler confidante  and sometime lover  Natalie Bauer-Lechner, instead shows that he had numerous affairs and infatuations.

title: Stare at the Sun
description: A version by Wesley Stace.

title: Call Me Mansion
description: The new mansions of Manhattan, and the urban Gatsbys flush enough to buy them, are having a moment, uptown and down. But these 21st-century mega-estates  pretenders, in the opinion of some traditionalists  are a bold departure from the definition of the classic city palace: a monolith optimally possessing ample frontage on a distinguished avenue.

title: Installing Windows Updates, Automatic or Manually
description: Q. I have Windows 8 set to update itself automatically, but it doesnt always work and I end up having to click around and install some updates myself. Why?

title: Calendar: Coming Events in New Orleans; Wisconsin; Goteborg, Sweden
description: Satchmo SummerFest, New Orleans A three-day jazz festival in New Orleans, dedicated to the life, legacy and music of the citys native son, Louis Satchmo Armstrong, is scheduled to take place Aug. 2 to 4 in the French Quarter at the Louisiana State Museums Old Mint. Satchmo SummerFest will feature performances by traditional and contemporary jazz and brass band musicians, with a lineup that includes Allen Toussaint, Ellis Marsalis, Wycliffe Gordon and the Preservation Hall Brass Band. Festivalgoers can also attend movies, exhibits, family activities, seminars, dance lessons and special events like the Jazz Mass at the St. Augustine Church in Treme, a traditional second line parade and the annual Trumpet Tribute, which closes the festival Sunday night. Events are free and open to the public, with the exception of the Aug. 1 opening reception.

title: Potholes as Art, Garbage as Great Books
description: When most people think of Los Angeles, they visualize the Hollywood sign, palm trees, the beach. The conceptual artist Daniel Knorr sees potholes. For his first Los Angeles exhibit, Depression Elevations, at Kayne Griffin Corcoran, the Bucharest-born, Berlin-based artist took to the streets, scouring the L.A. landscape in a van for aesthetically appealing divots and puddles to cast with polyurethane. We gave him a van, vests and flares, and he went all over town, the gallerist Maggie Kayne said. The resulting wall pieces  Knorr describes them as materializations rather than sculptures, to denote the shift from idea to object  are hung smooth side out, creating the impression of fluorescent relief maps, as translucent as gummy bears.

title: Why Smokers Still Smoke
description: GIVEN how hazardous it is to their health, why do smokers continue to smoke?

title: The Antidote to Emptiness
description: Anthony Weiner sent lewd texts to a series of young women even after he resigned in disgrace as a congressman for having done the same thing while in office.
