description: TEL AVIV  For nearly four years, the Barnoar murder case was one of Israels highest-profile and most disturbing unsolved mysteries.

title: No Parole for Imprisoned Members of Pussy Riot
description: Updated, July 27 | The two members of the Russian activist collective Pussy Riot who remain imprisoned were both denied parole this week. On Friday, Nadezhda Tolokonnikova was told by a court in Saransk that she had not sufficiently repented for her act of hooliganism in performing at a Moscow Orthodox cathedral last year. Maria Alyokhina received similar news from a court in Perm on Wednesday. Both are being held in prisons near their courts, and are not expected to be released until next year.

title: Arbitrator Becomes a Baseball Power
description: Over the past six months, Major League Baseballs investigators have been working to build cases against a dozen or more players, trying to prove that they violated the leagues antidoping rules.

title: Book Review Podcast: When America Entered the Good War
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Jacob Heilbrunn considers two new books that revisit the arguments over Americas entrance into World War II: Those Angry Days, by Lynne Olson, and 1940, by Susan Dunn. Mr. Heilbrunn writes:

title: Clip: 'The Canyons'
description: A clip from The Canyons,  directed by Paul Schrader and featuring Lindsay Lohan.

title: Fast Food Labor Links
description: In conjunction with my column today, here is some companion reading (and viewing):

title: Niche Travel Bloggers
description: Portraits of five people who blog to the beat of their own drum.

title: Seeking Light in the Heat of Energy Investing
description: Energy independence. Oil exports. Fracking. Electric cars. Solar power. And as of last week: the heat dome. These are phrases that are bandied about, sometimes dividing people along political lines. But all mean one thing: this is a boom time for the United States energy sector, from pulling it out of the ground to moving it around the country to finding ways to use less of it.

title: Travel Blogging Today: Its Complicated
description: When Keith Jenkins plans a trip, he doesnt have to cobble together vacation days, or frequent flier miles, or scour the Web for deals on big-ticket items like hotels. Mr. Jenkins, the Amsterdam-based blogger behind Velvet Escape (velvetescape.com), simply finds sponsors.

title: The Great Wall, Our Way
description: At first, I thought the faded pink pillow on the crumbling stone floor of the watchtower was a remnant of a previous camping trip.

title: Forbes and Aspinwall Go to War
description: John Murray Forbes was feeling half ill in his Milton, Mass., home on Saturday March 14, 1863, when he received a brief telegram from Treasury Secretary Salmon P. Chase. The secretary wanted to meet with him the next day at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in Manhattan. Forbes, a man who once served tea to John Brown, could not refuse. Shaking off his sickness, Forbes hurried overnight to New York. The next day, he sat down with Chase, like him an ardent abolitionist. This was no ordinary meeting: also attending were Navy Secretary Gideon Welles and the New York businessman William H. Aspinwall, the owner of the lucrative gold-hauling Pacific Mail Steamship Company.

title: Once Writer for The Young and Restless, Is Charging Into a New Episode
description: LOS ANGELES  In true soap opera fashion, Maria Arena Bell was killed off.

title: Drugs, Sex, Sarcasm and Irony
description: In a trailer for The Canyons, the coming thriller written by Bret Easton Ellis, Lindsay Lohans character thinks back to the days when people watched movies in a theater. Images of the old spaces in ruins remind us  a bit paradoxically, in a preview for a film being released both in theaters and on iTunes  how the times have changed. But just as we begin to sense a dab of sentimentality, Ms. Lohan says, Its just not my thing anymore.

title: Clip: 'Our Nixon'
description: A scene from the documentary "Our Nixon," directed by Penny Lane.

title: Death Penalty Sought in Case of Killing of Texas Prosecutors
description: HOUSTON  Prosecutors in Kaufman County announced Friday they would seek the death penalty against Eric L. Williams, the former justice of the peace accused of murdering two prosecutors as revenge for handling a case against him that led to his removal from office and the suspension of his law license.

title: Youre on White House Candid Camera
description: These days, Dwight Chapin shoots movies on his iPad. But in the Richard M. Nixon White House, he and his colleagues John Ehrlichman and H. R. Haldeman were Super 8-wielding auteurs, capturing intimate moments that eluded the press corps: Tricia Nixon before her wedding; the president in Beijing enjoying a ballet about a workers insurrection; Pope Paul VI shot sideways (because Haldeman had smuggled his camera into the Vatican).

title: Unemployed and Older, and Facing a Jobless Future
description: I WAS recently talking to a friend at a party whose husband  in his 60s  has been unemployed for more than two years. While there are many challenges, she said, one of the hardest things is trying to balance hope with reality.

title: Trailer: 'Intolerance'
description: A preview for the restoration of D. W. Griffith's film.

title: Medical Procedures May Be Useless, or Worse
description: We usually assume that new medical procedures and drugs are adopted because they are better. But a new analysis has found that many new techniques and medicines are either no more effective than the old ones, or worse. Moreover, many doctors persist in using practices that have been shown to be useless or harmful.

title: Slaveholders Estate, Hiding in Plain Sight
description: New Yorkers may think of slavery as a Southern institution, but it thrived here in colonial times. And in The Manor: Three Centuries at a Slave Plantation on Long Island (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, $28), the landscape historian Mac Griswold tells the long story of a surviving slaveholders estate, hiding in plain sight on Shelter Island and occupied by the 11th generation of the family that settled it in 1651.

title: Birth of Another Spectacle, and Its Life
description: Both admired and reviled, D. W. Griffiths 1915 feature The Birth of a Nation still occupies an unusual position in American cinema. When it was released, its unnervingly compelling account of star-crossed Civil War families and the Ku Klux Klan was the subject of protests and censorship battles. After all that, you might expect a filmmaker to be taken down a notch.

title: Never Mind the Prince! About Kate Middletons Dress ...
description: Never have polka dots seemed quite so disruptive. For the globally televised debut of her son, Prince George Alexander Louis, the Duchess of Cambridge (nee Kate Middleton) stepped out of St. Marys Hospital in cornflower crepe de Chine sprinkled with the playful pattern. The above-the-knee dress, featuring cap sleeves and a gently gathered empire waist, was a custom creation by Jenny Packham.

title: The Art of War
description: Up on a three-story building on Jay Street in Dumbo, an old Artist Lofts rental sign remains, a vestige of this gentrified Brooklyn neighborhoods past as a haven for struggling artists.

title: Escaping One Prison for Many
description: Crashout, a 1955 film noir directed by Lewis R. Foster, begins under the opening credits with a violent prison revolt, much of it constructed from footage borrowed from Don Siegels Riot in Cell Block 11, released just one year earlier. As crowds of angry men brave machine-gun fire from the guard towers and surge toward the prison walls, a few get over the top and run for cover. Foster singles out six of the escapees with individual close-ups, labeling each with the name of the actor who plays him.

title: Bill Cunningham | Crisper
description: Looking great during the heat wave were white tops of all sorts, from classic shirts and shells to floaty trapeze shapes and roomy dolman sleeves.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A two-bedroom in the Gramercy area with a roof terrace, a second floor walk-up in Chelsea with one-bedroom and a two-family in Bushwick.

title: Ethics Panel Advancing Inquiry Into Illinois Republican
description: WASHINGTON  The House Ethics Committee announced Friday that it was pushing ahead with an investigation into Representative Peter Roskam of Illinois, a member of the House Republican leadership, and that it was pursuing inquiries into three other lawmakers, including Michele Bachmann.

title: Big Ticket | An Heiresss Private Sale Yields $21.85 Million
description: A penthouse near the peak of the Trump International Hotel and Tower with double corner exposures providing cinematic views of Central Park and the Hudson River as well as the action at Columbus Circle sold for $21.85 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Tomatoes Plain and Simple
description: With tomato season upon us, Martha Rose Shulman turns to tomatoes for her annual Recipes for Health tomato week. She writes:

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. I was driving home to New York on the Garden State Parkway recently when I saw an electronic sign reading Silver Alert, along with a car make and license number. What is a Silver Alert?

title: Slain Youths Mother Criticizes Defense Law
description: PHILADELPHIA  The mother of Trayvon Martin, the unarmed Florida teenager whose fatal shooting by a neighborhood watch volunteer has provoked a national debate over racial profiling and gun laws, appealed to a crowd of African-American advocates here Friday to use my broken heart to prevent a repeat of what happened to her son.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A meticulously renovated 1883 Victorian in Sea Cliff and a five-bedroom contemporary in Maplewood built on 11 levels and offering views of Manhattan.

title: Jane Austen Bank Note Earns Huzzahs and Nitpicking
description: The news that Jane Austen would become only the third woman, besides Queen Elizabeth II, to appear on an English bank note drew almost as many huzzahs this week as the birth of the royal baby.

title: Squeezing It All In, to an 80s Soundtrack
description: Eric Helms, 45, founded his Juice Generation chain with a single juice bar in Hells Kitchen in 1999; he now has 11 in Manhattan, with 4 more scheduled to open this year. Since 2008, he also has been co-owner, with the actress Salma Hayek, of Cooler Cleanse, which delivers juice cleansing programs and meals of raw food around the country. Part of his Sunday is devoted to a book on juicing that he is writing for Simon & Schuster along with Amely Greevan, a health and wellness writer. He takes time to work out or swim and see friends  to an 80s soundtrack, when possible. Mr. Helms lives on Riverside Boulevard in the West 60s and also has a small apartment in Long Island City near his 9,000-square-foot headquarters.

title: Wheelies: The Next NSX Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Lia Buffa and Michael De Feo
description: Lia Buffa and Michael Anthony De Feo were married Saturday at the High Line park in New York. Nicole De Feo, the grooms sister who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Gettysburg, Readdressed
description: The Battle of Gettysburg, a turning point in the Civil War, was fought in July 1863 over three days of unrelenting heat, smoke and death. The ground was soaked with the blood of as brave men as ever fell on the red field of battle, a Confederate colonel recalled. This month, 150 years later, thousands gathered to watch re-enactments of the battle, including Picketts Charge, a disastrous move for the Confederates, seen on the following pages. Allen Baldwin, who played the role of the Union commander, says everything was carefully scripted and rehearsed. The characters who died were chosen in advance, some based on their birth month, and had to stay dead for the battles duration, sometimes as long as an hour. Re-enactments are intense experiences, Baldwin says. Guys are paying honor to their ancestors, and theres a lot of emotion.

title: Full Range of Heat at Summer Festival
description: Of the many concerts presented by the International Keyboard Institute and Festival at Mannes College the New School for Music each summer, the performances of the pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin are invariably among the most highly anticipated. Accordingly, this years Hamelin recital, on Wednesday, drew an overflow crowd of enthusiasts.

title: Going After Steven Cohens Wallet
description: The Justice Department did not file criminal charges accusing Steven A. Cohen of insider trading, but it did the next best thing by indicting his firm, SAC Capital Advisors. While the criminal case is likely to result in a conviction of SAC on at least some charges, a companion civil asset forfeiture action filed the same day gives the government a means to try to take a sizeable chunk of his fortune if the criminal case does not do so.

title: An Extraterrestrial Rave, Intense but Eerily Frosty
description: BECKET, Mass.  First, many voices in the darkness, incomprehensible and arriving in choppy waves as might inundate a deranged mind. Then, through the haze, a figure with metallic-colored skin emerges.

title: A Flavorful Alternative to Shrimp Cocktail: Cctel de Mariscos
description: It feels almost un-American to admit that theres no bottle of ketchup in my refrigerator. Certainly I was raised to believe there ought to be, along with a bottle of slightly thicker so-called chili sauce. Cocktail sauce, made the Midwestern way, combined the two in equal parts, along with a dab of horseradish. And cocktail sauce was the only thing to serve with cold, boiled shrimp, even in fancy restaurants.

title: Daralene Jones and Antoine Bell
description: Daralene Mesha JoAnna Jones and Antoine Jamaal Bell were married Saturday evening at the Orange County Regional History Center in Orlando, Fla. Dr. Marvin A. Jackson, lead pastor of the River of Life Christian Center of Orlando, officiated.

title: Taking Collaboration to a Whole New Level
description: The pianist Fred Hersch and the tenor saxophonist Joe Lovano met on a level playing field just once during their first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night, on a ballad called Hot House Flower. Its Mr. Herschs song, dedicated to the composer Billy Strayhorn, one of his jazz totems. But Mr. Lovano gave it his courtliest treatment, caressing the wistful melody with a whispery, feathery grace. Both musicians connected with the song, and the interplay between them felt comfortable, if not quite cozy.

title: A Deco Confection, Flamboyant and French
description: A 1935 Avions Voisin C25 Arodyne with flamboyant coachwork and a fascinating past will go across the auction block on Aug. 18 at a Gooding & Company sale in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: French Vogue
description: A 1935 Avions Voisin C25 Arodyne with flamboyant coachwork and a fascinating past will go across the auction block next month in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: Elisheva Baskin and Michael Stein
description: Elisheva Baskin and Michael Stein are to be married Sunday evening at the Palisadium, an event space in Cliffside Park, N.J. Rabbi Yaacov Love is to officiate.

title: Mostly Mozart, Mostly Improved
description: A dozen years ago the Mostly Mozart Festival epitomized much of what was wrong with the tradition-bound ways of classical music.

title: Keeping It New
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival remains relevant by embracing young talents.

title: Mrs. Carter on Her Tour
description: Who wants that perfect love story, anyway? Beyonc sings on Part II (On the Run), a track on her husbands new album. He, of course, is Shawn Carter, a k a Jay Z, and the album is Magna Carta ... Holy Grail. In case her reservations about storybook romance werent clear, she adds a disdainfully silky refrain: Clich, clich, clich, clich.

title: Britten Serenade in the Park
description: Although it has generated less hoopla than the Verdi and Wagner bicentennials this season, the English composer Benjamin Brittens 100th birthday is also cause for celebration in 2013. Major events loom as Brittens actual birth date (Nov. 22) draws near. But on Tuesday, the Knights, a terrific independent orchestra, get a jump on the festivities with their second appearance in the free Naumburg Orchestral Concerts series in Central Park.

title: The Summer of Their Lucky Lot
description: William Shakespeare, whose characters ignore signs and portents at their peril, would surely have appreciated the mystical convergences involved in performing his Richard III in a parking lot. Bones believed to belong to the real Richard III were exhumed last fall from beneath a municipal parking lot in Leicester, England. Now that discovery is being most happily capitalized upon by the enterprising Drilling Company in its free series Shakespeare in the Parking Lot, which this summer ends with the story of Old Crookback.

title: Defense Calls Mannings Intentions Good
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  A defense lawyer for Pfc. Bradley Manning on Friday portrayed his client as young, nave, but good-intentioned when he sent databases of secret documents about American military and diplomatic activities to WikiLeaks, and he urged the judge in his court-martial to be lenient when she decides his fate.

title: North Carolina: First in Voter Suppression
description: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina didnt like our recent editorial that criticized the state for abandoning its traditions of racial equality, strong public schools, and economic fairness. He wrote a letter to the editor saying he was leading the state to a powerful comeback.

title: Audubons Words, Worthy of Show
description: John James Audubons place in painting has long been secure, but recognition of his powers as a prose artist  a naturalist to be read alongside Thoreau or Aldo Leopold or Edward Abbey  has begun to emerge only in recent years. Thats partly because his monumental Birds of America, a complete first edition of which sold at auction in 2010 for $11.5 million, was printed without the texts he wrote for it. His writing is now getting equal billing with his hand-colored prints in Audubons Birds, Audubons Words, a jewel-box exhibition of some 30 works that opened July 27 and continues through May 11 at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

title: Caroline Kennedy, Catching the Torch
description: Some version of this occurs almost everywhere Caroline Kennedy goes.

title: The Deadline of The Killing
description: When The Killing set off on its somber course in April 2011, viewers didnt expect to wade through two seasons of Seattle murk to answer Who killed Rosie Larsen? Soon critical acclaim and a loyal fan base dissolved into outrage and dwindling viewership, as the first season ended with a cliffhanger not resolved until the final moments of the second. Thats when The Killing was pronounced dead. But the patient still had a pulse.

title: A Rare Sighting of Paris Talent
description: The Paris Opera Ballet doesnt travel much, and its dancers tend not to be a presence on the international guest-star circuit. If you want to see how the company is dancing, and who might be up and coming, you generally have to go to Paris.

title: Five Reasons to Go Mod
description: The British band the Dave Clark Five was among the most successful pop groups of the 1960s, combining catchy tunes with a propulsive beat. Its hits included Glad All Over, Do You Love Me and I Like It Like That, and the quintet turned up on The Ed Sullivan Show so often it seemed like the house band. Din Overpowers Dave Clark Five, a May 1964 headline in The New York Times ran atop an article about the bands appearance at Carnegie Hall. Rivals of the Beatles Hailed by Screaming Girls.

title: Week in Review: A Crippling Blow Follows Outsize Profits
description: Fund indicted; called magnet for cheating. | Wall Streets exposure to hacking laid bare. | Trader and S.E.C. lawyer spar over e-mail. | A legal bane of Wall Street switches sides.

title: Upstart in the Backyard of Italys Supercars
description: SAN CESARIO SUL PANARO, ITALY  Dont be fooled by the buildings homely exterior of brown tile and glass, or by its location in a nondescript industrial area some 20 miles northwest of Bologna. Inside is the two-story workshop of Pagani Automobili, maker of some of the worlds most advanced  and most expensive  cars.

title: Asking the Man Who Owns One: The Praise Flows
description: When it comes to Pagani, Juan Barazi, a Danish businessman and racecar driver, is what one might describe as the quintessential satisfied customer.

title: Genres, Like Sand, Tricky to Pin Down
description: MANCHESTER, England  It is pitch dark as you are swallowed up in a crowd of unknowable size, voices chanting and burbling around you, bodies jostling close by. There is no way to know how big the room is, where you are going or whether you are about to collide with a wall or a human. It is Tino Sehgals This Variation, and as your eyes adjust, performers become slowly visible, moving amid the crowd, dancing and singing or pausing to talk about money and jobs.

title: Just the Beginning of Their Growing Time
description: Describing her view of life, the writer Joyce Maynard said: Im a believer in diving in. It has sometimes been disastrous and painful for me but I think I have better judgment about where to dive now. Id like to have tattooed on my wrist: Whats the worst that can happen?

title: Sweet Corn Ice Cream
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates a sweeter way to use summer corn.

title: On Beauty | Travel-Friendly Products Thatll Make Your Summer a Whole Lot Smoother
description: These nine travel-sized products are just the ticket for combating summertime woes like sunburn and frizzy hair. Stash them in your carry-on, and youll be ready for any last-minute weekend getaways between now and Labor Day.

title: The Weekend Wheels Calendar
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Ice Cream Is a Cold, Sweet Way to Show Off Corn
description: Ripe summer corn is as sweet as many of the fruits we habitually make into dessert, but rarely do we see it at the end of the meal.

description: A look inside the workshop of Pagani Automobili, maker of some of the worlds most advanced, and most expensive, cars.

title: Pope Francis in Brazil
description: As Pope Francis, the first pontiff from Latin America, visits Brazil, the crowds he faces offer diverse messages.

title: If These Walls Could Talk, Theyd Lie
description: The subject of Murmurs, an 80-minute mime/circus production conceived and directed by Victoria Thierre Chaplin, is illusion. People sit on chairs  or lie on mattresses  that arent there. A man looks down to find that he has three arms. Individuals have movement dialogues with empty costumes that become animated or with walking people who suddenly crumble into mere bundles of clothes.

title: France Orders Strauss-Kahn to Stand Trial
description: PARIS  Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the disgraced former chief of the International Monetary Fund, was ordered Friday to stand trial in France on charges linked to his involvement in a prostitution ring prosecutors say was operating in France and in the United States.

title: A Furor Over Sales by the Petersen Museum
description: The Auctions America news release announcing the sale of a burgundy red 1957 Mercedes-Benz 300SL roadster in early August trumpets its celebrity ownership by the late actor Robert Stack and its original hardtop and leather interior. But nowhere does it mention that the car, which could sell for more than $800,000, is from the collection of the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles.

title: Deft Declarer Play at Senior World Trials in Florida
description: The diagramed deal featured perhaps the best piece of declarer play during the senior world championship trials in Orlando, Fla., earlier this month. It was sent to me by Karen Allison, one of the Bridge Base Online commentators.

title: Pitchfork Post-Mortem
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss flaccid indie rockers, transcendent rappers, R. Kelly and other stars of the Pitchfork Music Festival in Chicago.

title: Queen of Tap Hits the Floor Stomping
description: BECKET, Mass.  One way to distinguish American tap dance and Appalachian clogging from their British and Irish relatives is to watch a dancers waist. In British and Irish dancers, the hips lift and fall; in Americans, they sink and resurface, as in some African dance. And in the gifted American tap dancer Michelle Dorrance, the sinking is especially pronounced. She drops very low.

title: Stepping Into Cleanup Spot, Soriano Winds Up 0 for 5
description: While the Yankees continued to field questions about Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter, two injured superstars who are not on the 25-man roster, the team announced the reacquisition of the seven-time All Star outfielder Alfonso Soriano, whose return to the Bronx may bring a sorely needed spark to a depleted and feeble lineup.

title: Mets Get Two Strong Performances From Starters but Only One Victory
description: WASHINGTON  Before Matt Harvey, long before Zack Wheeler, there was Jenrry Mejia, all tantalizing youth and talent, winning plaudits and rousing hype.

title: 45 Killed in Sectarian Bombings in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In a deadly sectarian attack, at least 54 people were killed Friday evening and about 75 wounded when two bombs ripped through a town in a tribal region of northwestern Pakistan, officials said. A militant group affiliated with the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility.

title: Rising Animators Spring Into Motion
description: Theres an apocryphal story about a director on The Simpsons who didnt like the way a scene looked and asked to see the other two camera angles. If you dont understand the absurdity of that anecdote, well, youre not alone. Lots of people dont understand how animation works, how time consuming it can be, how every single thing on screen has to be meticulously planned and often assembled over months (if not years).

title: Open Source Science Fair 2.0
description: Last night, we hosted our second annual Open Source Science Fair. Our exhibitors showed off their projects using everything from laptops and tablets to custom-made Arduino controllers and robots to tri-fold display boards and glitter glue. After taking a break for dinner, we heard from our keynote speakers Dan Sinker, Haleigh Sheehan and Hilary Mason.

title: San Diego Mayor Says He Will Go Into Therapy
description: LOS ANGELES  Besieged by accusations of sexual harassment, Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego announced Friday that he would enter two weeks of what he described as intensive behavior therapy, but he refused to bow to a flood of demands that he step aside.

description: Photos from Egypt, India, Mali and the West Bank.

description: A recent pride festival in Crotona Park drew a few hundred people for a day of drag performances, speeches from elected officials and tables providing free condoms and H.I.V. tests.

title: On Rooftops, a Rival for Utilities
description: For years, power companies have watched warily as solar panels have sprouted across the nations rooftops. Now, in almost panicked tones, they are fighting hard to slow the spread.

title: It Was Like I Was by Myself
description: The Bronx has 1.4 million residents and no full-time gay bar. When its gay and lesbian center closed down last year, after 16 years, it left a hole in the daily lives of many in the borough.

title: Wagners Dutchman Explores New Times
description: BAYREUTH, Germany  Well, it wasnt quite Oscar night. But it was a German high-culture equivalent when a procession of V.I.P.s, including Chancellor Angela Merkel, walked a red carpet past hundreds of gawkers and photographers as the Bayreuth Festival opened here Thursday evening with a performance of Wagners Fliegende Hollnder.

title: More on Preventing Hospital Readmissions
description: Suffering from heart failure, Eddie Malleis, 73, had been at the University of Colorado hospital for 13 days. All he wanted to do was go home.

title: Hoarders Loot Onstage in The Capables
description: The value of Greg Kozateks Beanie Baby collection has plummeted since he started amassing the once-hot plush toys in the late 90s. But the Beanies have become an invaluable part of the set that he and George Hoffmann, a fellow designer, created for The Capables, a new drama by Jay Stull. Thousands of items reach to the ceiling and stretch across the floor of the Gym at Judson, the theater where the show, about a hoarder and her family, plays through Aug. 3.

title: Rebirth of Book by Aide to Carter
description: Hamilton Jordan, Jimmy Carters young, brash chief of staff, was famous during the administration for negotiating tough deals, carousing at night and shunning the stuffy customs of official Washington.

title: Museum Welcomes Wikipedia Editors
description: WASHINGTON  No one knows the components of dark matter, the mystery of Mona Lisas smile or precisely how long it will take Kim Kardashian to lose the 50 pounds she gained during her pregnancy.

title: Stolen Backhoe Couldnt Reach A.T.M.s Cash, Police Say
description: A man stole a backhoe from a construction yard in Queens early Friday, drove it several blocks to a Chase bank branch, and used the bucket to pry loose an A.T.M., the police said.

title: Tahrir Taken, Some Egyptians Look for Third Square to Resist Islamists and Army
description: As hundreds of thousands of Egyptians crammed into dueling rallies in different parts of Cairo on Friday, responding to calls for support from rival political factions around the army and the Muslim Brotherhood, activists who mistrust both the military and the Islamists were left wondering how best to register their disgust.

description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Wild Swings in Markets Fuel Anxiety of Japanese
description: TOKYO  Mika Tanabe, a new investor in the Japanese stock market, has been on a stomach-turning roller-coaster ride. Since March, her shares in Softmax, an electronic medical records company, have slumped 30 percent, surged 120 percent, lost half their value, then climbed 20 percent again.

title: Burglaries Turn Once-Comfortable Residents Into Crime-Stoppers
description: A woman in Hollis, Queens, answered the ringing of her doorbell on Friday morning by pulling open a narrow window in the basement, peering up past a visitors shoes and asking, Who are you?

title: Turning Off Tracking on the Internet
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubts Start on Day 1 for Holmes and for Jets
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  One practice into training camp, and it was all going so well for the Jets. No embarrassing mishaps at quarterback, no egregious mistakes or defensive breakdowns. Under the vast blue sky, and amid the rolling green hills, it was possible to forget about all their defects, if even for a second.

title: Week in Pictures for July 26
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the mayoral candidates having a sleepover in public housing, a shark hunt in Montauk, N.Y., and a commute on Manhattans High Line.

title: Cuomo Signs Law Banning Shark Fin Sales
description: Following the lead of several other states, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a bill on Friday banning the possession, sale and  presumably  the ingestion of shark fins, signaling the death knell for a traditional Chinatown delicacy: shark fin soup.

title: Ronnie Cutrone, a Warhol Assistant, Dies at 65
description: Ronnie Cutrone, an artist, nightclub impresario and longtime assistant to Andy Warhol whose job required him to make unusual and highly personal contributions to some of Warhols canvases, died last weekend at his home in Lake Peekskill, N.Y. He was 65.

title: A Candidate Eclipse
description: Last week we learned more about what Anthony D. Weiner was doing after he resigned from Congress, and despite his new fatherhood he wasnt spending all his time debating sleep training. Instead, Mr. Weiner was bringing shame to the world of epistolary eroticism while apparently never missing a cycle of laundry. On Wednesday, People magazine released outtakes from its interview last year with Huma Abedin, in which she claimed that she was the envy of her friends because she never had to wash a piece of clothing. I have not been to our dry cleaner, she said, leaving us to wonder whether Mr. Weiner wasnt such a literalist that he would pursue stain removal as a means of moral absolution.

title: With New Book, Seeking Truth in Statistics of Soccer
description: Soccer is not a sport seduced by numbers, unless that number is three  as in the points awarded for a win.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Double Murder Seen as Part of Mans Quest to Kill Sex Offenders
description: When Charles Parker registered as a sex offender in the small upstate town of Jonesville, S.C., he became a prospect on another mans kill list, the authorities say.

title: G.M. Dismisses Executives as India Begins Investigating Recall of Vehicles
description: General Motors has forced out several executives and managers, including the head of its global engine operations, as the companys recall of vehicles in India raises questions about improper emissions tests.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: American Tour Features Elite Teams
description: Another American summer. Another overseas invasion of muscular European soccer teams that have come trawling for games and greenbacks.

title: A Dark Orton Farce, Taking Extremes to Extremes
description: IT IS QUITE the busy day at the McLeavy house in London: A funeral, a nervous escape by two novice bank robbers and an unexpected visit from the water board. There will also be inappropriate marriage proposals, a traffic accident involving a hearse and a mystery surrounding a glass eye.

title: After Filling in a Blank, Trader Finishes Testimony
description: In February 2007, Fabrice Tourre sent an e-mail to his boss at Goldman Sachs, calling a meeting he was attending surreal.

title: Number of Catfish Inspectors Drives a Debate on Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Deep-fried catfish served with a side of hush puppies and coleslaw has been a regional specialty for years and a cash crop for states in the Deep South. Now, catfish is at the heart of a dispute as the House and Senate prepare to work out their differences on a new five-year farm bill. The current bill expires on Sept. 30.

title: As Training Camp Starts, Only Thing Missing for Giants Is a Motto
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There were no holdouts on the first day of Giants training camp Friday. No salary disputes. No unexpected injuries or infirmities of consequence. Only one player, who was not identified, was considered overweight, but it was not wide receiver Victor Cruz, who missed the spring workouts during the teams one recurring off-season contract drama.

title: Soldiers Mass Execution Reported by Syria Group
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Islamist extremists in Syrias insurgency killed 150 soldiers in a battle for control of an Aleppo suburb this week, including 51 who were executed after they had surrendered, according to a Syrian monitoring group that has been chronicling casualties and evidence of atrocities.

title: Views of the 30s From Nol Coward
description: BEFORE TONIGHT at 8:30 begins at the John Drew Theater of Guild Hall in East Hampton, the mellifluous voice of Simon Jones, the wonderful English actor who performs in all three of the evenings Nol Coward plays, is heard delivering the customary pre-curtain speech about turning off cellphones. He announces that there will be an intermission after the first two plays, before the evening finishes with the final one in a hurtling half-hour.

title: Smartphone Rivals
description: Apple and Samsung are locked in a global struggle for dominance of the smartphone market. Samsung, though a bigger company, is only now deriving more profit from cellphones than Apple does.

title: Johns Rebuilt Left Arm Should Lead the Way to Cooperstown
description: Not long ago, two middle-aged baseball fans were chuckling about how one had said, When you asked me who Tommy John was, I thought he was a doctor.

title: Mysteries of an Unusual Traveling Salesman
description: Bernadette M. Rogoff, curator of museum collections at the Monmouth County Historical Association in Freehold, has a recurring, unsettling dream: She is in downtown New Brunswick, and a man ahead of her, dressed in black and carrying a bundle, is walking away.

title: Thompsons Wife Hits the Trail, Solo
description: Elsie McCabe Thompson has been out on the campaign trail with her husband before, so her presence at a couple of campaign events on Friday should not have been unusual.

title: Expanding, Musically and Geographically
description: When the saxophonist David Liebman unwinds onstage, he unleashes waves of sound that recall his days with Miles Davis in the early 1970s. Offstage, hes a bit more subdued. Sipping a beer after a volatile set at the Greenwich Village club Smalls last month, he mused about Expansions, his first new band in 23 years  and the one he will bring to the Hudson Valley Jazz Festival next month.

title: George Mitchell, a Pioneer in Hydraulic Fracturing, Dies at 94
description: George P. Mitchell, the son of a Greek goatherd who capped a career as one of the most prominent independent oilmen in the United States by unlocking immense natural gas and petroleum resources trapped in shale rock formations, died on Friday in Galveston, Tex. He was 94.

title: Staring at Two Suns
description: A couple of years ago, I started to write songs with Eleanor Friedberger, the singer of the Fiery Furnaces, just before the release of her debut solo album, Last Summer. The first songs were ostensibly for the fictional band in my next novel, but things went well and we kept going. These co-written songs  a mixture of her words, my words, mutual melodies and disparate memories  have recently been released as her second album, Personal Record.

title: Turbulent Journey for Americas Cup
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The race was scheduled to begin at 12:15 p.m., and fans were expected to pour into the well-manicured Americas Cup Park and line themselves all around the waterfront of San Francisco Bay to watch. Years of planning, promise and promotion were built toward what organizers called Americas Cup Summer of Racing.

title: The Charitable-Industrial Complex
description: I HAD spent much of my life writing music for commercials, film and television and knew little about the world of philanthropy as practiced by the very wealthy until what I call the big bang happened in 2006. That year, my father, Warren Buffett, made good on his commitment to give nearly all of his accumulated wealth back to society. In addition to making several large donations, he added generously to the three foundations that my parents had created years earlier, one for each of their children to run.

title: Citing Scandals, Quinn Sees Way to Stand Apart
description: In an electoral season awash with misbehaving men, a mayoral candidate with her own weaknesses is making a subtle plea to New York City voters: Im not one of them.

title: A More Streamlined Charity
description: As part of their own philanthropic efforts, Toyota is helping the Food Bank for New York City to improve its efficiency.

title: Friday Night Music: Sprawl, Again
description: Consider the following thought experiment: you are driving on a road  lets arbitrarily call it Interstate 91  and must choose a lane. Traffic is so heavy that you cant really change lanes thereafter. But there are many bad patches along the road; half of the distance can be covered at 60 miles an hour, but the other half only at 15.

title: In Lieu of Money, Toyota Donates Efficiency to New York Charity
description: The Food Bank for New York City is the countrys largest anti-hunger charity, feeding about 1.5 million people every year. It leans heavily, as other charities do, on the generosity of businesses, including Target, Bank of America, Delta Air Lines and the New York Yankees. Toyota was also a donor. But then Toyota had a different idea.

title: The War Over Health Care Exchanges
description: Federal and state governments are entering the home stretch in the race to carry out the most important health care reform in more than four decades. The most pressing task is to establish new health care exchanges, the electronic marketplaces in which consumers will be able to compare and buy insurance plans just as they buy airplane tickets or rent cars on the Internet.

title: Ex-Tiffany Executive Pleads Guilty to Stealing Jewelry
description: A former Tiffany & Company executive who the authorities said stole about $1.2 million in jewelry from the store pleaded guilty on Friday in a Manhattan courtroom.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Civic Treasure in Detroit
description: A visitor to the Detroit Institute of Arts can see some of the worlds greatest artworks. The Wedding Dance, Pieter Bruegel the Elders lusty rendering of a peasants celebration from the 1560s, is there. So is a self-portrait by a wary and anxious-looking Vincent van Gogh. There are treasures by Matisse, Rivera, Picasso and Calder, to name only a few in Detroits vast collection.

title: Goldman Sachss Aluminum Pile
description: History is filled with examples of financial speculators who tried to make big profits by hoarding commodities like gold, silver and copper. Now, some big users of aluminum, including Coca-Cola and MillerCoors, say that the practices of large financial institutions like Goldman Sachs have driven up the price of that important metal.

title: A Trail of Masterpieces and a Web of Lies, Leading to Anguish
description: CARCALIU, Romania  On a snowy day in January, Radu Dogaru, sheltering with a computer at his mothers house in this remote Romanian village, set out the terms for a deal that had eluded him for months but that now suddenly seemed tantalizingly close.

title: On the Trail of Stolen Masterpieces
description: Investigators have been unable to locate seven works stolen from a Dutch museum by a Romanian thief and his gang.

title: Mick Jagger, Birthday Boy
description: We interrupt our consideration of the profound political issues confronting America to point out that Mick Jagger just turned 70.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 27, 2013
description: As a citizen of the world, I want to believe that the paintings still exist.

title: Walter De Maria, Artist on Grand Scale, Dies at 77
description: Walter De Maria, a reclusive American sculptor whose multifaceted achievement and sly Dadaist humor helped give rise to earthworks, Conceptual Art and Minimal art, on an often monumental scale, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 77 and lived in New York.

title: Editors Note: July 27, 2013
description: MAGAZINE

title: Quiet Rivalry Over the Next Fed Leader Comes Out of the Shadows
description: WASHINGTON  Three times in the last 35 years, a president has quietly picked a new chairman for the Federal Reserve and then quickly obtained the Senates confirmation. The choice of the nations most powerful technocrat has far-reaching consequences, but it has rarely generated much public anticipation or political debate.

title: Putting You Through Your Paces
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  That John Lieb. Such a NAME DROPPER (Across Lite, Solution, blog). He made his New York Times debut in the aforementioned puzzle, and now hes back in a collaboration with David Quarfoot.

title: The Baby Formula Barometer
description: Edward Wongs terrific front-page article in  The New York Times on Friday is as good an encapsulation of the issues currently facing China and its economy as anything youre likely to read on the subject. As it tries to move from a fast-growing, export-oriented, developing economy to a more mature economy, it keeps bumping up against problems that could prevent it from becoming the kind of economic power it so clearly longs to be. These problems are almost entirely self-inflicted.

title: Carving Up the Country
description: Our 50 states seem to be united in name only.

title: President-Elect Stirs Optimism in Iran and West
description: TEHRAN  Bogged down in faltering nuclear talks with the European powers nearly 10 years ago, Hassan Rouhani did something that no Iranian diplomat before or since has managed to do.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Banks mint gold by storing aluminum, a new royal prince elates advertisers and SAC Capital Advisors, a big hedge fund, is indicted on criminal charges.

title: Demonstrations Grow in Egypt
description: Friends and foes of Mohamed Morsi, the ousted president, turned out for rallies across the country.

title: The New Yorker Gets In on the Act
Black New York and the Draft Riots
description: Reflecting on New York Citys tumultuous summer of 1863, the Rev. Charles Bennett Ray, pastor of Bethesda Congregational Church on Sullivan Street in Manhattan, noted later that year:

title: A Welcome Back for Soriano, Followed by a Debacle for the Yankees
description: With the trade deadline looming next week, the Yankees front office will meet this week to discuss trade possibilities that it hopes will jump-start the team into a late-season playoff run. While General Manager Brian Cashman said on Friday that he was hesitant to trade valuable prospects for aging veterans, he knows the Yankees never concede a season so early. If the math says the Yankees are still in the race by the July 31 nonwaiver trade deadline, well, the Yankees will be in the pennant race.

title: Art on a Grand Scale
description: Walter De Marias multifaceted achievement and sly Dadaist humor helped give rise to earthworks, Conceptual Art and Minimal art.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (Sundance) THE VIRGIN SUICIDES (2000) In this first movie from Sofia Coppola, based on Jeffrey Eugenidess first novel, four sisters in affluent 1970s Michigan dance toward their deaths after being sequestered in their home by their authoritarian parents (James Woods and Kathleen Turner) following the suicide of a fifth sister, Cecilia (Hanna Hall), and a broken curfew on prom night by the Lolita-esque Lux (Kirsten Dunst, right). Giovanni Ribisi is the narrator, a grown version of one of the adoring boys with whom the sisters communicate in their isolation by means of light signals and songs over the phone. Ms. Coppola has carefully preserved the spirit of her source and, for the most part, succeeded in her efforts to find a visual idiom appropriate to the lush melancholy of the novels language, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The book, a hazy linguistic daydream, he added, required, Ms. Coppola to create a feature film essentially without characters or a story, and to hold the viewers interest through moods, associations and resonant images. That she has done so is impressive.

title: Crackdown in Egypt Kills Islamists as They Protest
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian authorities unleashed a ferocious attack on Islamist protesters early Saturday, killing at least 72 people in the second mass killing of demonstrators in three weeks and the deadliest attack by the security services since Egypts uprising in early 2011.

title: North Korea Showcases Its Military Might at a Mass Rally
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea observed the 60th anniversary of the end of the Korean War by showing off its military might to the outside world in a parade through the center of the capital, Pyongyang, that featured columns of rocket tubes, goose-stepping paratroopers and intercontinental ballistic missiles, or at least mock-ups of the weapons.

title: Europe and China Agree to Settle Solar Panel Fight
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions trade chief said on Saturday that a deal had been reached with China to settle a dispute over exports of low-cost solar panels that had threatened to set off a wider trade war between two of the worlds largest economies.

title: The Bible Gets an Upgrade
description: Is it possible to improve on the word of God?

title: Miltons Paradise, Still Lost
description: Robert Skidelsky has an interesting note asking why quantitative easing has received so much stress in recent economic debates. Its effectiveness is, after all, questionable  whereas there is overwhelming evidence that fiscal policy works as advertised.

title: A Burst of Violence in Cairo
description: The police and armed civilians opened fire Saturday on protesters against Egypts new military government, killing scores of people.

title: Lindy Boggs, Longtime Representative and Champion of Women, Is Dead at 97
description: Lindy Boggs, who succeeded her husband in the House of Representatives after his plane crashed in Alaska and who went on to serve nine terms on Capitol Hill, notably as a champion of womens rights, died on Saturday at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 97.

title: A Closer Look at That North Pole Lake
description: A Web search for North Pole lake turns up a lot of hype. I posted a YouTube video trying to clarify what is and isnt going on:

title: Our Pulchritudinous Priesthood
description: I NEITHER spotted a psychotherapist nor heard mention of therapy in Woody Allens newest movie, Blue Jasmine, which pokes fun at faddish, pampered New Yorkers, as Allen tends to do. But a personal trainer flits across the screen and factors into the plot.

title: Once a King of Romance, Now an Angry Militant
description: SIDON, Lebanon  His success was a dream come true for this tough port city on the Mediterranean coast: a poor kid whose honeyed voice and ballads of love and heartbreak rocketed him to wealth and fame far from the gun-ridden neighborhood where he grew up.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Variety: An Animated Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  One of my earliest television-related memories is of sitting in front of our set watching the Road Runner outrun and outwit Wile E. Coyote. Watching Wile E. Coyote skid off the cliff of a mountain, hanging in mid-air until the exact moment he noticed that the ground beneath him had run out. The why me? look in his eyes just before he dropped out of sight never failed to make me laugh.

title: Syrian Government Blamed for Ballistic Missile Attack
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A missile attack by government forces on the city of Aleppo in northern Syria killed at least 29 people, including 19 children, Syrian monitors said Saturday.

title: Amid Protests, Inmates Escape From Libyan Prison
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  More than 1,000 prisoners escaped from a prison near here on Saturday, security officials said, after a wave of political assassinations and attacks on political offices across Libya.

title: Trailing a Trader
description: By indicting SAC, prosecutors have set off one of the biggest Wall Street cases since the 1980s.

title: Thousands Gather to Bury a Slain Tunisian Politician
description: TUNIS  Several thousand demonstrators gathered here on Saturday for the funeral of a slain opposition politician in a show of force against the Tunisian government, which many blame for the assassination. Supporters filled the tree-lined avenues here in downtown Tunis, the capital, as they followed the funeral cortege on foot to a hilltop grave in the citys main cemetery.

title: With Aly Raisman
description: Aly Raisman, the gymnast who won a gold medal at the 2012 London Olympics for the floor routine she performed to Hava Nagila, was in Jerusalem to light the torch for the July 18 opening ceremony of the Maccabiah Games, the international Jewish sporting competition held every four years in Israel.

title: Weeks After Deadly Fire, Town Struggles to Pick Up Pieces
description: YARNELL, Ariz.  The flames that killed 19 members of an elite firefighting squad moved capriciously through this old gold-mining village, scorching structures indiscriminately, as if playing a drunken game of hopscotch. They spared everything on one side of Route 89, which doubles as Main Street here, but proved cruel on the other, sometimes destroying entire blocks, sometimes burning a single house and nothing else.

title: Fred Hassan of Bausch & Lomb, on Managers as Ambassadors
description: This interview with  Fred Hassan, chairman of Bausch & Lomb and a managing director at Warburg Pincus, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Our Attitudes About Debt
description: Readers debate the importance of reducing the nations debt.

title: The Yankees Recurring Injury Issue at Third Base
description: Perhaps it was inevitable that a player like Alex Rodriguez, with such outsize talent, salary demands and hunger for the spotlight, would wind up with the Yankees. But it is easier to blame Aaron Boone.

title: Finally Elected to the Hall, the Man Who Bought Babe Root
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  Jacob Ruppert died in his Fifth Avenue apartment shortly before the Baseball Hall of Fame opened in 1939. Despite being the first great Yankees owner, Ruppert was neglected by voters even as less-distinguished counterparts were elected.

title: Using the Third Ear
description: To the Editor:

title: Owning vs. Renting a Home
description: To the Editor:

title: The Hunt for Melanoma
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Gauge SAC on the Richter Scale
description: NO major financial firm has survived a criminal indictment, and with SAC Capital Advisors facing insider trading charges, this gigantic hedge fund founded and run by Steven A. Cohen may have to unwind its portfolio. If it does, will the liquidation of its securities roil the stock market?

title: Im Still Waiting for My Phone to Become My Wallet
description: DURING the sweltering heat wave earlier this month, it seemed too hot to wear much, carry much or do much of anything at all. Every time I left the house, I tried to figure out where to stuff my bulky wallet. I always had room for my iPhone, even if it meant carrying it in my hand. But the wallet was one thing too many.

title: In Search of Romance, and Maybe a Refund
description: SOMEHOW, in the four-tenths of a decade that the Haggler has been aiding consumers, no one with dating-service issues has written in. Until now.

title: Budging (Just a Little) on Investing in Gold
description: SHOULD gold be a part of my portfolio?

title: Apollonia Poilne
description: Apollonia Poilne is the chief executive of Poilne, a celebrated artisanal bread baker in Paris that supplies the lyse Palace as well as more than 2,500 of the citys retailers and restaurants. She took over the family business in 2002 at age 18 when her parents died in a helicopter crash.

title: New Roads to Learning
description: MY mother, a former middle school math teacher, was a model for my career in education, although I did not take the classroom path. She and my father, a bank executive, raised me and my younger sister and brother outside Chicago, in Skokie and Glencoe, Ill.

title: Getting Creative With the G.D.P.
description: WE have undervalued creativity and research. And despite the hoopla whenever Apple or Google releases a new product, we havent grasped the full significance of innovation.

title: A Blow for the Press, and for Democracy
description: SOMETIMES James Risen feels like Jean Valjean, the beleaguered protagonist of Les Miserables, hounded for years by the authorities.

title: Paul Liebrandt Is Leaving  Corton
description: One of the most acclaimed restaurants in New York is losing its chef. Paul Liebrandt, who for five years has been the  fastidious auteur in the kitchen at Corton, in TriBeCa, has parted ways with the restaurant, a publicist for him said on Saturday.

title: The Hype Over Hospital Rankings
description: LAST week U.S. News and World Report released its annual list of Best Hospitals. Web sites are being updated to celebrate victories. (Johns Hopkins ranks No. 1!) Magazines will be plump with advertising. (NewYork-Presbyterian is first in New York and tied for seventh nationally!) And, because I am a reporter covering health care, my in-box is accumulating e-mails from the Honor Roll of the Top 18 hospitals.

title: She Turned Her Upspeak Down a Notch
description: How old are you?

title: July 27: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: The Low-Wage Americans
description: The roughly 21 million workers who earn between the minimum wage and $10 an hour are largely young and without children. But a significant number are older, college-educated or raising families.

title: Want World Domination? Size Matters
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  HORACE GREELEY, Napoleon Bonaparte and Cecil Rhodes may seem strange bedfellows, but they all agreed that territorial, political and economic size was critical to a countrys success. They wanted more land  in the West, in Europe or overseas. In 1904, Halford Mackinder, an Oxford geographer, told an august assemblage at the Royal Geographical Society that the country that controlled the Russian heartland, a frostbitten Central Asian steppe, would dominate the world island  the combined territory of Europe and North Asia  and in time come to rule the world. A centrally located piece of territory like the Russian plain, Mackinder argued, could be expanded West and East without the need for naval power.

title: Time to Hard-Delete Carlos Danger
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN you puzzle over why the elegant Huma Abedin is propping up the eel-like Anthony Weiner, you must remember one thing: Huma was raised in Saudi Arabia, where women are treated worse by men than anywhere else on the planet.

title: The Rules of Magic
description: I WISH I was rich, says the little boy, just as most of us have wished at least once in our lives. But this little boy has a magic talisman that grants wishes. Instantly, right in front of his distraught siblings, he is transformed into an elderly gentleman, handsomely but rather dowdily dressed, who was looking down at them through spectacles and asking them the nearest way to the railroad station. He cant understand why he finds himself surrounded by unruly children and instead of enjoying his newfound wealth, he heads to his office in London, presumably to make himself still richer.

title: Egypts Missed Opportunity
description: ATLANTA  WHEN Mohamed Morsi was elected president of Egypt in June 2012, it was the first time an Islamist had reached executive office through the ballot box in the Arab world. Contrary to the expectations of conservative pundits in the West, his government did not follow in the draconian path of the Afghan Taliban or Irans ayatollahs. But nor did Mr. Morsi and the Muslim Brotherhood place Egypt on the road to a truly inclusive democratic order.

title: City of Wonder, Then and Still
description: OXFORD, England  SIXTY years ago I went to Manhattan for the very first time, on the ocean liner Mauretania from Liverpool, and annually since then, without a break, I have returned. This year is my Diamond Jubilee visit, and everyone, New Yorkers and outsiders alike, asks me how much the place has changed.

title: Can We See Our Hypocrisy to Animals?
description: A NEW documentary, The Act of Killing, explores the human capacity for mass murder. It addresses the Indonesian fratricide of the mid-1960s, in which a million people may have been killed.

title: I Want to Be a Mayor
description: AS Americans, weve been raised on the notion that any child could dream of becoming president. But when you see how much fun Barack Obama and his immediate predecessors have had in that job  and when you look at where the most exciting innovations in governance are happening  how long will it be before our kids, when asked what they want to be when they grow up, answer: I want to be a mayor. Except in Detroit, mayors today have more fun.

title: Fighting Back Against Wretched Wages
description: OFTEN relegated to the background, Americas low-wage workers have been making considerable noise lately by deploying an unusual weapon  one-day strikes  to make their message heard: theyre sick and tired of earning just $8, $9, $10 an hour.

title: The Psychology of an Irish Meltdown
description: DUBLIN  FOR the past month, Ireland has been outraged by tapes of Anglo Irish Bank officials, back in 2008, discussing lying to the government about how big a loan they needed, and how they knew there was no chance that the loan would ever be repaid. That loan was the first domino in a sequence that ended with the whole Irish economy flat on its face.

title: Status and Stress
description: Although professionals may bemoan their long work hours and high-pressure careers, really, theres stress, and then theres Stress with a capital S. The former can be considered a manageable if unpleasant part of life; in the right amount, it may even strengthen ones mettle. The latter kills.

title: Going for Bolingbroke
description: BEFORE political movements can be understood by others, they need to understand themselves: what they want to be, what they actually are and how they might bridge the gap between aspiration and reality.

title: A Writer by Any Other Name
description: After J. K. Rowling admitted that she, and not a military veteran named Robert Galbraith, wrote the new mystery novel The Cuckoos Calling, The New York Times asked several writers to choose a hypothetical pen name and describe what kind of book they might write under  or perhaps behind  that name. (Note: This informal survey was conducted before any of them had a chance to consider Carlos Danger as an option.)

title: The Chatter for Sunday, July 28
description: When so many people from a single hedge fund have engaged in insider trading, it is not a coincidence.

title: Night of the Blue Crabs
description: Midnight on the Great South Bay. Smudgy clouds, a stiff wind, a full moon, now hidden, now in the clear, gloriously bright, high beams on rippling blacktop.

title: Austen on Money
description: Writers often daydream about making money, but they almost never daydream about being money. After all, the honor of appearing on a bank note is terribly posthumous. For Jane Austen, who will appear on the British 10 note probably beginning in 2017, it comes 200 years after her death. She may find the company a bit dull.

title: Republican Spin
description: Storm troopers from the Obama administration banging down your door to take away your ceiling fans? Not implausible, say House Republicans who are worried about an assault on your appliances.

title: A New Defense of Voting Rights
description: On Thursday, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. took an important step toward repairing the damage from last months Supreme Court ruling striking down a central element of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. He is right to adopt an aggressive approach to defending the most fundamental right in our democracy.

title: Mr. Putins War on Gays
description: To the long list of Russians whom President Vladimir Putin is persecuting, add gay people and those who support gay rights. Along with political dissidents, journalists and billionaire businessmen, they are increasingly the focus of repellent laws and repressive practices that could send them, and anyone who dares defend them, to jail.

title: Airport Security Without the Hassle
description: The chance of dying in an airplane is vanishingly small. The chance of being killed by a terrorist in an airplane is smaller still. Mark Stewart, a civil engineer who studies probabilistic risk, has put the odds at one in 90 million a year. Yet the best Americana, once it gathers an audience, knocks its comfortable expectations away.

The hard-working X-Men character was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, with ticket sales of about $55 million, but 20th Century Fox had hoped The Wolverine  the sixth installment in this superhero franchise  would take in at least 15 percent more. (Some box office analysts had even predicted an opening-weekend total of $75 million to $85 million.) Fox, which said it spent about $120 million to make the movie, not including marketing costs, hopes that strong interest overseas will make up for the soft reception in the United States and Canada, where audiences are increasingly expressing their fatigue with Hollywoods recycled formulas by staying home.
