Exploring the objectified body with a feminist eye. Showing the formality of a flexed buttock.

title: Harlem Stage Prepares to Export Its Own Opera
description: Since its founding 30 years ago, Harlem Stage has burnished its reputation by presenting innovative artists like Bill T. Jones and Vijay Iyer and plumbing social issues. Now, the theater is betting that Makandal  its first opera commission and an ambitious, contemporary work revolving around the leader of an 18th-century slave revolt in Haiti  will raise its international profile and win it respect as a producer. But the group faces large hurdles.

title: Old-Time Religion in Modern Guise
description: Its not unusual for a mid- or late-career white pop singer to declare an interest in African-American gospel music, especially from the 1950s, considered its late golden age. Gospel contains forces such singers might desire access to: virtuosity, resistance, belief, magic. But the picture feels different when the pop singer is, say, a 46-year-old Irish female priest  ordained in 1999 by an independent Catholic group not recognized by the church  with serious interests in Rastafari and Hinduism and serious problems with organized religion.

title: The Real Rhinemaidens of Route 66
description: BAYREUTH, Germany  Wagner traditionalists incensed by Frank Castorfs new production of Wagners Ring here at the Bayreuth Festival, which presents the epic cycle as a story of the global race for oil ricocheting from North Texas to the Caspian Sea, should take some solace: It could have been worse.

title: Popes Trip to Brazil Seen as Strong Start in Revitalizing Church
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Pope Francis celebrated the last Mass of his trip to Brazil on Sunday before more than a million people gathered on the beach in this city, the national flags of Catholics from around the world hoisted in the air as a chorus of Brazilian priests belted out songs before the multitude. It was a vibrant display of the Vaticans ambition of halting the losses of worshipers to evangelical churches and the rising appeal of secularism.

title: Air Force Asks Students to Solve Real-World Problems
description: THE Air Force, as part of its recruitment efforts, is approaching young people for help in solving real-world technological problems using a collaborative online platform.

title: Bill Would Alter FEMA Policy to Assist Co-ops and Condos
description: A group of New York and New Jersey legislators plan to introduce a bill in Congress this week seeking to change a longstanding Federal Emergency Management Agency policy that they say discriminates against the owners of cooperative and condominium apartments.

title: Like a Hilarious Story
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I always get the feeling that some of you would like nothing better than to take Monday off after a long week of tussling with the crossword puzzles. Sorry everyone, Andrea Carla Michaels wants you up out of your seats and moving.

title: Mets Are Back to Misery; Nationals Show No Mercy
description: WASHINGTON  The ugliness here Sunday was prolonged and profound.

title: PC Industry Fights to Adapt as Tablets Muscle In
description: SEATTLE  The death of the personal computer may be an exaggeration. But the industry around personal computers seems to be in limbo.

title: Theater for a New Audience Sets Full Season at New Home
description: Theater for a New Audience has announced the full schedule for the inaugural season at its new home, the Center for Shakespeare and Classical Drama, in Brooklyn. As previously reported, Julie Taymor will make her return to the New York stage for the first time since Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark to direct Shakespeares Midsummer Nights Dream, with music by Elliot Goldenthal. Previews are set to begin on Oct. 19 with opening night scheduled for Nov. 2.

title: U.S. Drone Strike Kills at Least 6 in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, PakistanAt least six militants were killed and four others injured after the latest American drone strike in Pakistans restive tribal belt on Sunday, Pakistani intelligence officials and militant commanders said.

title: Thief Gets Away With Estimated $50 Million in Jewelry at a French Riviera Hotel
description: A jewel thief brandishing a gun entered an exclusive hotel along the French Riviera on Sunday morning, eluded security guards and well-heeled guests, and left with a glittering haul worth perhaps $50 million, according to the regional state prosecutors office.

title: Baltusrol Is a Landmark Course in Almost Every Sense
description: Golf is often associated with exclusivity. But truly exclusive clubs in the United States might have more to do with history than high-priced memberships.

title: Outrage as Homeowners Prepare for Substantially Higher Flood Insurance Rates
description: For the last seven years, Palmer Doyle, a retired firefighter, has paid between $350 and $458 annually for federal flood insurance. He lives a block and a half from the water in Queens, but his premiums have stayed low because of a federal policy that had protected residents from sharp increases in flood insurance costs.

title: Dozens Killed as Bus Plunges in Italy
description: ROME  At least 37 passengers died when a bus hit several cars and plunged 50 feet off a viaduct on the A16 highway in the Campania region of Italy, the local authorities said. The stretch of road between the towns of Monteforte Irpino and Baiano, near Avellino, is mountainous.

title: Historians Seek a Delay in Posting Dissertations
description: FIRST came years of being a foot messenger in New York City and working in data entry. Then, frustrated with his life, and feeling the responsibility of providing for a child, Michael D. Hattem entered the Borough of Manhattan Community College  the only college that would admit him, he says, as a high school dropout with a G.E.D. He succeeded at community college, and, in 2011, graduated from City College.

title: After Delayed Vote, E.P.A. Gains a Tough Leader to Tackle Climate Change
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md.  When Lisa P. Jackson announced at the end of last year that she was stepping down as the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, President Obama faced a choice. He could play it safe by appointing her deputy or he could confront Congress head-on and signal a strong commitment to tackling climate change by appointing the agencys head of air quality, Gina McCarthy.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of July 29
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released will include pending home sales for June (Monday); the Standard & Poors Case-Shiller home price index for May and the consumer confidence index for July (Tuesday); the first estimate of second-quarter gross domestic product, ADP employment for July, and the Chicago Purchasing Manager Index report for July (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, Institute for Supply Management data for July and auto sales for July (Thursday); and the United States unemployment report for July, factory orders for June and consumer spending for June (Friday).

title: VCRs Past Is Guiding Televisions Future
description: The last few weeks have been a rugged legal stretch for incumbent television companies.

title: Bloomberg Media Recruits a New Chief From The Atlantic
description: Justin B. Smith, whose digital strategy swiftly transformed The Atlantic, one of the statelier media vessels around, is about to get a bigger boat.

title: Mali Holds Elections After Year of Turmoil
description: Under pressure from France and other Western powers, Mali held a presidential election on Sunday that some observers said the country was not ready for and that risked excluding thousands of its citizens.

title: A Link Straight to Syrias Ancient Past Endures as War Creeps Closer
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The Street Called Straight, long bereft of its bustle, was finally crowded again. Wall to wall, people shuffled forward in a slow procession. Shopkeepers had closed their wooden shutters, packing away the inlaid furniture and brocade shawls that no one had been buying anyway, to clear the sidewalks for a funeral parade.

title: Off-Season Problems Cloud Hopes for Giants Connor and Hill
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Not every day of a football training camp is sunny, cheery and full of enthusiasm.

title: So Much More Than Peter Rabbit
description: Like Beatrix Potter  the author of The Tale of Peter Rabbit whose 147th birthday is July 28, 2013  I have long kept journals. Unlike hers, mine are not written in a code that will not be deciphered until years after my death. My best friend has instructions in the event I die before her, though, to fly across the country immediately and destroy them. They arent meant for anyone but me, a reminder of the moments of my life, good and bad.

title: This Heroine Wears a Burqa to Fight Evil
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Cartoon fans in Pakistan have been excited by the arrival of the countrys first caped crusader, in the form of a female superhero who flies through the air, battling villains using pens and books.

title: Jets Ryan, Used to Having Last Word, Becomes Voice in the Mix
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  There was once a time when Rex Ryan would speak as if he were the prevailing voice on all on-field decisions for the Jets. That time was Thursday, when Ryan, addressing the timetable for announcing whether Mark Sanchez or Geno Smith would start at quarterback, said, When I make that decision, clearly Ill feel great about it.

title: White House Muted in Response to New Mass Killing of Egyptian Protesters
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations response was once again muted on Sunday after the second mass killing of Egyptian demonstrators in three weeks, as Western diplomats worked behind the scenes to calm the tensions, and lawmakers expressed scant support for cutting off American aid to Egypt.

title: Syrian Opposition Leader Says He Would Meet Assad Officials
description: The new head of the main Syrian exile opposition group says he is prepared to attend a peace conference in Geneva with representatives of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria without preconditions.

title: Detroit Looks to Health Law to Ease Costs
description: As Detroit enters the federal bankruptcy process, the city is proposing a controversial plan for paring some of the $5.7 billion it owes in retiree health costs: pushing many of those too young to qualify for Medicare out of city-run coverage and into the new insurance markets that will soon be operating under the Obama health care law.

title: Only Echoes Stir the Quiet at the Hall of Fame
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  The Baseball Hall of Fame celebrates the sports history at this time each year by inducting at least one new member with small-town pomp and fealty to decades of tradition.

title: Gangplank to a Warm Future
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  MANY concerned about climate change, including President Obama, have embraced hydraulic fracturing for natural gas. In his recent climate speech, the president went so far as to lump gas with renewables as clean energy.

title: A Crescendo of Errors
description: FITZGERALD did it. Can you believe that? And in Gatsby, no less. It sent me reeling. The historian James M. McPherson did it in Battle Cry of Freedom. Twice. George F. Will, William Safire and countless other prominent journalists have done it, as have Southern writers, Northern writers, writers of science and of science fiction, novices and old pros.

title: Two Ad Giants Chasing Google in Merger Deal
description: For years, the advertising business has been driven by the Madison Avenue mythology of small independent shops coming up with the snappy catchphrase or memorable TV commercial that becomes part of everyday culture.

title: Ukrainian Court Fines Feminist Protesters
description: A court in Kiev fined three activists of Femen, the Ukrainian feminist organization known for its bare-breasted protests, and a Russian photojournalist on Sunday and released them following their Saturday arrest.

title: One Goal, but Plenty for U.S. to Celebrate in Gold Cup Final
description: CHICAGO  Landon Donovan did not score the goal that clinched a title for the United States in the Gold Cup, a tournament that will be remembered for his return to the national team and the national stage. Nor was he credited with the assist.

title: Not Too Big to Fail
description: New rules on bank capital, recently proposed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and other bank regulators, are a welcome step toward a safer and sounder financial system. And they come at a politically timely moment. Big banks invariably argue that new rules will impede their ability to thrive and, in the process, harm the economy. But their profits are soaring, even as the economy slows, a situation that makes their shopworn anti-regulatory argument all the more threadbare.

title: A Straphangers Campaign
description: Say this for Rudolph Giuliani: In 1997 he made it free to ride the Staten Island Ferry, a small daily improvement in commuters lives that, multiplied by millions of rides and many years, surely adds up to something monumental.

title: More Independence for the FISA Court
description: There are so many deeply troubling things about the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court that it is difficult to know where to begin, but a good place might be the method by which the courts judges are chosen.

title: Jacksons Earning Potential Is at the Heart of a Wrongful-Death Suit
description: He is one of the top-grossing artists in music. His influence is heard all over the Top 10, his songs have inspired two hit Cirque du Soleil shows, and Jay Z raps about him obsessively as the ultimate symbol of success.

title: Stranded by Sprawl
description: Detroit is a symbol of the old economys decline. Its not just the derelict center; the metropolitan area as a whole lost population between 2000 and 2010, the worst performance among major cities. Atlanta, by contrast, epitomizes the rise of the Sun Belt; it gained more than a million people over the same period, roughly matching the performance of Dallas and Houston without the extra boost from oil.

title: Momentum Builds Against N.S.A. Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  The movement to crack down on government surveillance started with an odd couple from Michigan, Representatives Justin Amash, a young libertarian Republican known even to his friends as chief wing nut, and John Conyers Jr., an elder of the liberal left in his 25th House term.

title: Few Suitors to Build a New Marine One
description: Wanting to clamp down on wasteful spending, President Obama halted a project to create new presidential helicopters four years ago, saying its soaring price was a symbol of government contracting gone amok.

title: Weak Finish From Europe on Chinese Solar Panels
description: HONG KONG  The European Commissions investigation of solar-panel imports from China was the worlds biggest antidumping case when it began last September, signaling a new willingness in Brussels to challenge Chinas extensive assistance to favored export-oriented industries.

title: Profiling Obama
description: FOR much of his public life, Barack Obama has been navigating between people who think he is too black and people who think he is not black enough.

title: Facing a Recall After Supporting Stronger Gun Laws in Colorado
description: DENVER  As he prepared to vote for some of the strictest gun control measures in the country earlier this year, John Morse, a former police chief and president of the State Senate, knew he would infuriate some constituents.

title: Aberdeen, With a Foot on the Seafloor
description: ABERDEEN, Scotland  Peter Blake has an American employer, the oil giant Chevron, and his work is global. It is his job to pull together and dispatch billions of dollars worth of sophisticated undersea equipment needed for oil and natural gas fields in the Gulf of Mexico and offshore from Angola, the Republic of Congo, Indonesia and Australia.

title: Verrazano Back in Conversation for Top 3-Year-Old After Record Haskell Win
description: OCEANPORT, N.J.  Verrazanos trainer, the usually stoic Todd Pletcher, was hugging and high-fiving anyone who wandered into his path in the winners circle at Monmouth Park on Sunday. The New Jersey residents Kevin Scatuorchio and Bryan Sullivan, managers of the colts main ownership group, Lets Go Stable, swapped the Yankees caps they favor for the backside with ones bearing their colts name, and they were all smiles, too, taking time to breathe in the warm ocean air.

title: Voting Rule Change Is Seen as Crucial to Dell Founders Takeover Bid
description: A seemingly small concession during the original negotiations over the proposed takeover of Dell by the companys founder has come into focus in the increasingly protracted deal saga.

title: Protesters Press Tunisian Government to Resign, as Ruling Party Supporters Rally
description: TUNIS  Protests continued around the country Sunday on the fourth day after the assassination of an opposition legislator. Demonstrators were back out in front of the National Assembly building after police officers broke up their camp overnight and opposition parties continued to press for the government and the National Constituent Assembly to resign.

title: Beauty School Students Left With Broken Promises and Large Debts
description: The debt collectors call so often that Amarilis Madera knows them by name. For years, they have threatened to take her possessions and drain her bank account. In February, her $5,000 tax refund was seized.

title: Seeking Support, Biotech Food Companies Pledge Transparency
description: With pressure growing to label genetically modified foods, the developers of biotechnology crops are starting a campaign to gain support for their products by promising new openness.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Rare Chance to Stroll a Park Avenue Tunnel, in the Name of Art
description: Since the 1930s, the Park Avenue tunnel has been closed to pedestrians, and its weathered stone walls and ridged metal ceiling have been visible only to New Yorkers whipping past inside their automobiles.

title: In Old City of Damascus, War Closes In
description: Straight Street has been known since at least the early years of Christianity for its ramrod course through the twisting alleys of the old city of Damascus.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (1) vs. Panama (0)
description: For the first time since 2007, the United States national team is the Gold Cup Champion, its title secured with a 1-0 victory over an upstart Panama team on Sunday at Soldier Field in Chicago.

title: Body Found in Hudson Believed to Be 2nd Boat Crash Victim
description: The police said Sunday that a body discovered in the Hudson River by a Jet Ski rider was probablythat of the second victim of a boat crash Friday night that also killed a bride-to-be.

title: Obama Invites Hillary Clinton to Lunch
description: President Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton will have a private lunch at the White House on Monday.

title: A Fascination With Sanitation Work (and the Rsum to Prove It)
description: Robin Nagle, a self-described P.K.  preachers kid, offers a benediction for the citys sanitation workers. She has even inscribed it in a book that she wrote about them.

title: Garry Davis, Man of No Nation Who Saw One World of No War, Dies at 91
description: On May 25, 1948, a former United States Army flier entered the American Embassy in Paris, renounced his American citizenship and, as astonished officials looked on, declared himself a citizen of the world.

title: National Figures Call for Weiner to Leave Mayors Race
description: New York Citys political elite have spent days attacking Anthony D. Weiners increasingly embattled mayoral campaign. On Sunday, it was Washingtons turn.

title: Summer Tacos
description: Ive always had a weakness for green salsa made with tomatillos, so when I stumbled upon a stall at a small farmers market selling beautiful firm, purple-tinged tomatillos last week, I bought them on impulse. I let the other produce at the market guide my decisions about the taco fillings I now knew Id be working on in the coming days. That wasnt difficult; the same farmer who had the tomatillos had pink-skinned potatoes and red onions. I bought corn and squash, cilantro and beautiful green beans at other stands. And now I had a great destination for the serrano chiles that were ready in my garden.

title: Photo Replay, July 22-28
description: Looking back at the week in sports, from the opening of N.F.L. training camps to the swimming world championships in Spain.

title: A New Role for Amazon: An Engine for Jobs
description: American technology companies like Apple have been criticized for outsourcing manufacturing of their gadgets to China, rather than employing people to do the work in the United States. But one tech icon, Amazon, is seeking to call attention to the thousands of working-class jobs its creating in the United States.

title: Understanding Eczema to Treat It
description: Summer is both a blessing and curse for millions of people afflicted with a common chronic skin condition called eczema. The dry, red and usually intolerably itchy patches often recede when the air is warm and damp and skin is exposed more often to sunlight.

title: Fast Food Versus Slow Food
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 29
description: The military needs to be taught a lesson. At this point its a zero-sum game: its either the Brotherhood or the old regime.

title: Vows: Christine and Indra
description: Christine Guan and Indra Sen went international, yet local, for their wedding in Flushing, Queens.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (Univision) LA TEMPESTAD Damin Fabr (William Levy), a tough and sexy sea captain in Nuestra Seora del Mar, a fictional town on the Mexican Gulf Coast, begins a torrid relationship with Marina Reverte (Ximena Navarrete, a former Miss Universe, above with Mr. Levy), a beautiful refugee from the city who has abandoned her career in hotel management to lead the local fishery, in this new Spanish-language telenovela, which translates as The Storm. But galelike forces are intent on keeping them apart  among them, the mayor (Csar vora) and his daughter (Laura Carmine); Marinas biological mother (Daniela Romo) and twin sister (Ms. Navarrete again); her former schoolmate (Ivn Snchez), with links to the mafia; and the mobster (Manuel Ojeda), who separated Marina from her family in the first place. Christina Aguilera performs with Alejandro Fernndez on the opening soundtrack. Closed captioning in English is available.

title: Reinvented in His 60s, After 26 Jobless Months
description: When I last wrote about Michael Blattman, it was August 2009, he was 58 years old, and had been unemployed for 18 months. Like a lot of baby boomers during the Great Recession, he had worked his whole adult life and could not believe this was happening to him.

title: News Quiz | July 29, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Cambodian Opposition Rejects Election Results
description: PHNOM PENH  Cambodia faces a volatile and possibly prolonged political standoff after leaders of the opposition said on Monday that they rejected the preliminary results of Sundays election and accused the authoritarian government of Prime Minister Hun Sen of large-scale cheating to achieve a relatively narrow victory.

title: 38 People Killed as Bus Plunges Off Highway in Italy
description: ROME  At least 38 people died and more than 10 were seriously injured on Sunday night when a bus plunged off a viaduct on a treacherous stretch of mountainous highway in the Campania region of southern Italy, officials told the Italian news media.

title: A Reunion for War Survivors Who Escaped to India
description: On August 3, Franek Herzog, 82, will travel from Hebron in Connecticut to Orchard Lake in Michigan for a two-day reunion with a group of Polish war survivors. Mr. Herzog and his 18 friends will spend some of their time together recalling the arduous, improbable journeys they made seven decades ago from their war-torn homes in Poland to the erstwhile Indian princely state of Nawanagar, which provided an oasis for approximately 1,000 Polish children for four years until the hostilities ceased.

title: Test Yourself | Math, July 29, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question, created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article Masked Lawman Stumbles at the Gate.

title: A Modernists Challenge to Instant Gratification
description: We live in an age of instant gratification. Our news is delivered as it happens, our musings liked before our eyes. Our photographs pop up on the back of our cameras  or online  moments after clicking the shutter.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Pope Francis in Brazil
description: In Popes Trip to Brazil Seen as Strong Start in Revitalizing Church, Simon Romero writes about the new popes first international trip.

title: Wave of Car Bombs Kills Dozens in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A surge of violence in Iraq continued Monday when 15 car bombs killed at least 50 people and injured more than 100, according to security officials.

title: Perrigo to Buy Irish Drug Maker Elan for $6.7 Billion
description: LONDON  The drug company Perrigo agreed on Monday to acquire the Irish biotechnology company Elan in a cash-and-stock deal worth $6.7 billion.

title: Young, Black and Poor in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  A crowd of one million gathered here last Tuesday for the opening mass of World Youth Day, a Catholic extravaganza that this year included a visit by Pope Francis. Rios archbishop, Orani Tempesta, started the ceremony on a somber note, reminding attendees that July 23 also marked the 20th anniversary of the killing of eight homeless children in front of Candelria church, one of the most revered Catholic sanctuaries in this most Catholic of nations.

title: Driving in America May Have Peaked in 2004
description: At the dawn of the automobile age, America took the motor vehicle, made it its own and shaped it into something that has influenced transportation the world over for the last century. Theres no doubt about it, Americans are car people. But a University of Michigan study published this month reports that, by several measures, light-duty vehicle driving miles in the United States peaked in 2004, before the economic downturn.

title: New York Today: Some Pig
description: A piglet was found skittering among the cars and pedestrians on College Point Boulevard in Queens last week. He was most likely on a jailbreak from a local slaughterhouse, avoiding a bacon fate.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Andrew Meier on the 11 Men and 1 Woman Who Would Be New Yorks Next Mayor
description: Andrew Meier wrote this weeks cover story on the 12 candidates seeking to become the next mayor of New York City. Meier last wrote for the magazine about the Russian opposition figure Ksenia Sobchak.

title: Fear of Froth
description: Carola Binder parses President Obamas big interview with the Times, and thinks it hints at a Summers, or anyway non-Yellen appointment. Maybe; in any case, can I say just how really stupid it is for the White House to have allowed this show even to get started? Here we have Obama trying to reboot his economic message, and much of the reporting is instead focused on palace intrigue.

title: Hunting for Luxury, Retail Giant Buys Saks
description: Updated, 8:49 p.m. |  When the real estate scion Richard A. Bakeracquired the department store chain Lord & Taylorat the market peak in 2006, retail industry players laughed. Mr. Baker, they snickered, was just the latest money guy who would get clobbered trying to break into the fashion business.

title: Advertising in the Business of Big Data
description: IN MERGER, AD GIANTS CHASE GOOGLE | The announcement on Sunday that Omnicom and Publicis would merge to create the largest advertising company in the world signals that advertising is now in the business of Big Data: collecting and selling the personal information of millions of consumers, Tanzina Vega writes in The New York Times.

title: After the Delhi Rape, Small Victories for Women in Indias Popular Culture
description: There are few better places to advertise products of mass appeal than the back of an auto-rickshaw. In the recent past, we have seen the gainful surface being used to sell, among other things, CDs of the self-help superstar Shiv Khera and books of the popular fiction phenomenon Chetan Bhagat.

title: On Gay Priests, Pope Francis Asks, Who Am I to Judge?
description: ROME  For generations, homosexuality has largely been a taboo topic for the Vatican, ignored altogether or treated as an intrinsic moral evil, in the words of the previous pope.

title: A Day in the Life of My iPhone
description: Each morning at 7 a.m., I am awakened by the sound of a spaceship next to my bed. I reach my arm from under the covers, flail around blindly looking for my glasses, then grab my iPhone to silence my alarm. But its not any normal alarm clock; its an app, Walk Up!, which requires you to get up and walk around until the alarm stops its annoying blares.

description: The investment banking arm of the Royal Bank of Canada said on Monday that it had hired two bankers, one to cover health care companies and the other to work with consumer corporations, as it continued to expand its footprint in the United States.

title: In Ad Merger, a Boon for Two Smaller Banks
description: The $35.1 billion merger of Publicis and Omnicom, creating a new behemoth in the advertising industry, raised eyebrows for many reasons.

title: An Olympic Legend on Boycotts and Bigotry
description: Last week, as Russias cruel and repressive laws regarding gays and lesbians drew rapidly intensifying concern, gay bars throughout the United States pulled Russian vodka from their shelves. LGBT Americans and their supporters seemed to agree: a message had to be sent to Russia and its president, Vladimir Putin, and a boycott of Stolichnaya was one way to do it.

title: William W. Scranton, 96, G.O.P. Prodigy Who Led Pennsylvania, Is Dead
description: William W. Scranton, the moderate Republican governor of Pennsylvania from 1963 to 1967, who lost a run for his partys presidential nomination in 1964 and later served as the United States representative to the United Nations, died on Sunday in Montecito, Calif. He was 96.

title: Scientists Seek to Rein In Diagnoses of Cancer

description: Sweden is drawing attention to emissions from food production by requiring new labels and encouraging farmers to adhere to greener standards in order to combat climate change.

description: With new technology, builders are imagining structures made entirely of glass.

title: Where Rent Is Stabilized, Reopening After Storm Is No Certainty
description: Ronnie Landfield is a painter whose works have hung in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art, but most of his paintings  powerful waves of color, many measuring 9 feet by 10 feet, or 9 feet by 12  rest in racks in his Manhattan art studio. And that setup is not too shabby, either.

title: Image of the Day: July 29
Why I Hate Pinterest
description: Several months ago, I casually mentioned to friends that I was planning a pirate-themed birthday party at home for my 4-year-old son.

title: Longtime Apple Leader Drops Out of Executive Team
description: Bob Mansfield, a longtime top executive at Apple, has switched to a role outside the executive team, the latest change in management at the company.

title: New York Film Festival Will Open With Captain Phillips
description: For a film series that in the first few of its 51 annual programs began with works from directors like Luis Buuel, Jean-Luc Godard and Franois Truffaut, the New York Film Festival has more recently used its prestigious opening-night slot to spotlight more visible, mainstream and star-studded efforts. Those descriptions all apply to Captain Phillips, a new motion picture with Tom Hanks that will make its premiere as the opening-night selection of this years New York Film Festival, its organizers said Monday.

title: Colm Mulcahy: Sum Trick
description: This weeks puzzle is an original creation from a card expert, Colm Mulcahy, who will be a featured speaker and performer at the upcoming Mathematics of Various Entertaining Subjects (Moves) conference Aug. 4-8 at the Museum of Mathematics in Manhattan. If youre not attending the conference (registration is now closed), this weeks adventure will give you a taste of the experience.

title: Judge Says Bernanke Should Testify in A.I.G. Case
description: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, who was one of the central decision makers in the 2008 bailout of the American International Group, may have to revisit those tumultuous days in sworn testimony.

title: A Chef in the Field | Striped Bass
description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Sinclair Group Is Buying 7 Allbritton TV Stations
description: A busy summer of television station consolidation continued on Monday when the Sinclair Broadcast Group, already one of the countrys biggest owners of local stations, announced the acquisition of seven stations from the Allbritton family, including WJLA, the coveted ABC affiliate in Washington, D.C.

title: A Kennedy Babys Life and Death
description: WASHINGTON  Fifty years ago this summer, the nation was transfixed by a medical drama that is now largely forgotten: the desperate struggle to save the life of Patrick Bouvier Kennedy, the first baby born to a sitting president and first lady since the 19th century.

title: Son of Fallen Chinese Official Enrolls at Columbia Law School
description: The youngest son of Bo Xilai, the former senior Communist Party official now awaiting a criminal trial, has enrolled at Columbia Law School and is expected to begin studies this fall, according to a family associate and a person from Beijing with high-level contacts.

title: July 29: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: A Documentary by Teller Explores the Magic of Vermeer
description: A picture may be worth a thousand words, and Teller, the nonspeaking partner in the illusionist team of Penn & Teller, is a man of few. Still, hes interested enough in pictures, paintings and the creation of fine art that he has made them the subject of a new documentary, Tims Vermeer, that has been acquired for distribution by Sony Pictures Classics.

title: If Its Customers Love a Business, This Equity Firm Does, Too
description: The bookshelves and coffee tables at the offices of the private equity firm Brentwood Associates offer a window into its consumer-focused portfolio: Sundance catalogs with artisan jewelry and designer jeans; menus for vegan cuisine at Veggie Grill; stationery and calendars from Paper Source; DVDs for The Great Courses lectures on topics as varied as astronomy and wine tasting.

title: Lunch at the White House, and Friendship Is Served
description: WASHINGTON  Hillary Rodham Clinton has walked the halls of the White House as a first lady, a senator and a secretary of state. On Monday, she returned as a former diplomat who might just want one more job.

title: Street Style: Office Wear
description: The best of readers photos from the week of July 29.

title: Driving a 1935 Avions Voisin C25 Arodyne
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  To take a spin in a 1935 Avions Voisin C25 Arodyne, first one must learn how to get into it. Of course, it has doors  with delicate nickel-plated handles  but you must tug on them with just enough pressure to flex the handles outward. This effort separates a catch from a door-frame latch; there is no mechanical locking mechanism. The door is now free to open. Inside, to coax the door back into its frame, pull on a leather strap that comes out of the door panel, rather like summoning ones servant.

title: Science Events: Math Games, Bugs and Cloud Machines
description: MUSEUM

title: Reviewing the Deal One Business Made on Shark Tank
description: A recent episode of Shark Tank included a segment on a company called Nuts N More. By all accounts, the companys appearance was a big success. When the show was taped, the companys annual sales were about $100,000; they are now on track to hit $1 million. Dennis Iannotti, one of three partners in the company, attributes the growth to the tremendous exposure gained from the show.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

title: China Opts for Only Small Steps to Stimulate Economy
description: Beijing continues to resist a new large fiscal stimulus package, despite a report last week that the nations manufacturing sector had contracted in July at its fastest pace since last summer. Instead, the government announced a mini stimulus that included a tax cut for small companies, a reduction of red tape and costs for exporters, and the opening of investment in railroad construction to private capital.

title: Fall for Dance Lineup Expands
description: Seven more companies have been announced as part of the lineup of 24 international dance groups appearing at the Fall for Dance festival, Sept. 25-Oct. 5 at City Center. This is the 10th anniversary of the festival, which for the first time will include two free shows at the Delacorte Theater on Sept. 16 and 17, hosted by the Public Theater.

title: How Common Is It to Dream of Smelling Something?
description: Q. In a dream, I recognized the perfume worn by a family member. How common is it to dream of smelling something?

title: Court to Decide if Lawyers Can Block Gays From Juries
description: WASHINGTON  Last months Supreme Court rulings on same-sex marriage were major gay rights victories. But countless questions about the legal rights of gay men and lesbians remain.

title: Protesters in Rio Keep Asking, Who Threw the Molotov? and Where Is Amarildo?
description: Seeking to refute allegations that an undercover police officer had thrown a Molotov cocktail at a demonstration last week in Rio de Janeiro, sparking violent clashes, the citys military police force released slow-motion video of the masked bomb thrower, the newspaper O Globo reported Friday.

title: Military Continues Crackdown in Egypt
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian authorities pressed their crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood and its allies on Monday, arresting two more senior Islamist leaders and hinting at possibly declaring a state of emergency, even as the European Unions top diplomat was visiting Cairo and talking to both sides in an attempt to mediate an easing of the crisis.

title: Weekly News Quiz | July 23-29, 2013
description: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

title: Rite Aid Offers Extra Goodies to Customers 65 and Up
description: The Rite Aid Corporation has introduced a new loyalty program for customers 65 and older, based on its earlier wellness+ loyalty program, that it is promoting through a multi-media campaign.

title: The Complicated Killer Whale, A New War Against Germs, An Instrument That Changes With the Venue
description: What can science tell us about an orcas intelligence? One researchers quest to find drug-resistant germs that pass from animals to humans. Have you ever heard of a harp the size of a mountainside?

title: CBS Renews Under the Dome for a Second Season
description: LOS ANGELES  To the surprise of no one, CBS said on Monday that it would bring back its huge summer hit Under the Dome for a second series of episodes next summer.

title: Legacy Cemented, and Career Renewed
description: WASHINGTON  For most athletes, induction to their sports hall of fame would be an ending of sorts. But for Martina Hingis, it was just another beginning.

title: Lessons From the Glaxo Case in China
description: In advertising, the adage is that sex sells. In the world of white-collar crime, it is rare that there is anything other than money at stake, but the continuing corruption investigation in China into the British pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline now has a dash of the libido to draw even more attention.

title: Book Covers: Before and After
description: In the latest installment of Before and After, four book designers discuss recent examples of their work. Each designer shared early concepts for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

title: Walkabout: Jewel Thief Strikes France; American Business Travelers Return to Europe
description: Hitchcockian A jewel thief left the Carlton Intercontinental Hotel in Cannes, France, above, on Sunday morning with a glittering haul worth perhaps $50 million. And, no, its not a plot from To Catch a Thief. (New York Times)

title: Harnessing Physics in Grand Spaces to Make Music
description: From the stage of the Shanghai Grand Theater in China more than a dozen strings stretch from a wooden wing out across the audience and disappear into the darkness of the upper balconies. Its an instrument unlike anything Bach or Beethoven could have ever imagined. The entire concert hall has been recruited as an echo chamber to create a unique, ethereal sound. But this instrument has turned even grander spaces into music makers. When anchored to the Colosseum in Rome or Seattles Space Needle, the worlds largest string instrument is both a powerful sonic experience and an arresting visual image.

title: Potato Salad and Tomatillo Tacos
description: The filling for these tacos can also stand alone as a potato salad, but its very nice and comforting inside a warm tortilla.

title: Daniel Yergin on George Mitchells Shale Energy Innovations and Concerns
description: As news spread over the weekend of the death of George P. Mitchell, the 94-year-old Texas oil man widely credited with playing a pivotal role in unlocking the shale energy era, I reached out for a reaction from Daniel Yergin, the Pulitzer-winning chronicler of humanitys fossil fuel era. (He is also vice chairman of the consulting firm IHS.)

title: Romneys Reflections
description: Two of the big questions about Mitt Romney when he was running for president in 2012 were: How much did he want the job? And, just how out of touch with reality was he? The answers, judging from an excerpt in the Washington Post of Dan Balzs new book Collision 2012, are: Not much, and more than we ever imagined.

title: Fainting in Heat
description: With temperatures in the Northeast often in the 90s this summer  and the heat index sometimes surpassing 100 degrees  just standing on the street or on a steamy subway platform can place the body under excessive stress. In New York City during the week of July 14, 911 calls were up by 9 percent over the previous year, with many related to the heat, the fire department said.

title: Bryce Pinkham and LaChanze Are Broadway Bound
description: Casting additions to two shows scheduled for the coming Broadway season were announced on Monday. Bryce Pinkham, who is playing Longaville in the Public Theaters Shakespeare in the Park production of Loves Labours Lost, will join the cast of A Gentlemans Guide to Love and Murder, the musical by Robert L. Freedman and Steven Lutvak that had a successful run in Hartford last fall and opens on Broadway at the Walter Kerr Theater on Oct. 22. Mr. Pinkham is to play Monty Navarro, who stands to become the Earl of Highhurst once he dispatches the eight better claimants. Those eight heirs are all portrayed by Jefferson Mays, who played the octuple role in Hartford. The show is directed by Darko Tresnjak.

title: Talks Begin on Mideast, to Doubts on All Sides
description: WASHINGTON  For all of the intricacies of issues like the shape of future borders, security arrangements and the status of Jerusalem, the Middle East peace talks that resumed Monday night are dominated by two simple questions: If it took Secretary of State John Kerry countless phone calls and six trips to the Middle East just to get Israeli and Palestinian officials to the negotiating table, how will it be possible to achieve a comprehensive peace agreement? And what will happen if his herculean negotiating efforts fall short?

title: BMW Unveils i3 Electric Car
description: BMW seems to have stepped into the limelight with confidence where its first all-new electric car is concerned. At its official introduction Monday in New York, London and Beijing, BMW promised that the i3 would be, despite its new architecture and batteries-only powertrain, like every other ultimate driving machine in terms of driving quality.

title: Hedge Funds Suit on Fannie and Freddie May Spell Trouble for U.S.
description: The lawsuit brought by the hedge fund Perry Capital against the federal government over the Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac bailout may be the case that finally subjects the governments bailout practices to closer outside scrutiny.

title: Some Investing Stories Sound Good Until You Analyze Them
description: Making smart money decisions is an incredibly difficult way to behave. So after my post last week about buying a house based on your situation, my jaw dropped when I saw an article in The Wall Street Journal about young home buyers.

title: Historians Defend Howard Zinn Against a Former Governors Critique
description: Updated, 4:18 p.m. | The historian Howard Zinn won a dubious prize of sorts last year when his best-selling Peoples History of the United States came in second in an informal online poll to determine the least credible history book in print.

title: Tourres Defense Rests Without Calling a Witness
description: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | Lawyers for Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader accused of defrauding investors in a mortgage deal six years ago, rested their defense on Monday without calling any witnesses, a surprise move that now sets the stage for the closing of one of the most prominent cases from the financial crisis to go to trial.

title: Verifying Gmail on the Road
description: Q. I have the Gmail two-step verification turned on for my account, but I am preparing to travel overseas and will not be able to use my cellphone to get verification codes. Should I just turn off the two-step verification for my trip?

title: Hurricane Tips From Cuba
description: HAVANA  Old computer processors whirred and paint crumbled from the walls in the National Prognostic Center of Cubas Meteorological Institute, set on a rise above Havanas old city. Half a dozen meteorologists shifted their gaze between satellite images on large video screens and a giant overhead map of the United States.

title: With Too Much Rain in the South, Too Little Produce on the Shelves
description: FORT VALLEY, Ga.  Peaches, the gem of the Southern summer, are just not so sweet this year.

title: Tracing Germs Through the Aisles
description: Twice a month for a year, Lance Price, a microbiologist at George Washington University, sent his researchers out to buy every brand of chicken, turkey and pork on sale in each of the major grocery stores in Flagstaff, Ariz. As scientists pushed carts heaped with meat through the aisles, curious shoppers sometimes asked if they were on the Atkins diet.

title: Wasteful, Harsh and Discriminatory
description: Last week brought a wave of good news in the battle to stop states and cities from enforcing harsh, discriminatory immigration laws.

title: When Clean Was a New Concept in the Operating Room
description: Today, keeping things clean as a way to ward off germs and infections just makes sense. But before antibiotic-resistant superbugs became a hospitals biggest concern, there were the bad old days when doctors would move from surgery to surgery without washing. And surprisingly it was only during the 20th century that sterilization evolved from a simple and very new concept into one of the most important life-saving practices in medicine.

title: Behind the Popes Surprising Shift
description: The Timess Ian Fisher, a former Rome bureau chief, on the popes statement on gay priests and how it differentiates Francis from previous leaders of the Catholic Church.

title: The New Mideast Talks: Much Risk, Little Hope, but Still We Must Try
description: WASHINGTON  THE success of Secretary of State John Kerry in leading Israelis and Palestinians to resume negotiations is presenting the United States with an immense challenge.

title: White House Ties Immigration Overhaul to Farms
description: An immigration overhaul of the kind supported by President Obama would help ensure a stable, predictable work force for the nations agricultural industries, a new report released by the White House argues.

title: Concerns About Dementia Screening
description: Marie Theriault started having trouble with her hands more than three years ago. She was the director of a day care center, but suddenly she couldnt change diapers or tie shoelaces. She started dropping things.

title: Triple Play: Week 17 Results
description: Injuries decided the answer to Question No. 1 before the week began. A couple of achy quads and perhaps some off-field issues took the likely favorites out of the running, as Alex Rodriguez did not play all week, and Derek Jeter returned on the last day. A knee injury to Luis Cruz left Eduardo Nunez as the only legitimate choice.

title: More Classical Music on the Radio for Westchester County
description: Over-the-air broadcasts of the classical music radio station WQXR are being restored for some Westchester County residents. The stations parent company, New York Public Radio, on Monday bought the small Ossining radio station WDFH-FM, at 90.3.

title: Man Who Disappeared From Long Island College Hospital Is Found in Florida
description: The peculiar journey of Celso Heredia appears to have ended happily over the weekend  though, like everything else in his six-week odyssey, in somewhat bizarre fashion.

title: For Some Worms, Its Heads or Tails
description: Losing your head is a bigger problem for some species than others. Among flatworms, there are those that can fully regenerate a severed head or tail, and those that can regrow only a tail. The question is, Why the difference?

title: Troubling I.C.U. Stays (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: New World Fort
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: That Photogenic Blueberry Pie
description: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tweaked for home cooks.

title: The She-Devil of Constitution Avenue
description: Ive spent five years and more watching the inflationphobes, who werent particularly sensible to begin with, descend into shrill unholy madness. They could have reacted to the failure of their predictions  the continued absence of the runaway inflation they insisted was just around the corner  by stepping back and reconsidering both their model and their recommendations. But no. At best, we see a proliferation of new reasons to raise interest rates in a depressed economy, with nary an acknowledgment that previous predictions were dead wrong. At worst, we see conspiracy theories  we actually have double-digit inflation, but the BLS is spiriting the evidence away in its black helicopters and burying it in Area 51.

title: Thompson and de Blasio Vie for Opening as Quinn Rises
description: William C. Thompson Jr. stood in front of City Hall on Monday flanked by two elected officials, both of them pastors. One by one, each called for New York State to stop prosecuting nonviolent 16- and 17-year-olds as adults.

title: On Beauty | Drip Bars: The Latest Craze for Wellness Fanatics
description: After Miamis Ultra Music Festival in March, a debilitated crowd rebuffed the hair of the dog for the new South Beach fix: intravenous vitamin and electrolyte cocktails at Reviv, a buzzy Hydration Med-Spa that opened off Collins Avenue last summer and will expand to Las Vegass MGM Grand  where it will be open daily until midnight  in the next two weeks.

title: Monday Motorsports: A Native Son Wins at the Brickyard
description: Ryan Newman, an Indiana native, scored a victory on Sunday in the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: Stuck, With a Swarm of Mosquitoes, on a Guadalajara Runway
description: MY parents were in the travel business, and I took my first international flight as a teenager in the 1970s. I design hotels around the world and most of my travel involves presenting ideas to potential clients and making sure that current clients are happy. People still like face-to-face meetings, especially in my business.

title: Choreographers Crucible: Friendship and Tragedy
description: There is something almost painfully romantic about the memories of viewers wowed by dancers you yourself never had the chance to see. Take this account, by the Russian ballet dancer Vera Sergeevna Kostrovitskaya, who came of age at the Imperial Theater School in St. Petersburg amid the chaotic, difficult years surrounding the 1917 revolution:

title: Task Force Urges Scans for Smokers at High Risk
description: WASHINGTON  An influential government health panel recommended on Monday that heavy smokers get an annual CT scan to check for lung cancer, a major change in policy that experts said had the potential to save 20,000 lives a year.

title: Another View on Gas Drilling in the Context of Climate Change
description: Ive received a Your Dot contribution on gas leaks and global warming from Louis A. Derry, an associate professor in the earth and atmospheric sciences department at Cornell University. Its a critique of one element in Gangplank to a Warm Future, an Op-Ed article by Anthony R. Ingraffea, a professor of engineering at Cornell who is a prominent foe of expanded gas drilling using the bundle of methods commonly known as fracking.

title: Plan to Capture an Asteroid Runs Into Politics
description: It is known, informally, as the asteroid-lasso plan: NASA wants to launch an unmanned spacecraft in 2018 that would capture a small asteroid  maybe 7 to 10 yards wide  haul it closer to Earth, then send astronauts up to examine it, in 2021 or beyond.

title: War May Be Over, but One House Fills Up With Blood
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  Hardly a newcomer to the summer arts game, Bard College has long attracted cognoscenti to its Bard Music Festival, a two-weekend musicological intensive doubling as a sumptuous smorgasbord of concerts. This years festival, devoted to Stravinsky, starts on Aug. 9. Fairly recently, as a prelude to the main event, Bard began to offer a fully staged opera whose composer or theme has been related to the festival. Under the watch of Leon Botstein, the conductor, scholar and Bard president, we have seen memorable revivals of once-esteemed works by Meyerbeer and Schreker, alongside more quixotic resurrections.

title: A New Shrew and Mice Memory
description: Scientists discovered a new species of shrew, corrected erroneous beliefs about the body temperature of cheetahs, fed bees polluted pollen with disastrous results and planted a false memory in the mind of a mouse. In the meantime, NASA wants to know why a spacewalking astronauts helmet suddenly took on water.

title: Third Point Takes Aim at Sony in Investor Letter
description: Updated, 7:02 p.m. |  The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb is turning up the heat on Sony.

title: In a Rainstorm of Brass, the Lightning Struck From Audience Smartphones
description: Musicians and audiences have wilted in the heat at outdoor concerts this summer. But on Sunday evening, a hardy audience sat on wet chairs and huddled under umbrellas for several hours to hear the Asphalt Orchestra and the Kronos Quartet perform as part of the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival.

title: Greyhound Rolls Out Streaming Movies and Music for Passengers
description: Greyhound has begun rolling out a streaming entertainment system that allows its passengers to watch movies and television shows, listen to music, surf the Web and play online games with their own Wi-Fi enabled portable electronic devices.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, Italy, Kashmir and Thailand.

title: Gender Undertones on Fed Choice Provoke Reader Reaction
description: A front-page article on Friday  with its engaging lead paragraph, eye-catching graphic illustration and provocative concept  created plenty of buzz. It quickly garnered nearly 300 reader comments  and some complaints to this office.

title: Guides to a Journey Into the Brain
description: A journey into the human brain starts with the usual travel decisions: will you opt for a no-frills sightseeing jaunt, a five-star luxury cruise, or trek a little off the beaten track, skipping the usual tourist attractions?

title: On the Trail of Germs
description: Lance Price is a microbiologist on a mission to precisely match bacteria in the supermarket meat with those in women with urinary infections.

title: Uncovering the Truth Behind a Twisted Anti-Abortion Tale
description: In November, the magazine publishedEmily Bazelons profile of Charmaine Yoest, the head of the Americans United for Life, an anti-abortion group, which has been working with Republican state legislators to write laws making access to abortion more difficult. In her article, Bazelon wrote about the controversy that was sparked when Todd Akin, a Republican congressman from Missouri who was running for the Senate, claimed that victims of legitimate rape cannot become pregnant. Akins comments had apparently been based on, as Bazelon wrote, a1972 essay by an obstetrician named Fred Mecklenburg, who cited a Nazi experiment in which women were told they were on their way to die in the gas chambers  and then were allowed to live, so that doctors could check whether they would still ovulate. Since few did, Mecklenburg claimed that women exposed to the emotional trauma of rape wouldnt be able to become pregnant, either. Mecklenburgs essay was published in a book financed by the anti-abortion group.

title: A Complicated Cetacean
description: Orcas, known popularly as killer whales, are the subject of a new documentary that hopes to bring attention to problems they face in captivity.

title: A City Invokes Seizure Laws to Save Homes
description: The power of eminent domain has traditionally worked against homeowners, who can be forced to sell their property to make way for a new highway or shopping mall. But now the working-class city of Richmond, Calif., hopes to use the same legal tool to help people stay right where they are.

title: A Savior Taking the Reins
description: In the American dream as it once was, one person with an innovative idea and a lot of elbow grease could make a difference, and maybe a fortune. It was a myth  sometimes realized, but a myth still  created for the little guy.

title: Smart, Social and Erratic in Captivity
description: Should some of the most social, intelligent and charismatic animals on the planet be kept in captivity by human beings?

title: Aspen Music Festival Embarks on New Era
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Give the Aspen Music Festival and School full points for resilience. In 2010 the institution was just emerging from several years of turmoil. Alan Fletcher, its president and chief executive (and a composer represented in this seasons programming), had been fired and rehired amid faculty uprisings and administrative disputes. Its board chairman had been voted out. The conductor David Zinman, its music director and a founder of its American Academy of Conducting, had left in a serious huff.

title: CNN to Produce Documentary on Hillary Clinton
description: The intense focus on Hillary Rodham Clinton, former secretary of state and 2008 presidential candidate, heading toward a potential second run at the presidency was stepped up again Monday as CNN announced that its film division would produce a documentary on her.

title: A Summer Internship at a Place Where Most People Stay for Good
description: Even the best internships can require some degree of menial labor: answering phones, working copy machines, making Starbucks runs.

title: Whats an Idea Worth?
description: Like a lot of accountants, Jason Blumer never really wanted to be an accountant; he wanted to play guitar in a hair-metal band. But like most guys who want to play guitar in a hair-metal band, Blumer eventually realized that there wasnt much money in touring bars and being paid in beer-smeared $20 bills. So he changed gears and decided to follow his dad into what seemed like one of the more steady businesses around. After college, he bought some suits, joined a midsize firm in South Carolina and processed his clients payroll and tax returns. He billed them by the hour. He hated every second of it.

title: Pivot TV Pitches to Young Viewers
description: Toward the end of Evan Shapiros semester-long course on television management at New York University, he spends an hour on the topic Building a Post-Network Channel from the Ground Up. For the 19- and 20-year-old students  the fickle viewers that advertisers and programmers so desperately want to reach  the final assignment is to pitch some sort of TV innovation, be it a new way to schedule shows, a distribution strategy or even a brand-new network.

title: Dumpstaphunk, Five Finger Death Punch and Ben Monder
description: DUMPSTAPHUNK

title: Hotels Add Libraries as Amenity to Keep Guests Inside
description: Reading material in many hotel rooms has become about as spare as it can be  open the desk drawer and it might hold a Gideon Bible and a Yellow Pages.

title: In Performance: Avenue Q
description: Sala Iwamatsu, as Christmas Eve, and the puppeteer Veronica J. Kuehn, with Kate Monster, sing The More You Ruv Someone from Avenue Q, which celebrates its 10-year run on July 31.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Emoji Tracking and Spoofing GPS
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: People Who Need Famous People
description: When the weather turns hot, Americans crave celebrity. Not for themselves, necessarily. Who wants to work hard at anything, even becoming famous, in July and August? But theres something about the lives of notorious others, laid out as flat as comic strips, that grips the lazy consciousness that is our summer state of mind.

title: Senate Backs F.B.I. Chief and Considers Other Picks
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed James B. Comey as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Monday even as Republicans and Democrats struggled to hold together the fragile deal that preserved the filibuster for executive branch appointees.

title: Clashing Titans for Sale
description: Many paleontologists agree that two fossilized dinosaur skeletons found in the Hell Creek formation in Montana might be a major discovery.

title: The Jump to a Composite Plane
description: Plane manufacturers have been increasingly using composite materials instead of traditional ones like aluminum. Half of the weight of Boeings latest plane, the 787, comes from composites.

title: Video of the Popes Gay Lobby Remarks
description: During a news conference on his flight back to Rome from Brazil on Monday, Pope Francis was asked about his much-reported acknowledgment last month that there is a gay lobby inside the Vatican hierarchy.

title: How to Catch an Asteroid
description: NASA is proposing an unmanned spacecraft that could capture a small asteroid passing near the Earth.

title: U.S. Accuses JPMorgan of Manipulating Energy Markets
description: The nations top energy regulator on Monday formally accused JPMorgan Chase of manipulating energy markets, foreshadowing a multimillion-dollar settlement that is expected as early as this week, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Fast Airport Screening Is in Store for More
description: THE Transportation Security Administration is rushing to greatly expand its popular PreCheck program, with the goal of having 25 percent of all air travelers eligible for a fast-pass through airport checkpoints by the end of the year  and 50 percent by the end of 2014.

title: Hot Rods and Hot Nights at a Hamptons Party for Kenny Scharf
description: WhoI live in space, but Im on planet Earth, Kenny Scharf said. I dont want to go live in Mars but in my mind I go there all the time. The painter, who was the roommate of Keith Haring and a friend of Jean-Michel Basquiat during the anything goes days of 1980s New York, was in East Hampton, N.Y., on Saturday for an opening at Eric Firestone Gallery that paired photos of the era by the late Tseng Kwong Chi with Scharfs own paintings. Spotted at the party were downtown veterans like Bob Colacello; Patrick Demarchelier; Vincent Fremont and his daughter Casey; Calvin Klein, Max Levai, Kyle DeWoody, Lisa Marie Fernandez; and Kembra Pfahler. Cindy Sherman remarked that her friendship with Scharf began in the 1980s, but I dont remember how or in what context. As the proverb goes: if you remember it, you werent there.

title: Weinstein and Disney, Together Again
description: LOS ANGELES  Time apparently does heal all wounds: Harvey Weinstein, who bitterly parted ways with the Walt Disney Company in 2005, leaving behind his Miramax Films, will produce a movie adaptation of Artemis Fowl for Disney.

title: Ad Watch: Christine Quinn
description: Michael M. Grynbaum, a New York Times Metro reporter, deconstructs Christine Quinns first campaign ad.

title: F.D.A. Strengthens Warnings on Lariam, an Anti-Malaria Drug

Mr. Laarayedh said the government would stay in office to see through the transition. We are not clinging to power, but we have a duty and a responsibility that we will exercise to the end, he said in comments on state television. One of the smaller parties in the ruling coalition, Ettakatol, has joined opposition calls for a government of national unity to replace the current government after the assassination of the legislator Mohamed Brahmi last week.

title: Iran: Ahmadinejad Granted License to Start University
description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, whose tumultuous two-term tenure is in its final few days, will be moving to academia. The governments Islamic Republic News Agency announced Monday that Mr. Ahmadinejad had been granted a license to start an international university in Tehran. It was the first official confirmation of Mr. Ahmadinejads postpresidential plans, which had been the subject of speculation for some time. The news agency said the charter of Mr. Ahmadinejads university, which apparently has not been named yet, must still be approved by two government ministries. Mr. Ahmadinejad, who could not run for a third term, is to relinquish the presidency on Sunday to the cleric Hassan Rouhani. Mr. Rouhani has promised a less confrontational style than Mr. Ahmadinejad, a conservative whose eight years in office were marked by fewer personal freedoms, more economic problems, fraud accusations and violent protests over his re-election in 2009, and Irans increased isolation over its disputed nuclear energy program.

description: MEXICO CITY  Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, the two-time left-wing presidential candidate, is angry  very angry. The proposal from PANs elites to privatize our oil reaffirms their role as lackeys. Posers. Followers of EPN, he wrote in a tweet, referring, first, to a rival political party, and, second, to President Enrique Pea Nieto. Traitors to Mexico.

title: Missing Stradivarius Violin Is Recovered in Britain
description: Music lovers and insurance adjusters alike are surely breathing sighs of relief after the recovery of a valuable Stradivarius violin in Britain more than two years after it was stolen from a musician in London. BBC News reported that the violin, three centuries old and valued at 1.2 million (about $1.8 million), had been found after a 2010 incident in which it was stolen from the violinist Min-Jin Kym while she was at a sandwich shop in North London.

description: After several grueling years, Oprah Winfreys cable channel OWN has turned the corner toward profitability, her business partners at Discovery Communications said on Tuesday, six months ahead of its previously stated goal.

title: Waiting for Trades, Suspensions or Maybe a Jolt of Adrenaline
description: Somewhere in the fine print of how to tell if we have truly reached the dog days of summer, perhaps it describes this week. Because when you are spending late July waiting for Major League Baseball to dump a boatload of drug suspensions, trying to get excited about a trade deadline at which almost no one youve ever heard of will get traded, or scanning the highlights to see what household appliance David Ortiz might smash in his next fit of anger, well, that is hitting a serious skid.

title: Daily Report: Apps That Anticipate Your Needs
description: A range of start-ups and big companies like Google are working on what is known as predictive search  new tools that act as robotic personal assistants, anticipating what you need before you ask for it.

title: Pope Francis in Context
description: The cycle is familiar: A pope says something about a controversial issue that doesnt fit the medias semi-informed preconceptions about Roman Catholic teaching, a firestorm of coverage follows, and then better-informed observers are left to pick up the pieces and explain that no, actually, the pope is just reasserting an idea an openness to Darwinian evolution, the possibility that nonbelievers might go to heaven, pick your controversy that the church already accepted or believed or allowed to be considered.

Bradley Manning not guilty of aiding the enemy for his release of hundreds of thousands of military and diplomatic documents to WikiLeaks for publication on the Internet, rejecting the governments unprecedented effort to bring such a charge in a leak case.

description: In May, Yahoo riled up photography lovers everywhere by revamping its popular Flickr photo-sharing site. The new Flickr offers everyone 1 terabyte of free storage. Thats a lot. Its enough to back up and display 600,000 photos at full resolution. (Heres my review.)

title: Congress Party Supports Creation of Telangana State
description: After years of hunger strikes, sit-ins, and even suicides by activists, Indias ruling Congress party has endorsed the creation of Telangana as the 29th state of India by dividing the southern state of Andhra Pradesh. The Congress Working Committee, the highest body of Indias governing party, passed a resolution Tuesday evening after its allies in the United Progressive Alliance coalition backed the formation of the new state.

title: Why an Alibaba I.P.O. Is Both Promise and Problem for Yahoo
description: Alibaba is Yahoos best investment, and its most frustrating problem. Its 24 percent stake in Alibaba, Chinas biggest online retailer, is probably worth more than Yahoos entire booked assets of $16 billion. But a future initial public offering, in which Yahoo has promised to sell half its shares, may deliver much less. That is because Alibaba holds most of the cards.

title: Son of Fallen Chinese Official Is Removed From Columbia Law Directory
description: BEIJING  References to Bo Guagua, a son of the fallen Chinese politician Bo Xilai, were removed from an online directory for Columbia Law School after a family associate and a person from Beijing with high-level contacts said on Monday that he was expected to attend in the fall.

I can recognize a fine automobile, but my objectivity is clouded by passion. Although that may disqualify me as an arbiter of automotive worth, its conducive to enjoying a day at a car show. All that follows is based on owner interviews and documentation provided by the concours.

description: A new study, published in the Journal of Pediatrics, found that most 3- and 4-year-olds were able to open, and within two minutes swallow, what was left in uncapped or incompletely closed child-resistant liquid medication bottles (96 percent for uncapped and 82 percent for incompletely closed).

title: For Chicken With Onions and Cardamom Rice, Try a Chenin Blanc
description: Chenin blanc wines are among the most glorious and the most underappreciated. I think serving a good demi-sec Vouvray with this chicken dish will offer immediate insight into their deliciousness. Demi-sec indicates that the wine has some residual sugar, but dont fear a wine thats not dry. Chenin blanc, like riesling, has such lively acidity that it will balance out the moderate sweetness, leaving you refreshed while matching the sweetness of the fruit, spices and caramelized onions. Whats more, chenin blanc has a beautifully rich texture that not only feels great in the mouth but will also enhance the amplitude of the basmati rice and chicken. A young demi-sec is fine, an older one even better.

title: Travel Guide: Paris for Kids
description: First, the bad news: Since Paris is one of the worlds most visited cities, seeing its best-known monuments and museums can require wading through masses of people and waiting in long lines. If youre traveling with children, you will probably be exhausted before you even get inside.

title: Feeling For | A Travel-Size Fragrance Pouch in Monogrammed Leather
description: Many fragrance brands offer complimentary travel-size bottles of perfume along with a larger purchase. But Atelier Cologne ups the ante in the most elegant way imaginable. Perhaps this is no surprise, considering that the three-year-old fragrance houses founders live in Paris and New York, and surely appreciate the value of traveling in style. When you purchase any 200-milliliter bottle of one of their clean, unisex scents  Orange Sanguine, Grand Nroli, Vtiver Fatal  you get a 30-milliliter travel spray of your choice along with a French leather case that comes with custom hand-engraving. There are seven possible shades of leather  aubergine, turquoise, lilac, red, burgundy, black and gray  and your choice of silver or gold lettering. Simple initials are probably classiest, but the brand offers you up to 20 characters to say what you want. You can also purchase the pouches  la carte.

title: Pentagon Is Buying 71 More F-35 Fighters
description: The Defense Department on Tuesday announced an agreement in principle to buy 71 more F-35 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin at somewhat lower prices than last year. description: The San Diego City Council on Tuesday unanimously voted to file a lawsuit against Mayor Bob Filner to recover any damages the city may have to pay as a result of a sexual harassment lawsuit that has been filed against him and the city. The mayors former communications deputy, Irene McCormack Jackson, sued last week, alleging that he harassed her on the job. Six more women have since accused him of harassment, though no more lawsuits have been filed. The Councils lawsuit does not admit any liability, but moves to hold Mr. Filner responsible for any damages and legal fees.

title: Ohio State Gives Its Ex-President Another Job
