Gordon Gee, who resigned as president of Ohio State University in June after a series of gaffes attracted media attention, will earn $5.8 million over the next five years under a new contract with the university that calls for him to continue as a tenured member of the law school faculty, conduct research on education policy and serve as president emeritus. Under his previous contract, Mr. Gee would have earned about $6 million over the next four years. Mr. Gee, 69, frequently topped the list of highest-paid college presidents.

title: $250 Million, a Record Gift, Set for College in Kentucky
description: Centre College, a small rural college in Danville, Ky., announced Tuesday that it had received the largest outright gift ever made to a liberal arts college: $250 million, in stock from the A. Eugene Brockman Charitable Trust.

title: Political Inquiry Makes Judge a Star, as It Reveals Flaws in Spains Courts
description: MADRID  At just 34 years old, Pablo Ruz was a surprising choice to replace Baltasar Grzon, Spains most famous investigative judge, when Mr. Grzon was   suspended for illegal eavesdropping. But Judge Ruz quickly made himself a household name, driving the investigation of payments to Popular Party politicians that now threatens Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, who is scheduled to appear before Parliament on Thursday to explain his partys finances.

title: Plan Aims to Enliven Pariss Financial District, Long Called Soulless
description: PARIS  On Bastille Day 1989, when President Franois Mitterrand inaugurated the Grande Arche, a 40-story postmodern bookend about three miles to the west of the Arc de Triomphe, it seemed its own form of triumph.

title: Shirking Responsibility in the Gulf
description: BILOXI, Miss.  IF you dont live near the Gulf Coast, you may have the impression that the area has fully recovered from the BP Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010, the largest environmental disaster in American history. Sadly, thats not the case for tens of thousands of gulf residents still trying to put their lives back together.

title: Missed Connections at La Dfense
description: La Dfense, the business hub of Paris, has long been criticized as dehumanizing and disconnected to the city. Efforts are under way to change that.

title: Neighbors Battle With Park Avenue Caterer Goes All the Way to Cuomo
description: It is among New York Citys longest-running food fights, pitting the well-heeled residents of one its most exclusive neighborhoods against an extravagant catering operation that is run out of a Park Avenue church.

title: Mr. Stringers Choice
description: By midnight Wednesday, Scott Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, will have to make a crucial decision about the future of New York City. That is the deadline by which Mr. Stringer, who is running for city comptroller, must state his opinion on a proposal to rezone a huge area around Grand Central Terminal. The mayors office and the City Council do not have to accept the borough presidents views, but they usually listen. During Mr. Stringers six-and-a-half years in office, he has often charted a reasonable middle way for developments in his borough.

title: Egypts Dangerous Slide
description: Deadly blundering by Egypts military rulers is making a bad situation much worse. Last weekends massacre of marchers supporting the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, will make national reconciliation and a return to democracy far more difficult.

title: Revenge of the Mistresses
description: Every so often you read a news article so revealing that it triggers this thought: I wonder if well look back on that story in five years and say, We should have seen this coming. That story was the warning sign.

title: Weiners Women
description: THERE is something missing from the endless moralizing and sophomoric jokes aimed at Anthony D. Weiner. That something is the role of women in a coarse and creepy Internet culture dedicated to the fulfillment of both male and female desires for virtual carnal knowledge.

title: Success Brings Scrutiny to Chinese Mystic
description: HONG KONG  Wang Lin, an exponent of the ancient Chinese practice of qigong, claims he has used his powers to cure cancer and has performed other mysterious feats, like conjuring snakes out of thin air. But none of his abilities were enough to ward off the fury of the Communist Party, which has accused him of using superstition to draw in gullible citizens and officials.

title: A Specialty Brew
description: The Pulley Collective, a coffee roasting facility in Red Hook, is serving as a training ground for a new generation of coffee roasters in New York City.

title: Fatal Crash Came While Train Driver Took a Call
description: BARCELONA  Preliminary investigations show that the driver of a high-speed train that derailed last week, killing 79 people and injuring 150, was on the phone and traveling at 153 kilometers per hour  almost twice the speed limit  at the time of the accident, a Spanish court said Tuesday.

title: New Unit to Turn Brands Into Publishers
description: THE creation of the worlds biggest advertising company earlier this week, a merger between the Publicis Groupe and the Omnicom Group, underscored the importance of consumer data and sophisticated technologies like automated buying in advertising.

title: The One-Day Contract, a Last Hurrah for Athletes
description: Hideki Matsui announced his retirement from baseball last December. Donovan McNabb has not appeared in a football game since 2011.

title: Over a Million Are Denied Bank Accounts for Past Errors
description: Mistakes like a bounced check or a small overdraft have effectively blacklisted more than a million low-income Americans from the mainstream financial system for as long as seven years as a result of little-known private databases that are used by the nations major banks.

title: Catskills Comedy Era Is the Focus of Documentary
description: When Comedy Went to School mines the rich history of borscht belt entertainment, revisiting those who honed their acts in that upstate New York vacation destination for Jewish families in the mid-20th century. Fortunately for the filmmakers, most of the comedians interviewed here  Jerry Stiller, Jackie Mason, Jerry Lewis and many other (mostly male) voices  provide lighthearted remembrances to elevate this poorly executed documentary.

title: Reflections on the Road to Harvard
description: Travis Reginal and Justin Porter were friends back in Jackson, Miss. They attended William B. Murrah High School, which is 97 percent African-American and 67 percent low income. Murrah is no Ivy feeder. Low-income students rarely apply to the nations best colleges. But Mr. Porter just completed a first year at Harvard, Mr. Reginal at Yale. Below, Mr. Porter writes about his journey. Click here to read Mr. Reginals essay.

title: Reflections on the Road to Yale

description: I wake up at 3 in the morning with a pile of work I havent touched and deadlines that stand as daunting as skyscrapers and I think about you mother.

title: In Baseball vs. Rodriguez, a Show of Tough Posturing
description: As Major League Baseball moves closer to suspending Alex Rodriguez for what it believes to be his involvement with performance-enhancing drugs, it has taken an increasingly tough stance in public. Baseball has conveyed its willingness to issue a lifetime suspension to Rodriguez and possibly to circumvent the usual appeals process that a player can normally use under the sports Joint Drug Agreement.

title: Efforts to Recruit Poor Students Lag at Some Elite Colleges
description: With affirmative action under attack and economic mobility feared to be stagnating, top colleges profess a growing commitment to recruiting poor students. But a comparison of low-income enrollment shows wide disparities among the most competitive private colleges. A student at Vassar, for example, is three times as likely to receive a need-based Pell Grant as one at Washington University in St. Louis.

title: Blue-Hued Stepparents Enjoy Some Redemption
description: Stepparents, the villains of so many fairy tales and other childrens stories, get some redemption in The Smurfs 2, a new, not very engaging movie featuring a lot of blue skin and household-name voices.

title: After a Spring to Forget, a Summer to Remember
description: LOS ANGELES  As summer announced its arrival, the Los Angeles Dodgers had not. The team with the $217 million payroll was languishing in last place in the National League West, nine and a half games out of first. Many of the Dodgers high-priced players were hurt, questions were being asked about Manager Don Mattinglys future, and not even a couple of bench-clearing brawls against division rivals had awakened them.

title: A French Dining Staple Is Losing Its Place at the Table
description: PARIS  The French, it seems, are falling out of love. Not with free health care, or short workweeks, or long vacations in August.

description: Hundreds of thousands of Americans are being shut out for relatively small mistakes.

title: Daily Report: Court Upholds Cellphone Tracking Without a Warrant
description: In a significant victory for law enforcement, a federal appeals court said on Tuesday that government authorities could extract historical location data directly from telecommunications carriers without a search warrant, Somini Sengupta reports.

title: Michael Stern
description: Mr. Stern, 34, is the managing partner of the JDS Development Group, which specializes in multifamily homes and retail space in the New York area and in South Florida. The companys projects include Walker Tower in Chelsea and Steinway Hall, both of which it is developing with the Property Markets Group.

title: It Takes a Thief to Explain Robbery
description: The insiders level of detail that gives so many good crime movies their bite is also what makes the documentary Smash and Grab: The Story of the Pink Panthers guiltily absorbing. In sketching out the story of the Serbian thievery ring of the title, named after the Inspector Clouseau movies, this unpretty but titillatingly informative film from Havana Marking essentially lets two criminals give a master class in high-stakes robbery. Their accounts cover preparation (cast a distracting woman to case the joint), execution (no job should last more than a half-minute) and aftermath (fencing goods is no picnic, and expect a permanent hangover of paranoia).

title: Loner Sought a Refuge, and Ended Up in War
description: WASHINGTON  Feeling outcast and alone in Iraq, Bradley Manning, then a 22-year-old Army private, turned to the Internet for solace in early 2010, wanting to share with the world what he saw as the unconscionable horrors of war, an act that resulted in what military prosecutors called one of the greatest betrayals in the nations history.

title: Assemblyman With Sway in the Orthodox Jewish Community Endorses Hyness Opponent
description: Among the most daunting obstacles Kenneth P. Thompson faces in his bid to unseat Charles J. Hynes, the longtime Brooklyn district attorney, is the boroughs Orthodox Jewish community. It votes in large blocs, and its sizable support has helped propel Mr. Hynes to re-election over and over again.

title: Giants Revisit Glory Days Grown Distant
description: PHILADELPHIA  The clubhouse television showed an out-of-town ballgame, sports magazines cluttered a nearby table and his cellphone offered plenty of diversions. But as Hunter Pence relaxed before batting practice here on Tuesday, he sought a higher form of refuge: The Seven Spiritual Laws of Success, a pocket-sized self-help book by Deepak Chopra.

title: Term of Address
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This is an interesting idea by H. David Goering, who is making his debut today. The idea here is that there are two towns that can be typed using only one hand: SWEETWATER, TEXAS can be typed using only the left hand, and UNION, OHIO can be typed using only the right hand.

title: Cheryl Boone Isaacs Chosen to Head Film Academy
description: LOS ANGELES  Cheryl Boone Isaacs, a veteran film marketer, was named president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the Academy said on Tuesday. Ms. Isaacs is the first woman to hold the Academy's presidency since Fay Kanin, who was president from 1979 to 1983, and is the first African-American to serve as president in the group's 86-year history. She previously held various Academy offices, and was most recently the group's first vice president.

description: Every day, millions of office workers prepare memos and reports using scissors and paste, and store data on floppy disks, though they have plenty of digital memory in their computers and the cloud. Smartphone-toting executives have their mail dumped into in-boxes, one corporate message atop another.

description: MIAMI  Near no-hitters tend not to be remembered. But compile enough over time, and a notable pattern may begin to emerge. From each fragment, a meaningful picture can be shaped.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (VH1) THE 2013 DO SOMETHING AWARDS Sophia Bush, below, hosts this ceremony honoring do-gooders 25 and under, including five who will compete for $100,000. The finalists, from whom viewers will choose the winner, are Sasha Fisher, a founder of Spark MicroGrants, which provides money to communities in Rwanda and Uganda to build schools, health centers and wells; Daniel Maree, whose Million Hoodies Movement for Justice helped bring the Trayvon Martin case to national attention; Jillian Mourning, whose organization, All We Want Is L.O.V.E. (Liberation of Victims Everywhere), was created to educate the public about sex trafficking in the United States; Lorella Praeli, who advocates for the fair treatment of immigrant children and their families through United We Dream; and Ben Simon, whose Food Recovery Network uses student volunteers at the University of Maryland to collect leftover food from dining halls and donate it to soup kitchens and shelters. The competitors who dont win the top prize will receive $10,000 community grants. Patrick Dempsey, Jesse Tyler Ferguson, Jennifer Hudson, L L Cool J and Kelly Osbourne will be honored for their own philanthropic work.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: As Afghan Pullout Nears, Civilian Casualties Rise
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The number of civilians killed or wounded in Afghanistan rose by 23 percent in the first six months of 2013, according to a United Nations report on civilian casualties, reversing a decline last year and signaling the challenge Afghan forces face as they take over all combat duties from American soldiers.

description: Updated, 4:52 a.m. |

title: Fading Yankees Squander a Gallant Effort by Their Aging Core
description: LOS ANGELES  The Yankees, old and infirm as they may be, have continued to hang on the fringes of the playoff race, limping along as gingerly as Derek Jeter runs to first base, and with a margin for error as narrow as that on Andy Pettittes fastball.

description: Test your math skills with this question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Brazil, Fortune and Fate Turn on Billionaire.

title: Dreams of a Mother
description: NEW DELHI  Akbari Begum Khan was exhausted by a long morning of cooking for several homes, where she works as a maid. The 46-year-old woman in a white and blue nightie sprawled on the hard floor of her small rented room. Mrs. Khan snored through the unruly game of carom being played by Sahil, her 3-year-old adopted son, and Nashad, her 6-year-old grandson.

title: Stephen Kings Family Business
description: Life in Maine, where Stephen King has spent most of his adult years, requires long drives down country roads, time that King, whose mind is restless, likes to fill by listening to books on tape. In the 80s, however, he sometimes could not find the books he wanted on tape  or maybe he just did not bother. He had three children: Naomi, Joe and Owen. They could read, couldnt they? All King had to do was press record. Which is how his school-age children came to furnish their father, over the years, with a small librarys worth of books on tape.

title: Be a Human First, Then Take the Photo
description: Demetrius Freeman is one of two photo interns at The New York Times from Western Kentucky University. Before joining The Times, Mr. Freeman, 27, spent two years after high school traveling in Denmark, Spain, Germany and Atlanta, Ga., while picking up freelance photo assignments for clients including Home Depot, Norfolk Southern and the Georgia Innocence Project. Originally from Atlanta, he recently completed a semester abroad at the Danish School of Media and Journalism and will be returning to Western Kentucky in the fall to complete his degree in photojournalism.

title: Bills Unpaid, Power Is Cut to Province in Philippines
description: MANILA  A Philippine province of 1.2 million people was without electricity for more than a day after the corporation that runs the national grid cut it off over $92 million in unpaid bills, officials said.

title: Report Says Spanish Train Driver Admits Reckless Speeding
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The driver in the train crash last week in northwestern Spain that killed 79 people told prosecutors that he had recklessly exceeded the speed limit and would have to deal with the guilt of what happened for the rest of his life, according to a statement he made to prosecutors published Wednesday in the Spanish newspaper El Pas.

title: Schneider Electric to Buy Invensys for $5.2 Billion
description: LONDON  Schneider Electric of France agreed on Wednesday to buy the British engineering company Invensys in a cash-and-stock deal worth 3.4 billion, or $5.2 billion.

description: Shattered houses, sand-caked cars, felled trees.

title: In Heavy Zimbabwe Voting, No Repeat of Disastrous 2008 Events
description: DOMBOSHAWA, Zimbabwe  For Nyaradzai Majuru, the choice of how to cast her ballot was simple. Before she and her husband received a two-acre plot of land that had been seized from a white farmer several years ago, they were penniless subsistence farmers on a scrap of communal land. Now, they grow green beans, sweet potatoes, tomatoes and cabbages that they sell in the market.

title: U.S. Economy Grew 1.7% During the 2nd Quarter, Topping Forecasts
description: The American economy managed to stay on track last quarter, defying fears of another spring swoon, but doubts remain as to whether it will finally gain the kind of sustained momentum that has proved so elusive since the recovery began four years ago.

title: Dell Buyout Bid in Peril as Voting Rule Remains
description: Michael S. Dells effort of several months to buy the company that bears his name was thrown into jeopardy on Wednesday, as a special committee of the computer makers board refused his demand to change the voting rules on the huge buyout.

title: NEC of Japan Is Exiting Market for Smartphones
description: TOKYO  NEC, once the leading cellphone maker in Japan, said on Wednesday that it would quit making smartphones, acknowledging that it had failed to keep pace with the likes of Apple and Samsung Electronics.

title: New Siemens Chief Sees Weakness in China
description: FRANKFURT  The newly named chief executive of Siemens has promised to restore stability to the company that symbolizes German engineering and electronics prowess. But he also issued a warning that could bode ill for the euro zone economy: Dont count on China.

title: I Do Not Want My Daughter to Be Nice
description: My 10-year-old daughter, Birdy, is not nice, not exactly. She is deeply kind, profoundly compassionate and, probably, the most ethical person I know  but she will not smile at you unless either she is genuinely glad to see you or youre telling her a joke that has something scatological for a punch line.

title: Milestone Claimed in Creating Fuel From Waste
description: WASHINGTON  After months of frustrating delays, a chemical company announced Wednesday that it had produced commercial quantities of ethanol from wood waste and other nonfood vegetative matter, a long-sought goal that, if it can be expanded economically, has major implications for providing vehicle fuel and limiting greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Bell Peddlers Mobile Carillon Could Be One of the Heaviest Marketing Tools Ever
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Dont honk your horn at Jeffrey Crook or the unusual cargo stowed atop the 21-foot trailer hes towing behind his Mack truck. The feeble sound your vehicle emits is no competition for what he has on board.

title: A Sense of Place
description: What would it be like to stay in one place  to have your own bed, to ride your own bicycle? a little girl named Anna wonders in Maxine Trottiers 2011 picture book, Migrant. Now that would be something. Annas parents, who are migrant workers, move from one temporary home to another, and Anna imagines herself as a rabbit, living in abandoned burrows, or a bee, flitting from flower to flower. She is effectively homeless, and longs to live a settled life, like a tree with roots sunk deeply into the earth.

title: Revealing a Health Care Secret: The Price
description: The Surgery Center of Oklahoma is an ambulatory surgical center in Oklahoma City owned by its roughly 40 surgeons and anesthesiologists. What makes it different from every other such facility in America is this: If you need an anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction, you will know beforehand  because its on their Web site  that it costs $6,990 if you self-pay in advance. If you need a tonsillectomy, thats $3,600. Repair of a simple closed nasal fracture: $1,900. These prices are all-inclusive.

title: The Ad Campaign: Catsimatidis Calls Quinn Out of Touch on Public Safety
description: Law and order has been a prevailing theme for John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire Republican candidate who has repeatedly pledged to keep hoodlums off the streets. In a 30-second spot, Safe, Mr. Catsimatidis warns that one rival in particular, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, could fall short in this arena.

title: Senate Panel Presses N.S.A. on Phone Logs
description: WASHINGTON  Senators of both parties on Wednesday sharply challenged the National Security Agencys collection of records of all domestic phone calls, even as the latest leaked N.S.A. document provided new details on the way the agency monitors Web browsing around the world.

title: Karachi-upon-Thames
description: LONDON  For many years Pakistanis have joked that their capital, Islamabad, is run from Washington. These days, however, it looks more like Karachi, Pakistans financial and business hub, is being run from London  thanks to an exiled Pakistani politician settled in the middle-class neighborhood of Edgware.

description: In an age when the syringe has practically replaced the scalpel, the phrase Park Avenue dermatologist likely calls to mind Real Housewives with unmoving foreheads and plumped lips. But those are not the patients in the waiting room of Dr. Macrene Alexiades-Armenakas.

title: Seeking Capital, Some Companies Turn to Do-It-Yourself I.P.O.s
description: Flying back to California, empty-handed, after one last investor pitch in late 2011, Brahm Ahmadi was ready to call it quits. Despite a track record, a clear market opportunity and a loan pledge, he had not been able to attract a single investor. He called his lawyer and told her, We hit a wall.

description: WASHINGTON  Facing dissent from Congressional Democrats, President Obama on Wednesday offered a strong defense of his potential choice of Lawrence H. Summers to head the Federal Reserve, though he said no final selection had been made.

title: The Rock of New Orleans
description: On Wednesday, July 29, 1863, an unprecedented crowd of slaves, runaways and free people of color gathered along the downtown streets of federally occupied New Orleans. They did so not only to honor and bid farewell to one of their own, Capt. Andr Cailloux of the 1st Regiment of the Louisiana Native Guards, who had fallen at the siege of Port Hudson, La., but also to send a message of defiance to white New Orleanians, most of whom favored the Confederate cause.

title: Your First Crush

A new essay will arrive each week, paired with stories from readers who work within the given discipline about their own cultural epiphanies.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Question No. 1: On Direct Quotations in Articles
description: A reader, Edward Hershey of Portland, Ore., wrote to me some time ago about an article in Sports by the basketball writer Howard Beck. Mr. Hershey, who described himself as a former sportswriter in the Red Smith-Jimmy Cannon era, wondered about Mr. Becks use of a quotation from the Miami Heat forward LeBron James. It came deep within what he accurately called a compelling deadline story following the first game of the N.B.A. championship series.

title: Debate Over Controversial Delhi Encounter Continues
description: NEW DELHI  The questions surrounding the controversial Batla House encounter in New Delhi continue to be unresolved. On Tuesday, a local court sentenced Shahzad Ahmad, 24, the only person arrested after the September 19, 2008 gunfight between Delhi police officials and suspected terrorists in Batla House area of south Delhi, to life imprisonment for killing a police officer. But human rights activists contesting the police version say that the legal battles around the half a decade old episode are far from over.

title: A Feast for the Eyes Leads to One for the Ears
description: When I was 9 or 10, our family acquired a new book called Album Cover Album, a collection of record cover reproductions: 160 pages, with from 1 to 16 records arranged on each page. It was made by Hipgnosis, the English design firm, and Roger Dean, the illustrator of album jackets for Yes and some less savory prog-rock bands.

title: Resuscitating Chivalry
The Power Behind the Throne at the Federal Reserve
description: The debate over whether Janet Yellen or Lawrence H. Summers will be the next Federal Reserve chairman  or some dark horse, Timothy F. Geithner perhaps?  is doubtlessly important.

title: Moon Phases Tied to Sleep Cycles
description: The lunar cycle has been tied to a range of mysterious powers, from increases in violent crimes and hospital admissions to fertility and blood loss, and scientists consider most such beliefs nonsensical.

title: Listen Up | Violin Meets Modern Dance in a New Video From Arcade Fires Sarah Neufeld
description: For the video for her song Forcelessness, Sarah Neufeld  best known as the violinist for the Grammy-winning indie collective Arcade Fire  wanted to go outside the bounds of indie rock. The clip for the track from her debut album, Hero Brother, which has its premiere here, pairs Neufelds hypnotic string arrangement with an intimate routine performed by two dancers in a brick-walled studio, a simple conceit that proves remarkably mesmerizing. Its the debut project by Pressur.es, a new Brooklyn-based multidisciplinary arts organization and film series dedicated to exploring artistic modern dance and progressive music.

title: Did Zeus Exist?
description: When my children were little, they liked to play Mother, May I? At one point, I combined the game with an early introduction to classical culture, changing the key question to Zeus, May I? with an imaginary thunderbolt throwing back anyone forgetting to ask permission.

title: An Easter Egg Hunt With Stephen King and Family
description: When Tabitha King, a writer married to Stephen King, wrote a novel about a woman from warmer climes who opens a diner in Maine, she lavished almost two pages of description on the man who taught the novels heroine how to cook. Dick used to work summers in a resort in Colorado, that character, named Pearl, recalls, in the novel that carries her name. Summers in Key West, nobody came there back then, except diehard fishermen and drunks like Hemingway, maybe theres no difference, huh? Fans of The Shining might be surprised to find Dick Halloran, a hero of The Shining, showing up in a novel that is essentially a liberated womans love story, a novel without so much of a hint of the supernatural (they might also be surprised to learn that the brave and gentle Dick had a taste for fast women, strippers and dancers and scat singers, as he is further described in Pearl).

title: Finding a Seat That Fits on a Flight
description: For travelers who are taller or broader or heavier than the average American, who have had their knees bashed, heads bonked and hips squeezed on flights from coast to coast, a little relief is in sight.

title: From Bocce to a Trolley in a Washington Neighborhood
description: H Street NE, near the Capitol, is dotted with restaurants and cultural spaces, with a new trolley line set to open soon.

title: Death Sticks at Rockaway Beach Will Soon Be No More
description: They lurk just below the surface at high tide, ready to scrape or snarl an unsuspecting surfer. They have shattered boards, ripped open skin and wet suits, impaled unsuspecting bathers and caused at least one death in recent years.

title: John McCain and the Wacko Birds
description: After Senator John McCain referred to Senator Rand Paul, Senator Ted Cruz and Rep. Justin Amash (all Republicans) as wacko birds back in March, he apologized. In an interview with The New Republics Isaac Chotiner published this morning, he used much nicer language to explain why he dislikes the avian cohort.

title: The Mostly Good Old Days: Boris Kachka Talks About Hothouse
description: The consolidation of the book publishing industry continues apace, with the recent merger of the two behemoths Penguin and Random House being just the latest development. In this climate, the story of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the fiercely independent publisher (even after it was no longer privately owned) of authors like T.S. Eliot, Flannery OConnor and Joan Didion, has particular resonance. In Hothouse, Boris Kachka writes about FSGs star authors, and about the three men  Roger Straus, John Farrar and Robert Giroux  who made the company a success. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Kachka discussed what he learned about literary legends, his approach toward reporting gossip, his efforts to resist a nostalgic view of the publishing industry and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

title: Masks That Stay on and Moisturize the Skin
description: The old-school beauty ritual of slathering on a mask and waiting for 10 to 15 minutes before rinsing it off may be pass. The following formulas are meant to be left on.

title: Deliberations Start in Goldman Traders Case
description: The federal governments lawsuit against Fabrice Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs trader accused of misleading investors in a mortgage security six years ago, went to a jury Wednesday morning, setting up the end to one of the most prominent cases to arise from the financial crisis.

title: Why Republicans Miss The Realists
description: Chris Christies comments attacking Rand Paul and other right-wing civil libertarians, extracted by my colleague Jonathan Martin in an Aspen forum last week, have generally been interpreted as setting Christie up as a spokesman for Republican hawks in a looming 2016 battle over the partys direction on foreign policy. On Friday, Politicos Alexander Burns ran down some polling numbers that help explain why the more hawkish perspective is no longer an obvious political winner, even in a G.O.P. primary:

title: Facebook Shares Touch a Symbolic Threshold
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It took more than a year, but Facebooks stock has fought its way back.

title: U.S. Financial Firm Courts Start-Ups in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The SVB Financial Group in California has long been an important banker and investor in American venture capital firms and technology start-ups. Now, the company is testing the waters in South America, particularly Brazil.

title: Homes for $1,500,000
description: A photographic tour includes a home near St. Louis, a Queen Anne in Massachusetts and another in Wyomings ski country.

title: What You Get for ... $1,500,000
description: WESTWOOD, MO.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Spectacular Now'
description: The director James Ponsoldt narrates a scene from his film featuring Miles Teller and Shailene Woodley.

title: Recipe Lab Video Chat on Jerusalem
description: For this months Recipe Lab, The Timess Julia Moskin asked home cooks what recipe from Jerusalem: A Cookbook theyd most like to discuss with the authors, Yotam Ottolenghi and Sami Tamimi, in our Google+ Hangout.

title: Whistle-Blowers in Limbo, Neither Hero Nor Traitor
description: Even as Americans expressed increasing concerns about government intrusions into their life in a recently released Pew Research Center study, they have hardly embraced those who decide to take matters into their own hands.

title: Egypt Vows to End Sit-Ins by Supporters of Deposed President
description: CAIRO  Egypts military-backed government instructed its security forces on Wednesday to end two sit-ins by tens of thousands of supporters of the deposed Islamist president, a decree that many feared could lead to a new round of violent confrontations.

title: Not Everythings Ho-Hum as the Trade Deadline Approaches
description: Ah, the joys of baseballs trading deadline. No, it is not very dramatic and is painfully lacking in team executives acting like game show contestants (see: N.H.L. and N.B.A. trade deadlines), and as we know, it is not actually a deadline. Trades made before 4 p.m. Eastern time do not require a trip through waivers. We get another month until the waiver trade deadline. And then after that, teams have to have a note from Mom. We all know how complicated that can be.

title: House Hunting in ... Amsterdam
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM HOUSE ON AN AMSTERDAM CANAL

title: A Canal-Side Home in Amsterdam
description: A restored 17th-century house on the Prinsengracht, one of Amsterdams main canals, is priced at $3,652,592 million.

title: A Suburban Jersey Spin in the 2014 Ford Fiesta
description: Ford gave us an opportunity to take its 2014 Fiesta for a spin Tuesday morning; great timing, considering it would have been Henry Fords 150th birthday. From the brief interaction I had with the car, the new Fiesta turned out to be a capable, if somewhat predictable, economy car. But there was one thing that set it apart from its competition: styling.

title: On Tonight, Playful Advice for Weiner to Be Popular
description: New Yorks campaign for mayor is getting a little wicked.

title: Rising G.O.P. Star Expected to Challenge Arkansas Democrat
description: Representative Tom Cotton, Republican of Arkansas, is expected to announce his challenge to Senator Mark Pryor of Arkansas in 2014, according to two Republicans familiar with his thinking. For Mr. Pryor, a two-term Democrat, the bid would further complicate his efforts to hold onto his already vulnerable seat.

title: Image of the Day: July 31
Brides: Steal His Heart, but Borrow the Jewelry
description: Want jewelry from a hotel? You can save your mask and gloves, but youd better bring a wedding dress. Despite the theft at the Carlton in Cannes, a number of hotels are continuing new programs in which they lend jewels out to brides.

title: Scents for Men, Minus the Mating Calls
description: THREE YEARS AGO, the siblings Matthew and Madison Ruggieri of Los Angeles had a smart idea for an online company. With $10,000 and a spare bedroom in their San Fernando Valley home, they started The Motley, a retailer of mens grooming products with an eye for quality and aesthetics. Their theory was that guys, when shopping for moisturizers and such, have evolved at a faster pace than most stores.

title: Anatomy of a Scene Video: The Spectacular Now
description: The Spectacular Now looks at the budding relationship between two misfit teens, Sutter (Miles Teller) and Aimee (Shailene Woodley). In this video feature, the films director James Ponsoldt narrates a scene where the two characters first meet.

title: Choking Still Sends Too Many Children to the E.R.
description: Choking continues to be a leading cause of injury among children, a new study shows, reminding us to remain vigilant about what and how they eat.

title: Air Products Faces Modern Form of Hostile Takeover
description: The hunter becomes the hunted.

title: Why Arent Direct Public Offerings More Common?
description: Weve just published a small-business guide to using direct public offerings to raise money. Also known as do-it-yourself I.P.O.s, they have been around for decades but have been gaining prominence of late  especially with the rise of social media. They are considered especially useful for businesses with strong, loyal followings. And beyond raising money, they can be extremely useful as marketing.

title: Bond Purchases by Fed Will Continue, at Least for Another Month
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve issued a 700-word statement on Wednesday, but four words would have sufficed: see you in September.

title: Poll Shows Republican Voters at Odds on Party Leadership and Direction
description: As a number of prominent Republicans trade barbs and jostle to become the partys standard-bearer after a disappointing showing in the 2012 election, a new poll finds a majority of Republican voters support significant changes in the partys direction, but there is no consensus on what direction the party should take.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Question No. 2: On Identifying Writers of Letters to the Editor
description: As the famous line from Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid goes: Who are those guys? A version of that alarmed question sometimes comes up regarding letters to the editor in The Times.

title: To Make It Up to Rowling, Law Firm Makes a Donation
description: The London law firm responsible for revealing that J.K. Rowling is the author of the detective novel The Cuckoos Calling has agreed to make a substantial donation to charity as part of an apology.

title: Making the Case for Eating Fruit
description: Experts agree that we are eating too much sugar, which is contributing to obesity and other health problems. But in the rush to avoid sugar, many low-carb dieters and others are avoiding fruits. But fresh fruit should not become a casualty in the sugar wars, many nutrition experts say.

title: Selena Gomez Hits No. 1
description: After five weeks of rap albums topping the Billboard charts, its back to pop. Selena Gomez, who made her name as part of Disneys fold of singing, smiling teens, has scored her first No. 1 album with Stars Dance (Hollywood). The album, her fourth, sold 97,000 copies last week, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and Billboard notes that Ms. Gomez, now 21, enjoys a distinction that is getting rarer: each of her last three albums has opened with more sales than the one before it.

title: Essence Magazine Names New Top Editor
description: After being without an editor in chief since February, Essence magazine has announced a new leader, its fifth in 13 years. Vanessa K. Bush will assume the top job immediately.

title: George Saunderss Advice to Graduates
description: Its long past graduation season, but we recently learned that George Saunders delivered the convocation speech at Syracuse University for the class of 2013, and George was kind enough to send it our way and allow us to reprint it here. The speech touches on some of the moments in his life and larger themes (in his life and work) that George spoke about in the profile we ran back in January  the need for kindness and all the things working against our actually achieving it, the risk in focusing too much on success, the trouble with swimming in a river full of monkey feces.

title: Facebooks I.P.O. Breakthrough
description: Facebook has at last mobilized back to square one. Its shares finally broke above the $38 price set in the companys messy initial public offering 14 months ago. Thats largely thanks to Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive, making the social networks platform work on smartphones and tablets even as his tech rivals mostly flounder at the task.

title: The Gun Report: July 31, 2013
description: On July 18, four young girls were caught in the crossfire of a shooting in a residential neighborhood in East Lansdowne, Pa., and yesterday they told the local ABC News affiliate what it was like.

title: Conservative Catholics and the New Pope
description: A number of Catholics of my acquaintance are resistant to the idea, raised in my last post on Pope Francis, that there might be real daylight between the new pontiffs emerging program and the approach of his two predecessors. In their view, the possibility that Francis intends to be a social-justice pope who deliberately soft-pedals debates over doctrine and morals is just a media creation, reflecting press caricatures of the churchs divisions rather than Franciss actual statements and intent.

title: In Search of Her Romeo, This Juliet Gains a Friar Laurence
description: Classic Stage Companys new production of Romeo and Juliet has lost its leading man to a film, but gained a film star and onetime New York theater luminary  William Hurt  in the role of Friar Laurence.

title: Hagel Gives Dire Assessment of Choices He Expects Cuts to Force on the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel warned on Wednesday that if across-the-board budget cuts were not lifted, the United States would have to reduce its global security objectives by trading away the size of its armed forces or its edge in technology as the Pentagon seeks to remain solvent.

title: Obama to Appear on Tonight Show
description: President Obama, who has made the rounds of most of the late-night shows in the past, will return to the most-watched of the genre on Tuesday when he visits The Tonight Show With Jay Leno on NBC for the fourth time since taking office.

title: What Republican Voters Want
description: Republican voters have surveyed the wreckage of their partys 2008 and 2012 presidential tickets and concluded that something important must be done. In a new survey by the Pew Research Center, solid majorities of Republicans said the party needs to address major problems (69 percent), which would require shifting positions on some issues (59 percent).

title: Governments, Led by U.S., Seek More Data About Twitter Users
description: The number of requests for Twitter user data from governments around the world continued to grow in the first half of 2013, the microblogging service said in its semiannual transparency report, released Wednesday.

title: The Consolations of a Schubert Sonata Surplus
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  The world would be a better place if Schuberts final piano sonata, the B flat (D. 960), were everywhere in it. The first two movements of this majestic piece are its heart and soul, each gorgeous in its own way, and if the slighter third and fourth movements disappoint at all, it can only be in relation to that impossibly beautiful first half, with its heavenly lengths.

title: The Wind Shifts to Buy and East Harlem Beckons
description: David Karpa used to be dead set against buying. It seemed financially imprudent. I dont want to stretch just to get into an apartment, Mr. Karpa would say. His Midtown rent was $2,400 and, for the same price, he didnt think he could find a nicer place to buy.

title: The Marginalized, Front and Center
description: Peter Baryshnikov is following in the footsteps of his father, Mikhail  but not with jets and battements.

title: Turn the Showers Off. Splash Is Closing.
description: Last week, Splash, a sprawling two-floor gay club on West 17th Street in Chelsea, announced that it was closing on Aug. 11 after a storied 22-year run.

title: A Shifting Workplace Experience
description: Compared with offices of the past, the modern workplace is paradoxically both more informal and more relentless. Doors have been replaced by cubicles, formal desks with tables, and long-planned meetings with ad hoc collaboration. Work and home have blended, to the general benefit of work: more and more of us are available at all times, on smartphones and tablets, for e-mail and instant messaging.

title: In Store | French Satchels Make Their Debut Stateside
description: The French leather-goods house Moreau-Paris dates back to the mid-19th century and finally made its stateside debut last week at Barneys New York. It happened through a rather unorthodox referral, said Daniella Vitale, C.O.O. and executive vice president of Barneys. Narciso Rodriguez was in Paris on holiday and walked past a tiny shop on Rue de Miromesnil, and sent me an e-mail telling me that I should take a look at it next time we were in Paris. The brand is most famous for its embossed leather travel trunks and accessories, but in recent years, under the design leadership of Fedor Georges Savchenko, formerly of Goyard, it has gained interest for its hand-sewn carryalls. In this five-piece collection designed exclusively for Barneys, fine and exotic leathers are complemented with clean lines, minimal hardware and sophisticated shapes ranging from messenger bags to the open and zip totes sure to be spotted during fashion week. While the just-released basic leather versions are worth a trip to Madison Avenue or barneys.com, the crocodile versions that come out in September may be worth the wait.

title: Using the Masses to Improve Apps
description: Crowds are a hit. Millions of people, connected by the Internet, are now contributing ideas and information to projects big and small. Crowdsourcing, as it is called, is helping to solve tricky problems and providing localized information. And with the right mobile apps, contributing to the crowd  and using its wisdom  is easier than ever.

title: Bronx Bombers, a Yankees Play, Comes to Primary Stages
description: The playwright Eric Simonson has explored the worlds of professional basketball (Magic/Bird) and football (Lombardi) in recent New York theater seasons. Now its baseballs turn. On Monday the Off Broadway company Primary Stages announced that Mr. Simonson would direct his latest play, Bronx Bombers, a drama about the New York Yankees, this fall at the Duke on 42nd Street. The show is to run Sept. 17 through Oct. 19, with opening night to be announced.

title: Some Syria Missiles Eluded Israeli Strike, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  American intelligence analysts have concluded that a recent Israeli airstrike on a warehouse in Syria did not succeed in destroying all of the Russian-made antiship cruise missiles that were its target, American officials said on Wednesday, and that further Israeli strikes are likely.

title: Pataki Is Cleared in Lawsuit Over Sex Offenders Rights
description: A federal jury in Manhattan found on Wednesday that former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York was not liable for violating the rights of six convicted sex offenders who had sued, claiming they were wrongly confined in state psychiatric hospitals after completing prison sentences for their crimes.

title: Pictures of the Day: Zimbabwe and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Zimbabwe, Syria, Russia and India.

title: The Silent Partner Behind the Shale Energy Boom  Taxpayers
description: Since 2011, Alex Trembath, a tireless and talented energy analyst at nonprofit The Breakthrough Institute, has been digging into the complicated history of public and private initiatives and investments that unlocked the vast gas and oil resource contained in layers of shale rock.

title: Decades After a Strike, Still Living With the Fallout
description: I Forgive You, Ronald Reagan wants very much to be a modern-day Death of a Salesman, with its very own working-class hero who loses his identity (and ultimately his sanity) after being forced out of his livelihood, and who compensates by pinning unrealistic hopes upon his coddled, lazy offspring.

title: Decoding the Feds Statement
description: Compare the June and July statements issued by the Federal Open Market Committee.

title: Scene City: Film on Porn Classic With All-Star Cast
description: Amanda Seyfried, Sharon Stone, Peter Sarsgaard and other Lovelace stars were at New York premiere.

title: The Greek Bailout Isnt Working
description: For some time now, its been clear to many analysts that the European and International Monetary Fund bailout program for Greece is not working. The country is mired in a depression and its government shoulders a large and unsustainable debt. Few policy makers have been willing to acknowledge that reality in public because doing so would be an admission of failure and require them to change their approach, which they have already done once before. But on Wednesday, a member of the I.M.F.s board who represents Brazil and 10 other countries broke that silence by issuing an unusual and refreshingly candid statement.

title: Keen Company and Womens Project Announce New Seasons
description: Keen Company and the Womens Project, two Off Broadway theater companies, have announced their 2013-14 season offerings.

title: Its Time to Vote for a Sticker on Voting
description: Its not quite as striking as an ink-stained finger  the proud marker in many countries signifying that someone voted. But the New York City Campaign Finance Board hopes that a sticker saying I voted! will help motivate New Yorkers to go to the polls in the mayoral election this year.

title: Celebrating a Film About a Film
description: For a 62-minute pornographic film made for $30,000 in 1972, Deep Throat had remarkable impact. It became a barrier-breaking piece of pop culture, a First Amendment cause and even a Watergate reference. And later its star, Linda Lovelace, became an advocate for women against pornography and abuse.

title: Spoofy Heroes, Super and Otherwise, Join the Streaming Fray
description: One way to judge a streaming-video service  the only way, if you look at recent news coverage  is by its original series. By that measure, Hulu is the scrappy, undersized contender of the Big Three, ranking below Netflix, the steamrollering champion, but above Amazon, which is still standing outside the ring lacing its gloves.

title: Ludwig Meets Wolfgang in a First-Night Encounter
description: For all the advances that Lincoln Centers Mostly Mozart Festival has brought to New Yorks music scene  offering a launching pad for rising artists, lending Avery Fisher Hall a modicum of intimacy with a thrust stage and surround seating  its core orchestral programs remain stubbornly conservative.

title: Defending a Spingold Knockout Title in Philadelphia
description: The premier event at the Summer North American Championships, this year in Atlanta, is the Spingold Knockout Teams, which starts on Monday.

title: Judging Breaks, on Greens and on the Calendar
description: AKRON, Ohio  When Brandt Snedeker headed out the door for work Wednesday morning, his 2-year-old daughter, Lily, asked him to stay.

title: Virtual Currency Gains Ground in Actual World
description: Depending on whom you ask, bitcoins are a goofy geek invention with as much long-term value as Monopoly money  or a technology development that could transform currency the way e-mail and texting have transformed correspondence.

title: Marginalized, Yes, but Also a Nasty Guy
description: An unpitiable swine. He liked to hurt people  being extremely sensitive to wounds himself  and as he drove the knife in he smiled. A total narcissist.

title: Rashida Jones and Rob Lowe Leaving Parks and Recreation
description: Updated, 8:16 p.m. |

title: Spotify Losses Grow, Despite Successful Expansion
description: After five years, the streaming music service Spotify has established itself as a financial force in the music industry, with more than $500 million in revenue last year. Yet its losses have also grown as the company expands around the world and tries to attract paying customers.

title: Banning Guests That Bite or Buzz
description: Earlier this month, the raspberry bushes on our property exploded with berries, thanks to the seasons big rains. Unfortunately, the backyard puddles that had harbored bug larvae exploded with life, too, so our berry harvest exacted a high price in mosquito bites.

title: Cute and Cozy (for a Loaf of Bread)
description: Every once in a while I fall for cute in a really bad way. One of the worst times, about 40 years ago, involved a pale blue Fiat 850 convertible that I bought from a guy I knew. It overheated the first time I took it out on the road, teaching me the meaning of the terms cracked engine block and trust.

title: Shopping for Faucets
description: Eve Robinson goes shopping for functional, attractive water faucets.

title: Where Fitness and Zombies Collide
description: To start running, sometimes you need something scary chasing you.

title: Kitchen Faucets for Cooks and Wannabes
description: For a while now, the kitchen has been the center of most peoples homes. Just like the hearth was a place where people congregated, said Eve Robinson, a New York interior designer, the kitchen is now the place.

title: Goodbyes and Grief in Real Time
description: Scott Simons first Twitter message about his mother, dated July 16, squeezed a universal story involving heartbreak and humor into 21 words. He wrote: Mother called: I cant talk. Im surrounded by handsome men. Emergency surgery. If you can hold a thought for her now ...

title: At Zombie Races, Its Survival of the Undeadest
description: Even with the looming prospect of fitting into a wedding gown, the only way Cindy Brandeckercould imagine taking up running was if someone were chasing her.

title: U.N. Warns It Will Disarm Congo Rebels
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The United Nations has threatened to forcibly disarm rebels in the Democratic Republic of Congo, an early test of the robust new mandate for the multinational peacekeeping contingent that includes going on the offensive there.

title: Sharing Sahara Sentiments of Romance and Roots
description: The most direct route for African music to reach American listeners is via the dance floor, which was full and overjoyed when Bombino, a Tuareg guitarist and songwriter born in Niger, brought his band to Brooklyn Bowl on Tuesday night. Bombino and his three band members wore desert robes and turbans; he sang in his native language, Tamashek, and thanked the audience between songs in French. But it looked like ethnomusicological curiosity mattered far less to the audience than Bombinos pithy, incantatory electric guitar lines and the bands perpetual grooves. By the end of the set, their robes were drenched in sweat.

title: Dark Sheep of the Family Has a History to Uphold
description: Introducing Concertos  5, the opening program of the 4x4 Baroque Music Festival on Tuesday, the harpsichordist Avi Stein said that each era has its ubiquitous format, like the string quartet in the 20th and 21st centuries and the Trio sonata in the Baroque era. The five-part ensemble, an invention of an earlier period, is the dark sheep of the family, he added. Its Renaissance flavor, with a rich polyphonic texture created by the instrumental combination, lingered in scores written in later centuries.

title: A Blacklist Delays Book on Iran
description: Last month, Fabrica, a think tank in Treviso, Italy, run by the fashion company Benetton, released a book that offered a rare view of the domestic lives of Iranians. Overseen by Enrico Bossan, Fabricas head of photography, Iranian Living Room (about $45) presents images by photojournalists in Tehran and other cities of people in residential settings occupied with chores, socializing, leisure and prayer. But when Fabrica tried to sell Iranian Living Room on its Web site, with transactions processed through PayPal, the orders were initially blocked.

title: Riding a Carpet Back to the 1950s
description: In the early 1950s, the industrial designer Raymond Loewy created area rugs in defiance of the fashion in America for wall-to-wall carpeting. As his client, the elite carpet manufacturer Edward Fields, recognized, small rooms were giving way to the open floor plans of postwar architecture, and floor coverings were useful for breaking up spaces. Such rugs were a big deal at that time, said Yasmina Benazzou, director of design and creative development for Tai Ping/Edward Fields, which is reintroducing Mr. Loewys original collection.

title: Plumped Up on Perennial Grasses
description: At Tara Firma Farms, pigs, cattle and chickens thrive without relying on fertilizers, pharmaceuticals or hormones.

title: Life on the Farm: E-I-E-I ...Oh?
description: Petaluma, Calif.  Tara Smith does not mind squealing on herself about the mistakes she has made since becoming a farmer at 47.

title: A Sleek Way to Add Fizz, but Not Much
description: A recent entry into the field of carbonate-your-own-drink devices, Purefizz ($80), from a French company called Mastrad, puts bubbles into a wide variety of beverages. This sets it apart from products like SodaStream that carbonate water before flavoring is added.

title: Boardroom to Barnyard
description: Tara Smith, a California business woman, traded in her plush city life for the hard work of starting a farm from scratch.

title: In Gaza, Iran Finds an Ally More Agreeable Than Hamas
description: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip  The oil, sugar, pasta and other staples looked innocuous enough as dozens of young Palestinian volunteers, sweating in the heat at a warehouse here, packed them into cartons destined for Gazas poor during the holy month of Ramadan.

title: An Outdoor Shower Inspired by P.S. 122
description: Kirsten Oxboel and Jim Lobley, founders of the outdoor shower manufacturer Oborain, recently released their third design, which they named after a New York City school-turned-performance-space. We both went to public schools, so we thought it would be cool to do a P.S. 122 shower, Ms. Oxboel said.

title: Midcentury, Even for Baby
description: Three friends from the British design world have collaborated on Triangle, a new shop on Chatsworth Road in the East London borough of Hackney. The owners  Matthew Naylor, a graphic designer; Victoria Mullen, a former visual merchandiser; and Mary Wagstaff, a trained ceramist  are devoted to midcentury modern, and Triangle reflects that aesthetic with both vintage and new products, many from local artists and crafters.

title: Sales at Cassina, Didriks, Fishs Eddy and Others
description: Cassina is discounting all beds by 20 percent through Sunday (the Moov king-size bed, by Piero Lissoni, in midgrade fabric with the Motion Fissa slatted base, regularly $6,135, is $4,908); 151 Wooster Street (Houston Street), (212) 228-8186, and 155 East 65th Street (Third Avenue), (212) 245-2121, cassinausa.com.

title: The Presidents Men, at the Lenses
description: It always comes back to the tapes.

title: Should We Build a Fence So Buyers Wont Worry About Privacy?
description: Q. Our neighbors can see straight into our house from their backyard. Should we build a fence so buyers wont worry about privacy?

title: City Allots $50 Million to Favored Arts Project
description: When the details of Michael R. Bloombergs last capital budget as mayor were made final in June, one project stood out in particular: a $50 million appropriation for a nascent arts organization, the Culture Shed.

title: Food Matters | A Meeting of the United Nations of Gastronomy

title: Welcome to Summer Camp
description: George Yabu and Glenn Pushelbergs beach house has a cantilevered construction, complicated sliding-glass doors made in Germany and a clever push-button dumbwaiter, but the element that best captures its spirit are the playful wood lockers. Lined in a row opposite a wall of bunk beds in a small downstairs room, the lockers suggest a summer camp for design-minded adults and practically scream houseguests welcome.

title: Architecture Curator at MoMA to Return to Columbia
description: Barry Bergdoll is stepping down after six and a half years as chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, he announced in a letter to journalists late Wednesday afternoon.

title: A Hamptons Beach House Where Everyone Is Welcome
description: With plenty of bunk beds, lockers and towels.

title: Playland Motel
description: The Rockaways are already home to a colony of raffish surfers, young artists piled into bungalows and Bushwick-types who have made it their urban beach resort. Now it has a designer motel with a hopping bar scene populated by the sort of young, well-coiffed life-forms that might otherwise go to Montauk. Opened last month, the Playland Motel is run by the owners of the Output dance club and Rosarito Fish Shack in Williamsburg. It feels like Berlin or Ibiza, David Terranova, a music video producer from Brooklyn, said last weekend at a crowded dance party.

title: The Croods Helps DreamWorks Animation Increase Quarterly Profit
description: LOS ANGELES  Glass half full: The cave people of The Croods came through for DreamWorks Animation in the second quarter, as strong ticket sales for that movie raised the companys profit by 73 percent, to $22.2 million.

title: Mini-Me With High Heels of Her Own
description: The last time Erica Greenberg Ring, a mother of three in Davie, Fla., went shopping with her daughter, Madison, she knew exactly where the 11-year-old would end up: in the shoe department, cradling a pair of high heels.

title: Songs and Sunscreen Spread the Health Insurance Message
description: THE part of President Obamas Affordable Care Act that requires Americans to obtain health insurance has been a contentious issue politically, but new advertising from the 17 states setting up marketplaces where residents will buy insurance tends to be buoyant.

title: Reluctantly Returning to the Stage
description: When fashionable types talk about the 1990s revival, they are probably not thinking about Sarah Phillips. But in the early part of that decade, Ms. Phillips was a designer of some renown.

title: Mets Decline to Make Any Moves
description: MIAMI  The Mets remained inactive as baseballs nonwaiver trade deadline passed Wednesday afternoon.

title: Documents Show Thatcher-Reagan Rift Over U.S. Decision to Invade Grenada
description: LONDON  Thirty-year-old documents newly released by the British government reveal just how severely Americas decision to invade the Caribbean island of Grenada in 1983 tested the warm ties between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan.

title: Crowds Return to Las Vegas, but Gamble Less
description: LAS VEGAS  When the last recession battered the nation, the bottom fell out in Las Vegas. One out of every six jobs vanished. Home prices dropped as much as 50 percent. Construction projects stopped in place, and tourist spending on the Las Vegas Strip, the economic driver of this city, went into an alarming slide.
